October 14, 2019 - Five Down, One to Go!
  by Willa Silverman, October 14, 2019  
My infusion went smoothly today. Happily, my blood counts were in the normal-ish
range. My liver function was a bit elevated but Dr. Patel said that it's because it's
working 'overtime' now to process the various drugs in my system.
I was at Dr. Patel's office from 8:15 to 2:15 and even dozed a bit this time, wrapped up in
a blanket, as I didn't sleep much last night and was also given Benadryl before the
chemo drugs. No ranters this time, thankfully, but rather several skilled, calm and
solicitous nurses. Four angels (in addition to the nurses) brightened my day. My friend
Gay picked me up at home bright and early (dropping off some homemade chili and also 
pumpkin pie for the Canadian Thanksgiving she's observing today), and stayed with me
for the first hour of my infusion. At around eleven, Jackie -- one of the "III Cs" and a lovely
person -- stopped by with the now traditional vanilla milkshake from Meyer Dairy. A mild
cold prevented her from staying with me as planned, but she blew me a big kiss.
Sometime in the early afternoon (I was snoozing), Rhonda, my mentor from the Hopkins
Woman to Woman program who lives in nearby Lewistown, stopped by to visit briefly.
We had a great talk about how to stay positive and keep going despite all the
uncertainty and legitimate reason for sadness and depression (which it is also important
to acknowledge, but not wallow in). That talk did me a lot of good. Finally, when I was
done my kind next-door neighbor Janis was waiting outside to take me home. We talked
about her losing a five-year-old son to cancer -- something I had not known --and how
she managed to get through that. She was gracious to confide in me that way. I was
tired on my return so I rested for a while. Sorry to have missed the glorious weather
today but I may be able to catch more of it tomorrow. Thanks so much to friends and
family who sent texts and emails today- I'm feeling the love!
My last chemo infusion in this series is on Nov. 4th. It is unclear what will happen after
                       204 / 1.901
that. I will need to have the fistula repaired at Hopkins. Much will depend on the result of
the scan I will have on October 22nd, also at Hopkins. This will reveal a lot about how
successful the treatment has been. In this context, I have mentioned the CA125 marker,
an ovarian tumor marker that is normally supposed to go down as treatment continues.
In July, after surgery, my marker was 164.5, which is considered high. For the next three
treatments, to my surprise and even annoyance, Dr. Patel did not request that the
CA125 marker be included in my blood work, so *there is no data for those three
treatments.* As mentioned in an earlier post, he does not want me to get fixated on the
number, as the scan is the most revelatory indicator of progress and as, as he said to
me, "I still need to treat you no matter what." I still think, though, as a patient it is my
right to know this information. But now I won't. Oh well. 
Today's CA125 number is 57.4. It's dropped a good deal but is still listed as high. The
normal range is considered 1-30 (I note that in August 2017, way before I was ever
diagnosed with cancer, my number was 4.6). So the good news is that the number has
dropped significantly (Dr. Patel seemed to think so), and perhaps will drop even more
next time. But as predicted, the fact that it's still considered a bit high is causing me
anxiety in terms of what follow-up treatment I will need (More chemo? Parp inhibitors?
More surgery? None of the above)? I will know more after I have my scan and discuss
with Dr. Beavis. So for now, one day at a time. The whole world is a narrow bridge, but
the most important thing is not to give in to despair. These mantras still work for me.
Daydreaming about a little getaway with pals to mark the end of this round of chemo,
probably in my neck of the woods, and have a discussed with a friend or two.
Suggestions? Interested? Spa day? Overnight in the city (likely not my hometown, which
I expect/hope to visit in November, but... Pittsburgh? Good museums, good food, not
far...). Finger Lakes? More than one celebration possible. Fun to think about!

October 16, 2019 - From the Depths...
  by Willa Silverman, October 16, 2019  
If you find yourself in hell, a friend said to me over coffee Sunday, just keep going. Or in
my case, sleeping, as I have for the better part of the past two days. Of course I am
beating myself up for feeling slothful, listless, unproductive and the opposite of vibrant,
but unfortunately there is no alternative in this case to simply...succumbing, while the
chemo drugs work their way through my system (hopefully killing lots of cancer cells
along the way). I have no more than mild nausea, no vomiting, a mild upset stomach,
some mildly puffy glands-- but mainly crushing fatigue, which makes it challenging to do
some of the 'basics' (administer antibiotics etc.) -- but I managed. Some red lentil soup
made by my friend Esther was soothing and nourishing.
I trust that, following the pattern, I'll start to rebound fairly soon. I will make every effort
to respond to emails I have not had the stamina to answer the past two days - my
apologies.
Many thanks for your texts and emails - lifelines - I need them. Love, Willa

October 18, 2019 - Not what I was expecting...
  by Willa Silverman, October 18, 2019  
Writing from the ER at Mount Nittany Medical Center where I’ve spent a mind-numbing
eight hours or so. This morning, the visiting nurse who came to deaccess my port
thought the discharge from my drainage site looked disconcerting and advised I go to
the ER. I had also discussed this possibility, by phone, the night before with an infectious
diseases doctor filling in for Dr. Mehta. So I headed to the ER around 1:30, knowing that
I’d likely be stuck there for hours. To make a llloong story short (partly because I’m
typing on my iPhone), I had bloodwork and cultures done (sepsis is always a worry...),
followed by a CT scan. Then the ER doctor here, who seemed quite competent, conferred
by phone with the infectious diseases doctor at Hopkins. They decided that they should
keep me here in the hospital for a night or two to make sure nothing untoward happens
with the infection. My heart rate was also high when I got to the hospital and my blood
pressure was low; I didn’t feel great.
So here I am. I’m praying I can go home tomorrow. I’m a bit weepy but am just trying to
get through this short-term situation. And probably best to err on the side of caution.
While the standard of care seems adequate here, and the staff has been kind, it can’t
compare to the world-class care I receive at Hopkins. Also, nary a brown or black face
here; welcome to central PA...
It’s been one of those days when I hope I’m not becoming my disease, a mass of
unpleasantness. How I would have liked to be striding through big piles of leaves today,
in the sun!
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app

October 20, 2019 - Sweet home
  by Willa Silverman, October 20, 2019  
Immensely relieved to have been discharged from the hospital at about 8 p.m. last night,
only to be unleashed into the zany traffic patterns around the stadium (holding over
110.000 last night), as the game had just started (I caught the final three quarters at
home). It would have been preferable for someone to have picked me up at the hospital,
but with the game traffic that was not feasible.
I am feeling better today, freshly pumped with two units of blood due to my
disconcertingly low hemoglobin count. Of course, this wasn't what had initially brought
me to the ER, ie some suspicious looking discharge from my stomach drainage site. In
the end, though, from what the the doctors told me, this should not be a cause for
concern. But straight lines and clear-cut solutions are infrequent in this journey.
My weepiness yesterday morning at feeling isolated and caught off guard, missing a
beautiful day etc. didn't seem to resonate with the nurses. But I got myself out of my
funk, partly by visualizing scenes from Ben's birth at the same hospital nearly twenty-
five years earlier. Kathryn and Bénédicte, two dear friends who are also my colleagues,
brought good cheer and culture high (_The Economist_) and low (_People Magazine_)
when they visited me.
In dozens of ways I noted throughout my 30 or so hour experience, the care at MNMC is
way below that at Hopkins, not surprisingly, although I'm grateful to the staff for its care,
and the ER doc was sharp. Lesson to self: always try to target best health care providers,
if possible (given the real real concerns regarding insurance etc.). Also: if you can, give
blood. Much gratitude towards whomever donated the blood that reinvigorated my
chemo-depleted hemoglobin last night.
I will go to see Dr. Patel tomorrow morning at 9 for more tests. Unclear yet whether I'll
be going to Hopkins on Tuesday to see Dr. Beavis for a consult, as scheduled, or not (we
may postpone until after my final round of chemo at which point I'll have a scan).
Looking forward to seeing my grade school friend Jill, who will either be my 'wing woman'
on a road trip to Hopkins on Tuesday and/or my house guest for a long overdue catch
up! She'll be driving here from visiting her daughter in Princeton, NJ.

October 23, 2019 - The best Rx
  by Willa Silverman, October 23, 2019  
                       214 / 1.901
                       215 / 1.901
Perhaps my 'reward' for last weekend's depressing hospital stay was a wonderful,
uplifting visit from my high school friend, Jill, who arrived on Monday afternoon and left
Wednesday morning. Jill lives in Calabasas, CA but is often on the east coast visiting her
daughters in NY and Princeton, NJ. When she learned that I had to go to Hopkins on the
22nd, she offered to drive out here from Princeton, spend the night at my home and then
drive me to Baltimore and back! As it turns out, though, my appointment yesterday at
Hopkins wound up being rescheduled until Nov. 19th. Dr. Beavis felt that since I had just
been hospitalized and am feeling better from having had a blood transfusion, and since
two CT scans here in State College revealed that my stomach drain is still correctly
placed and functioning fine, we could forego this appointment, which was going to be a
consultation with no procedures involved. On Nov. 19th, I will have a post-chemo scan to
see whether there is still evidence of disease (fingers crossed). We'll also talk about the
rest of the treatment plan going forward, including repairing the fistula if it has not
closed on its own.
So our girls' road trip to Balto turned into a relaxing catch up visit here in State College. I
last saw Jill about 2-3 years ago (?) at a memorial event for one of our classmates. As our
graduating class consisted of *23* young women, most of us are still in touch (in fact,
more and more so as the years pass and thanks to social media; I know that several are
kind enough to follow this journal). Jill was one of my closest friends in high school,
having arrived at Nightingale-Bamford (our school) in 9th grade, unlike most of us who
had entered in first or, in my case, second grade. Jill and I remained in touch over the
years via birthday cards and Facebook, but have only really reconnected in person in the
past few years.
A (Jewish) New Yorker after my own heart, Jill came bearing 'the good stuff' from the city:
a large container of chicken soup from the 2nd Avenue Deli (accompanied by two large,
fluffy, schmaltzy matzah balls), walnut pumpernickel from Orwasher's bakery -- like a
Proustian madeleine for me, as one bite sent me back to my grandmother's townhouse
on E. 94th street where, when I visited her after school, we'd eat Orwasher's raisin
pumpernickel slathered in butter, accompanied by...Kahlua!; and a box of delicious
cookies (palmiers, hamentashen, black and white, macaroons), also from Orwasher's.
There was no end to the catching up and reminiscing (we tried to recreate in detail the
apartments of each of our classmates, while recalling the quirks of their parents and
siblings), with plenty of time to take stock of the present (aging parents, twenty-
something children, insurance plans). With great sensitivity, Jill gave me plenty of space
to talk about my cancer if I felt like it; it turned out that I didn't feel I needed a lot of
room to do so, beyond acknowledging the challenge of balancing a tough diagnosis and
treatment with a strong will to live my life, the best one possible. It poured all day
yesterday, but between the raindrops we managed to sneak out for a coffee/tea at Cafe
                       216 / 1.901
Lemont and a quick trip to the farmers' market, followed by a rainy drive around town
and campus (complete with the requisite photo-op by the Nittany Lion shrine) and dinner
at Barrel 21.
I had been telling my therapist the other day that I don't laugh very much these days
(kinda sad to think that, but it turns out that cancer isn't that hilarious after all), so I very
much appreciated all the smiles and laughter Jill's visit elicited, in addition to her
'positivity' (for lack of a better term) around my illness (stressing how well I looked and
strong I seemed, etc.) . It was all therapeutic, and I've been feeling pretty well the past
few days (with an appetite, too).
After Jill left, I got back into bed and slept a bit longer (still need a lot of sleep...), then
took a drive out a pretty country road to admire the foliage on this beautiful sunny day.
The leaves looked like golden glitter with the sun streaming through them. No buggies
today, but a laid-back general store in Spring Mills, PA, and lots of pick-up trucks.
Grateful for the balm of friendship. 
Photos

                       218 / 1.901

October 28, 2019 - Easy pleasures
  by Willa Silverman, October 28, 2019  
                       221 / 1.901
                       222 / 1.901
There is not too much to report. I am generally feeling well. The further removed I am
from chemo, the better I feel. But the closer I get to the next round of chemo, the more
anxious I become. So I'm sort of on that cusp right now. I feel relieved that Monday will
be my last round of chemo, perhaps warranting a small celebration of sorts. But I feel
uneasy anticipating the scan I'll have at Hopkins on 11/19, which will reveal if the
treatment's been effective and I've gone into remission. Nothing on this journey is
straightforward. Sigh.
My thoughtful sis-in-law, Ronit, texted me the other day to say she was thinking of me
and to wish me well (much appreciated). She wrote that she hoped I was enjoying some
'easy pleasures,' despite the dreariness of my medical situation. This seemed not only a
kind wish but good advice too. I've been trying to milk a lot of enjoyment out of easy
pleasures, ones that are within my control (it turns out there are many), including coffee
at our local second hand bookshop/coffee shop w/my friend Clare; farmers market with
my friend Maria and her son (and my former student) Anthony; a delicious dinner
marking Diwali at a local Indian restaurant, with lots of special dishes, also with Maria; a
nice visit from my friend Helen, w/whom I have a lunch date tomorrow at a local hole in
the wall Mexican place that serves great food! It is true that my 'easy pleasures' often
involve friends and food (and right now my appetite seems to be back with a
vengeance). I also enjoyed a long walk in the mellow sun today; my favorite ginkgo trees
have turned yellow, others are brilliant red...
I had a strange dream in which I was drunk on champagne. I was drinking unfinished half-
glasses in some sort of hotel or banquet hall, dressed in a ball gown [?], waiting for a
party to start [?]. Meanwhile, in reality I've had about a half a glass of wine since May!
Then, I began walking through the public spaces in the hotel singing loudly with abandon
to anyone who would listen the first verse of "Tracks of my Tears" by Smokey Robinson
and the Miracles: "People say I'm the life of the party/Cause I tell a joke or two/You know
I'm not really laughing loud and hearty/Deep inside I'm blue/So take a good look at my
face/You know my smile seems out of place/If you look closer it's easy to trace/The
tracks of my tears." Somehow this resonated with an image I saw on an ovarian cancer
support group page today (see pic). I don't normally feel this 'blue' 'deep inside' (or
rather, that feeling has abated since May as I have settled into the 'new normal' and
have proved myself pretty resilient) but perhaps the song and image tapped into a once
in a while feeling, or one that's buried away from my everyday consciousness.
My rabbi was in another dream, in a protective, nurturing (of me) role. He was sort of a
caretaker. The same dream also featured, I believe, Ben and another boy as little boys,
with me in the caretaker role. That's all I remember.
My friend Mary made me some delicious soup with chick peas, garlic, Parmesan cheese
                       223 / 1.901
and I can't tell what else and I look forward to enjoying it for dinner. I bought fixings for
carrot soup (w/miso and ginger) at the farmers market. Maybe a project for tomorrow.

October 31, 2019 - The Best Rx (bis)
                       225 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, October 31, 2019  
I just returned from getting a flu shot and the first of two pneumonia shots. My PCP
(Primary Care Provider), Dr. Damaske, wrote me and encouraged me to get both to make
sure to protect my immune system through the winter. While the nurse was giving me
the shots in an examination room, Dr. Damaske stopped by to say hello. We really had
not been in contact since my initial diagnosis in April, as he's taken the back seat to the
Hopkins team and Dr. Patel in State College. Yet he's been a caring, concerned,
sympathetic presence all along (he had given me his personal cell number for me to use
as needed), and I was touched by his taking the time to chat with me about how I'm
doing.
The town cancelled trick or treating tonight because of a tornado watch! It's been rainy,
gray and chilly all day, with strong gusts of wind whipping up the leaves -- weather
appropriate for Halloween or tomorrow's Day of the Dead (All Souls'/Toussaint).
Unfortunately, I ate a lot of the chocolate I had bought for the trick or treaters so I'll have
to get some more (although kids rarely seem to come around this neighborhood, and not
many live here).
Rather than wallowing in the late October gloom right now, I'd rather be at a conference
I often go to, in sunny Sarasota. Granted, I didn't send in a proposal for this conference
this year (as I now most often gravitate towards history conferences), but many
delightful friends/colleagues are there and the pictures now being posted on Facebook
reveal a lovely venue, colleagues drinking cocktails at a rooftop bar, research being
shared, conversations and laughter etc. Once again that feeling of being sidelined and
wondering how and when I will be able to jumpstart my professional life. It feels like I've
lived a whole other, alternate life in the meanwhile.
In much happier news, this weekend two of my graduate school bffs, Shanny and
Isabelle, will be driving out from New York to visit me! I very much look forward to seeing
these two dear 'filles' (as we've always called each other) for a few days of hanging,
cooking, reminiscing, laughing riotously, sharing. dancing (Shanny's request!) and more.
And the visit's perfectly timed to keep my mind off my *last* chemo treatment this
coming Monday.

November 4, 2019 - Six and done!
  by Willa Silverman, November 4, 2019  
                       228 / 1.901
                       229 / 1.901
I finished my last of six rounds of chemo today. Over the course of an eight-hour day at
Dr. Patel's office, everything went smoothly, and my blood counts were fine. I placed a
small figurine of the Hindu god Ganesh, a gift from my friend Shanny, on the arm rest
next to me during treatment; Ganesh is the god that both places obstacles in one's path
and also removes them. I was grateful for two visits from friends in the morning: from
Jackie, a fellow "IIIC," who brought good cheer and a vanilla milkshake (a sixteen-year
OC and breast cancer survivor and a highly active, vibrant woman, she is inspirational)
and from Kathryn, with whom it's always uplifting to chat. So kind of them to make time
to spend with me.
I am relieved to be done with this part of the treatment. Dr. Mehta even authorized me
to have *one* cocktail (I am jonesing for a stiff Manhattan or a Negroni - anyone care to
join me?). I can't really have more than that as my liver is working overtime these days...
I need to stress strongly, though, both to myself and anyone reading this, that my
journey seems far from over. Dr. Patel even said something like: "it's going to be a long
haul," or something like that. My CA125 marker for ovarian cancer has dropped after
each infusion, but is still 51.2, which Dr. Patel said was "persistently on the higher side"
and "concerning." It could mean that not all the cancer cells were killed off during this
part of the treatment (a particularity of my type of ovarian cancer, as I think I've noted,
is that a portion of my cancer cells are both microscopic and unusually aggressive), or
maybe it could mean something else (I'm not sure what, but at times I've heard this
marker referred to as "just part of the picture"). My stomach abscess also must resolve
so as not to hinder my further treatment. For example, I have not yet been able to
receive Avastin, a strong drug that might have helped kill cancer cells, because it would
have worsened the stomach abscess problem. Dr. Patel told me that having these types
of abscesses along with cancer is fairly uncommon. It's complicated my treatment.
I'll learn a lot when I go to Hopkins on 11/19. I will have a CT scan of my abdomen, pelvis
and chest, meet with both Drs. Beavis and Mehta (who is overseeing the stomach
abscess part of the equation). Along with Dr. Patel, they will determine a follow-up
treatment plan, if any, and will also discuss timetable for removing the stomach drain. I
am placing a lot of trust in them. The next step will be to repair my fistula, if it hasn't
healed on its own. This will be done either laparoscopically or surgically (which would be
much more invasive). My brother Ethan has very kindly offered to join me in Baltimore
for this visit.
So while I could definitely feel myself tearing up when Dr. Patel told me that my marker
(actually the previous marker of 57) was "concerning" (raising the possibility at least that
I won't go into remission after this first treatment), I will try to get myself to a better
place emotionally and psychologically. I am "stable" (per Dr. Patel), really pretty strong
in terms of overall conditioning; I walk, drive, go out with friends, have not had any
                       230 / 1.901
fevers, notable nausea, colds etc. If the marker is persistently on the higher side, at least
it's trended downwards each time. And if I could survive a thirteen-hour surgery, I'll be
ready for whatever they throw at me next. [btw, Dr. Patel put my mind to rest about the
discharge coming from my stomach drainage tube; he said it's just a reaction to a
foreign object being placed in my skin and does not believe it is an infection of any sort].
I had a terrific time with "mes filles," Shanny and Isabelle over the weekend. We gabbed
non-stopped, giggled mightily, laughed uproariously over old pictures from our grad
school days, reminisced, cooked a nice dinner together (actually, Isa and Shanny did
most of the cooking), did a little dancing to r&b tunes as we have done many times in
the past, ate some goodies from NY and NJ (rugelach, superior bread and bagels), sat in
the sun in the beautiful arboretum, enjoyed a relaxing coffee on the porch at Cafe
Lemont, drove out pretty Rte 45 to Milheim for brunch at Elk Creek cafes, watching the
Amish buggies roll by. Thanks to Shanny's strong interest in spirituality, we also held a
crystal over our hand to obtain answers to certain pressing questions in our lives (the
crystal moved one way for yes and another for no). While I can't reveal everything about
our experience in divination, I do have a scoop to share, confirmed by each of us asking
the crystal the same question: Trump will *not* be reelected president in 2020! Finally,
Shanny taught us a 'loving kindness meditation,' which is ultimately supposed to
encourage that quality in ourselves. I will practice it with the travel meditation kit she
brought me (Isa brought me gorgeous candlesticks from Vienna with a Klimt design on
them). We three are working out a plan to spend a few nights at a retreat (called Kipralu)
in the Berkshires in December, hopefully with a few other of our other NYU friends. In
any event, it was a wonderful visit, spent reaping the rewards of nearly forty years of
friendship, including sharing all the ups and downs that life has placed in our path.
The massive fatigue has not yet hit me but may well do so tomorrow. Still, I asked my
neighbor if she would drive me to vote at some point as I feel strongly about that. I may
be in my sweats, half asleep, and look like a ragamuffin, but I hope to get there!
The challenge of living with a serious disease that may not be definitively curable while
at the same time living a meaningful life and continuing to define what that means for
myself.
Thanks so much for the many caring texts yesterday and today, and for the comfort food
meals for the next few days. I appreciate them so much. Please keep me in your
thoughts and prayers going forward too, if it's not too much trouble.
Love,
Willa

November 11, 2019 - Fixing a hole
  by Willa Silverman, November 11, 2019  
"I'm fixing a hole where the rain gets in/And stops my mind from wandering where it will
go...."
A therapy session was helpful today in starting to raise me out of the funk I'd fallen into
the past few days, maybe the past week (since my final round of chemo last Monday). I
spend a lot of time alone, thinking, letting my mind wander "where it will go." I also
spend a lot of time horizontal, either sleeping or resting. While much of this time likely
serves a beneficial purpose - my body needs the rest to gain strength and combat
disease -- some of it seems more avoidant, of the "pull the quilt up over my head and
check out of reality" variety. I can usually tell the difference. 
I know I am anxious about my appointments at Hopkins next week. A lot is riding on
them. The CT scan should reveal whether the six rounds of chemo were successful (ie it
may show NED - no evidence of disease - or, conversely, evidence of residual cancer).
Either result will determine a further course of treatment (PARP inhibitors as
maintenance therapy? more chemo? more surgery??). And I presume how 'well' I pass
this milestone will inflect my prognosis. This in turn will have implications for whether
and in what form I can return to work in January. And so much of it is out of my hands,
despite being centered in my body, ie in what is 'closest' to me. This morning, the
"Serenity Prayer" went through my mind: "God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot
change, Courage to change the things I can, And wisdom to know the difference." I am very grateful that my
brother, Ethan, will travel from NY to Baltimore to be with me during my appointments. I will appreciate his
steady and compassionate presence.
My anxiety about the appointments had started to spin wildly and weepily into terror of a
shorter than anticipated lifespan and separation from loved ones. This feeling of grief is
so powerful it's hard even to write about it.
                       241 / 1.901
In any event, what I realized today is that while the quantity of life I have left (or that any
of us has left) is likely among the "things I cannot change" (beyond, of course, practicing
good self-care etc.), I can change its quality to some extent. I can do my part to ensure
that my interactions with beloved family, friends etc. are meaningful and impactful. I
may not be able to do that incredible hike my friend Mitchel and I took two years ago
today to a hill town overlooking Nice and the Mediterranean (thank you, Facebook
Memories), but I can treasure its memory, and remind him of that lovely day (and future
such hikes are not outside the realm of possibility!). I hope this all doesn't sound too
corny or Pollyanna-ish, but I've needed to get 'unstuck' and feel that I'm making some
progress towards that goal.
During services at shul, we thank our 'foremothers' -- Rebecca, Rachel, Leah, Sarah -- for
'girding on' faith when times got tough and for being an example of virtuous behavior for
us. A mystical faith also seemed to be an inspiration for Harriet Tubman in leading over
70 slaves to freedom, per the biopic I saw this weekend. While I'm skeptical (at least at
this point) that faith is going to be my prime motivator through this ordeal, I will at least
try to continue to 'gird on' courage, wherever it may come from (the support of family
and friends is a huge inspiration and source of support).
It's been warm enough to enjoy a cappuccino outdoors in the sun and then a nice walk
by the PA Military Museum with my friend Monique. Grateful for the autumn sunshine as
long as it lasts.

November 19, 2019 - Surveillance and survivorship
  by Willa Silverman, November 19, 2019  
The news is the best I could have hoped for: today's CT scan revealed that I am in
remission (which for Dr. Beavis means that "nothing obvious appeared on the scan"). So
I am among the 80% of women who go into remission after debulking surgery followed
by chemo. Normally, in a week I can also discontinue the two antibiotics I've been taking
by infusion for several months. This feels like a wonderful 'reprieve' in the context of a
punishing disease, and I will certainly take it! Dr. Beavis and Dr. Westin (another
wonderful doctor in the gynoc practice) stressed to me that I am now entering a new
phase -- the 'survivorship' stage -- during which I can and should begin to focus on
resuming my 'old' life to the extent possible -- beginning with enjoying the upcoming
holidays!
I had not anticipated such welcome news. Because my CA125 level (ovarian cancer
marker) was "concerning," according to Dr. Patel, I surmised it was because I had
residual cancer. Drs. Beavis and Westin explained to me, though, that that number could
reflect *any* inflammation in the abdominal area, including the abscess that is still
draining in my abdomen.
I am now also entering the "surveillance" stage. This means that Drs. Beavis and Patel
will be keeping very close watch on me through blood work, exams, CT scans, PET scans
etc.; the first six to twelve months are especially crucial. I will see one or the other of
them every three months. The issue regarding my fistula also must be resolved, but Dr.
Beavis wants to let my body recover completely from the chemo before the fistula is
repaired. So I will return to Hopkins the first week in January to determine whether -- if
the fistula has not closed on its own -- it will be repaired laparoscopically or surgically. If
the latter, the recovery time will be much longer (about six weeks). This in turn will pose
                       246 / 1.901
problems regarding whether I can return to work in January, as I'm hoping to. There are a
number of important, complicated matters such as this that I have to figure out now... 
I also have to decide whether to take chemo drugs called PARP inhibitors as a
maintenance therapy. According to the newest studies, these inhibitors can delay
recurrences by several months, but they have no curative function. On the other hand,
they have side effects (fatigue, nausea, lowered blood counts). It's a quality v. quantity
of life decision. Another tough one...
Carpe diem seems even more urgent given that half the women in my position (ie
ovarian cancer patients who have had debulking surgery plus chemo) have a recurrence
within five years. A sobering statistic. Others, of course -- and I have met some of them --
have recurrences between five and ten years out. Cancer-free for ten years is considered
cured. 
Still plenty of uncertainty, then, but for now there is reason for modest or even less
modest celebration (perhaps I'll indulge in that one cocktail I'm allowed to have...).
My brother has been my stalwart companion/'ride or die' the past two days and I'm ever
so grateful to him for being by my side during my appointments. The upside is that
we've been able to catch up and simply hang out together (we had a wonderful Italian
meal at La Scala last night, and were glued to the impeachment hearings this morning).
Thank you, Ethan. :) 
Thanks to friends and family members who sent texts, emails. And any prayers sent my
way appear to have worked!

November 24, 2019 - Waiting to exhale
  by Willa Silverman, November 24, 2019  
Each phase of this disease has its challenges. Transitioning from being a patient
('victim??') to a survivor (although I realize the two categories can overlap) is fraught.
Why? First, while I'm certainly very relieved that Tuesday's CT scan showed nothing
worrisome in terms of cancer regrowth, I also know that a recurrence is likely; it seems
to me that the word "remission" would need to be qualified in some way. It feels like a bit
of a swindle. Next, in all honesty I have probably felt 'wedded to my disease' in some
way; it provided me with an identity (I suppose 'survivor' does as well), and also ensured
an outpouring of care and love from my 'village.' Now that I'm 'better,' will there be an
expectation on the part of others (and perhaps myself) that things return to 'normal' (or
to the new normal, or the newer normal)? Finally, and related to the previous point,
simply returning to my life after going through such an arduous, even hellish experience
since April cannot be accomplished seamlessly, it seems to me. Perhaps every day
further from chemo the easier the transition will become.
Thank you to everyone, though, for your warm outpouring of relief and enthusiasm on
my good news! If all goes as planned and I continue to feel well, I have a bit of a reprieve
until January, when I will need to have my fistula repaired at JH, hopefully in the least
invasive way possible...
A wise and compassionate woman who is a fellow survivor was able to articulate exactly
what I'm feeling, and offered some sage advice (I hope she won't mind my quoting her
text here, but I'm not including her name for confidentiality purposes): "It's tough on us
emotionally when treatment ends and we are left on our own [...] One day at a time. Live
your precious life well! It's a gift. Enjoy it. Celebrate it. And lastly, lean on other survivors
who KNOW the feeling [...] we are in treatment forever. Our lives have changed. The
blinders are off. So your job now...live love laugh. That overused statement is so true."
Drs. Beavis and Westin also stressed to me that my mission now, from their perspective,
                       252 / 1.901
is to live my life to the fullest. I suppose I'm the type of person who always tries to
practice this, but perhaps there's more urgency or purposefulness about that now. I am
greatly looking forward, for starters, to Ben coming home on Tuesday for the holiday! We
will be going to Michael (Ben's dad) and Sue's, and I'm sure we'll have a lovely holiday. I
spent part of the afternoon cooking a *vat* of cranberry chutney (jalapeno cornbread
and sweet potato casserole to follow). 
It occurred to me that now that the 'initial treatment' chapter of my journey is over, I
should end my journal, or at least go on hiatus. But I suppose that I still have things I
want to write, and as long as I do I'll keep going. Thank you for taking the time to read
my posts.
P.S. Dr. Beavis wrote me to say that she thinks I am doing "remarkably well given
everything [I've] been through" -- hopeful words...

for pie. Heart-warming to see these pals together after so many years.
*A comfortable home, freedom from want...
*My own patience and fortitude.
 
I am feeling pretty well overall, but am getting nervous about a slightly scratchy throat
                       257 / 1.901
that I'll have my PCP look at this week if it gets worse. As I'm no longer receiving
chemotherapy, nor am I taking the two antibiotics I was prescribed for several months, I
suddenly feel rather unprotected, and this in turn is making me hyper-focused on my
body. Perhaps it's unavoidable.
 
I hope that you have many reasons to feel thankful, too, and that you spent an enjoyable
holiday..

December 4, 2019 - Survival v. survivorship
                       264 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, December 4, 2019  
I have been thinking about this distinction ever since Drs. Beavis and Westin exhorted
me to grab life by the horns and ride it hard during this 'honeymoon' period of remission.
I associate 'survival' with specific images from the past six months -- waking up in the
ICU after a thirteen hour surgery with a breathing tube down my throat, barely able to
press the pump with pain meds that were providing some relief from the excruciating
pain in my abdomen; having a needle inserted into my back (and I think my lung?) to
drain two quarts of fluid; inability to keep any food or liquid down for days. 'Survivorship,'
I'm learning, is something else; it is forward looking, hopeful. It resides in the 'sweet
spot' between acceptance (or non-denial) of a probable recurrence -- if I remain fixated
on the probability of a recurrence, am I somehow complicit in the idea that 'remission'
may be to some extent a swindle? -- and the courage to move forward or simply to
*move* in some direction. It is the courage, in the works of a song I like by Debbie
Friedman (Mi Shebeirach/Prayer for Healing), to "make one's life a blessing."
For the first time since late April, I have begun to make some forward looking plans. In
thinking about how I want to use my time to *live* I actually focused on what I would
miss most when I *die.* This strategy, if one can call it hat, was suggested in an NPR
interview I read with BJ Miller, a highly inspirational, brilliant palliative care doctor, whose
new book, A Beginner's Guide to the End, I have put on my reading list (turns out this
'how to die well' book is all about *life,* which echoes my strong feeling that until we are
dead we are *living* and not 'dying,' and our lives can and do have meaning until the
end). This strategy of focusing on death to chart a path in life simplified things for me: I
would most miss Ben, the rest of my family, my friends, and meaningful work (those
were the first things that came to me, although I might have added travel; there may
well be others!).
Consequently, today I booked a trip to D.C. between Xmas and New Year's (treating
myself to a favorite hotel there...), bought my Megabus ticket to New York, where I will
spend some time after the 13th, and further firmed up plans for a yoga/wellness retreat
in the Berkshires next week with four dear friends from grad school. Finally, remaining
details are pending, but I'm now expecting to return to work in January in conditions that
will work well for me right now. I'm feeling energized by all these developments
(although I hope I haven't overdone it...). Now I just need to keep fingers firmly crossed
that my health holds  -- nothing is guaranteed and those cancer cells may well be
lurking, although I benefited from a very aggressive debulking surgery in May -- and that
I continue to regain my strength. I will have the procedure to repair the fistula in my
abdomen at the beginning of January. Fingers crossed again that the necessary
procedure will be minimally invasive. The degree of invasiveness will be determined, also
in January, by a 'fistulagram' revealing the exact size and nature of the fistula.
In my 'thankfulness' list from my last post, I need to add that I am enormously grateful to
                       265 / 1.901
my college classmate Steven Sherman, an endocrinologist at MD Anderson Cancer
Center in Houston. When I contacted Steve via Facebook for help/information in an utter
panic after receiving my diagnosis last April, he immediately got on the phone to several
oncologist colleagues, telling me "we'll get you situated." Very shortly after that, he
hooked me up with the gyn oncs at Hopkins (where Steve completed part of his medical
studies and where one of his colleagues specializes in ovarian tumors). I received a call
from Dr. Anna Beavis a day or two after that. We spent an hour speaking by phone. As
luck would have it, she happened to have an opening for a lengthy surgery for the
following week. Fortuitously, then, I very quickly found my way into expert hands, and I
really owe this to Steve. :)

can be of help again. Best wishes always, Steve

December 9, 2019 - On the Road Again
  by Willa Silverman, December 9, 2019  
                       268 / 1.901
                       269 / 1.901
My dear friend Shanny, whom  I can't wait to see on Wednesday when we trek north
from NYC to Kripalu Yoga and Wellness Center in Lenox, MA, recently sent me a care
package composed of several thoughtful gifts, including crystals, some "Inner Strength"
loose tea, and "contemplation cards" consisting of words to meditate on, discuss, absorb.
The first word I chose at random was "detoxify." I eagerly await several days of
"detoxifying" with four wonderful grad school friends (aka "les filles") at Kripalu, where
I've booked both a massage and a facial and which boasts energizing yoga classes, a
relaxing sauna, idyllic surroundings in the Berkshires and food that's - apparently -  both
healthful and delicious. And lots of laughs and sharing guaranteed with this crew.
I should have borne detoxifying in mind on Thursday, when some poor eating choices
(nuts, dried fruits, greasy Thai take out) may have contributed to my going to bed with
excruciating stomach pain, which eventually became so bad that I called an EMS
ambulance at 2 a.m. to take me to the ER. I stayed at the hospital in State College the
better part of the day, and was well attended to. Saw four doctors both in the ER and
then on the floor once I was admitted, who told me the CT scan revealed a 'lazy bowel'
or perhaps the beginning of a bowel obstruction (this no longer appears to be the case). I
also needed an infusion of magnesium. Over the course of the day I began to feel better
and was released c. 5 p.m. I had a few teary moments of 'aloneness' in the hospital, but
in the end felt I had made the right decision, given all my abdominal issues resulting
from the big surgery last May, to err on the side of caution and get the pain checked
out. 
 
In the interest of detoxifying, I changed my order at the last minute at a soul-warming
lunch today with the "III Cs" (local OC survivors) plus our mutual friend Aileen Galley (see
photo), who in the context of her former job was responsible for bringing these OC
survivors together. Instead of the spicy and carb-heavy Thai chicken salad, I opted for
the protein-rich scallop salad. Eliminating 'toxins' of all sorts, in all realms of my life,
seems essential to strong survivorship.
A few updates: the procedure to repair my fistula is scheduled for Jan. 3rd. I'll meet Dr.
Holly, the interventional radiologist who will perform the procedure, on the 2nd. I am
rooting for the less invasive 'patching' procedure. Getting my head around another open
surgery would be hard for me to deal with right now....
...and would delay my return to work, now scheduled for the beginning of next semester.
I'll be returning in optimal conditions given the major health challenges of the past six
months: I won't be department head, nor will I be teaching. My interim department head,
dean, and HR staff have been very compassionate in working out this arrangement with
me. I'll perform service (committees, specific tasks for the department etc.), work with
the graduate students whose dissertations I'm directing or am involved with, and
                       270 / 1.901
hopefully push forward with my research. If my health holds, I'll likely return to the
headship in the fall. I am looking forward to feeling useful and returning to the work that
I enjoy very much and to the collegial atmosphere on campus. I just pray that my
stamina and health hold and that my return to work will be unproblematic.
In other news: let the fun continue in DC, where we've booked both dinner at a buzz-
generating restaurant (The Queen's English, featuring Hong Kong cuisine) and tickets for
a concert by the Roots (Questlove!) at the Kennedy Center. Can't wait to see Ben (whom
I'll also see in NY next weekend) and Sammi, and perhaps a few friends if the scheduling
works out.
So I'm on the road again, as I love to be, Megabussing it to the city tomorrow. This will be
my first non-medical travel since April! Happy trails, all.

December 15, 2019 - Breathe
  by Willa Silverman, December 15, 2019  
                       272 / 1.901
                       273 / 1.901
When I awoke in the ICU following my thirteen-hour debulking surgery in May, the only
way I realized for sure that I was alive was by hearing the sound of my breathing. Slowly,
other parts of my body came into focus: I could wiggle my fingers and toes, see the
outline of a clock on the wall in front of me.
In retrospect, "breathing" seemed a central focus of my restorative recent stay at Kripalu
Center for Yoga and Health in Stockbridge, MA, in part a celebration of my long
friendship (37 years!) with Isabelle, Vinni and Shanny, whom I met at age 23 in grad
school at NYU (in various combinations, we've been roommates over the years too, in
both New York and Paris). Many of the wonderful classes (eg Gentle Yoga and the
particularly excellent, body- and soul-freeing Yoga Dance) and workshops (Seven Steps
to Aging Well) I attended focused on breathing techniques, on calming the body, de-
stressing, letting go to the point where if I closed my eyes and let myself drift I could
envision a calmer version of myself, wearing my purple chemo cap and wrapped in a soft
gray blanket, floating above my physical being.
Life-sustaining breath also enabled my body to impress me with its stamina, given all it's
been through since May. With my friends I walked at least a mile if not more over snow
covered trails through pine groves to a pretty lake; granted, this is much less than I am
normally capable of walking but nowadays because of lingering discomfort in my
diaphragm/abdominal area I tend to get winded after a while. I also took two vigorous
yoga classes the same day -- balanced (following the mantra of "we deserve it!") by a
relaxing aromatherapy massage, Dr. Hauschka facial, and stimulating dip in the
whirlpool.
I embraced the focus on well-being, including the emphasis on 'conscious eating.' The
meals, despite being prepared for what seemed like a full house of 600 or more
guests,** were unusually delicious and healthful: the breakfast buffet one day featured
pumpkin brioche French toast with local maple syrup; yummy cold sesame noodles and a
portabella mushroom 'lasagna' were served lunch, and shrimp in cilantro pesto for dinner
(I also loved the creamy parsley feta salad dressing, one of about six homemade
dressings available). **quite a cool 'scene,' about 80% women, lots of toned bodies and
some not so toned, and a great variety of interesting yoga attire; with my purple chemo
skullcap, dangly silver earrings and lovely Indian shawl that Vinni gifted me I did not feel
out of place!
My friend Shanny, both highly adept at yoga and knowledgeable about various forms of
non-Western spirituality, encouraged us other 'filles' (French for 'gals,' as we've called
each other for years...) to set an intention for the day. "Listen to your body" became my
intention one day (especially pertinent after my recent trip to the ER), "be gentle with
yourself" was the guiding principle for the following day (following a night of less sleep
                       274 / 1.901
than I usually need).
Friendship is an essential nutrient in my emotional and spiritual diet. The opportunity to
reconnect with three of my closest friends was, consequently, soul-warming. Like the
twenty-somethings we once were, we still giggle and often laugh raucously when
together (enhanced by some *legal* 'contraband' smuggled into the center for the
occasion...), speak in franglais, take ridiculously goofy selfies, and stay up late at our
impromptu slumber parties; we also had fun asking a crystal pendulum all sorts of
questions both silly and serious. Yet now our gossip sessions are intermixed with other
concerns: recent illness and death of parents, disease (two of us are cancer survivors),
worries about our kids, career-related issues, the prospect of retirement. In short, the All
of It. Shanny and I spent an additional seven hours or so gabbing in the car from
Brooklyn to the Berkshires and back. Our convo roamed from relationships of all sorts
(familial, romantic, marital, with our exes and friends etc.) to spirituality to climate
change to the meaningful concept of wabi-sabi, a Japanese esthetic that stresses the
beauty that comes with imperfection, flaws and age (exemplified by rust or cracks in
porcelain). Hopefully my sternum to pubis scar (my 'battle scar') also manifests this
concept -- the 'crack' or brokenness that, in Leonard Cohen's lyric from "Anthem," lets
the light in ("There is a crack, a crack in everything/That's how the light gets in").
In short, it was a wonderful, relaxing, fun and meaningful getaway, one that we hope to
make into an annual tradition.
*** 
I am grateful to be in the city for the week, reveling in a welcome change of scene,
spending time with family and friends (Ben was up from DC yesterday and we enjoyed a
family dinner at my mother's apartment with my brother, sister-in-law and nephew). A
special treat today was meeting Diane, another "IIIC" OC survivor about a year out from
chemo (and a member of my extended family). It was encouraging for me to both share
information and experiences (eg about post-surgery complications) and meet another OC
survivor who appears to be thriving (Diane was back to work very shortly after
completing chemo). The support and friendship of other OC survivors has come to be
quite important for my own continued forward-looking survivorship. I share a depth of
understanding with these women that is unique to our experience.
***
On another note: if anyone is available to drive me to Hopkins on the morning of Jan. 2nd
(*actually, it will most likely need to be Jan. 1st) and/or pick me up most likely the
morning of Jan. 4th (but that is still tbd), it would, of course, help me out immensely.
***
All's well.
Namaste

December 20, 2019 - A Heart in New York
  by Willa Silverman, December 20, 2019  
"A heart in New York, a rose on the street
I write my song to that city heartbeat"
If friends are an essential nutrient in my diet -- and in my *recovery* diet -- than my hometown is as well.
Spending the week in the city energized me, as it often does, and actually made me feel better. Can a city, or
any special place, really do that? Granted, I made sure not to overdo the running around and, except for one
foray to the UWS (Upper West Side), retained downtown as my center of gravity. My mother also kindly
made sure I was especially comfortable in her apartment, even installing me in her bedroom for the week
while she slept on the sofa bed in the second bedroom. So for the most part I continued to get the extra
sleep I still need. :) And the security blanket of family feels especially welcome and safe these days. We (my
brother, sis-in-law Ronit, niece Eve and nephew Isaac, my mother and her partner Arnold, and Ben who was
                       277 / 1.901
up from DC for the weekend) enjoyed a family dinner/pizza party one evening at my mother's apartment. A
few days later, my mother, niece and I braved the deep freeze of the tip of Manhattan island (Bowling Green)
to shop at an Alsatian-style holiday market, before seeking out some hot soup.
Friends + family +/in New York = a nutrient with a special boost. I am just sorry that I couldn't see more
friends during this stay. I had a perfectly zen moment yesterday morning (thank you, Lexapro?) sitting in the
midst of incredible bustle at Breads Bakery on 16th street, where my brother Ethan and I treated my mother
to a birthday breakfast (see pics). Somehow, the long line to get coffee, tables jammed together and turning
over constantly, and employees hurriedly pushing carts of fragrant, warm baked goods all blended into what
became a pleasant 'whoosh,' creating a cocoon of sound that was, simultaneously, comforting, slightly
'exotic' because so far removed from the absolute stillness I am used to at night in State College, and yet
familiar to me from my growing up years in the city and my grad school years at NYU. Will I wind up back in
NYC one day? There's certainly a good chance of it, but who knows? 
Given that I'm generally feeling well right now and am really starting to regain energy (please may it
continue...), I am overjoyed to be back to one of my favorite activities -- breaking bread (hopefully, notably
good bread...) and diving into conversation w/a friend or relative in an interesting/cool/relaxing setting. Over
delicious udon noodles in curry broth (perfect for a downright frigid day in the city), my college friend Josh
brought wisdom from his long practice of martial arts and wrote me this email after lunch, encouraging me to
channel what I might call my 'innner samurai:' "You may discover an inner resilience as you've never noticed
before--the stalk of bamboo rather than a brittle iron rod--and observe parts you never knew were working inside you. If it
is toughness there, you may need even more toughness. If it is gentleness there, then you may find even greater
gentleness." And over a brunch that turned into a lunch at the wonderful Marlton Hotel (in a renovated 1900 building in the
Village), another dear college friend, Bryan, encouraged me to rethink my diet with the goal of even greater healthfulness
(smoothies, apparently, might be key); I felt guilty eating even a few of the yummy frites accompanying the mini-turkey
meatball and mozzarella panini we shared, but do intend to be even more mindful than currently about my diet. I am so
grateful for the sage advice of my friends. I hope I can pay it back and/or forward...
Heading back to State College tomorrow for the week; I'll see Dr. Patel on Tuesday to discuss maintenance
therapy, have my port flushed, and have blood taken for my upcoming procedure at Hopkins. Next Friday I'll
fly to to DC to visit Ben. In a change of plans, instead of returning to SC for basically one day, I will likely stay
in DC over New Year's (at Ben's, while he is in NY) and then head to Baltimore on New Year's Day to get
ready for my appointments and (hopefully) procedure on the 2nd/3rd (my mother is kindly meeting me there).
If any State College peeps are driving back from Baltimore/DC on the 3rd or 4th and could give me a ride it
would, as ever, be greatly appreciated!
Pics: 1) NY is getting ready for Chanukah with four kinds of sufganiyot (jelly doughnuts); 2) Breakfast w/the
birthday girl (aka mom) at Breads Bakery; 3) Very yummy hot Ukranian borscht at Veselka, an iconic
restaurant on lower Second Avenue.

December 23, 2019 - Light
  by Willa Silverman, December 23, 2019  
                       283 / 1.901
                       284 / 1.901
Written by the glow of the menorah...
 
Light is life, and I especially welcome its presence, illuminating the dark corners, not just
during the most lightless days of the year (I love the convergence of the solstice and
Chanukah) but at the end of a year that was often pitch dark for me. Chanukah also
commemorates the victory of the few over the many, the triumph of spirit over military
might -- "not by might, not by power, but by spirit alone." Yes, spirit, I've learned, can be
remarkably strong and resilient. As for the 'miracle' part, in the case of the small vial of
oil that lasted for eight days -- "Do you believe in miracles?" sings Matisyahu -- I'm not
necessarily convinced. And warfare leaves me cold. And yet, there is beauty and
meaning in this 'festival of lights.'
Can light drive out the darkness that has cast our nation into such horrific chaos for the
past two years? I pray so. "Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that.
Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that," wrote Martin Luther King, wisely. As
for my own 'dark corners,' I currently need more clarity about whether or not to take a
maintenance chemo drug called a PARP inhibitor that data suggests can delay a
recurrence but that can have some undesirable side effects (exhaustion, vomiting,
nausea) and that seems to work better in patients who are BRCA positive, (which is not
my case; instead of having a hereditary component, my cancer is the result of a random
genetic mutation). This morning, my medical oncologist, Dr. Patel, did not express a
strong opinion on this (but said, variously, "let's wait until after your fistula is repaired"
or "please consult Dr. Beavis to see whether she has data on success rates for patients
such as you, who are BRCA negative and had/have a lot of cancer" -- that last part of
his comments really stuck in my throat...). Dr. Beavis, in turn, has initially left the choice
about whether or not to take the PARP inhibitors -- which have no curative effect -- up to
me, so I really hope I'll be able to further consult her on this at Hopkins when I am there
Jan. 2-3. Apparently, at Sloan Kettering they do not even prescribe PARP inhibitors to
women who are BRCA negative and who have responded well to first-line chemo.
So....much...uncertainty, which is frustrating and anxiety-provoking.  I will get further
input and try to make the best informed decision I can. My vitals were all good this
morning so there is that, and I continue to feel stronger, with little need for rest during
the day.
I was also thrown into 'obscurity' briefly today when no pharmacy in town appeared to
have the saline-filled syringes that I need to flush my stomach drain. After about seven
phone calls, though, I found a pharmacy that carries them, got my prescription
transferred from the pharmacy I usually use, and will pick them up tomorrow.
It was lovely to have coffee today with a favorite undergraduate student, and to revel in
the "normalcy" of that welcome, relaxing "down time" feeling I associate with winter
                       285 / 1.901
break in our much quieter than usual college town. She gifted me a cool candle
embedded with pieces of volanic lava from her trip to Iceland over Thanksgiving break. I
feel incredibly touched to also receive, today, a homemade holiday cranberry bread,
which one of my neighbors hand delivered, and a gift bag containing an interesting-
looking novel and a divine-smelling product from Occitane awaiting me on my doorstep,
from a very kind friend. I am trying to finish up my card writing before I leave for DC on
Friday, although I find it hard to express my gratitude for all the love, care and concern,
support and encouragement and generosity that's been showered on me this year.
Dozens of points of light in the darkness, for sure.
We enjoyed a sweet first-night celebration of Chanukah at synagogue last night -- candle
lighting followed by a soup and latkes dinner. So nice to share this w/my community. I
met an intriguing-seeming man at the event -- a local chiropractor (and, apparently,
actor) who divides his time between State College and NYC (where he also has a 'healing
arts' practice) and who grew up in SC (played football for PSU). We have a coffee date for
tomorrow. Will anything come of it? Now *that* would be a Chanukah miracle. But living
one day at a time (still hard for a type-A person like myself) has taught me to be quite
zen about encounters of all types... Wherever you go, there you are...

December 30, 2019 - Journey
  by Willa Silverman, December 30, 2019  
                       287 / 1.901
                       288 / 1.901
This past Friday morning bright and early (the sun was just starting to rise), as I sat at
my dining table eating a yogurt before getting ready to leave for DC (my neighbors
kindly drove me to the airport), I decided to select a 'contemplation card' from the deck
Shanny had given me, hoping it might provide some food for reflection during my
upcoming trip. I selected, at random, "Journey." I placed the card in the window that
accompanies the box holding the deck, making a mental note to contemplate later.
As if on cue (thank you, subconscious) that night, in DC, I had an exhausting (and
exhaustive) dream about a journey; unfortunately, I didn't write it down immediately so I
am forgetting some of the details. I was with a group but also, somehow, separate from
them. The journey consisted of portions by sea and by land (with sub-portions of this
latter phase with transportation and on foot). Each portion was marked by notable
events or occurrences. For example, during one portion I noticed that at least two people
in the group had formed a couple. At long last we were at the very northern (I believe)
edge of Harvard's campus with several miles to walk to our destination (which was
unclear). Melded into this dream was another dream about resuming therapy (with my
previous therapist, not my current one) after this long journey. I was completely foggy on
my appointment time/date, because I had been away for so long. I took a chance and
showed up at what I believed to be the correct time/place. It's possible that a high school
friend of mine also showed up at the same time, but I don't remember more.
As if this voyage wasn't enough, I realized that the next day would be the last day of the
semester (at Penn State, I believe) and I had to prepare something for the session. I
decided it would be 'easy' to prepare a trivia quiz or game (and perhaps also a
'hangman' game?) for the students, until I realized that generating questions for the quiz
would be very time-consuming. I also realized with dismay that in a course (similar to
one I've taught many times in reality) that was supposed to end with World War I, we
had only covered only up to 1850.
My not very enlightened interpretation of all this is that I've indeed been on the psychic,
emotional and physical journey of a lifetime since my diagnosis in April, a journey
constituted of several phases. I've been well surrounded by a group of companions but
have also been going it alone. This journey has at times drawn my thoughts backwards
in time (in the dream: Harvard, my previous therapist). Now that I'm returning to work in
January, I feel anxious -- this "I'm unprepared for class" dream is one I've had many
times; interestingly, though, while I usually dream about the first day of class in this case
it was the last day. Indeed, I missed the entire last semester as I was on medical leave,
'reemerging' at campus events only at the very end of the semester when I started
feeling better. I am not certain what else to make about the end/beginning connection.
There's likely more stuff to tease out in the dream; perhaps it will come to me on further
                       289 / 1.901
cogitation.
Of course, recently I've started to travel again, for the first time since my diagnosis. New
York and now Washington, where I'm spending a few days with my dear son. I am
generally feeling well, despite some lingering and nearly chronic discomfort/tenderness
on my right side (near my drain insertion site). Dr. Patel said it's likely some
inflammation but nothing to worry about. I am praying that this will not interfere with my
upcoming procedure at Hopkins... But as Ben observed, my appetite is back with a
vengeance. Ben, Sammi (Ben's delightful girlfriend) and I enjoyed some great meals at
Queen's English (a trendy place in Columbia Heights featuring Hong Kong cuisine), Bistro
Lepic (a great neighborhood bistro in upper Georgetown that I discovered when I was
staying at Dumbarton Oaks about a year ago; they serve excellently prepared classics
like coquilles Saint-Jacques and sweetbreads, with profiteroles for dessert). I've regained
about ten pounds of the 25 I lost following surgery but am still feeling relatively trim. We
also walked about four miles on Saturday through Rock Creek Park to Hillwood Museum
and Gardens, where we took a docent tour of Marjorie Merriweather Post's estate and
strolled the gardens (including a Japanese rock garden after my own heart...). Last night,
after seeing the crazily intense film "Uncut Gems" to  escape a downpour outside
(followed by a shopping trip to Zara and walk around the newish Wharf District), we went
to the Roots' concert at the Kennedy Center; unfortunately, the lyrics of this talented hip-
hop group were unintelligible but I've been reading them online today. If "living well is
the best revenge" - against the Beast, in this case?... -- then I am throwing myself into it
pretty hard core, soaking it all up as I love to do. Please may it last.... it sure beats a
hospital bed... Shortly, I'll pack up my stuff here in my hotel (the wonderful Mandarin
Oriental, where I sit now in my room on the top floor with a lovely view of the Tidal Basin
and the Potomac) and Uber to Ben's, where I plan to finish out the year in a mellow
mode. Ben and I will cook something at home tonight before he leaves to spend NYE in
New York, and I hope to have lunch with my friend Jeff tomorrow.
So Ben will travel from DC to New York, I will go from DC to Baltimore (and then return to
State College on Saturday, hopefully), my mother will travel from NY to Baltimore to
meet me at Hopkins, and my brother is making a quick round trip from NY to Baltimore
and back, to spend time, per tradition at the end of the year, with his college
roommates. Journeys...

December 31, 2019 -- Annus horribilis?
  by Willa Silverman, December 31, 2019  
                       292 / 1.901
                       293 / 1.901
Happily ensconced in Ben's bedroom in the row house where he lives on M Street,
overlooking the small housing project and the huge white church that takes up almost a
city block (the United House of Prayer for All People of the Church of the Rock of the
Apostolic Faith). Ben and Sammi are in NYC for NYE, but I am here, cozily on this mild
day, winding down the year (and decade). My friend/ex-bf Jeff met me for a while to
select some goodies at Buttercream Bakery, before sitting outside in the sun at La
Colombe cafe in Blagden Alley, catching up and trading tales as we like to do (see pic).
Headed to Baltimore at some point tomorrow. The PET-CT scan on Thursday, the results
of which I will discuss that day with the interventional radiologist (Dr. Holly), will
determine whether the procedure to repair my fistula laparoscopically can go forward
the next day. If the scan reveals significant fluid collection, for example (that niggling
stomach abscess...), the procedure may well be off, to be replaced by an open surgery at
another date. There are no guarantees. I hope for the best outcome, but need to be
prepared for a different one. I am not certain if the PET will also screen for any new or
residual cancer, but I presume it will. I'll also meet with my gyn onc, Dr. Beavis, on
Thursday afternoon.
In no way has cancer been a 'blessing,' in no way am I 'grateful' for having this disease.
In no way do I feel that "God does not give you more than you can handle" and/or
"everything happens for a reason." I understand that this counters the belief of several
religious traditions that find value in suffering. In no way was spending the night before
my 'mother of all surgeries' retching into a garbage can in my hotel room while my
family looked on helplessly a redeeming experience, nor was the crushing post-chemo
fatigue that had me waking up from seventeen-hour slumbers in a stunned stupor, nor
was feeling so overwhelmed I could scarcely make myself a cup of tea, nor was the fact
of missing at least three friends' weddings and a long-planned trip to France with Ben,
nor was having my entire life come crashing down around me, leaving me to grapple
with the possibility of a shorter than hoped-for lifespan.
And yet...
I will simply echo the measured words of my rabbi, David Ostrich, during a visit he paid
me shortly after I returned home from my three-week post-surgery stay at Hopkins: "You
may find that this experience offers some opportunity for learning:"
*I am stronger than I thought, both physically and mentally. It surprised me to learn that
some cancer patients, even at early stages of their treatment, feel they simply can't
continue with it. Except for a few rare instants when feeling particularly debilitated and
overwhelmed, this has never been my attitude. I'm still feeling well enough, and tough
enough now, to say "bring it on." I will keep fighting if need be (and it may very well be,
                       294 / 1.901
given the likelihood of a recurrence...)
*Goodness exists, and it is powerful. At the risk of sounding pollyannaish, and while fully
conscious of the fact that evil, ugliness, and mean-spiritedness also exist in spades
(examples too numerous to mention here, and in our faces every day), let me quote
Anne Frank: "It's a wonder I haven't abandoned all my ideals, they seem so absurd and
impractical. Yet I cling to them because I still believe, in spite of everything, that people
are truly good at heart." One friend brought me a hamsa (protective hand symbol) that
her mother had blessed at the Kotel in Jerusalem; another came by my house to check
on me when Ben and Michael were worried because they couldn't contact me (I was
deep into one of the aforementioned post-chemo big sleeps); another prepared a picnic
and drove me to sit beside a calming creek on a gorgeous summer day; another drove
me, twice, from State College to Baltimore; three others came to spend weekends with
me, to help out with whatever was needed; others ran errands, made chicken noodle
soup, borscht, quiche, rice pudding (the prodigious Meal Train kept me fed for months...),
texted, called, emailed, sent cards, gorgeous floral arrangements, and other thoughtful
gifts (one friend, envisioning me in a hospital gown, sent a colorful, elegant scarf),
prayed, visited, drove me to doctors' appointments, slept over when I was feeling shaky,
sat with me during chemo, brought me milkshakes when that was virtually all I could
stomach, invited me on outings as I continued to improve, took care of everything I left
hanging at work when I had to schedule surgery on short notice, added encouraging and
perceptive comments to this page. My family members have continued to provide rock
solid love and support, accompanying me to Baltimore, providing strong arms to lean on
when my post-surgery 'walks' extended to the house next door, and keeping up a
courageous front despite their fear. ETC. Goodness is restorative (and really beautiful
and pure!). It manifests itself in countless ways. It continues to be an essential element
in my recovery. I do feel privileged to have witnessed so many instances of grace.
Perhaps, in some ways, I have learned to be a 'better' (ie kinder, more empathic) version
of myself, too. I would be glad for that.
*As I wrote earlier about my upcoming procedure, there are no guarantees. But I think I
really understand this now. It's become easier to say "I love you" -- and mean it -- to
friends and family. And I hold those hugs for longer, and squeeze tighter. No filter. No
b.s. No day but today.
*I am intoxicated by life, and unready to leave it.
That's what I've learned so far.
Wishing everyone a healthy, happy, successful, fun, peaceful, loving and blessed new
year.
Love, Willa 
                       295 / 1.901

January 1, 2020 - Update from Baltimore
  by Willa Silverman, January 2, 2020  
It's 5:45 p.m. and I've just returned from a long day at Hopkins. There's been a lot to
absorb in one day; there is some news to feel good about yet, as Dr. Beavis confirmed
and as I've said all along, some uncertainty as well.
It looks like I *will* have the laparoscopic (ie 'easier') procedure tomorrow morning, as
hoped for. I met with Dr. Holly, the very confident and competent interventional
radiologist -- and the go-to guy for this relatively new procedure -- who reviewed the PET-
CT scan I had this morning (which took two hours and involved drinking two cups of a
yucky barium drink). My stomach abscess has decreased in size to the point of pretty
much resolving itself; this means that tomorrow a)I can have my stomach drain and
drainage bag, which I've tended to for months, removed (yay!) and b)the abscess does
not pose a risk for the procedure. The procedure will involve a wire, a catheter and a
laser, the result being a 'scarring' (maybe like cauterizing?) of the tissue around the
fistula (hole), closing it. I will be lightly sedated. There is a chance that the fistula will
have closed on its own already (the doctor won't know until he 'goes in'): best case
scenario. Otherwise, he will close it. The procedure, he told me, is successful in 2/3 of
                       297 / 1.901
cases. If it winds up not succeeding -- which will be revealed by a follow up CT scan,
likely in State College in a few weeks -- they can make a second attempt at the
procedure. I am not sure what would happen if that second attempt fails. Dr. Beavis said
to me later that the option of open surgery is "still on the table."
With Dr. Beavis, later this afternoon, we reviewed the results of the PET scan. The
*preliminary* radiologist's report indicates that there is an area near where my small and
large intestine meet that *may* be a metastatis (or it may simply be an inflammation, as
Dr. Patel had thought). There is another fluid pocket in the lung that *may* be
suspicious. The CT scan in a few weeks may/should bring further clarity on this. Being
reminded by Dr. Beavis that my cancer was "extra-extensive" was not pleasant to hear.
But she also reminded me that there are many treatment options for the recurrence that
in most cases of ovarian cancer is likely. My vital signs are good (low blood pressure, as
always!) and her internal exam of me revealed nothing suspicious (a 'thickened' area in
my vagina that she was concerned about has healed, and there is no evidence of cancer
in the area where my ovaries etc. used to be -- this is good news. Also no evidence of
cancer in my liver, which she had been concerned about too: more good news. Finally, I
can stop taking one of my medications, another bit of good news.
Dr. Beavis and I also discussed whether or not I should take the PARP inhibitors as a
maintenance drug. She shared a very recent (Dec. 2019) _New England Journal of
Medicine_ study that showed that for patients 'like me' (ie BRCA negative) the average
gain in months before a recurrence was less than four months (for patients who are
BRCA positive the gain is much more significant). Is it worth it for me to take these drugs
and risk the side effects (fatigue - although it can be managed, high blood pressure,
altered blood counts, and in a small number of cases, leukemia) to gain a few months
before a recurrence?  On the other hand, if I have a recurrence soon will I regret not
having chosen the more aggressive path? Tough decision, one that I will not make until
after the fistula issue is completely resolved.
So I expect to return to State College on Saturday sans stomach drain and hopefully sans
fistula but with some unresolved questions. Perhaps I'll even know more tomorrow. I
continue to feel like I am in expert hands medically.
Thank you, everyone, for your care and concern. My mother has, as usual, been stalwart
and has maintained a positive attitude all along. We are going out shortly to a Lebanese
restaurant recommended by Dr. Beavis (who cleared me to drink in moderation!). I do
look forward to a nice glass of wine after a tiring day and before tomorrow's procedure. I
didn't sleep well last night because I was anxious, so I'm hoping tonight I'll fare better.

January 3, 2020 - Update from Baltimore II
  by Willa Silverman, January 3, 2020  
My procedure - a drain plug closure of an enterocutaneous fistula -
appears to have gone smoothly this morning. It took about an
hour. The doctors, nurses, technicians and other staff at
Hopkins continue to be unfailingly skilled, kind, and highly
professional. The small fistula had not closed on its own so Dr.
Holly closed it. I will have a CT scan in about two weeks in
State College to see whether the repair has 'held' (as
mentioned, this procedure has about a 2/3 success rate). I was
also delighted to say good riddance to my 'appendage' - the
stomach drain and drainage bag that I've needed to flush and
clean twice a day and that have dangled from me for several
months. Reinsertion of this tube, however, is not off the table
if fluid begins to collect again in my stomach.
For every bit of good news - and there were certainly some to be
                       300 / 1.901
glad about on this visit - more questions, it seems. A second
radiologist's report of my PET-CT scan confirmed the results of
the preliminary report: there are two 'suspicious' areas (one
where my small and large intestines meet, the other in my lung)
that may or may not be cancerous. The CT scan in two weeks
should help clarify the situation. Dr. Holly (and Dr. Patel)
believe the first area of concern, in the abdomen, is due to
inflammation. We'll see. In the meantime, as my aunt Marlene
wisely advised in response to my post yesterday, I will not
"borrow worries" (as challenging as that might be). As she
further noted, correctly: "This is a tricky disease."
In what Dr. Beavis terms "great news!!," though, my CA125 number
(a marker for ovarian cancer) has dropped 50%, from 51 to 26,
and is now in what she identifies as the "normal" range (as
opposed to what Dr. Patel referred to as a "worrisome" range).
While this is only one indicator for ovarian cancer, it's an
important one, and my number has not been this low in months. So
a big yay for that.
While I bounced back pretty quickly from the 'twilight' sedation
I had administered for the procedure this morning (after which
my mother and I enjoyed a tasty lunch at a great local place,
Atwater's), I'm feeling rather drained from the past few days
and all the medical "stuff." I am eager to get back to PA
tomorrow and chill for a while before school starts on the 13th.
I figure that I once again have a little 'reprieve' until my CT
scan in a few weeks, during which time I can revel in feeling
'normal.' Perhaps I have also exhausted (and/or bored) *you*
with these laborious descriptions of my medical condition, but
it can become quite all-consuming. Thank you, as ever, for
reading.
