January 8, 2020 - I'm Still Standing
  by Willa Silverman, January 8, 2020  
As if I didn't have enough on my hands medically, on Monday I fell in my house and
chipped a bone in my ankle! I was having a pretty crummy day to begin with -- receiving
an astronomical medical bill put me in a rotten mood -- when I got up from the chair I
had been sitting in for quite a while as I was working at my computer. No sooner had I
extended my right foot than I found myself tumbling down onto the wood floor, winding
up in a sort of contorted position with my right ankle and elbow and my left knee hitting
the floor, hard, and leaving me stunned. I surmise that the neuropathy (nerve damage)
in my toes, a lasting side effect of chemo, made me lose my balance. I went to the
urgent care clinic the next day, had my ankle and foot xrayed, and learned that I had an
avulsion fracture, a small fracture that can occur when a small fragment of bone chips
off a larger one. I'm in an air cast, can walk (or rather hobble) and drive. Tomorrow
morning I'll go to the orthopedist, see if they need to put me in another cast (please, no
plaster!) and learn how long this may take to heal. I've read that most often this type of
fracture heals on its own. Please, no surgery!! I'm not in pain, and thank goodness I
                       305 / 1.901
didn't hit my head or my side where I've just had a procedure last Friday. But the 'lesson
to self' is that I need to be careful getting up if I've been sitting a long time because my
toes tend to feel numb by that point. Oy.
Somehow this last incident has made me reach for black humor, instead of tears. I don't
know if this is healthier, but it just *is.* No pity party. The first image that came to mind
was that of the Black Knight in _Monty Python and the Holy Grail_ ,valiantly (or
foolishly??) continuing to fight his opponent despite having each of his limbs whacked off
in succession (you must watch this iconic clip if you never have):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZmInkxbvlCs
Next, I began singing, as loudly as I could, Elton John's "I'm Still Standing" and then,
perhaps more appropriately, Steven Sondheim's lyrics to "I'm Still Here" from _Follies,_
with several lines that rang particularly true to me:
I've run the gamut, A to Z
Three cheers and dammit, c'est la vie
I got through all of last year
And I'm here
You want to take my ovaries, uterus and fallopian tubes? Go right ahead. A piece of my
colon? Why not. Gall bladder? No problem. And throw in my appendix while you're at it.
I'm still here.
The word from my "contemplation deck" that's been staring at me the past few days is
"strength." Physically, I've certainly been stronger than I am currently (although my
energy and activity levels continue to be good); and I'm so disappointed that my plans to
restart a serious exercise program will now need to once again be on hold for a bit. But
'strength' is also mental and psychic toughness. When the going gets tough, the tough
get going. Maybe it's what the French call "le moral," a psychological state that allows
one to confront difficulties and challenges. When I wrote to my editor in Paris, Corinne, to
wish her a happy new year and update her on my health, she responded that she hoped
I had "le moral" to get through this difficult period. She knows something about this. At
my last meeting with her, she was the one wearing the wig during her treatment for
breast and kidney cancer. Yet there she was at her desk in her office, reviewing captions
for the illustrations for my book, toughing it out. Later, over drinks at a cafe, she
introduced me to her partner, another cancer survivor, before the two of them sped off
on his motorcycle. Over a year later, she's still here.
So please no pity but good vibes welcome for my orthopedist appointment tomorrow and
then next Friday the 17th's follow up CT scan, bookending the first week of the semester
                       306 / 1.901
during which I look forward to being in the office!

January 9, 2020 - These boots are NOT made for walking aka Update
from State College
  by Willa Silverman, January 9, 2020  
Just a quick update for those of you kind enough to follow my travails. I am back from
the orthopedist, where I received some further clarification on what happened when I
fell: basically, I sprained my ankle but when the ligaments pulled (which is the essence
of a sprain), they chipped off one and likely two tiny (no long than 3 mm) fragments of
bone from larger pieces on the right side of my foot and ankle. These should heal on
their own; the bone won't regenerate (at least I don't think it will) nor will the fragments
reattach to the bone; they simply get absorbed into tissue. No plaster cast necessary
(yay) nor any surgery (yay). Instead, their orthotics guy fitted me with a boot that I need
to wear as much as possible to immobilize my foot. The injury should heal in about a
month max. I will be checked again in 2-3 weeks to see how things are progressing. I
might need some physical therapy after that to recover range of motion.
The boot is extremely unwieldy and heavy and not conducive to walking; I can drive if I
take it off. My first reaction when I saw it was: "This thing is the antithesis of sexy." ("I'm
                       308 / 1.901
too sexy for my boot, too sexy for my boot, too sexy woot woot?"). I've tried my best to
rock a bald head and no eyebrows, a port, and a torso length scar, but rocking this
clunky thing is going to be a challenge. Moreover, because the boot sits on a raised
platform, I also received a matching platform thingy to affix to my left shoe, so that my
hips and back don't get out of whack. Oy. To be honest, I feel like a bit of a hot mess
right now but expect to be back to fighting form soon. I would be grateful for a rapid
return to wholeness of body and no more mishaps. It certainly could be worse.

January 12, 2020 - Hi-ho, hi-ho, it's off to work we go!
  by Willa Silverman, January 12, 2020  
Even after thirty-three years in my current job, I still get anxious before the first day of
the semester, and this one is no exception. I can tell, because I have not been sleeping
well for about a week. It takes me a long time to fall asleep because my thoughts are
careening out of control and once I do fall asleep, I doze lightly.
Something feels different this semester, though, and of course it is. I am not returning
from a 'normal' leave but from a medical one and - without any exaggeration -- from a
sometimes harrowing journey that feels a million miles removed from the bulk of my life
experience. It makes me think about -- without the slightest pretense *whatsoever* to
compare -- survivors returning from the camps, many of whose accounts I've read, and
whose feelings of alienation, of inability to communicate the hell they'd been through,
whose extreme difficulties reinserting themselves into their now foreign-seeming
routines, are palpable in their writings. I know this is a somewhat irrational fear on my
part: I can't wait to see my colleagues, our office staff, and students, who I'm sure will
greet me with open arms and who have shown unfailing kindness towards me. While I'm
not teaching this semester, I'm really hoping I can be productive and helpful to my
                       310 / 1.901
department -- there is some fear of feeling irrelevant. Yet I can't help feeling, too, that
my cancer has made me cross some invisible threshold, to a realm perhaps only (or
best) understood by those who have been there. So it's no wonder I can't sleep. I hope
these feelings will dissipate the further I delve into the semester.
And of course I'm very anxious about my upcoming scan on Friday and praying that it
does not reveal a recurrence. And if it does, what will that mean above all for my
prognosis but also for my engagement with the semester that will have just gotten up
and running? So....much...uncertainty. Don't borrow worries, don't borrow worries. For
now, I will simply look forward to an enjoyable and productive week ahead, doing what I
love.
I'm still in my boot, likely for the next two weeks, but so be it. When I remove the boot
and walk gingerly, I can tell that my foot/ankle are healing. It can't happen any more
quickly.
My hair is starting to grow back and I look like a porcupine.
Thank you Maria, Clare and Lisa, Jackie, and Helen for the wonderful recent visits, gab
fests, ramen soup and Mexican lunches, and yummy homemade beef stew! Thanks to
those friends who sent texts recently too. All very warming (and not just temperature-
wise).

January 17, 2020 - Update = no update
  by Willa Silverman, January 17, 2020  
I don't yet have an update to share about this morning's CT scan. I could barely sleep
due to anxiety, amplified by a text received from Penn State at 1 a.m. warning of icy
road conditions. The road in front of my house had not been plowed by 6 a.m., when I
woke up, so I took a cab to Geisinger (and an Uber back). I was there by 7:30 to ingest
the yucky drink over the next hour and a half, and then had the scan (I've had so many
of them by this point that I'm an expert at submitting to them!). I was disappointed that
Geisinger would not upload the images to the Hopkins image sharing website whose
address I gave them, for fear of viruses. This would have enabled my Hopkins doctors to
read/view the images today. The nurse did say she sent the images to Hopkins via a
program called Life Image but Dr. Beavis' nurse at Hopkins said she had no idea what
this is. Frustrating. In the end, I had to mail the disc containing the images via overnight
express mail, with a tracking number. Further, the nurse told me that a Geisinger
radiologist would likely not read and complete a report for up to a week! I'm hoping in
that case that the Hopkins radiologists will simply take the lead here. So I may not know
anything for a few days. My right side (the 'troublesome' side) feels a bit sore, as
mentioned, and is not getting better, so the sooner the images can be read the better.
There is not much else I can do while waiting, unless I really start to feel worse.
Meanwhile, I will try to have a calm (and calming) weekend. As I'm tired and there are
still patchy spots on the road, I think I'll work at home this afternoon, with a quick
Wegman's run at some point to stock up for the next big snow, due -- tomorrow! Thanks
to everyone for all the caring texts, FB messages, well wishes, prayers etc.

January 22, 2020 - Update = not much of an update
  by Willa Silverman, January 22, 2020  
My apologies for the air waves going silent for the past several days, and thank you so
much for your inquiries about the results of my CT scan. In what my mother rightly calls
'disc-gate,' the disc I sent to Hopkins last Friday, immediately after my scan, and which
was supposed to arrive the next day, only reached Dr. Beavis' office TODAY, five days
later. Apparently, per USPS, it arrived in Baltimore yesterday but Dr. Beavis' office had
no idea where it was to be retrieved. As mentioned, Geisinger in State College did not
want to upload the images electronically to Hopkins' website for fear of viruses. In the
meanwhile, I could have made several round trips to Baltimore to hand deliver the disc! I
was in my car headed to Geisinger on my lunch break today to pick up two new copies of
the disc (was not going to take any chances with just one copy), when Dr. Beavis' office
called to let me know it had arrived. I will spare all the additional details that conspired
to cause such an anxiety-provoking delay.
I have no other news to report. I presume that I'll be contacted once Drs. Beavis and
Holly have looked at and discussed the imaging. I am still quite anxious but being at
work has been a great diversion.
As if my day could not have started out any more tensely, as I was driving to work this
morning, having figured out my plan regarding the AWOL disc, what did I see in my rear
view mirror but... a cop car with flashing lights. Oh my. I pulled over and got out my
license, insurance and registration cards. Unfortunately, as I knew, I am overdue for my
yearly inspection. I was scheduled for it last week but the fractured bone in my ankle
(which is, incidentally, healing well) really put the kibosh on my walking the quarter mile
or so from my garage to my office, so I cancelled the appointment. I do realize that I
should have taken care of this earlier and will make sure to get it done asap. The young
officer -- to whom I showed my big clunky boot as 'evidence' -- was very polite and gave
me a citation, not a ticket -- but still. Not what I needed.

January 24, 2020 - Update
  by Willa Silverman, January 24, 2020  
                       320 / 1.901
There is some very good news and some less good news.
The very good, indeed excellent news, per Dr. Beavis in my phone conversation with her
today about the results of my CT scan, is that there appears to be no recurrence of
cancer; "nothing alarming," she said, based on the Geisinger radiologist's report and her
own viewing of the images (which the Hopkins radiologists have not yet looked at). The
'suspicious' spot (pleural effusion) on my lung is, in fact, tiny and apparently not a cause
for concern; the other 'suspicious' area on my right side is due to inflammation and what
I will discuss below. I was extremely worried that my cancer might have spread to my
lung, which would of course be very serious. I was consumed with anxiety, imagining my
aggressive cancer cells running amok in my body. Since November, then, I have
apparently remained in the clear, with NED (no evidence of disease). Praise be.
Less fortunately, fluid is still amassing on my right side, near my fistula. The procedure
to close that fistula, which I had performed at Hopkins on Jan. 3, was not a success (in
part due to the new fluid collection). This means that I still have a hole between my
abdomen and my bowel, with the risk (small but still there) of sepsis, infection and other
awful things. This leaves me with two options. I can have a new stomach drain placed
(likely this week at Hopkins, and hopefully during the first part of the week as we have a
series of job candidates coming to campus beginning next Thursday); then, in four
weeks, Dr. Holly can attempt the procedure again. Two weeks after that, as was the case
this time, I'll have another CT scan to see if the procedure was successful. My doctors
seem to me pessimistic about the procedure working this time. It has a 2/3 success rate
in the best of circumstances (ie no fluid collection), but given that it didn't work the first
time, my odds are likely slimmer, although not non-existent. Dr. Beavis said that it would
probably be like "kicking the can" down the road, with surgery likely eventually.
However, it still might work and would also provide me with about 6-8 weeks of relative
'normalcy' as I am just getting into a groove at work and with other aspects of my life.
Dr. Beavis understands how important these 'quality of life' issues can be (and are, for
me). At the same time, she would like me to, in her words, "have this whole episode
[concerning the fistula and the fluid collection] behind me."
I could also opt for surgery right away or, as mentioned, surgery if the procedure fails. I
will need to meet soon with the colorectal surgeon, Dr. Sandy Fang, but as I understand
it, this surgery might be (partly?) laparoscopic or not; might involve removing another
part of my colon or not; and might involve placing an ostomy bag *temporarily* or not. It
will depend on how things look inside, including the extent of adhesions etc. I will need
to ask more questions about the surgery, including amount of recuperation necessary.
But it is likely that there's another surgery in my (not terribly distant) future.
I am strongly leaning towards trying the procedure again both so I can attempt the less
invasive option first and so I can keep building on my newfound momentum at school
and elsewhere.
                       321 / 1.901
I will need to (re)gird on patience and fortitude for the next hurdles, while hopefully not
backsliding out of the 'new normal' it's taken me so long to claw my way back into and
where I am so very happy to find myself again.
I am grateful that I was able to come down from my stress cloud over a nice glass of red,
some cheese and other nibbles, and calming and fun conversation with my friend Helen
this evening. I realize that I've been holding a lot of anxiety this week, much as I've been
trying to refocus my energies and attention elsewhere.
Many thanks to everyone for the care and concern. With love,

January 27, 2020 - Back to Baltimore
  by Willa Silverman, January 27, 2020  
Sorry I only have time to post a brief update for now but I'll write more soon. I just got
home from work and errands (7:00 p.m.) -- I am not complaining about this new
schedule! -- and need to make dinner and pack. I'll be heading to Baltimore tomorrow for
two appointments at Hopkins on Wednesday: at 9:15 I'll meet with Dr. Sandy Fang, a
colorectal surgeon, for a consult about the surgery that it seems like I may have to have
sooner or later to remove (?) or repair a sinus tract (per woundsource.com, "a narrow
opening or passageway extending from a wound underneath the skin in any direction through soft
tissue and results in dead space with potential for abscess formation"). I'm sure I'll find out more
                       323 / 1.901
about the surgery when I speak with Dr. Fang and ask all my questions. At 4:30 I am having the
procedure to place a drain into the abscess that has reformed in my abdomen. This is at least the
second, if not the third time I've had this procedure It will be performed by Dr. Holly, the wonderful
interventional radiologist who also performed the procedure to attempt to plug my fistula (even though
that procedure did not succeed, I still think he's an excellent doctor, as they all seem to be at
Hopkins). I hope to leave Hopkins on Thursday morning with clarity about the best path forward for
me, ie second attempt at the fistula plug v. straight to surgery. The fact that I'm really getting into a
groove at work and in other aspects of my life is a big factor for me, but I won't do anything to
jeopardize my health.
For me, these are simply hurdles to jump over in this 'marathon.' These hurdles pale in comparison
with those directly related to the cancer (eg debulking, chemo etc.). Unpleasant as what's upcoming
is, I can handle it. Dr. Patel (or another doctor) had warned me that this was going to be a "long
haul." 
I will be infinitely comforted by, and grateful for my brother's presence in Baltimore on Wednesday.
He very kindly again offered to come down on W to be with me for the procedure (in any event, I need
someone with me as I'll be sedated. Hopefully, we'll have a nice dinner that evening and catch up,
then head our separate ways the next morning.

January 30, 2020 - Back from Baltimore
  by Willa Silverman, January 30, 2020  
I am facing another major surgery before too long. This was what I came away with after
a two-night stay in Baltimore full of twists and turns, uncertainty, and stress, along with a
bright spot or two.
                       325 / 1.901
To begin at the beginning: on Wednesday morning I had an appointment with Sandy
Fang, a colorectal surgeon, to discuss surgery to repair or eradicate my the
fistula/abscess/inflammation in my abdomen. I was at that point going with the idea that
surgery might be a second option, following a second attempt to plug the fistula
laparoscopically. Unfortunately, Dr. Fang was running about 45 minutes late, which in
the end left us only a rushed 30 minutes before I had to go to another building for my
procedure (stomach drain placement); watching the time slip away as I waited for her
was quite stressful, as I had driven 3.5 hours for this appointment. In the half hour we
had together, she began to explain what the surgery would entail, and she asked me
some questions and examined me. However, she stated that she would be fine with my
trying the less invasive fistula plug procedure first. She said it would be important to first
drain as much fluid as possible from the abscess, to create the 'cleanest' possible
environment for possible surgery, so she was intent as I was on getting me to my next
appointment on time. I tried to get a sense of possible timetable, length of recuperation
etc. but she wanted to first explain the operation to me. She kindly offered to meet with
me again the following morning at 9:00, so we could have a more in-depth conversation
and so she could answer my questions.
I hustled over to the Zayed building to check in for my stomach drain placement. The
very nice nurse who had attended to me last time I was at Hopkins (earlier this month) --
her name is Lisa  -- saw my name on the list of patients for the day and "chose" me. I felt
happy and relieved to see her again and we chatted about our kids, thoughts about
eventual retirement (we're about the same age), etc. as she placed an i.v. and started an
antibiotic drip, covered me with warm blankets etc. Dr. Holly, the interventional
radiologist who attempted to plug my fistula earlier this month, came by to say hello and
to explain that he would be (re)inserting a stomach drainage bag in an attempt to reduce
inflammation on my right side as a prelude to making a second attempt to plug the
fistula in a few weeks. One of the fellows assisting Dr. Holly on the procedure also came
by to introduce himself and to say "we'll take good care of you." I continue to feel that,
overall, I'm in excellent, skilled and compassionate hands at Hopkins. At around noon I
was wheeled into the procedure room (I remember looking up at the white ceiling while
machines whirred around me and thinking: "Sometimes I still can't believe all this is
happening to me..."). The fellow (I didn't catch his name) performed a sonogram to
locate the abscess into which the drain would be placed and he and Dr. Holly looked at
the screen together. Meanwhile, a nurse administered a sedative cocktail (Fentanyl and
something else) that made me....very ...drowsy.
I woke up disoriented back in the recovery bay. No drain. Dr. Holly came in shortly
thereafter, looking slightly flustered, to explain that he had not been able  to perform the
procedure as the fluid collection was too small; this is not what Dr. Beavis had led me to
believe from the CT scan, but I understand that once Dr. Holly and his team 'went in' to
actually try to insert a tube into the abscess, it was a different story. There were three
                       326 / 1.901
puncture marks on my right side where the team had tried to access the abscess. Dr.
Holly said something like: "I'm sorry I wasn't able to do it. There's something else going
on here [>at the time that sounded ominous to me]. There's nothing more I can do for
you." Thus ended the possibility of option #1, ie stomach drain leaving only option #2:
surgery.
So it was back to Dr. Fang for the follow-up appointment the next morning. I was very
glad that Dr. Beavis also joined us, as she happened to be free that morning.  We spent
about an hour together, with Dr. Fang explaining in detail (with the aid of a drawing and
my CT scan images, which had never really been shown to me with explanations before)
what the surgery would entail. To my surprise (or was I simply in denial?), the surgery is
much more of a big deal than I had imagined. It is major abdominal surgery. Urological
(?) surgeons will first have to place stents in my ureters to make sure no urine seeps into
the abdomen. Then Dr. Beavis will need to see if there is any cancer for her to remove.
This gave me a sinking feeling. I was reminded that cancer under a certain dimension (1
mm?) does not show up on a CT scan and that there was a bit of cancer she was unable
to remove in May (but hopefully the chemo got it). Then Dr. Fang will remove the entire
'problem' area (fistula, sinus tract, abscess). I will not be able to describe the procedure
in as much technical detail as Dr. Fang did, but of course this involves complex issues
regarding blood supply, adhesions, what she called 'tension' (of the tissue?), etc. Another
piece of my colon and small intestine (I think) will be removed (following those removed
last May). Complications could arise if there is cancer in the area to be removed (will
need to review my notes on this); if cancer winds up being removed during the
operation, it will likely be followed (once I recover) by more chemo. In the absolute worst
case scenario, I could wind up with a permanent ostomy bag; in better (less bad??)
scenarios, I might have a temporary otsomy bag. Then there will be a hospital stay, like
last time, with the whole shebang (pain management for abdominal pain, goals to meet
before I can be released, like eating without nausea or vomiting) and recuperation at
home, no driving for six weeks etc. Dr. Beavis implied that I might "lose" my spring to
get back on track for summer and fall. Also, I can expect to lose 10-15% of my body
weight because I won't feel like eating.  
I don't yet know about timetable. I am now on antibiotics for two weeks to try to reduce
inflammation before having another CT scan. My right side feels uncomfortable because
of the inflammation, which Dr. Fang showed me on the CT scan, describing it as a 'rind.'
If the antibiotics seem to be effective, we'll probably wait a while longer before surgery.
So I'm in a holding pattern for at least two weeks and will be delighted to dive back into
work and my other activities during that time. 
Of course, I felt sort of numb receiving all this news and I'll need to write more about my
reactions another time as I have to move on to other things soon. I felt somewhat
'retraumatized' breaking the news to my family and feeling their distress (which I always
feel responsible for, even though I know that this whole cancer thing is just plain 'ole
                       327 / 1.901
dumb luck of the genetic draw...). What I need to keep in mind is a)as Dr. Beavis said,
the expectation is that this surgery will resolve once and for all this complication (she
explained what would happen if I didn't have it; infected fluid from the abscess would
eventually start seeping out of my skin.....) and b) I am in much better shape physically
than when I had my debulking surgery last May, when my body was full of cancer.
The brightest spot of the trip, and certainly not a negligible one, was having my dearest
'people' with me. My brother's presence is so comforting. We had breakfast in the hotel
(after he made a Starbucks run for us) and schmoozed about cars, Kobe and our kids. It
didn't matter that I was still a bit loopy from my sedation. And Wednesday night Ben
came from DC for dinner! Ben and his uncle Ethan are close, which is lovely to see. The
three of us went to a cute cafe in Fells Point called Water for Chocolate. I was so happy
to hug and kiss my son. "May you walk with good companions."
More before long. Must get ready for work!

February 8, 2020 - (Not) having it all
  by Willa Silverman, February 8, 2020  
                       330 / 1.901
                       331 / 1.901
I was groomed for success. I was groomed to have it all. From my privileged private
school education in New York, which honed the intellect and confidence of young women
before launching them to the top colleges and universities in the country, to Harvard, to
graduate school at NYU, where it was perhaps implicit -- for better or worse -- that I
would follow in my father's own successful academic career, to realizing that expectation
(more modestly, but that's another story) over my thirty + years at Penn State, nothing
seemed beyond reach. I cultivated my career with single-minded grit and determination
because, as a Harvard friend highly impressive for her own career as a dean of a top
business school in Japan remarked to me in a text (as she was en route to the economic
summit in Davos), "in our professions work is not just a job but life." Month-long trips to
Paris, other travel, frequent trips 'home' to New York or to see Ben in DC, pricey haircuts,
cute clothes, and other forms of pampering were only a click of a credit card away. As for
the proverbial work-life balance, I've been blessed to be a mother (and have done pretty
well in that capacity, if I may). Marital/romantic relationships may have proved slightly
more challenging but certainly within reach, buttressed by many beautiful moments. 
And so this is why I was teary last night, as the debate in NH droned on in the
background. Adjusting (lowering?) expectations is hard. 'Acceptance' is hard, even after
sixty years of experiencing abundant privilege and opportunity that should be more than
enough for one lifetime. Even gratitude for what remains is hard. I sit in my office,
overjoyed to be back at work and grateful for the modified responsibilities this semester
that have allowed me to continue my recovery while working, yet sad that I'm not in the
classroom, as I normally would be. I'm depressed that I can't yet make plans to go to
France (or anywhere) this summer as things are on hold until a timetable for my next
surgery is determined and while the specter of again losing a 'season' hangs over me.
I know I will return to appreciating the 'new normal.' I know that gratitude for what is will
again flood my heart. I know that I'll again return to the conviction that giving up a trip is
a small price to pay for the hope of quality and quantity of life. But it's still hard.
God, grant me the serenity
to accept the things I cannot change,
the courage to change the things I can,
and the wisdom to know the difference.
Living one day at a time,
enjoying one moment at a time,
I am feeling ok overall. My sleep is so-so. I have discomfort on my right side, where the
problematic fistula/abscess are located. I am somewhat doubtful that the strong
antibiotics I am taking to reduce the inflammation on my side are working. My CT scan
this coming Thursday will help determine the path forward medically. And here comes
                       332 / 1.901
the scanxiety: will any new cancer show up on the CT scan? Is any lurking, eluding
detection? Damn this parasite that is lying in wait, destroying what I need to live.
Meanwhile, my energy level has been really pretty high. I had a productive week at work,
at the office from about 9:30 to 5 or 6 each day. It is such a pleasure to cram into my
colleague's office once or twice a week for lunch with one or more other colleagues (who
are all friends) and dish about what we are reading for fun, our latest makeup purchases,
our kids, and goings on in the department. I had a great convo over dinner with a job
candidate. Enjoyed another dinner and a lunch out with friends. Per tradition, taking my
friend Monique out for brunch tomorrow for our bdays (she's Feb. 4th, I'm March 4th) and
then going to see "Parasite" with Maria, as it's been highly recommended. Treated
myself to breakfast this morning at a cute cafe in town and enjoyed a hearty meal (eggs,
pancake, oj, cappuccino) while reading a magazine.
Had a lovely day in Harrisburg last Sunday with a new friend, brunching at Rubicon in a
sweet little townhouse, further relaxing over a coffee at Little Amps, right near the
Capitol, then taking a stroll by the Suquehanna (see pic). Simple pleasures like getting to
know another person will always be wondrous to me. Resolutely seeking out and reveling
in human connection has always been my m.o. But now it's also part of my f*** you to
cancer. Yes, grateful for the moment.
“Because I know that time is always time
And place is always and only place
And what is actual is actual only for one time
And only for one place
I rejoice that things are as they are and
I renounce the blessed face and
I renounce the voice
Because I cannot hope to turn again.”
T.S. Eliot, "Ash Wednesday"

February 12, 2020 - Praise be
  by Willa Silverman, February 12, 2020  
A very quick post before I get to work to share reassuring results of the blood work I had
done yesterday in preparation for my CT scan tomorrow and upcoming visit with Dr.
Patel on Monday:
                       334 / 1.901
I reviewed your blood workup done on 2/11/2020:
-Cancer marker CA 125 level -> 23.8 which is in the normal range
-Normal kidney and liver function test noted
-Normal blood counts noted.
Overall normal and stable blood test result noted.
I told my mother on the phone last night that I was too nervous to look at the results,
which had come in yesterday. Given all the discomfort I've been having on my right side
due to the fistula/abscess, plus a perception of slight (?) bloating in my abdomen (a
telltale sign for ovarian cancer), I had convinced myself that new tumors were growing
and pressing into me. I do need to stress that there may well be some microscopic
cancer floating around inside me, and that the CA125 marker is not the 'be all and end
all' of cancer detection, but I'm nevertheless, for today, holding onto this bit of good
news about my overall blood counts. Yay for "normal and stable!" I was so relieved when
I read Dr. Patel's note that I started hyperventilating, then crying!
Onward.

February 15, 2020 - Let's hear it for 'Guy who Died'
  by Willa Silverman, February 15, 2020  
In the hall of fame (or notoriety) of tragicomic first encounters marking the flurry of
online dating into which I plunged post-divorce (now ten years ago!), there were some
real doozies (in all fairness, I must say that there were many lovely first dates too - some
of you know who you are! :) -- and on the rare occasions I take a peek online these days
I'm much more discriminating). Someday, maybe, I'll write about all these fellows, using
a title suggested by a friend who knows of what she speaks: Some College (this an
allusion to an educational status that people may select for their profiles). There was (in
                       337 / 1.901
no particular order): Guy Obsessed with Disney; Anger Issues Guy; the Republican; Guy
who Accused me of being a Cougar; Nasty Basketball Coach; Guy who Declined to Spend
the Night, Citing a Flatulence Problem; and Guy who Refused to Date Women too Uptight
to use Sh** and F** in the same Sentence (ok, I borrowed that last one from a friend).
But, when we tell the tales among girlfriends, the one that always elicits a stone cold
silence, followed by a muffled, embarrassed guffaw, is Guy who Died. Guy who Died was
a retired professor, perhaps in his 60s (or maybe 70s) at a local university (not Penn
State), with whom I exchanged several pleasant enough emails. We agreed to meet for
coffee. Several days later, before we had even met, I opened my local newspaper, only
to discover, in the Obituaries section, that my prospective date had died! No cause of
death was cited, only information about the funeral, his next of kin, and a brief bio
(incidentally, my experience echoes an episode of Sex and the City, in which Miranda is
stood up for a date, only to find out that he has died of a heart attack, then only to
attend the wake and see that the prospective date was very cute, and then only to pick
up another guy at the wake). So maybe this is a.... thing?
Did my Guy who Died pass suddenly, of a heart attack? Or rather did he know he was
about to die and, in the face of death, courageously cling to the hope of life and love, up
until the end?
I've thought a lot about him recently. In the fantasy I have spun around him (which may,
I realize, contain a fair amount of projection on my part), he knew he was to die soon.
While I hope and expect this is not my case, I too have found, when confronted up close
and personal with at least the specter of death, as serious illness tends to do, a strong
desire (and ability) to love fiercely and purely and hopefully. As if the essence of life
could be distilled into love, which is timeless, and therefore, in some sense, a guarantee
of life eternal. While Freud (about whom I"m surely no expert...) wrote of the primal
urges of Eros (the life urge, including libido and sexuality but also other forms of love)
and Thanatos (the destructive urge) that exist in each person, I see them intertwined
differently. "Love never fails" (1 Corinthians: 8), even -- especially - in the face or the
wake of death.
So let's hear it for the Guy who Died. And let's be cheerleaders for love.
****************************************
Speaking of love, I had a lovely Valentine's Day - bought myself roses and some eye
shadow, and brought a box of chocolates from La Maison du Chocolat, sent to me by my
dear, kind friend Paula, to work to share with a few friends.
My CT scan on Thursday went smoothly (although it's a tiring, all-morning ordeal) and I
managed to upload the 600+ images to Hopkins' image-sharing site for the doctors to
view. No word yet. I'm feeling a bit frustrated that Dr. Fang, the colorectal surgeon who
ordered the scan and who will likely perform the projected fistula operation along with
                       338 / 1.901
Dr. Beavis, has not responded to my emails. While very friendly and while she spent a
good amount of time with me at Hopkins explaining the upcoming procedure and
answering all my questions, she also made it clear that she is deluged with emails and
requests for consults from all over the country... So I will need to be more proactive in
making sure she remains responsive to me. Dr. Beavis is out of the country until this
coming week, so I'm presuming I'll hear from her then. I will see my medical oncologist
here, Dr. Patel, on Monday, so I can also share my concerns with him. Meanwhile, the
discomfort in my side and abdomen is more or less manageable depending on the day
(Ibuprofen helps) but clearly needs medical attention.
I queried a few trusted friends about the need for such major abdominal surgery.
However, this is a case in which it would be helpful for me to avail myself of a caregiver
who could do some research for me; I'm doing it all myself as I also work full time now
etc. So I'm doing the best I can -- but no pity party. My friend Marty, a scientist who
teaches at Penn State and whose wife succumbed to ovarian cancer eight years after her
diagnosis, shared that Wendy had six operations but bounced back after each one to a
very good quality of life. My (ex)-bro-in-law, David, a gastroenterologist, said that
surgery seems a reasonable option at this point given that draining the abscess and the
laparoscopic procedure to plug the fistula both failed. He did reassure me, in the case
that I would need an ostomy bag (temporary or permanent), that many people have
them and that it winds up not being a big deal to them. This was quite reassuring. But a
permanent bag would be worst case scenario only.
I had a full week at work interviewing a visiting job candidate, working on projects for the
department, seeing a student or two, writing recommendations, meeting with the
current and former deans of our College, doing some research etc. and I held up well.
Still very glad to be back at work, feeling productive and purposeful. Looking forward to
tea this afternoon with my friend Clare and maybe our friend Lisa as well.

February 19, 2020 - A bit of an update
  by Willa Silverman, February 19, 2020  
As I was about to leave the office today to go meet my friend Helen for Mexican dinner at
Lupita's, my cell phone rang. It was Dr. Sandy Fang, the colorectal surgeon at Hopkins,
who had ordered the CT scan I had last Thursday and whose results I had been anxiously
awaiting since then, all the while sending multiple emails via MyChart to make sure the
images had reached the right hands and been read by the right pairs of eyes.
I am feeling more reassured now, not because anything has changed in terms of the
need for what Dr. Fang termed a "big surgery" but because a plan is now emerging. It's
the uncertainty that really unsettles me; yesterday afternoon, my therapist and I
discussed to what extent my anxiety *might* be aggravating the significant abdominal
discomfort I've been having recently, which I've been attributing exclusively to my
fistula/abscess or else to *imagined* problems, such as new tumors pressing on my rib
cage and into my abdomen, blockages etc. All these fantasies had been coalescing in my
mind during what may be (in my analysis of the situation) a kind of retraumatization (a
word?) I'm experiencing with the one-year anniversary of my diagnosis on the horizon
(but not until April, in fact). After my discussion w/Dr. Fang, however, presto! my
stomach somehow feels better, 'lighter.' Not all better, for sure, but just more ... at ease.
Dr. Fang told me that the new CT scan imaging has not significantly changed since my
second to last CT scan two weeks prior. That was a relief, dispelling the fantasy of large
new tumors growing, blockages forming etc. She also said that she did not see any new
cancer in the images - relief - but that she would let Dr. Beavis weigh in on that. She said
that people with my condition, ie with a fistula/abscess in the abdomen, often feel pretty
crappy - also somewhat of a relief as this explains why I've been feeling...pretty crappy.
Finally, she reassured me of her competence/experience/expertise, as well as that of Dr.
Beavis -- also a relief, as I had mistakenly thought I had heard her say during our last
meeting at Hopkins that she had not operated on a case exactly like mine. This turns out
to not be true. She has performed many such surgeries, and many of them on cancer
patients. She and Dr. Beavis often operate together. She assured me that she would take
                       341 / 1.901
good care of me, although of course there are always risks with such a big surgery. But I
place my trust in these two very talented young women and the rest of the staff at
Hopkins.
We talked about projected dates for the surgery. It will depend on the coordination of Dr.
Beavis' calendar w/Dr. Fang's (they are both very busy and in demand), but I was glad
that she asked me to weigh in too. I asked that she spare me from the knife on my
birthday (4 March), but suggested that the week of spring break (the week of March 9)
might be possible. After saying that, I wondered if I should try to preserve my spring
break to take a week to relax and get a change of scene before surgery, but then
wondered about my potential for relaxation under such circumstances. I guess the
sooner I can have the surgery done the sooner I can start recovering, and since I'm on a
good roll with work I hope I'll be able to continue working at home while I recuperate. I
guess there is no optimal time for the surgery. It also depends, Dr. Fang said, on how
symptomatic I am. As mentioned, my abdomen has been feeling uncomfortable but with
the plan in place I'm banking on it not feeling as bad, and I have a few nice events to
look forward to, beginning with Ben and Sammi being in State College this coming
weekend. :)
It is still lovely to be at work. My colleagues are so kind, so pleasant. A few of us have
been having lunch in one of our offices on MWFs, complete with a delicious espresso
made for us by the dear colleague, Heather, whose office we use for our gatherings. It's
always convivial and there are lots of laughs. I do miss teaching though. Good motivation
to get better soon!

February 23, 2020 - Holding steady
  by Willa Silverman, February 23, 2020  
A very pleasant and fun weekend lifted my spirits, as I await word regarding the date of
my surgery; I really hope to have this nailed down soon and will contact my Hopkins
doctors tomorrow.
Friday I left work around 4 to grocery shop in anticipation of Ben and Sammi's arrival for
the weekend and a friend coming up from Baltimore for the day on Sunday. At Wegman's
I ran into a friend I had not seen in several years who told me that shortly after he
learned about my diagnosis from a coworker, his wife was diagnosed with breast cancer
and that he's had to hold down the fort (including caring for a two-year-old) while his
wife has undergone treatment. He told me that he'd been following my CB page in order
to know what to anticipate: chemo (in his wife's case overseen also by Dr. Patel, who
seems to treat nearly every cancer patient in town), a trip to the 'wig lady,' etc. I am
terribly sad for what he and his family are going through, but happy that my blog may
have provided some small measure of help. Cancer automatically creates bonds between
people - we're in the club no one wants to belong to, and we need to be there for each
                       343 / 1.901
other. My friend and I hugged warmly when saying goodbye.
It was of course really wonderful to have Ben and Sammi stay over both Friday and
Saturday nights. Now that I subscribe to NYTimes recipes, I made an easy but very tasty
baked salmon dish, in a glaze with honey, apple cider vinegar, soy sauce and jalapenos,
served w/basmati rice and some sauteed spinach. After dinner we all went to the
Creamery, where we laughed about ingesting so much sugar and cream that we were all
three nearly in shock! Clearly, my appetite is no longer failing me... On Saturday, I had to
be part of a 'ruse' to distract Michael while his house was being readied for his surprise
60th bday party. So we chatted in my living room while Ben took an extra long time
changing light bulbs for me. After they left, I made a quiche with goat cheese and fresh
herbs, some oat scones with cranberries and orange zest, and a beet salad. So glad to
have the energy for this major burst of binge cooking -- and I sent Ben back to DC
w/homemade chicken soup too!
Last night I went to a fun party for 'carnevale.' All the guests wore Carnival masks (some
from Venice) and beads (mine, bought in New Orleans years ago, feature lobsters). We
acted silly and danced up a storm! Again, I surprised myself w/my stamina. It felt so
good to enjoy some spirited partying, the kind I like (even sans alcohol for me...).
Today a friend came up from Baltimore to spend part of the day with me. We had a
lovely brunch that I had prepared, then went to the Palmer Museum, which we visited
pretty thoroughly, then sat outside in the sun at the Creamery, enjoying yet another ice
cream cone. It felt like spring.
My hair has grown enough so that I think this week I will have it colored and trimmed. I
imagine that this will feel quite liberating for me, eliminating the need to rely on a wig.
It's ultra short and I still look somewhat like a porcupine, but I will wear my new 'do'
proudly.
My commitment card word this week (thank you again, Shanny, for this gift) is
'positivity,' as in try to remain in this state. Very important.
Grateful, then, for this weekend. Trying not to waste a minute. Anxious about backsliding
big time with the upcoming surgery (and praying that there will be no need for follow up
chemo if any cancer is found during the surgery). I'll just have to try to get to a good
space mentally and emotionally, be patient and accepting, and keep of the goal summer
trips on the horizon.

February 25, 2020 - Update re surgery
  by Willa Silverman, February 25, 2020  
                       351 / 1.901
                       352 / 1.901
Note to self: never read emails in bed on waking up. That's how I found out, in an email
from Dr. Fang, that my surgery has indeed been scheduled for Monday 9 March, which
was later confirmed when I spoke with Val, the nice administrator in her office. 
I don't know why -- or maybe I do -- but that news turned me into a slobbering weepy
mess within minutes. I haven't cried so hard in a long time. I guess it's simply the 'feeling
all the feelings' in a rush: guilt about again causing distress to my loved ones overtook
me while I was sitting in my pjs at the dining room table, eating my scone; next came a
kind of 'holy shit' fear and panic while I was showering (combined with a niggling feeling
that I should update my will before the operation); then huge feelings of disappointment,
sadness and anger at the prospect of again needing to 'step out' of my normal life (yet
what is normal for me anymore?) while the world goes on without me, all the while
desperately wishing I could simply be my usual vibrant, energetic, productive self; then
some confusion about how I should best use the time until the operation (likely simply
hewing to my work/play routine, which suits me just fine). Then there is the
'retraumatization' factor, as memories of physical pain, long recuperation, emotional and
psychological fragility etc. came flooding back. It was so hard, and I just pray that my
body and spirit have the wherewithal to bounce back again.
It will be a big surgery. Per Val, the kind administrator at Hopkins, I will need to be at the
hospital at 5:30 (!!) for a 7:30 operation, scheduled for 6+ hours. So maybe it won't be
as long as that "mother of all surgeries" I had last May, but it will be long. Then a "3+
day" hospital stay. In addition, I have to go to Hopkins this coming Monday for pre-op
meetings with the anesthesiologist and the ostomy nurse, in case that worse-case
scenario becomes a reality. The night before the surgery I have to do a bowel prep (hope
this is not TMI), which was an absolute horror last May as I was very sick and had a hard
time with it. At least this time I know what to expect, will be in a much better/nicer hotel
than the one we were in last time, and will aim to be calmer. I know the drill.
I am feeling rather frustrated that my surgeons have not seemed as responsive as I'd
like to my requests to speak with them before the operation. Dr. Beavis' nurse "runs
interference" for her and won't always forward notes from patients (at least from this
patient). She (Kelly, the nurse) suggested that I really should be talking to Dr. Fang, the
colorectal surgeon. However, I would really like to speak with Dr. Beavis as the doctor
who oversees my care (and who will be present at the operation). I will need to regroup
and try again.
Hold the presses! At the time of this writing, I have indeed spoken with the wonderful,
upbeat Anna Beavis, who called me in my office at about 5 p.m., just as I was getting
ready to leave (and actually just as I was writing the previous paragraph). As usual, she
spent as much time as I needed on the phone, answering all my questions. I took two
                       353 / 1.901
pages of notes, and there's a lot of info to convey, so I'll just condense some of it here:
as with my surgery last May, the type of surgery they will do will depend largely on what
they see when they 'go in.' She laid out three possible scenarios from best to middle-
ground to worst, all depending on a)whether or not they find any cancer in addition to
the fistula, b)where the cancer is located (if they find any), and c)how much they find.
She said my latest CT scan did not reveal any new tumors but, as I've mentioned, below
a certain size some cancer will not show up on the CT scan. What they find will also
determine follow-up: if they find more cancer, I will likely need follow-up chemo. Dr.
Beavis is also monitoring a small amount of fluid in my lung, which has gotten slightly
larger but is still very small. As I'll be pumped with fluids (I think), if it turns out they
need to drain any from my lung (at a later point), they may look at some samples under
a microscope, but during the surgery they'll only be operating on my abdominal area,
not my lung cavity. I asked her whether she thought this big surgery will inhibit my body
from being able to deal with a recurrence if/when that happens and she said she
believed it would *not,* as my body is overall stronger now than it was last May. She also
is prescribing a painkiller to help ease my abdominal discomfort and to tide me over until
the surgery. She told me that she'd be assisting in the surgery from the 'ovarian cancer'
perspective and also as someone who can convey what she understands of my
preferences and wishes to Dr. Fang, ie as a type of 'advocate' for me. That made me feel
good.
I know it's a lot to absorb. Somehow I am not feeling overly anxious now writing about it,
perhaps because I felt better after my convo w/Dr. Beavis. She assured me that she'd
take good care of me. Dr. Fang had told me the same thing. I have to keep in mind that
the goal of this surgery is to permanently resolve this complication from last May's
surgery, so that I can get on with my life. Fingers crossed.
I *did* manage to have a productive day at work today. The brightest spot was having
the president and secretary of the French club, two undergraduates, appear in my office
to offer the faculty a King Cake (Gateaux des rois - sorry for the missing accent on the
'a'), bought at Wegmans (!), to thank the department for providing some monetary and
moral support for the club's upcoming trip to New Orleans over spring break. They were
terrifically sweet to make this gesture. I had totally forgotten that today is Mardi Gras.
Laissez les bons temps rouler �� 
My mother nicely assured me that Team Willa would be in place for the next hurdle. My
friend Lisa sat with me in my office in the late afternoon and kindly indulged another
bout of teariness. I am so appreciative of everyone's well wishes and prayers. Thank you!

February 26, 2020 - A setback
  by Willa Silverman, February 26, 2020  
Hi everyone,
Greetings from the ER of MNMC (Mount Nittany Medical Center), where I've been laid up
since about ten or so this morning. My abdominal discomfort, coupled with some nausea
and constipation, had been worsening over the past 2-3 days, culminating in a bad night
last night. The discomfort -- actually pain by this point -- was pretty acute: my abdomen
felt as if it were cramping or throbbing, I was burping a lot and felt on the verge of
vomiting. The pain kept waking me up, and of course I was becoming progressively more
anxious.
So I got out of bed at about 6 a.m. and wrote to both Dr. Fang and Dr. Beavis, describing
my symptoms and asking for their advice. Dr. Fang responded quite quickly, advising
that I go to the ER for blood work and a CT scan. I was able to drive myself to the
hospital but was really not feeling well. Fortunately, I did not have to wait long to be
checked in.
I'm being well taken care of here, by both a good ER doc, Eric Feese, and a
compassionate nurse, Carla (I don't know her last name). I had blood drawn to test
kidney function among other things, had a chest x-ray taken as well as an abdominal CT
scan. I've been receiving IV fluids (although I've had nothing to eat nor drink, per
doctor's orders) and some magnesium (as my level was low) by IV too. And I've been
blissed out on morphine all day.
The CT scan revealed that I have an obstruction in my small bowel. It's not large, but
large enough to be causing the pain that I experienced last night. It may be due to scar
tissue, of which much formed after my operation last May. It may resolve on its own, or it
may need to be resolved surgically. Right now, I have an NG tube running through my
nose into my stomach to drain what's above the blockage. Inserting it was painful, and
brought back memories of a host of painful procedures I had to undergo last spring. 
                       356 / 1.901
Dr. Feese spoke with Dr. Fang, who would like me to come to Hopkins for treatment. At 6
p.m. I'll find out whether they have a bed for me there (currently they do not). If so, I'll
be transported there by EMS ambulance (I do have my car here at the hospital and
asked if I could drive myself to Baltimore as I think the transport is expensive, but the
doctor said no way). If a bed doesn't open up today, we'll try again tomorrow. I don't
really know what the plan is, but it sounds like it will entail fixing all the problems at once
(blockage, abscess, fistula etc.). I don't know whether the date for that surgery will be
moved up to earlier than the currently scheduled one on 9 March.
I'm not sure how I am feeling emotionally about these latest developments. I am much
less weepy than yesterday. In fact, I feel pretty calm right now (the morphine helps...),
relieved to be taken care of and to know why I felt so wretched during the night. I'm just
rolling with it for now. As ever, a lovely, loving and supportive email from a friend, which
it looks like she sent at about 5 this morning and which I was thus able to read when I
rose at 6, was a balm to my spirit. Emails, texts and calls throughout the day from a few
friends and of course the family members I was able to update (my mother, brother, Ben
and Michael) also helped settle me. But the whole thing is really a drag....
I will share updates when I can. Pleased that I thought to grab my laptop before I left this
morning, as well as a long novel that I'm engrossed in, but I don't have too much else
with me and have no idea how long I may be away. Thanks to everyone who took the
time to read this entry. I appreciate your well wishes and prayers.

February 27, 2020 - Hanging in
  by Willa Silverman, February 27, 2020  
At least a brief update here as I'm feeling pretty crappy - have had a headache for two
days as I've been NPO (no food or drink, nor for the foreseeable future), feel nauseous,
exhausted (arrived at Hopkins by EMT ambulance around 3:30 this morning) and still
have an NG tube down my nose. On the brighter side, I have less abdominal pain as
they've been draining my stomach.
I am being very well taken care of here, naturally. I'm in a nice recently renovated room
in the historic part of the hospital, on a floor where Saudi princes stay (along with their
security) when they come to be treated here. I saw Dr. Fang this morning and Dr. Beavis
stopped by to chat for quite a while. They will be monitoring me over next few days to
see if the stomach blockage resolves, which is the hope (a good sign is that I have been
able to pass some gas - again, hopefully not TMI here). My big surgery is still set for 9
March, unless it needs to be done sooner in light of the blockage (Dr. Beavis noted that
things are rarely straightforward with my case...).So it's really day by day at this point.
No eating or drinking for now, and the tube will stay in my nose into my stomach.
Tomorrow they'll do a test w/contrast dye to see how things are passing through my
system.
A few bright spots through the gloom: chatting w/Dr. Beavis, 90% about my treatment
plan but 10% about other stuff, including how she met her husband, her recent biking
vacation in Colombia etc. She's a rock star in every way. Then a visit from Rhonda, the
wonderful chaplain (Methodist, but quite ecumenical) who I met after my first operation.
I also just love talking with her (and hearing her southern accent) and while we didn't
have time to pray today (as a phone call interrupted that), she will come visit me
tomorrow for some prayers of healing. Finally, my beautiful son and I chatted for a while
by phone; he'll kindly come from DC at some point this weekend to visit. As we
understand that my upcoming bday (4 March) *may* be spent in decidedly unfestive
conditions, Ben consented to this year 'share' his birthday, exactly one month after mine
on 4 April, with me! And it's truly a "birth day" for both of us.
Thanks, dear ones, for keeping me in your thoughts and prayers during this journey.

February 28, 2020 - Twists and turns
  by Willa Silverman, February 28, 2020  
                       363 / 1.901
                       364 / 1.901
Despite a three-day headache that I can't seem to shake, I wanted to write a brief
update. This morning began with the possibility that I might have to have my big surgery
*today:* Dr. Fang was afraid that the situation with the blockage might be degrading and
was also concerned about my own stamina waning having now been three days NPO
(nothing through the mouth, and with an NG tube still draining my stomach). However,
she said the upper GI test would determine the next steps. At that point, I texted my
brother the news and he and my mother were kind enough to get on the next train from
NY, arriving here around 2:00 p.m.
I had the upper GI test at 10:00 a.m.; it involved running a barium contrast dye through
my NG tube and then taking pictures at half-hour intervals to assess the progression of
the liquid through my digestive system. I couldn't hold the barium down at first, so we
had to start over. To my surprise, the test went more quickly than I expected (I was told
to bring a book as I might be there for several hours) and the radiologist then came to
tell me that the liquid had progressed quickly to the colon and that in fact the
obstruction seemed to be resolving!
So back to my room. Dr. Fang came by again to confirm this news and put forth a
revised plan. I will likely be here through Sunday or Monday, giving the obstruction
further time to resolve (although things can always change). Hopefully, the NG tube will
be removed tomorrow and I can begin receiving non-IV nourishment very slowly
(probably just a few sips of water at first). In order to be discharged, I will need to be
meeting certain benchmarks, which I already seem to be doing. If all advances as
planned, I'll be able to return to State College and regain some strength next week
before coming back to Baltimore next Sunday the 8th for the big fistula repair surgery on
the 9th.
I'm feeling pretty weak and, as mentioned, have had a non-stop headache, some
nausea, fatigue etc. but my abdomen feels less painful, which is a good thing. I continue
to have nothing but the highest praise for the doctors, nurses, technicians etc. at
Hopkins. Today I was cared for by a very sweet nurse named Kiki, who declared me
(based on my telling her that I teach French and her seeing a pretty amethyst and topaz
ring on my finger) "the cutsiest, classiest, boutique-y lady." I'll take it, especially as that's
hardly how I I feel today :) Then there was "Mr. G" ("Hi, Mr. G!," as the nurses greet him),
a dignified looking older gentleman who came to collect the trash in my room, which he
looks like he may have been doing since the Nixon (?) presidency. Many cheers for the
good, decent, dignified working people of Baltimore. 
It was comforting to have my mother and brother here. Ethan has to return to NY
tomorrow but my mother will stay on, and Ben will come from DC after a certification
test he has to take for work, perhaps spending the night if he can.
                       365 / 1.901
I am so very grateful for everyone's texts, emails, comments on CB. I did not have the
stamina today to respond to individual messages, but I'll try to get to them when I'm
feeling up to it.
With my very last iota of energy last night (see pic), I helped the grad student whose
dissertation I'm directing work through a final draft of her grant proposal, due today. I
really want her to get that grant!

February 29, 2020 - On the Mend
  by Willa Silverman, February 29, 2020  
Foods I am craving right now: mole, Szechuan noodles, spaghetti and meatballs with a
ton of grated cheese, bananas Foster bread pudding from Magnolia Bakery in New York.
Maybe a cheeseburger and French fries. And a NY bagel with veggie cream cheese. In no
particular order. Or maybe all at once.
Foods I have eaten today (60 mls per hour): veggie broth, red jello, mango and cherry
ices, cranberry juice. 
After going on four days without eating and with a little imagination, the latter foods
tasted almost as good as the former! Almost.
I am coming along well. The residents doing rounds this morning examined me and said
my stomach felt much softer, which is a good sign. The female resident told me her
daughter's name is Zahava! In the late morning they did a study (I forgot what it's
called) to see how well liquids were flowing through my digestive system; it involved no
longer relying on suction. The study was to last for four hours. However, at about the two
hour mark while I was changing into a fresh gown, I sneezed forcefully several times and
wound up *sneezing out* my NG tube, the one going through my nose into my stomach!
We were all very surprised and couldn't figure out where the tube had gone. Thankfully, I
was spared the agony of having the tube reinserted as it was clear that the study was
going well, ie there was very little gastric discharge in the canister. So the study was
stopped and at that point I was put on clear liquids in small doses. This has had the
advantage of making my blazing headache abate and giving me a bit more energy (my
mother and I walked all around the three floors of this pavilion today as my walking is in
no way inhibited and I normally have plenty of energy for walking long distances).
The resident and I discussed the timetable for my discharge. Presuming I continue to
progress, I may be released either tomorrow afternoon/evening or Monday morning,
when I must get to two pre-op appointments for the surgery on the 9th. So fingers
crossed that I can return to State College on Monday, and enjoy a few days of normalcy
at work and with friends, and hopefully a pleasant birthday, before returning to
Baltimore next Sunday.
My brother had to return to NY but it was wonderful to have my mother and Ben here.
They went off to dinner (and tempted me with pictures of what they ate), but will be
back in the morning before Ben has to return to DC.
                       368 / 1.901
I am already impatient for my upcoming surgery to be over and done with so I can get on
with my life, although I know that I'm in for a longish recuperation. Ugh. But I'm already
setting some goals for myself. One will be to participate in a 5K/1 mile "Stride and
Thrive" run/walk to raise $$ for gynecological cancer research/awareness at Johns
Hopkins on 7 June. Ben and I were getting excited about putting a team together. Let us
know if you'd like to join us. A second will be to get to Paris at some point over the
summer. And the third will be to make it to a close friend's wedding in July. #goals.
A very sweet nurse, Kaitlynn, just came in to tell me that I've been 'advanced' to
*unlimited* clear liquids - woohoo! To celebrate, she is bringing me another mango ice,
of which I'll probably eat half, having promised not to 'chug' any of my liquids!

March 1, 2020 - Ready, set...
  by Willa Silverman, March 1, 2020  
                       370 / 1.901
                       371 / 1.901
Things have continued to trend in a very good direction today. I slept relatively well, ie in
three solid 'chunks' of 2-3 hours each, interrupted by technicians coming to my room to
take vitals. My obstruction has continued to resolve, allowing me to 'graduate' to a full
liquid diet at lunch (cream of tomato soup, chocolate ice cream) and a full low-fiber diet
for dinner (cheese omelet, mashed potatoes). My very dear son returned to spend a bit
more time with me this morning; we walked around the hospital, very quiet today. The
sky looked the color of early spring and I felt sad not to be out in it. But I see mild
temperatures predicted for this week.
And I am going home tomorrow! I will be discharged in the early morning after the
doctors round and examine me, then get ready to go to two pre-op appointments in
another part of the hospital, then have some lunch and head back to State College,
hopefully to arrive by the end of the afternoon. My mother will kindly stay with me until I
take off, before catching her train back to New York. A number of friends are very
generously retrieving my car at the hospital, bringing me some homemade beef broth
and a few groceries.
The night (or rather early morning, c. 3:30 a.m.) I arrived at Hopkins as well as last night,
I had the sweetest nurse, Kaitlynn. The nurses here are all wonderful and highly skilled.
Kaitlynn, all of twenty-four years old and who addressed me as "sweetie" and "hon" (this
last one a Baltimore thing, I think) left me the loveliest note on my white board this
morning (see pic). I hope she'll get to take care of me during my next stay here.
I hope my recent spate of written 'logorrhea' has not been off-putting, too 'TMI.'
Somehow, the words just keep tumbling out. This has had unexpectedly fortuitous
consequences for my academic writing: last week when I was working on a scholarly
article the writing came much more easily and fluidly than it normally does. The Caring
Bridge writing seems to me both a way of helping me articulate my emotions and at the
same time of keeping them in check, giving cogent shape to a flood of feeling that might
'come out' other ways if not channeled here. And as long as I keep writing, keep typing,
I'm not breaking down too much, although rereading does on occasion bring tears to my
eyes (a sign that I've been as authentic as I can, I suppose). Thanks very much to
anyone who cares to read, and please don't feel obligated to keep up!
I am overjoyed to be going home and look forward to a wonderful week.

March 2, 2020 - Home!
  by Willa Silverman, March 2, 2020  
                       373 / 1.901
                       374 / 1.901
I am overjoyed to be home. The day began early (the doctors rounded at 6:15), with a
few snafus, but fortunately nothing health-related nor serious. I spent about an hour
looking for my shoes, having convinced myself both that I had left them in the
emergency room in State College and that I'd have to return home shoeless, wearing
only hospital socks. A random last-minute look under the bed uncovered my shoes. More
aggravatingly, around 8:15 I was wheeled about 15 minutes across the hospital to my
pre-op appointments, only to discover that I couldn't have the appointments without
having first been discharged. So all the way back across the hospital, only to find out
that, in the end, a)the ostomy nurse who was supposed to 'mark' me is out of the office
this week (!) and b)the anesthesiologists, having reviewed my EKG and other results,
determined that they didn't need to see me. Ouf. I suppose this means that I might have
been discharged last night... So I went to the pharmacy to pick up all the stuff required
for the prep I need to do Sunday for Monday's operation, then stopped at the cafeteria to
pick up some lunch (which thankfully sat well with me), then back up to the room to get
my bag and hug the very friendly, upbeat and savvy nurse, Rachel, who had helped take
care of me during my stay. My mother was kind enough to stay with me until the very
end, when we parted ways at the hospital entrance -- she Ubering to the station to get
her train back to NY and me waiting for the car service that takes me back and forth
when I don't have my own car with me and/or can't drive. I was so happy to take in big
gulps of fresh air in what felt like very early spring weather while awaiting my ride.
Wanted to add here that I'm feeling so much better than when I went to the emergency
room early last week. My abdomen is much less bloated, I'm having much less
discomfort and nausea. The Hopkins team knew what to do - some of it involved
basically starving me for four days. :)
The driver, Mohindr (who is my buddy now) and who is quite solicitous (he's praying for
me) and responsible (transporting me in a comfy, roomy, clean SUV), had brought along
his wife, Kashmir, to keep him company. They look to be in their 50s (?) and are very
sweet. He operates out of the Virginia suburbs and apparently drives several politicians,
prominent clergy at the National Cathedral etc. Kashmir gave me some tips for making
Indian rice pudding (like using a slow cooker, and throwing in a cinnamon stick). I
convinced them to make a detour for me so we could stop at Alvaro's, the phenomenal
old-style Italian bakery in Harrisburg that is usually my pit stop when I travel between SC
and DC or Baltimore. I bought two pounds of yummy Italian cookies for the bday potluck
lunch we are having at work on Wednesday. Mohindr and Kashmir bought cookies too,
and Italian bread. They took a picture of me with my 'stash' (see pic), which also
included a small portion of tiramisu gelato for me (so good...). Then Mohindr insisted we
take some selfies, apparently happy that I had proposed making the trip into a bit of an
adventure. It's been a wild and crazy ride all along, let me tell 'ya.
                       375 / 1.901
I forgot to mention that, while en route back to State College, Dr. Beavis called me.
Mohindr was nice enough to pull over to reduce traffic noise, but it meant that we were
sort of precariously camped out on a narrow highway shoulder. Dr. Beavis was very
touched and grateful that, thanks to the generosity of my friends (meaning here: the
ones on Facebook), I was able to direct a significant amount of $$ towards ovarian
cancer research/awareness programs at Hopkins, in Dr. Beavis' honor, timed as a
fundraiser on the occasion of my upcoming birthday (btw: if anyone else is interested in
donating, you can do so here: https://secure.jhu.edu/form/obgyn.
You might donate in Dr. Beavis' honor to the Susan Burgert Survivorship Program, which
is on the drop down menu). In any event, Dr. Beavis had come to see me in my room
today, but I had already left. We talked a bit more about the upcoming surgery. To
prepare myself psychologically, I tried to get more of a sense of how 'big' it will be in
comparison to my debulking surgery last May. As I knew, this is major abdominal
surgery. If I do have to have an ostomy, temporarily or permanently, that will be a new
element to adjust to and thus a new part of my recovery. But she stressed again that I'm
in better health than last May. Of course, if they uncover new cancer a new plan will
need to be put in place. She thought my hospital stay might be 5-7 days, which would be
*way* more manageable than the three-week stay last time, due to complications
(abdominal infection) that were already starting to develop then and that have
necessitated surgery now. I told her how strongly (underscore that many times)
motivated I am to recover asap in order to get on with my life. 
I look forward to enjoying every minute of the next five days here and to trying not to
think too much about the next hurdle. Many thanks to my friends Maria for having some
groceries waiting on my return, to Monique, for bringing copious amounts of one of her
delicious, restorative broths and to Deb and Tony for retrieving my car at the hospital
(and the beautiful springlike flowers) -- and needless to say to my mother, Sharon,
brother Ethan and Ben for being by my side in the hospital. So so grateful for all the
texts, emails, FB messages of support, love and good cheer from friends and family old
and new. Thanks for travelling this road with me.
Big love to all.

excitement. I've always been a 'birthday girl.'
Over breakfast I opened a number of cards and gifts that had been accumulating the
past few days, all of which made me smile with happiness and gratitude. I also started
checking Facebook (where the first bday greetings were coming in from France, six
hours ahead), as well as my texts, emails etc. While I have an ambivalent relationship
with social media, I love how on birthdays all these means of communication help
produce a splendid chorus of good cheer.
I got dressed to the 1978 song by one-hit wonder Patrick Hernandez, "Born to be Alive,"
who anyone who lived through the disco era with me should remember. The pulsating,
slightly manic mood of that song somehow seemed right for the day. I blared the music
and sung the lyrics at the top of my lungs: "It's good to be alive...be alive...be alive. It's
good to be aliiiivvvve!"
Then I set off for J. Stephens Salon, where my long time hair stylist, Sarah, colored my
*very short* hair (I have not had hair this short since I was an infant), which Chelsey then
cut for me. I had been anticipating this visit as a kind of 'watershed moment,' when I
would ditch my wig and begin 'living my truth' (except for the illusion of my hair still
being dark brown!). While I was initially unsure how I felt about the look, which is
dramatically different for me, I believe I am growing into it, even embracing it, even
rocking it! The response from friends and family has been positive and affirming, with
comparisons to French theorist/intellectual Hélène Cixious, singer Anne Lennox, and the
composer Laurie Anderson. My look has been variously described as 'cool,' 'edgy,' 'chic'
and 'sophisticated.' I like that my earrings now become a prominent accessory, dangling
from my super-visible ears, and that a bit of extra makeup adds to the dramatic overall
effect. Needless to say, all of this will go down the drain if I have to have more chemo
but until that happens (if it does) I am enjoying my new 'do.'
Next I headed to school for a potluck bday lunch. As several of my colleagues and I have
taken to lunching together informally 2-3 times a week, we decided to do something
slightly more ambitious yesterday. About eight of us (including two of my former
colleagues, now retired, who nicely showed up) gathered to enjoy a salmon quiche,
sushi, a pissaladière (a classic dish of Provence featuring caramelized onions, anchovies
and olives), salad and more. I brought Italian cookies from Alvaro's in Harrisburg, a cake
and chocolates. Every time a new person walked into the seminar room (where we had
lunch), everyone recommenced singing "Happy Birthday" to me in English or French. It
felt like Groundhog Day -hilarious. I probably went slightly off the rails in terms of my
food consumption - I avoided items like nuts that I knew would not sit well given my
recent abdominal troubles, but it was hard to resist having seconds of some of the other
                       379 / 1.901
treats (the cookies were my downfall).
Then it was time to get ready for a departmental faculty meeting and to take care of
some other work tasks. 
After work I gathered about ten friends for drinks and snacks at Barrel 21, a local
distillery. My Hopkins doctors had authorized one cocktail (I have not been drinking
because of a very potent antibiotic prescribed to me, but I was able to stop taking it a
few days ago). I treated myself to a stiff Manhattan with the good Bourbon B21 distills,
and thoroughly enjoyed it. I also had a burger, hold the bacon. It was a very merry
gathering of friends in different departments/units (French, Spanish, Italian, English,
German, Music and the Penn State Press). The group reprised the by now absurd
repeated singings of "Happy Birthday." So much fun.
An avalanche of FB messages, texts, emails, cards, phone calls, gifts and donations to
Hopkins left me feeling overwhelmed by the end of the day, overwhelmed by kindness.
My mother's card features a series of bright drawings of the sun, accompanied by the
message "There's a light inside you and every year it just gets brighter" - thank you,
mom. :) In a humorous vein, my friend Shanny sent a card featuring a drawing of a
beautiful princess or noblewoman looking radiant and enraptured in a bright yellow gown
as she seems to 'glide' in front of a medieval castle while a lord and lady look on, with
the caption "The anti-depressants seem to be working." Yesss.... Everyone who reached
out to me showed such thoughtfulness in their words and deeds... I am one lucky girl.
My birthday was a real 'high.' In fact, I've felt a bit 'heightened' since I've been back from
the hospital, especially knowing what's on the horizon early next week. Hoping that an
equally forceful 'crash' does not ensue... But between now and Sunday, living well will be
my best revenge...
PS: I hope to personally thank many of you in writing, but it may take me just a little
while. 
Photos
