March 8, 2020 - Let's do this
  by Willa Silverman, March 8, 2020  
I left home around 8:30 on this beautiful, sunny, springlike morning and was in Baltimore
before noon; I drove myself this time. I was going to leave later but last night I realized --
guess I hadn't read the fine print-- that I had to start my bowel prep by noon, and for that
I needed to be well installed near a bathroom. So I had to make a supermarket run at
about 7:30 last night to pick up some jello, chicken bouillon, and Gatorade to ingest
today as part of my clear liquid diet. Ugh.
I slept pretty well last night, although with the 'spring forward' it was still dark when I
awoke at 7:00. The previous two or three nights, though, had been plagued by insomnia,
as I started to feel very anxious about tomorrow's surgery. An avalanche of 'what ifs'
swirled through my mind: what if Dr. Beavis finds more cancer? and what if that means
I've reached a more advanced stage (ie IV instead of III)? what if I experience
tremendous pain in my abdomen/diaphragm, as I did last time? what if I wake up with an
ostomy pouch? what if there are complications during surgery? what is my body has
trouble handling the rigors of this surgery? what if it takes me a really long time to
recuperate? Staying busy at work this past week kept some of these anxieties at bay,
but they reemerged at night.
The pre-op prep is going more smoothly than last May, when I was so sick and anxious I
couldn't keep anything down and we all (my mother, Ethan and Ben) had a frightful
night. This time, I'm in a nicer, more comfortable hotel (the hotel in May was in a sketchy
                       382 / 1.901
neighborhood, adding to the stress), Ben is in DC until tomorrow (I told him that there
was no reason for him to come today, as my mother and Ethan are here), and I rested a
bit each hour after taking whatever was prescribed for that time (Miralax mixture, or
antibiotics, or laxative pills, or additional fluids etc.). If you've done this before, you know
it is not at all pleasant, but at least I'm feeling comfortable and as relaxed as I can be. I
have to wake up at about 4:30 to get the hospital at 5:30 (surgery's at 7:30) but I might
chill out until 10 by watching my guilty pleasure, "90 Day Fiance." Gotta have my junk
t.v.
It was lovely to enjoy two final 'normal' outings this weekend before my surgery
tomorrow. My friend Helen and I gabbed for a few hours over dinner Friday night at Gigi's
- much fun. Yesterday, my friend Clare and I drove to Tait Farm where a demo about
creating cute little teacup 'gardens' for succulent plants was taking place. We did some
shopping there, said 'woof' to the adorable Basset hounds they breed there, then went to
have tea at the Pump Station Cafe in Boalsburg. If felt so good to sit outside, sunning our
faces and chatting. My fervent wish is to return to all of this asap. It's the little things...
But for now I'll be slipping into the arms of Morpheus and entrusting Drs. Fang and
Beavis with my body (and life...) as they work to heal me. If this surgery resolves the
host of abdominal issues that have been pestering me since last May, and if I can back
on track before long, it will have been worth it.
As always, thanks so much for recent texts and emails (I still haven't responded to all the
birthday messages I received!). I'm too worn out to respond to them now, but hopefully
I'll be able to from the hospital as I recuperate. I've given my brother 'co-authorship'
rights to my Caring Bridge. I expect he'll provide an update once I'm out of surgery.
Love and hugs,

March 09, 2020 - Post-op report
  by Ethan Silverman, March 9, 2020  
Great preliminary news from Johns Hopkins Hospital! In Dr Beavis’ own words - “Better
than I allowed myself to hope.” Willa has just been brought to recovery (not ICU), after
the dream team of Dr’s Beavis, Fang & Han spent the past 5-6 hours in the OR. The
fistula and abscesses/inflammation have been removed, scar tissue was loosened and
there was no visible cancer. And, while there was some additional removal of parts of the
small/large intestine and colon, in a resection, she’ll be heading back to SC without an
ostomy (sorry, no accoutrements). We’re grateful, a bit tired, relieved and appreciative
of all your love and support - much love from Ben Berkman, Sharon Silverman & Ethan
Silverman.

March 11, 2020 - WZS - Making great progress
  by Ethan Silverman, March 11, 2020  
Having just spent the past 4 days with my sister/Willa (as well as mother and Ben), down
in Baltimore, I ponder for a moment about the last 10 months. Reflecting quietly, as I sit
on the train back to NYC, the mood doesn’t feel as frantic and urgent as May 2019. The
reason - she’s making great progress towards fighting this disease and reclaiming her
fulfilling life. Willa has once again shown tremendous grit, as she recuperates from
another major abdominal surgery. While it was not the M.O.A.S. of ‘19, it was
nonetheless excruciatingly painful and taxing. She has begun to strive for and achieve
necessary benchmarks towards her recovery and discharge. Just this morning, we took a
walk down the corrider of Marburg 2, her third such stroll in 2 days. These walks, and the
all day prodding are exhausting. She thanks you all for the outpouring of notes, texts,
and hearts, and will surely be back in touch with you once she is at full strength. She is
being very well cared for, and we cannot thank the team at Johns Hopkins enough for
their unwavering love, support and expertise. 
Regards, Ethan

March 13, 2020 - The time is out of joint...
  by Willa Silverman, March 13, 2020  
                       391 / 1.901
                       392 / 1.901
Appreciative thanks again to my brother, Ethan, and son, Ben, for posting for me the
past few days as I didn't feel up to it. Today I seem to. I made a big step with my
recovery today. After two 'clamp tests' to assess how much 'stuff' was still coming out of
my stomach, it was determined that my NG tube could be removed! It had been running
through my nose into my stomach for five days, and was really starting to irritate my
throat, nose, stomach etc. As a result, I orally ingested my first food (30 ml of mango ice
at one-hour intervals) in the past *six* days. Another bit of good news is that the tape
covering my incision was removed as it continues to heal. It's the same incision that was
used in May (a zipper might have been easier at this point....). I still have quite a bit of
abdominal pain, although it's certainly less than after last May's surgery. That will take
time to heal. However, I am coping with minimal pain meds at this point, whereas I spent
the first few days in a dialudid haze. Aside from one or two student nurses who definitely
need more training (they will get it here), my care has continued to be superb, with Drs.
Fang and Beavis as well as other doctors (eg pain team) closely monitoring my
treatment.
I don't remember if my brother or Ben shared additional good news (my mind is still
slightly foggy). The surgery went better than Dr. Beavis expected, in part because a)no
ostomy was needed (I had been anxious about this) and b)no significant cancer was
found. Dr. Beavis saw a few 'specks' that she sent to pathology to be biopsied. But she's
not even sure they are cancerous. If they are, her plan is to put me on the parp inhibitors
I was debating taking a month of so ago instead of suggesting additional chemo. So
thank goodness no more chemo for the time being. In the end, the surgeons 'took down'
the whole area surrounding the fistula, including the fistula itself, abscess and an
additional portion of my colon and small intestine. But I will recover and will be able to
manage with this reconfigured digestive system. 
Of course, as I deal with my own physical disequilibrium, the entire world has lost its
equilibrium in ways that are terribly unsettling, scary, and troubling, rife with
uncertainty. The verse from Hamlet came quickly to me: "The time is out of joint..." A
friend described this moment as 'dystopian,' which also rings true. I am so very sorry for
our students who had to return from their study abroad experiences (or will not be
permitted to undertake them this summer), for our seniors who will not be feted at our
lovely end of the year awards ceremony (and perhaps not even at graduation; U of
Michigan just cancelled theirs), for my colleagues who will be doing the heavy lifting as
Penn State puts all its classes on line for the next several weeks. We're in uncharted
territory here...
It is always chilling, when I teach the medieval plague in my culture courses, to read
contemporary accounts of how the social fabric was rent by "social distancing:" once a
home was affected by the plague, children no longer visited dying parents, husbands
                       393 / 1.901
could no longer tend to sick wives, babies died alone... The plague was the great social
equalizer. Let's hope that friendship, love, relationships, conversations and all that
makes life a gift can continue - maybe even strengthen during this seemingly calamitous
time.
I truly wish I could do more to help. But in the near future I must be very careful to
protect my immune system and limit my contacts, certainly avoiding large groups.
Fortunately (I guess), since Ben is teleworking all next week, he can drive me back to
State College -- I'll likely be discharged Monday or Tuesday -- and stay at home for the
week, helping run errands for me, take me to a doctor's appointment etc. He's been
nothing but a kind, patient, compassionate and helpful mensch during these last two
successive hospital stays and I am so lucky to have such a son. It's still very hard for him
to watch me go through this, but by now we sort of 'know the drill' on some level, and we
know that we're getting through it together along with the rest of our very solid, loving
support system. We sat outside today in the sun on a balcony overlooking the historic,
original buildings of the Hopkins Medical Center, while he enjoyed a lunch of delicious-
smelling Jamaican jerk chicken (I got to smell it). We even had some great belly laughs
(which hurt my belly!). My mother and brother have also been loving and invaluable
caregivers. I am so grateful.
Finally, I received some welcome spiritual sustenance today, as my rabbi from State
College called me and assured me that I'm in his prayers daily. Yesterday my dear first
cousin David and wife Ilene visited (they live in Baltimore) and brought good cheer and
assurances that they were davening and sending mi shebeirachs my way. Finally, the
wonderful Methodist (yet ecumenical) chaplain here, Rhonda, came to chat and provided
a blessing of healing. I suggested that she send the blessing out not just to me and my
family and the caregivers at Hopkins but to the entire world, which needs it now. Tonight
is shabbat, a shabbat of the soul, maybe time for the entire world to detach, turn
inwards, enjoy loved ones' company, and send love out around the globe.
Photos

March 15, 2020 - Progress
  by Willa Silverman, March 15, 2020  
Just a quick update from Hopkins Hospital, which is in near total 'lockdown' now. There
are armed guards at the entrances and personnel in full-body protective gear are
screening visitors. I can only receive one visitor at a time. I've been told that they're
short staffed because any health worker who has even a slight cold or feels
'compromised' in any way is staying home. It certainly seems quiet here today, even
though the floor is full with patients. I have only the highest admiration for the health
workers I've encountered here (and all others), who are now on the front lines, patiently
taking blood and vital signs, administering meds and procedures. Based on my convos
with them, they understand fully the risks of the current situation -- to them and
everyone. I was told that a Hopkins doctor has been affected by the virus but don't have
confirmation.
I'm coming along well. Ate solid food for the first time since my operation today and it
sat well, although my newly reconfigured digestive system is quirky. I think I've met all
the benchmarks, but now the docs have to stabilize my electrolyte levels, which were
low today. I'm really hoping that this won't impede my being discharged early this week,
but it's for my surgeon to decide tomorrow.
One of the worst things about these hospital stays, and about needing treatment for a
disease, is the pain. I've been in agony a few times since arriving here, including when a
potassium/magnesium infusion began corroding one of my veins, sending shooting pain
through my arm and hand. My abdomen still hurts a lot, especially when I stand up
straight. This pain will abate in time. I've been walking about eight laps around the
hospital floor each day and look forward to continuing my walking when I'm home.
On some level, though, I feel like my problems "don't amount to a hill of beans, in this
crazy world" (a line that came to me forcefully today). I would like to be on the 'helping'
side and not on the one needing help. I have been thinking about some ways I can do
this and am nurturing an idea or two... At the same time, I am very fortunate to belong
to a caring community. My synagogue sent out a note saying that weekly Friday night
services would not be cancelled (a six feet separation between congregants will be
respected) and also reaching out to anyone in need at this time. No sooner had I written
to the congregant coordinating this effort than she wrote me back to assure me that she
                       397 / 1.901
would be happy to shop for me.  Another friend has offered the same, and my house
cleaner is keeping my home ultra-clean and disinfected. So I consider myself quite
fortunate, and will be able to focus on my continued recovery and start working at home
before long. 
I have no words to describe my revulsion at the way our 'leader' has been handling the
crisis. He is in fact the opposite of a leader. How a Lincoln, a Roosevelt, a Churchill, an
Obama would have provided solace, wisdom, sound policies, and hope at this time, and
how they would have led by example. So tragic for our country.
I ordered a 2000 piece puzzle of Cinque Terre for Ben and I to attack this week and I also
plan to introduce him to _Casablanca_ (hence the reference above!).
Stay safe and healthy, everyone, and let's stay connected. Sending big e-hugs and lots
of love, 
Willa

March 16, 2020 - Home!
                       399 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, March 16, 2020  
Just a quick note to let everyone know that I am home from the hospital. Feels so good.
Dr. Fang came to examine and speak with me this morning. She thinks I'm making good
progress and can continue my recovery at home. At the same time, she suggested that
the hospital is going to need more beds very soon... Tents are being set up outside to
accommodate the overflow. I really feel like I've fled a rapidly-advancing tsunami here --
a very strange feeling indeed. The Hopkins personnel all understand that, as Dr. Fang
said to me this morning, "as doctors [and health professionals], we're obligated to treat
everyone." Yet the atmosphere in the hospital seemed tense.
I returned with some meds -- pain medication, a blood thinner (that I have to inject into
myself, not my favorite activity...), and some fiber powder to take 3X day. 
Wonderful Ben was on hand to pick me up in my car and drive me home, on a fairly
sunny early springlike day, across this strange new landscape (supermarket parking lots
were full, restaurant parking lots empty). A kind friend, Esther, dropped off some
groceries to tide us over for the first day or so. And an acquaintance had left a bag of NY
bagels.
Ben will stay here this week and telework -- an enormous help and comfort to me.
Although I have significant surgical abdominal pain (no driving for a month...), I overall
feel *much* better than when I returned from my surgery in May, when I could barely get
up from a chair and felt exhausted and overwhelmed. While friends will kindly help with
groceries and perhaps some meals they'll prepare at home, I also feel well enough (and
actually look forward to) doing some simple cooking.
The most important thing is for everyone to stay well and safe right now. Thank you for
all your messages, hearts, emails and texts while I was at Hopkins. Feeling connected to
my friends and family is important to me, especially  now.

March 18, 2020 - Good news
  by Willa Silverman, March 18, 2020  
Just a quick posting to share some good news: at Dr. Patel's office yesterday (I was
nervous to even keep the appointment for fear of contagion, but he couldn't offer me
another one until August so...), he had just received from Hopkins the biopsy report for
my operation last Monday; Dr. Beavis had had three 'specks' biopsied at the time. Very
happily, those specks tested negative for cancer. So no IV chemo in the near future
although, as mentioned, we may -- or may not -- try PARP inhibitors (a type of
maintenance chemo) in the interest of delaying a recurrence.
Normally, this kind of good news would have me determined to grab life by the horns
and ride it hard, ie by travelling, gathering with friends, dining out etc. Normally after
                       401 / 1.901
such news, my doctors advise me to do exactly that. I would get on the phone right now
and buy a plane ticket to attend my friend Elisabeth's daughter's wedding in Burgundy in
May. Granted, I am still recuperating from surgery, but the "honeymoon period" I am
envisioning is simply not possible right now because of the coronavirus -- and of course I
understand that. So the universe is sending me contradictory messages at this time and
I need to think more on what it is trying to teach me. 
After seeing Dr. Patel, I had my port flushed in the chemo room. I feel fortunate not to be
undergoing chemo right now, which would leave my immune system suppressed. I really
feel for those tackling this (Dr. Fang told me that my immune system is actually quite
'ramped up' from surgery right now, although recent treatment for cancer does
constitute an'underlying condition'). Anyway, I asked the nurse how they've been faring
since the explosion of the virus and she replied: "Fine, I think the media exaggerates the
threat of the virus anyway." I very rarely feel myself becoming irate, but I could sense
my face becoming red and my pulse quickening. "And what evidence is this idea based
on?" I asked her. "It's just my opinion, Willa. I don't want to cause a rift." Before I
launched into: "What reason would the media have for exaggerating this public health
threat?" "Do you think all media are exaggerating the seriousness of the virus or just
some?" and "Do you think Johns Hopkins Medicine is exaggerating the threat by setting
up tents outside the hospital and cordoning off an entire wing?," I managed to restrain
myself. It just seemed to me incredibly irresponsible -- and the word 'unpatriotic' also
came to mind - for a *health worker* to take a page from the FoxNews playbook. I even
thought about reporting the nurse to the office manager. But I did not and will not. It just
made me mad. Very mad. End of rant.
Ben and I watched _Casablanca_ last night. What a brilliant film and how it rings true in
the current climate. Refugees flood Casablanca, fleeing a 'moral' plague and willing to
take all risks to preserve their safety. When Rick has to sell off his cafe because of the
volatile situation, he insists that his employees, especially the popular piano-player,
Sam, be kept on payroll to ensure their livelihood. Everything from mundane concerns to
great loves seem overtaken by the sweep of history and politics in "this crazy world."
We'll always have Paris...
I continue to recover and Ben and I are hunkering down; he's working and I'm doing
some work, writing etc. It's peaceful here and we're fine. Maybe we'll watch _Raging
Bull_ tonight.  We'll go on a walk soon. Everyone take care, please.

March 21, 2020 - "All changed, changed utterly"
  by Willa Silverman, March 21, 2020  
                       404 / 1.901
The relentlessly upbeat, unflappable, and wonderful Dr. Anna Beavis (see pic) called me
this morning (gotta appreciate a doctor who will call on a Saturday morning) to follow up
from last week's surgery. She didn't know whether I knew - but I did, from Dr. Patel --
that my biopsy had come back negative for cancer. She declared this news "amazing."
And I am rejoicing in it too! Because of this, there will be no cancer treatment of any kind
(including with PARP inhibitors) for the foreseeable future. In any event, she said she
would discourage my taking the inhibitors at present because they'd suppress my
immune system, making me more susceptible to, for example, coronavirus (the irony of
having survived cancer to die from coronavirus has not been lost on me). So unless I
become symptomatic, I will now have a three-month *reprieve* before seeing Dr. Patel
for blood screening (to assess my CA125 number and other levels), with an appointment
with Dr. Beavis scheduled for three months after that. While I realize that 'remission' is a
conditional state and while fully understanding the sobering statistics for recurrences
with ovarian cancer, I am embracing this welcome news, which couldn't come at a more
opportune time.
We also discussed my upcoming (3/31) follow-up appointment with Dr. Fang. I had
already started to become nervous at the prospect of returning to Hopkins, where Dr.
Beavis tells me that they are treating at least ten confirmed cases of coronavirus. Since
many patients apparently share my unease (>lots of cancellations), we discussed the
possibility of a video appointment, during which Dr. Fang and I would talk about my
progress and she would (virtually) examine my incision. Dr. Beavis just needs to find out
about the legality (!) of this -- apparently, it becomes a bit complicated across state
lines. Insurance coverage could be tricky too. We agreed that we're in uncharted
territory here...
Meanwhile, I am coming along. Dr. Beavis had said to me: "You may lose your spring, but
you'll have your summer and fall." I'm cautiously optimistic that I may be running ahead
                       405 / 1.901
of that timetable. However, I still have surgical pain, get a bit winded after a walk around
the block, and need a lot of sleep and rest (hopefully not a reflection of low red blood cell
or magnesium/potassium levels). It's going to take me a while to get my stamina back,
and all the injunctions on Facebook to Zumba, cook, live stream operas, virtually visit
museums etc. make me feel even more strung out. Right now, I just need to be. I did
have enough energy yesterday, though, to make Indian rice pudding.
Thankfully, Ben is here and is a comforting, helpful, steady presence. As I write, he is
working on a 2000-piece puzzle of Cinque Terre that I bought for us to help bide the
time. I gave up after a while because I'm color blind and was tearing my hair out with all
the gradations of color. Ben is also color blind, although not as dramatically as I am. His
powers of concentration and (Aries) stubbornness are helping him stick with it. We drove
downtown, which was virtually deserted, but people are out, here and there, biking,
jogging, strolling, walking their dogs.
Ben asked if the coronavirus was totally unprecedented in modern times. I told him that,
for me at least, while 9/11 shook our nation to its core, and while we more or less all
'sheltered in place' on that day, only three areas of the country bore the awful physical
toll. AIDS was an epidemic with a frightful human cost, and we lost loved ones. Yet the
scope of the coronavirus is much broader, cutting across a broad swath of ages, genders,
sexual orientations, races, socioeconomic groups etc. As a New Yorker, I feel keenly the
kind of 'New York-centric' hit of all three of these plagues, even as I realize that
coronavirus is devastating many other areas of our country too. What I am
mourning/have mourned in all three crises is a type of insouciance, excitement, vibrancy
and romance I associate with my hometown (and ditto for Paris). New York has risen
from the ashes before. Will it again? What will anything or any of us be like on the other
side?

March 26, 2020 - Two Cs
                       407 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, March 26, 2020  
I realize it's been a while since I've written. The days have seemed to blur into one
another recently, during this strange parenthesis in our normal lives.
My recovery continues to go well, thankfully. I can stand up straighter as the abdominal
surgical pain continues to abate incrementally. My incision has closed into a scar and
looks fine. My stomach remains a bit unsteady but Dr. Fang has just prescribed some
Imodium that I hope will help. I'm adhering strictly to a low-fiber diet, which agrees with
me. On April 9th Dr. Fang said I could start experimenting with some raw fruits and
veggies. I definitely feel fatigued and need to rest during the day, but Dr. Fang reminded
me that I had a major surgery and that 4-6 weeks of fatigue is perfectly normal. I'm
getting lots of extra sleep.
                       408 / 1.901
Dr. Fang called me today to let me know that we can't meet virtually next Tuesday
because I'm a 'Pennsylvanian.' Since she is licensed only in Maryland, apparently video-
meetings with out of state patients are illegal (I am not sure why this is the case, as in-
person meetings with out of state patients of course happen all the time at the hospital).
However, we again agreed that an in-person meeting at Hopkins is not desirable for me
at this time, as the hospital is treating coronavirus cases. So we pretty much had our
appointment by phone (somehow, this is allowed...). I will also send her an image of my
incision. And I'll follow up with any further questions by email. I'm obsessively focused on
staying out of the hospital for any reason.
I feel very fortunate that I am not actively in treatment for cancer right now. The fact in
itself is reason to be thankful, but (even the prospect of) confronting that 'double
whammy' of cancer and coronavirus makes me fearful. My immune system would be ill-
equipped to handle it. Given the harrowing stories I'm reading in the _New York Times_
about packed to the gills hospital emergency rooms in the city, would I lose out if/when it
came to triaging patients, due to my doubly compromised condition? On the brighter (!)
side, because of last May's operation and my recent treatment I 'know the drill' in terms
of having to hunker down at home. It's not that dramatic an adjustment, although I do
wonder about the psychic toll on all of us of so much isolation... When this is all over, I
will want to give everyone I know the *biggest* hug!
I am so glad Ben is here. He has taken over my office (while I work at the dining table,
next to a big window) and seems busy with work. He has an upcoming decision to make
about grad school for next year, but as with everything else coronavirus has thrown a
wrench into admissions timetables, campus visits etc. We've watched a few classic
movies - _Casablanca,_ _Raging Bull_ - and a good new documentary, _Crip Camp_
(about the early disability rights movement). We take daily walks. And the puzzle is
coming along, but I'm afraid I sort of gave up on it. A number of friends have been kind
enough to bring meals and grocery shop for me, and Ben has been very helpful around
the house. My support network has shrunk a bit since the virus hit, but I completely
understand people wanting to be as risk-averse as possible.
 
As the one-year anniversary of my diagnosis approaches, and as I didn't begin writing
this journal until I had returned from the hospital in June (I believe), I will probably try to
reconstruct the timeline of events, mainly last April, that led to my surgery on 9 May. I
am not quite sure why I feel compelled to do this, as it will undoubtedly force me to
relive a trauma. Perhaps I need some clarity. Or some closure. Or some perspective. Or
perhaps I have some morbid attachment to this 'series of unfortunate events.' I'm not
sure. But it feels important to do, somehow.
In the interest of a bit of levity, I include a photo of my brother and me at the 1964 (!)
Worlds Fair in Flushing Meadow, NY. (Thank you, Ethan, for the tremendous and
generous job you've done in preserving our family archives, including some stills from
                       409 / 1.901
our films). I have some vivid memories of that Fair, including the attraction at which "It's
a small world after all" was played (I think I was with my grandmother). I wish I knew
what I was staring at (or reading??) so intently in that photo (I was all of five years old,
my brother likely two), but our poses seem characteristic.

Willa, glad you're doing well. The issue about interstate telemedicine relates to the
physical location of the patient. If you as PA resident are seeing a physician in MD, that's
under Maryland's regulations; however, if you are physically in PA, then your Hopkins
physician is not licensed to deliver medical service to you in PA itself. We are facing this
complex 50 state matrix as we try to set up telemedicine capabilities here, and it's a
morass despite the simplistic statements of our President that the process has been
simplified. And what's at stake? The MD who violates the rules could lose their license.
Makes no sense in a world where anyone can get a Viagra prescription online, I know.
But that's what we're dealing with. Sorry for being so technical! Stay safe.
  —Steven Sherman, March 26, 2020

April 2, 2020 - April is the cruelest month...
  by Willa Silverman, April 2, 2020  
We continue to live in a state of suspended animation, the days blurring into one
another. Even my outfit rarely changes, although some days I'll put on some makeup.
The news is grim - there are hardly words to describe the situation. Close to 10.000.000
unemployment claims! And an ocean of woe, fear, and uncertainty. Closer to home,
we've lost a cousin to COVID-19 -- our cousin Ruth Goldman in Toronto -- as her husband,
my mother's first cousin Gene, is now also hospitalized and in dire condition. Others we
know have overcome milder cases. And if April's tolls are as severe as predicted, we'll
surely all soon know someone affected. 
Here in Happy Valley we are relatively safe, although our local hospital just reported
admitting its first case of a patient with the virus. I am continuing to recover well from
my surgery, although I still have surgical abdominal pain and my digestive system
definitely has a mind (or nervous system) of its own most of the time. I've been
monitoring my diet very carefully (on 9 April I can start adding some raw fruits and
veggies to the mix) and have been allowing myself to sleep as much as I need. I was
able to forego my appointment at Hopkins last week, opting instead for a phone meeting
with Dr. Fang, to whom I also sent photos of my incision. To these she replied:"Looks
beautiful! You are healing extremely well!" and "You have done fabulously after
surgery." Of course, this was heartening to hear. However, I know that the sword of
Damocles is always hanging over me in terms of a possible (likely?) recurrence. Today I
started to let my mind wander to the small fluid pocket in my lower lung that Dr. Beavis
has been monitoring, until I realized that I was about five minutes away from a freak out.
                       411 / 1.901
Luckily, I was able to rein myself in and return to living in the moment.
Meanwhile, Ben continues to work full days while I continue to work slightly shorter ones,
punctuated by Zoom meetings with colleagues. I am anxious about the effects of the
crisis on higher education, one of x number of institutions that will undoubtedly be
adversely affected. In good news, Ben will stay at least two more weeks! He is going to
DC tomorrow to bring back his girlfriend, Sammi, who will stay with Ben's dad (Michael)
and stepmother (Sue). We have put in place many precautions to safeguard my health
(and everyone else's). Decisions large and small seem so fraught these days... Kind
friends and neighbors have been bringing meals every other day while Ben and I cook
simple dishes on the intervening days (I hope to concoct something a bit more ambitious
for Ben's 25th birthday on Saturday). We are well fed and housed and have everything
we need. We take walks in the lovely early spring weather. I consider myself extremely
lucky.

April 2, 2020 - April is the cruelest month (bis)
  by Willa Silverman, April 2, 2020  
As best as I can remember, it was last April that I started feeling 'symptomatic.' Granted,
I had begun to feel slightly bloated as early as January (?), but rationalized it this way: a)I
sit on my ass in front of a computer all day and have become lazy about exercise; b)as a
result of a)I have gained weight. No wonder my stomach appears a bit distended when I
look at myself from the side in the mirror, but when I suck in my stomach the bulge goes
away - so voilà, it can't be cancer.
Besides, I was simply too busy to have cancer. As a first-year department head, I was
working ten hour days. (This, incidentally, became another rationalization: I work ten-
hour days, have a hearty appetite, and sleep well for the most part; ergo, I can't possibly
                       413 / 1.901
have cancer). I was also firmly intent on bringing to fruition my week-long Holocaust-
focused trip to Paris over spring break, with eighteen students in tow, which I had been
planning for a year. The trip is immensely meaningful to me personally, and the students
invariably consider it 'transformative' too. So I downplayed the bloating, and we went to
Paris. The trip was extraordinary.
In fact (and my mind is a bit fuzzy here), I opted to cancel a January appointment to have
a sonogram. I believe this was recommended follow-up after a routine ob-gyn checkup I
had had a month prior. My dim memory is that I did not like the doctor or physician's
assistant I had for the first time at that appointment. I had to convince her to provide a
PAP smear (she didn't think it was necessary) and I can't remember if it was her or me
that requested the follow-up sonogram -- the one that I didn't wind up having until
March.
But by early April, as mentioned, I began to have tell-tale symptoms, and they continued
to worsen (as I'll describe in a future post). The abdominal bloating continued. When I
lifted something heavy (like my school bag), I felt a tugging or pulling in my abdominal
area. I also began to feel progressively more tired (rationalization: it's been a heck of a
busy school year, and it's almost at its end. No wonder you're exhausted). I would come
home from work/grocery shopping by 7:30/8:00, sink down into my couch, inert, and
think to myself: "Shit, I feel *really* exhausted."
Writing the above is a bitter truth serum. There is obviously self-blame, even though Dr.
Beavis, in our first conversation, tried very strongly to dissuade me of that. If I knew then
what I know now, I like to think that I would not have been so cavalier about ignoring my
symptoms. And I would encourage *any woman* with symptoms like the ones I describe
to seek medical help immediately. So let this be a cautionary tale. But it is what it is. In
my defense (more rationalizations coming, or simply reasonable explanations?), ovarian
cancer, the so-called "silent killer," is notoriously asymptomatic, often not becoming fully
symptomatic until it's late stage (which was my case, as I was diagnosed at stage IIIC).
Until April, my symptoms were indeed mild and easily confusable with weight gain, extra
belly fat as a result of not exercising often enough etc. Several girlfriends reported
similar types of bloating in conjunction with their periods. Further, it is not certain at all
that a sonogram in January would have revealed cancer; in fact, once I had the
sonogram in March, it showed something suspicious on my left ovary but did not detect
the more serious problem area on my right ovary, because that area was located higher
up in my abdominal cavity than the sonogram could detect.
I could likely have done more. And that's an awful truth to accept. I also could have done
less, ignoring the symptoms even when they became alarming. But I did not. What's
most important for me right now, in the end, is to be completely and ceaselessly
proactive about my treatment going forward. And I believe I'm succeeding in that.

April 6, 2020 - The Kids are alright (I think)
  by Willa Silverman, April 6, 2020  
                       416 / 1.901
                       417 / 1.901
Spring has arrived, with its delicate sunlight and pretty pink and yellow flowers. I
remember sitting by an open window in the rocker with Ben, then an infant, in the weeks
following his birth on 4 April, and literally watching the buds fatten and bloom over the
course of those first few weeks. It seemed as if Ben and the earth were coming to life
simultaneously, and since then I've always felt that early April was a most poetic time for
a birthday. Then on the 19th of that month, I turned on the t.v. as I prepared to nurse
Ben, only to witness the horrific images of the Oklahoma City bombing, including of small
children, covered with debris and blood, being evacuated. Horror amidst the beauty - an
early lesson. And not the 'agreeable horror' of the sublime, but unmitigated horror linked
to evil and mass destruction. 
This year Ben's twenty-fifth birthday came amidst another wave of mass destruction, this
one wreaked by nature. And Ben certainly understood that in the face of so much
calamity, this bday would necessarily be different. So our celebration was a bit tamped
down, but I was still intent on observing this important milestone. I awoke early on
Saturday morning (Ben's bday) and made a yummy chocolate mousse from Patricia
Wells' Paris bistro cookbook.This actually tired me out a bit (all that beating of egg yolks
and whites, not to mention of the whipped cream!), as I still get fatigued during the day.
But I pressed on and in the afternoon cooked fesenjoon, a delicious Persian chicken stew
with pomegranate molasses and ground walnuts that I have enjoyed in a Persian
restaurant in Paris. Ben, meanwhile, had driven to D.C. Friday afternoon to pick up his
girlfriend, Sammi, who was not faring entirely well in isolation and who had been self-
quarantining for several weeks. Sammi will stay with Ben's dad and stepmom for the
foreseeable future while Ben stays here. I would have liked for all of us to be together on
Ben's bday but we are trying to minimize contact, especially in my case. So Ben and I
drove to Michael's the next day to deliver three portions of the chocolate mousse and to
chat a bit with Sammi, at a six foot distance. My bday present for Ben, ordered long ago
off Amazon, will not arrive for several more weeks.
These were all very minor adjustments, though, and we fully realize how privileged we
are, as well as comparatively safe in State College, where our local hospital is only
treating two COVID-19 patients and where our county has so far counted about forty
cases. This past weekend, within three days, we lost not only my cousin Ruth but her
husband, my mother's first cousin Gene, both victims of COVID in Toronto.
While mellower than usual, Ben's bday was lovely and to top it off we enjoyed watching a
few episodes of our newest guilty pleasure, Tiger King, a disturbing and fascinating
documentary with an appropriately eerie, 'end times' vibe.
Every parent wants to keep her/his kid/s safe. As long as Ben and Sammi are here in
State College, I feel (rightly or wrongly) that I can ensure their safety. But I know too that
                       418 / 1.901
their relatively privileged lifestyle is not shared by many millennials who, unlike Ben, are
crippled by student debt, have little savings, and now face uncertain job prospects at a
time when they should be launching their careers, relationships and other foundational
aspects of their lives. I feel so badly for them. What kind of world will these kids confront
once we return to 'normal?' Ben said to me one day recently: "There's nothing to look
forward to."
I am still feeling pretty well, thank goodness, but I can't say I'm fully recovered by any
means. I did walk a mile the other day! My overall stamina is increasing. And I am
boasting some nice curves due to weight loss (but yes, what a way to lose the pounds,
and also: I'm all curvy with no place to go...). I just pray that my remission will continue
and that I can avoid a return to chemo for as long as possible.
A virtual happy hour (dubbed "l'heure heureuse") with my grad school besties made me
happy this past Friday. Not the same as in person of course, but a warming hour and a
half nevertheless. So happy to see Isa and Rob, Vinni, Shanny and Sally safely ensconced
in their living rooms and kitchens, enjoying an apéritif (a virgin one for me...). Shanny
even got our her crystal, now a bit of a ritual when we gather, so we could ask it some
questions about what the future holds.
Stay well and safe, everyone.
Photos

April 9, 2020 - L'dor vador (From generation to generation)
  by Willa Silverman, April 9, 2020  
We managed to have a lovely Passover, Ben and I, despite all the constraints, perhaps
first among them limiting our Seder to a party of two, whereas large gatherings of family
and friends have most always been our norm. Intent on approximating at least some of
my own personal rituals around the Seder, I cooked several dishes -- matzah farfel
stuffing with sauteed mushrooms and onions; tzimmes of carrots, butternut squash,
sweet potatoes and prunes; chicken thighs in a honey mustard sauce (a pale cousin of
"Mrs. Schindler's chicken," a recipe my aunt shared with me years ago that has since
become a holiday favorite); and apple compote. My biggest culinary regret is that I didn't
have the 'fixins' to make chicken soup w/matzah balls this year, nor chopped liver, which
I sometimes prepare as well. The cooking, admittedly, made me tired (although I'm an
old hand at "cook 'til you drop," usually spreading my holiday cooking out over several
full days). I'm not back to full energy yet, and needed to take breaks to lie down on my
bed. I also enjoyed setting a pretty table with my 'nice' (ie wedding) china, Lenox seder
plate, candlesticks and kiddush cup, platter for matzah, and some colorful orchid plants.
As the friend kind enough to shop for me couldn't find a shank bone, I put a post-it on
the plate in its stead!
Ben and I read from two different haggadot as we retold (and in theory, 'relived') the
story of the exodus from Egypt, the passage from slavery to freedom. Along with the
traditional blessings during candle lighting, I read a "Prayer for Passover in the Era of
COVID-19," which I found quite meaningful (from the Reform Judaism
website: https://reformjudaism.org/blog/2020/04/06/prayer-passover-era-covid-19) Other
current resonances of the story struck me too: the Egyptians and "people of Israel"
"sheltering in place" as God assailed them with plagues (we counted not ten but eleven,
the last one being the one we're living through now); the trials of hunger and suffering
(we are enjoined to invite anyone who is hungry to come eat our Passover table, and I
wish I could have done just that); the value of perseverance and courage in finding one's
                       426 / 1.901
way out of a 'narrow place of bondage' (mitzrayim/Egypt); the promise of redemption
and an end to suffering, augured by the prophet Elijah. I told Ben that my cancer journey
has often felt like it was requiring 'biblical' quantities (and qualities) of courage and
strength. As every year, I'm left with questions about the story: was it really necessary
for God to slay the Egyptians' first-born sons? What kind of God seeks retribution in this
cruel way? Still, it was meaningful for us to discuss the story, which we followed with a
few not necessarily traditional songs (although we did sing a spirited "Dayenu"): Linda
Hirschorn's "Circle Chant," which I love ("Circle round for freedom/Circle round for
peace/For all of us imprisoned/Circle for release/Circle for the planet/Circle for each
soul/For the children of our children/Keep the circle whole")
(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6I-UiDzeexU)
and "Miriam's Song," which we used to sing with Ben when he was little, about Moses'
sister Miriam and the other Israelite women "dancing with their timbrels" after they had
crossed through the Red Sea.
After dinner we FaceTimed with Ben's Berkman family in Amherst, MA, and with my
brother and family in the city. Several of the men are now sporting pretty wild-looking
beards! Nice to feel connected to family but hope that next year we'll be able to gather
with loved ones.
I continue to feel pretty well overall, sort of status quo. I do have some occasionally achy
areas in my abdomen, one near the incision the other on my right side, near the site of
the actual surgery. I've written my surgeon several times to figure out how to distinguish
between abdominal surgical pain and pain due to something else, but have not heard
back. I know I shouldn't jump to conclusions, but I'm getting paranoid about cancer
patients being overlooked against the backdrop of coronavirus. A recent NPR story
reported on just this, but in my particular case I have no evidence to support this
suspicion. I will just need to be a bit more persistent. And for the most part my health
*does* appear to continuously improve. Fingers crossed.
There will always be another gloss on the Passover/Easter convergence for me, and not a
pleasant one. By Passover last year (it fell later in April than this year) I was not feeling
well at all. A few days before Passover, a sonogram had revealed what appeared to be a
growth on one of my ovaries (as I mentioned in another post, a growth on the *other*
ovary, undetected by the sonogram, turned out to be much more problematic). I was
scheduled to have a follow-up test after Easter to confirm these initial results. I felt
freaked out, and in my recollection (admittedly, much 'fuzz' surrounds this period for me)
did not share the information with many people at all, intent on waiting for the follow-up
test. But I did tell my friend Monique -- I remember tears, fear, trepidation. She managed
to calm me down and convinced me to not rush to the worst-case scenario until I had
more information. So the Hillel-sponsored Passover seder we attended on campus
shortly after that was a strange affair for me -- and likely Monique too. Surrounded by
students we didn't know for the most part, we felt a bit out of our element, even as I
                       427 / 1.901
gamely attempted to chat up a very sullen, largely silent grad student at our table while
the three undergrads across from us remained glued to their cell phones. But the event
wasn't unpleasant, and the food was tasty. Throughout dinner I felt preoccupied and
worried, though, by the recent sonogram results. Once home, I sank into my couch,
exhausted and stressed. Easter would soon bring another blow.
Sorry to end on this sad note in the midst of the holiday season. Wishing everyone the
blessings of good health, peace and a sense of renewal.   
  
April 14, 2020 - A revolution
  by Willa Silverman, April 14, 2020  
I'm gazing at the lovely pink-purple lilacs that my friend Sandy brought me the other
day, along with a Passover-themed dinner of roast chicken with tsimmes and a potato
kugel (all delicious). At this time of year, as if on cue, fragrant lilacs bloom along "Deans'
Walk," a path on campus that runs under the deans' offices in Sparks Building. They
were blooming a year ago at this time. Since then, the earth has completed its orbital
path, its revolution around the sun. 
The good news, as Ben reminded me the other day, is that I'm doing much better than I
was a year ago, although it's been quite an odyssey. Last year on Easter I had been
suffering from worrisome constipation for several days. Worrisome, because none of the
known remedies, including lots of dried fruit and water, walking, yoga stretches etc.
seemed to 'work'. Later I found out that what was causing the blockage were lesions in
my colon... I became so alarmed that I jumped in my car and drove to Med Express, only
to learn that there would be a wait as long as four hours (on Easter?...). Then, almost on
autopilot, I did something I'd never done before: I drove myself to the ER at our local
hospital. The very young, rookie-looking ER doctor on call that day examined me,
pressing against my stomach, and then sent me to have a CT-scan. I remember the
technician asking me, after I had the scan, "how long have you not been feeling well?"
and then looking pointedly at me and saying: "Good luck." The young doc came in a bit
later, hurriedly, flustered, showed me the CT image, and said something like: "The
radiologist has looked at your imaging and believes he sees a malignancy." (To be
honest, the only word I definitely remember hearing was 'malignancy'). The doctor then
showed me the image and indicated all the places -- body parts such as 'omentum,'
whose names I had never heard before, along with familiar organs such as the ovaries --
where a malignancy had been detected. Strangely, though, he hastened to tell me that
"this doesn't mean for sure that you have cancer," and he counseled me to make an
appointment asap with an ob-gyn oncological surgeon at Geisinger medical center in
Danville.
                       428 / 1.901
To be honest, the rest of the day was a blur. My friend Clare, whom I had planned to
meet for tea, came to my house and talked me down from hysteria, helping me focus on
the immediate tasks at hand, such as making plans to consult a gyn-onc in Danville. She
was kind enough to stay overnight with me (and to buy the medication I needed to
relieve the constipation); I'll always be grateful to her for this. I had heart-wrenching
conversations with my mother, brother, Michael and Ben, stressing though that I awaited
a definitive diagnosis from a specialist. The irony of receiving this awful blow on Easter --
a day of renewal, rebirth, redemption and the promise of life eternal that also turned out
to be one of the worst days of my life -- crossed my mind at some point. But my thoughts
became a tangled jumble, and by the time I went to bed I was exhausted.
Yes, happily doing better for now (although how could I ever have anticipated, that day
in the ER, the plague that would hit us all a year later, compounding my concern about
my health?). I'm looking forward to driving this week for the first time since early March,
and to working some raw fruits and veggies into my diet. Easter this year passed quietly.
The previous day Ben and I drove over the mountains and down into the next valley,
where in the largely Amish village of Belleville horses were plowing, farmers hoeing, and
plain black clothing fluttering in the wind on clothes lines. It smelled earthy, like spring!
We crossed over a creek where a horse and buggy had stopped so that the driver could
fly fish. It all felt rather idyllic and reminded me that the earth's revolutions bring beauty
and stability as the seasons change, a counterpoint to all the uncertainty currently
unsettling us. 
Ben is at Michael and Sue's this week but I expect that he (or he and Sammi) will return
here next week or the week after. We are so happy to have them here until they feel
comfortable returning to D.C.
I have been enjoying some 'fun' reading recently -- Julian Barnes' _The Man in the Red
Coat_ (the title alludes to a portrait by Sargent of Samuel Pozzi, a renowned surgeon and
society figure of the Belle Epoque) and now Ann Patchett's latest, _The Dutch House._
Stay well and safe, everyone! XO

April 29, 2020 - Back to Gray's Woods
  by Willa Silverman, April 29, 2020  
                       430 / 1.901
This is the longest break I've taken from my blog since I started writing last June.
Everything had been going along smoothly, without much 'news' to report, almost with a
certain insouciance on my part due to the sameness of days and routine, walks in the
neighborhood, long nighttime sleeps, nice dinners at home with Ben and Sammi,
watching the tube after dinner (the ESPN series on Michael Jordan and the Bulls is
awesome). All of this, of course, against a deeply worrisome backdrop apparent in the
NYTimes headlines that I probably shouldn't look at - but do - first thing when I wake up.
...until yesterday's bloodwork punctured the reassuring rhythm of the days and my
confidence that I could *will* a non-return to any kind of medical office. Admittedly, for
the past while (few weeks? since my last surgery?) my stomach/digestive system have
felt a bit 'unhappy' (as a friend aptly put it), without going into too much detail. Trying to
tweak my dose of Imodium hasn't seemed to help much and there's been some
discomfort on my right side, which I've attributed to surgical pain. At the same time, I felt
frustrated to not have received a response to four or five emails I sent Dr. Fang (who
performed the last surgery) about my feeling a bit 'off.' This led me instead to call my
(ex) bro-in-law, David, a gastroenterologist, who encouraged me to reach out to my
broader team of doctors, and to have bloodwork done -- which Dr. Patel promptly
ordered. 
Yesterday afternoon, I went to Dr. Patel's office -- rather empty and therefore a bit eerie
-- for the labs and a port flush. It was the first time I had been in a medical facility since
leaving Hopkins on 16 March and thus my first encounter with a 'masked' and often
gloved population. What a strange, depressing and anxiety-provoking - albeit necessary -
mode of social interaction. In any event, Dr. Patel called me shortly after I returned home
to tell me that two of my four markers for liver function were 'significantly' elevated. He
said that he wanted to wait until the CA125 number (ovarian cancer marker) came in the
following day to suggest next steps. That number came in this morning at 34.6. This is
about ten 'points' above what is was last time (25, I believe) but still, I think, at the upper
limit of what's considered 'normal' (35). So next step is an abdominal sonogram
tomorrow morning and a redo of the blood work next week.
Fortunately I had a therapy session today, which helped me temper the panic response
that the news about the liver function markers induced in me. H. reminded me that panic
serves a useful purpose, grabbing our attention and directing it to something that may
well need it to be directed to. And we agreed that, while I often tend to catastrophize
and run to worst-case scenarios (liver cancer following the removal of a small patch of
my liver last May? the necessity of returning to Hopkins, aka COVID-central, absent the
reassuring presence of family?), it's counterproductive for me to lean too heavily into
those thoughts in the absence of more complete information. Instead, I am leaning into
the fact that I have a stellar, rock-solid support network and also that I 'know the drill,' as
far as this illness goes. And -- as I repeated to myself out loud several times today -- in
my mind, I've already been through the worst, ie the initial cancer diagnosis and
                       431 / 1.901
debulking surgery. I can likely deal with whatever might be thrown at me next.
I'll keep everyone posted.
'The worst' began to transpire exactly a year ago, during the last week of classes, ie this
current week, the week the lilacs, as if on cue, spring into fragrant bloom along "Deans'
walk," a path that runs along the windows of the Liberal Arts deans' offices. On Tuesday
of this week, a year ago, my kind friend Gay drove me to Geisinger Medical Center in
Danville, where I met with a gyn onc surgeon, Dr. Gogoi, whom my doctors here in State
College had set me up with. As I didn't know what the options were at that point
regarding treatment, I thought she seemed competent. I remember certain sound bites,
such as: "If you've been advised to come here for an appointment, you must know it's
fairly serious" and "You need to feel comfortable with me, as this may be the beginning
of a long relationship" (I received a form letter a few months later announcing her
imminent departure from her practice). She performed a pelvic exam on me that was
horrifically painful because of the cancer. I was in tears nearly the whole time, and Gay
showed a lot of fortitude in remaining 'present' for me. We went to Friendly's after the
appointment and had ice cream cones. I felt drained. Such a difficult day. It also
happened to coincide with the second to last session of my course on France and the
Holocaust, which my intern, Morgane, kindly took over for me while I was at Danville. I
think that class knew vaguely that there was something 'wrong;' I could tell by their
worried or confused expressions when I returned for the last class on Thursday, rising to
the occasion as best I could.
Also that week -- but my timeline may be fuzzy -- in a panic but still managing to think
somewhat clear-sightedly, I contacted my college classmate (and former dorm mate),
Steven Sherman, who I knew was a prominent physician at the Anderson Cancer Center
in Houston. We likely hadn't spoken since college (although we are Facebook friends),
but Steve without hesitation offered to see if he could connect me with doctors at world-
class medical centers within striking distance from State College ("we'll get you
situated," he said). A flurry of emails, phone calls, and faxed test results later, Steve had
spoken with colleagues at Hopkins. A day or two later, I received a phone call from the
wonderful Dr. Anna Beavis (perhaps more on that thread another time). Steve will always
be one of my angels -- or perhaps rather a great doctor? a trusted friend and classmate?
a mensch? All of the above?
About the same time I reached out to Marty, the father of a childhood friend of Ben's,
whose wife had battled OC for a good eight years (he's also a PSU colleague in the
sciences). As with Steve, I intuited that these people might be my needed 'anchors' at a
time when I felt completely adrift, drowning in a loss of certainty about *anything.* Marty
came to my office, hugged me warmly, asked questions, and shared the early 'narrative'
of Wendy's cancer - her symptoms, their search for the best treatment, his assessment
of how family dynamics changed etc. I remember, again, being in a very 'ramped up,'
                       432 / 1.901
panicked state during that conversation (I was talking very quickly, kept breaking down
etc.). While I've been less frequently in touch w/Marty recently, I know that he's still part
of my 'village' and a trusted support.
Around the same too, finally - the days in a two-week or so period all meld together in
my memory -- I was in a monthly meeting with the heads of the other language/literature
departments. I kept getting calls from Geisinger, including one during which Dr. Gogoi
confirmed my ovarian cancer diagnosis, each time returning to my meeting after having
to leave the room to take the call. Embarrassed at having to run in and out of the room,
devastated, my mind racing, I sat through the rest of the meeting before getting out
through my tears to two of my colleagues who had lingered in the conference room: "I
have cancer." They were, of course, empathic, hugging me as did a third colleague
whose office I barged into to explain why I had had to keep disrupting the meeting.
Those nightmare days seem, in some ways, long ago, thankfully. This journey's made me
stronger for sure. I want to live to experience another blessed day - even (or maybe
especially) in the midst of a plague - to be able to look at my pretty orchid plants on my
dining room table, next to the 2000 piece puzzle that Ben and Sammi have almost
finished, to trade emails and texts with friends and family, and to enjoy a nice dinner at
home followed by a sound night's sleep. More than enough to be thankful for, I'm sure.

May 8, 2020 - Alive Day
  by Willa Silverman, May 9, 2020  
I've been busy the past few days preparing for, then participating in, a dissertation
defense, reading a second student's dissertation, and writing up questions for Ph.D.
comps, among other work tasks -- and that's a good thing. A year ago today I could do
none of that. In fact, today is what I'm calling my 'alive day,' not necessarily in the way
that veterans refer to it (as the day they survived being severely wounded in battle) but
to mean the day I survived "the mother of all surgeries" and was rid of 99% of the visible
cancer invading my body. It was the day I got a second chance.
If I have my chronology straight, on 6 May 2019 my brother Ethan rented a car and
drove from New York to pick me up in State College before we headed to Baltimore. I
                       436 / 1.901
knew that this was a huge 'ask' on my part as I rarely request favors of this magnitude
from my brother. But he immediately rearranged his schedule to help me. Your being
there when I needed it most has not been forgotten, Ethan. My brother had actually
never been to visit me at my present address, but we didn't linger long. We lunched on a
couple of salads I had picked up from Trader Joe's and were then Baltimore-bound. I was
wearing yoga pants and an old pink Penn State hoodie that I throw on when I want to
feel both comfortable and comforted (on long plane rides for example), as my abdomen
ached and I generally felt ill. During our drive on a pretty spring day, we caught up on
some family news, the chitchat also comforting despite the undercurrent of anxiety. 
Unfortunately, the hotel we had booked was in a somewhat sketchy neighborhood, which
added stress. As I recall, Ben joined us from D.C. and the three of us went to dinner at a
not great Turkish (?-Ethan will remember) restaurant. We kept up the small talk but
again I could tell we all felt tense over what was looming. I tried to take deep breaths
and stay as calm as possible. I had cried so much during the previous week that I simply
felt worn out and ready to get on with the surgery.
The following day I had my first meeting with Dr. Beavis (Ethan and Ben accompanied
me), with whom I had only spoken by phone once previously and who was to perform my
surgery the next day, as she was leaving shortly after that for a European cycling
vacation. Again, I consider it a tremendous stroke of luck that, in rapid succession and
just about a week earlier, I had contacted my college friend Steve Sherman who in turn
reached out to colleagues at Hopkins who then set me up with Dr. Beavis, who just
happened to have one opening for surgery the following week.The meeting with Dr.
Beavis is something of a blur because much of what she told me (regarding prognosis for
ovarian cancer patients, for example) felt scary and devastating, as also mirrored in the
tear-filled, bleary-eyed faces of my brother and Ben, so painful for me to witness. She
described in detail the 'debulking' surgery she would perform. This would entail a
meticulous removal of the visible cancer; a liver surgeon, Dr. Burns, would also be on
hand as some cancer has 'blown' off my ovary like dandelion fluff onto my liver. What
reassured me were Dr. Beavis' clear explanations and kind manner, already in evidence
when I had spoken with her on the phone and she had asked me about my support
system before anything else. I left her office feeling stunned. We headed to the
pharmacy to pick up a few medications that I would need for a bowel prep that night.
Back at the hotel, my mother had arrived (again if I'm remembering correctly). At some
point, my mother, brother and Ben must have eaten dinner as I had to fast. The
Gatorade and other liquids I needed to drink made me sick to my stomach and I
continued to vomit throughout a sleepless night, the lowest point of this 'prologue' to my
surgery. We were all upset and Ben and I were clinging to each other as I tried to
comfort him. My instinct is to draw a veil across that evening because it was so
traumatic.
                       437 / 1.901
I believe we arrived at the hospital several hours before my surgery, scheduled for early
afternoon. As I lay in a bay in the pre-op unit, the anesthesiologist came by to introduce
himself and I believe we saw Drs. Beavis and Burns as well. I remember climbing onto
the operating table by myself in a large, very brightly lit room buzzing with activity. The
next I remember is waking up in the ICU. The operation had taken thirteen hours so it
spanned May 8th and 9th; Dr. Beavis had emerged from surgery to talk to my family at
about 1:00 a.m. on the 9th and said that the operation had gone well. The four of them
had all left the hospital together as Dr. Beavis' fiance was picking her (and her bicycle)
up. Meanwhile, I was intubated and gagging; I gestured frantically at a blurry figure near
my bed to remove the tube but she said she couldn't yet. She encouraged me to relax
and showed me the pump I could press to release pain medicine at five minute intervals.
That helped. My glasses had been removed so I could barely make anything out, but if I
squinted I could read the wall clock: 6 a.m. As I became more alert, I also became more
conscious of the pain. But for the moment, disoriented and groggy, I was awake enough
to realize that I was alive - and that was plenty.
So on this one-year anniversary of my 'alive day,' I've been to the farmers market
(masked and gloved), have sent work emails, straightened my house a bit, and may
treat myself to some clothes shopping now that stores have reopened here. My digestive
system is still kinda 'wonky' from my second surgery (which, while 'only' six hours,
turned out to be the doozy), but I'm generally feeling pretty well. The troubling liver
enzyme markers detected in a blood test two weeks ago have come down but are still
above normal; I'll have my blood retested in a week in the hopes that they've come
down further. And I'll see Dr. Patel, my oncologist here, in June for a routine visit,
including bloodwork to assess my CA125 number.
I'm looking forward to a lovely Mother's Day tomorrow with Ben and Sammi. I spent the
last one in the hospital.
Yesterday Diane, a fellow OC survivor who has become a friend through our shared
experience, texted me for World Ovarian Cancer Day. "Happy Day, warrior!!!!!" Yes,
happy day indeed.

for you and for him!

May 9, 2020 - I am a Woman
  by Willa Silverman, May 9, 2020  
On rereading my previous post, I think I did a credible job in narrating the events of a
year ago, ie the period encompassing my cancer diagnosis and surgery. But conveying
my state of mind at the time is harder, partly because I've repressed some of the
memories. I'm sharing below something I wrote during that period when, up close and
personal with the reality of my own mortality, I somehow felt compelled to leave traces
of myself in a series of affirmations. I would sit down and write one or more in moods
ranging from frantic to sorrowful to nostalgic to serene. And then I would repeat them
like mantras.I actually feel peaceful and happy reading these now, although that was not
the mood that inspired them. 
"These fragments I have shored against my ruins." 
As a young woman of eighteen, I’d wrap myself in a sexy purple clingy dress and
smudge kohl across my eyelids while listening to Fleetwood Mac’s “You Make Loving
Fun” on my record player, before heading downtown to my older painter boyfriend’s loft
in Soho.
I am a woman who has a ‘scarf lady’ named Martine at the Aligre Market in Paris. One of
my favorite pleasures is to spend Sunday morning over coffee and a croissant at a
favorite café, reading the paper while watching the market come to life, shopping at the
market (including its flea market), and buying a new scarf, hat, or purse from Martine.
I am a woman who has a jeweler in Paris named Chantal, who makes unique, eye-
catching pieces from her vintage finds at the flea market.
I am a woman who loves going out for drinks and dinner in a city.
I am a woman who doesn’t mind spending an hour on the metro every Friday night in
Paris to go to shabbat services led by Rabbi Delphine Horvilleur.
I am a woman who likes nothing better than to spend a day in a library or archive, doing
research for one of my projects.
I am a woman who loves buying and using makeup.
                       440 / 1.901
I am a woman who likes to wear bright purple nail polish in the summer.
I a woman who loves to knock around antique stores.
I am a woman who loves to drink green Chartreuse.
I am a woman who doesn’t know how to ‘pack light’ and is often seen hauling multiple
overstuffed bags (at school) or suitcases (on trips).
I am a woman who, whenever she’s at a conference with a group of former graduate
students, will gather them for a fun reunion evening of drinks and dinner.
I am a woman who loves to cook multicourse holiday or other festive meals and set an
eye-catching table for them.
I am a woman with a deeply creative spirit, whether in pursuing my academic writing or
more ‘creative’ pieces, cooking, decorating my home, taking pictures, arranging flowers,
collecting Limoges dishware and other pretty porcelain, or artfully applying makeup or
putting on nice clothes, jewelry and other accessories.
I am a woman who loves the visual motifs of gingko leaves and dragonflies, which have
become personal emblems.
I am a woman with a shockingly messy home office.
I am a woman with many beloved friends and a large social circle spread out among
State College, New York, Paris and Boston.
I am a mother, a daughter, a sister, a cousin, an aunt, a niece.
I am a city walker.
I am a woman who has danced through the night at a club in Florence, wearing a
shimmery sleeveless rosegold jumpsuit.
I am a woman who loves life.  I am an adventuress.
I am a woman who loves her son, Ben, more than anyone in the world and who is
eternally grateful to him for teaching her how to love.

May 19, 2020 - Please join team #willapower on Sunday 7 June!
  by Willa Silverman, May 19, 2020  
Dear friends, On Sunday 7 June I will be participating, in State College, in the 2020 Stride and Thrive
run/walk, organized under the aegis of Johns Hopkins Medical Center, as an ovarian cancer survivor. All
proceeds will support gynecologic cancer research and clinical trials, training for gynecologic oncology
fellows, and gynecologic cancer survivors through the Susan L. Burgert, M.D. Gynecologic Oncology
Survivorship Program. Last year, the race raised more than $240,000 and had 900 participants! I would be
honored if you would consider joining my team, #willapower, which will entail your walking 1 mile or
running 5k on June 7th, wherever you are (as unfortunately we can't be in Baltimore this year due to
COVID-19). To register (the $40 registration fee will go directly to the fundraising total), go
to charmcityrun.com/hopkins. Should you wish to make a donation without participating in the walk/run,
please go to runsignup.com/willapower. Please contact me should you have questions. Thank you for
                       443 / 1.901
considering a contribution to this Important (and important to *me*) cause!
My personal note (from my fundraising page):
In April 2019, after experiencing a period of mild abdominal bloating (OC is notoriously
asymptomatic), I was diagnosed with stage IIIC ovarian cancer (because it is notoriously
asymptomatic OC is usually diagnosed at stage III or IV). Last May I underwent a thirteen
hour 'debulking' sugery at Johns Hopkins Medical Center, during which 99% of the
*visible* cancer was removed from my body, followed by six rounds of chemotherapy. In
March of this year I underwent major abdominal surgery, also at Hopkins, to take down a
fistula and to remove parts of my colon and small intestine. I have been in remission
since November and am generally feeling well. I have been back at work since January. 
Over the past year, I have received extraordinary treatment at Johns Hopkins, from a
medical team directed by my surgeon, Dr. Ann Beavis, a gynecological oncologist. As
you may know, Hopkins is at the cutting edge of cancer research and treatment, but
much more work remains to be done to combat these awful 'below the belt' cancers.. I
would be honored and grateful if you would join me on Sunday 7 June, either in running
(5 k) or walking (1 mile) as part of team #willapower or in making a donation at
runsignup.com/willapower. Thank you!

May 22, 2020 - Blips
  by Willa Silverman, May 22, 2020  
                       446 / 1.901
                       447 / 1.901
I'm currently having a few health concerns (*just edited this as I had written "having few
health concerns" - wishful thinking?), which I indeed hope will turn out to be no more
than 'blips.' A third blood workup, this past Monday, following the revelation of extremely
high liver enzyme counts a few weeks ago, has shown these markers to be stable from
the last blood test, ie still elevated, less so than the time before -- but stable. So I'll have
more blood taken in two more weeks. Meanwhile, as I last reported I believe (?), a
sonogram of my liver revealed no apparent abnormalities, thankfully. Still, my mind of
course races towards the worst case scenario (cancer in my liver?) while wondering
about the persistent ache along my lower right rib cage, in the vicinity, I believe, of my
liver (gosh, I wish I knew my anatomy better, but as usual since my cancer diagnosis, I'm
caught up in an approach/avoidance pattern), At the same time, some persistent
discomfort on my right side -- reminiscent of the discomfort I felt with my fistula (ugh) --
led me to question whether this is still surgical discomfort ("your body's been through a
lot," said Dr. Beavis) or something new and unwelcome. And then I read on some
random website that -- TMI alert ahead -- excessive gas (guilty as charged) can be a
symptom of ovarian cancer. And *then* I read (or was reminded of? who knows what
other frightful facts I've blocked out at this point), in an online post by someone
undergoing OC treatment, that 'high grade serous' OC is both the most common type yet
also the one with the lowest survival rate. In any event, all of this led me to recontact Dr.
Fang, my colorectal surgeon, who had not responded to my previous 3-4 emails, leading
me to retreat in frustration for a while. This time she responded immediately, saying that
a CT-scan was advisable. So back I go for a CT-scan of my abdominal and pelvic areas
next Wednesday, in State College. Fingers crossed for a good result. In the meantime, I
am trying not to "borrow worries," as my aunt Marlene aptly put it.
It's amazing how my internal switch can instantly turn me from a (self-perceived)
'healthy Willa' into 'sick Willa' -- almost Jekyll and Hyde personas. These kinds of 'blips'
automatically discombobulate me, switching off my good mood and generally well- (or at
least ok-)feeling state and sending me tumbling into bleakness, depression and worst-
case scenario land. So I've been bumping around a bit between the two extremes the
past few days. Ugh.
Today I was able to pull myself up a good bit, however (or maybe it's just the Lexapro).
This morning, I reviewed and then discussed with my wonderful interim department head
(and friend), Bénédicte, all manner of Excel spread sheets and summaries for our budget
meeting with the Dean and college CFO next week. Delving into the details and thinking
ahead to the next academic year (and to its possibilities and challenges) actually helped
me forget about the discomfort in my side. After lunch, Sammi and I set off on an
'adventure' (or at least what passes for one in these parts), heading about 45 mn out of
State College on very pretty country roads (large working farms shrouded in mist today)
towards Mill Hall (or rather the hamlet of Salona) to a newish Amish market housed in an
                       448 / 1.901
old schoolhouse and featuring produce and meat, baked goods, plants, crafts and a flea
market. I bought free range eggs, fresh local asparagus, fresh spinach, dill pickles, and a
pretty planter for the front porch -- all reasonably priced. Unfortunately, a)not everyone
was wearing a mask, which made me nervous and b) the market was 'festooned' with
large Trump signs -- all seemingly part and parcel in this rural neck of the woods...
Nevertheless, I am delighted that 'farmers market season' is upon us and think I have by
now made most of the dishes one can make with rhubarb -- cobbler, crisp, compote,
vinaigrette (I guess this weekend, after stocking up at our local Saturday farmers market
tomorrow, I can produce a pie, cake, chutney or syrup).
So if "it's not time yet" (a mantra many of my friends and I have been repeating to one
another) for travel and other activities, at least we can enjoy the local benefits -- an
explosion of produce, great hiking trails, peaceful gurgling streams etc. On Mothers Day
Ben and Sammi cooked me brunch, then we drove out to one of my favorite creeks, past
more farms. Sure beats last Mothers Day, which I spent in the hospital. It was very
comforting to have my own mother with me that day, but Ben was at a meeting (in
Florida, I think). On his return (I was still in the hospital, spent three weeks there, in fact),
he gifted me the photo (below) of him running in a half-marathon in Pittsburgh. Beyond
the fact that he looks like such a buff, toned, strong, handsome guy (which he is), the
picture has always spoken to me of perseverance, grit, determination, focus, and
'moving through:' 'the only way out is through,' something I have often told myself
during my own 'marathon.' I love this photo.
Finally, speaking of running, I am very excited about having formed a team to run/walk
in the "Stride and Thrive" 5k run/1 mile walk on 7 June, a fundraiser for ovarian cancer
research, treatment and survivor support organized by Hopkins. Usually the event is held
in Baltimore, but as it can't be this year, it is a virtual event. Friends will be running
walking here, in Michigan and in Boston and other friends have generously made
donations to this great cause (it's not too late to do that and/or to join team
#willapower); I've ordered #willapower shirts for the runners/walkers.
And this is reminding me that I had set three goals for this summer: to get back to Paris
(it doesn't look like that's going to happen); to attend the wedding of my friends Maria
and Greg in the White Mountains of NH (now postponed until next July due to COVID-19)
and to participate in "Stride and Thrive" in Baltimore (now a virtual event). So I'll be
walking (I hope...), but in State College. The best laid plans...

surround you, the farmers markets and your joy of food, your work, your intense are
marvelous survivor skills. You wear them all so beautifully. May you continue to be in the
joy as much as humanly possible. You do have some super powers, you know! You
remain firmly in my heart.
  —Jane Ginsberg, May 23, 2020
