May 29, 2020 - Blips???
  by Willa Silverman, May 29, 2020  
I had hoped to title this entry "Sometimes a blip is just a blip." But no can do. Dr. Beavis
called me yesterday afternoon w/results of the CT-scan I had the other day (reviewed by
a Hopkins radiologist familiar w/my health history). She told me that it looks like I have a
partial obstruction in my small intestines, which could be causing or compounding some
of the discomfort I've been feeling in my abdominal area. So -- as when I had a bowel
obstruction a while back that landed me in the hospital -- I'm on a liquid diet for a few
days to see if that helps (currently drinking a mango protein drink). She was relieved to
know that I have not been vomiting (I haven't, at all), which would warrant a trip to the
ER.
More concerning are a few 'hazy' areas on the scan that *may* indicate a recurrence.
They appear to be on my right side and in the rectal area. It is also possible that this is
scar tissue or inflammation. So I have to have a PET scan, which produces better imaging
and 'lights up' areas that are cancerous. When I asked her whether she had a hunch
about which way this was going to go, she said she really did not, because my CA125
number (ovarian cancer marker), following my last blood test, was sort of borderline
(upper limits of normal). So I need to have that marker tested again too.
Dr. Fang (colorectal surgeon who operated on me in March) also called me this morning
to follow up. She again apologized for not responding to several emails I had sent (which
in my mind may [or may not] have delayed the process that's in motion now); she's been
operating every day, the hospital is very chaotic w/the advent of the coronavirus etc. I
am still annoyed that precious time may have been lost, but there's nothing to do about
it at this point. She said that from the perspective of the last operation everything looks
good: the hookup is 'pristine' (her word), no fistula etc. She did concur that my small
intestines look swollen. She said that Dr. Beavis was 'worried' that I may have a
recurrence but said "We don't have all the information yet, so let's wait until you have
the PET scan." When I asked her about Dr. Beavis having told me that they saw no
cancer when they operated on me in March, Dr. Fang reminded me that they would not
have been able to see any cancer that was of microscopic size. She (Dr. Fang) also put
my mind to rest about some other 'oddities' of my digestive system that I've been
concerned about.
When Dr. Beavis brought up the possibility of a recurrence, I was naturally gripped with
mortal dread, translated into all the physiological symptoms you might see in a horror
movie (rapid heart beat, gulping etc.). I felt (and continue to feel, when I think about it)
                       456 / 1.901
that I'm dangling over some sort of black hole. But I was able to calm down some, thanks
in part to Ben and Sammi's help, and that of my friend Diane, an OC survivor who has
also had scar tissue mistaken for something potentially worse on scans. I won't use this
page to indulge my worst case scenario fantasies, but will simply get on with my day,
which includes two Zoom meetings this morning and then car shopping w/Ben (for me!
We thought about putting this off given the recent update, but decided that we'd at least
go look and perhaps select what I'd like to buy eventually). It's a beautiful day here.
Shabbat shalom.
Thanks, everyone, for your support. Each of your 'hearts' (both the icons and the real
ones) and your messages is a gift to me. Big love,

June 2, 2020 - Prayers up, please
  by Willa Silverman, June 2, 2020  
                       459 / 1.901
                       460 / 1.901
Thanks in advance to anyone wishing to send some good thoughts and/or prayers my
way tomorrow morning, when I have a PET scan to take a closer look at two 'hazy' spots
from my CT-scan that Dr. Beavis and a Hopkins radiologist are concerned may be
cancerous. I had blood taken today that will reveal my CA125 number. I received
notification nearly immediately that the results of that test are in, and I can likely consult
them via the Geisinger portal, but I'm too anxious to do so. I will wait for Dr. Beavis or Dr.
Patel to share them with me once the PET scan results are also in.
Meanwhile, though, my crampy stomach ache (resulting from a partially blocked small
intestine, also noted on my CT scan) is much better, as I've been on a mainly liquid diet
since Friday. I still do have that niggling discomfort on my right side, one of the spots
that Dr. Beavis is concerned about. It's not at all bad, but it's there.
My worst moments emotionally over the weekend took me to strange, often unexpected
places. For the first time, I was feeling frustrated and angry about the whole situation (I
think I had forgotten to take my Lexapro that morning, which I now consider essential). I
have much too much that I want to accomplish for all this to be happening! It's not fair!
There were some weird almost out of body moments when I simply stood still and took
stock visually of the myriad 'things' surrounding me that make me 'me:' my orchid
plants, souvenir Eiffel towers on my kitchen table, pretty jewelry that I love wearing etc.
etc.
Not all the places I journeyed to were sad. I had a very  nice dream about Nightingale-
Bamford, the all-girls school I attended from grade 2 through grade 12: a formative
experience, including the friendships forged with my thirty-odd classmates with whom I
literally grew up. In the dream, it was the day of the annual NBS fair. I traveled uptown
on the bus (as the adult I am now, but it was the route I took as a girl) to 92nd street and
Madison. When I got off the bus, I saw little NBS girls in their blue uniforms ('pinnies' or
pleated skirts, like the ones I wore) lining up around the block to enter the school
building to attend the fair. I also saw, across a broad square that was as large as some
Parisian squares, not like your typical NY crosswalk, my classmates Lisa and Zia waving
excitedly at me, yelling something like "This is the place!" or "This is where it all
happened," or "It's all here." My classmate Eva (something about her both marrying and
having her ears pierced later in life) also appeared in the dream, as did our dear
classmate Debbie, my friend since we were six years old, who passed away about three
years ago from metastatic breast cancer.
In my dream last night, I saw at least one very pretty hamsa (the protective 'hand' that is
supposed to ward off the evil eye; I have worn them often as pendants during the past
year). This one was very much my style (or one of my styles): Victorian/'chintzy'/floral
looking with a pretty Victorian looking heart and flowers worked into it. It looked like it
                       461 / 1.901
could have been made by Michal Negrin, a popular Israeli costume jeweler I like who
often works Victorian motifs into her pieces.
Despite my anxiety, I had a pleasant enough weekend and generally feel well. As people
are venturing out more these days, cautiously, I caught up with both my friend Maria and
my friend Gay during strolls in Penn State's arboretum, resplendent right now in purple
and pink and blue (see pic). Also went to the farmers market (per usual on Saturday
morning), TJ Maxx (outdoor plant stands) and drove out to an Amish greenhouse in Brush
Valley.
I don't know if I mentioned my recent shopping 'rampage.' Unfortunately as I can easily
see it becoming a bad habit, I've discovered online shopping during the pandemic. I
bought several 'big ticket items' -- a bigger t.v. and a t.v. stand, a new office chair and --
wait for it -- a new car (a 2020 Toyota Corolla SXE in snazzy "crush metallic blue" to
replace my now sixteen year old Corolla). And then there was a cast iron skillet (I've
already made cornbread), a whole mess of makeup from Clinique, Guerlain Mandarine
Basilic perfume (divine), address labels (needed) and personalized note cards. It was lots
of fun, but also felt like I was trying to construct some sort of 'bulwark' against whatever
might be coming down the road. "I shop, therefore I am?" to paraphrase Descartes?
My own personal dramas, the sense of the "time being out of joint," are of course
unfolding against a terrifying fresco of fear and desperation caused by the pandemic,
righteous indignation and rage sparked by the (most) recent, blatant examples of
injustice and brutality in Minneapolis, and a total leadership vacuum (scarily combined
with an abundance of power). While my own fears sometimes run to keeping myself safe
(cancer + coronavirus = a bad combo), I also worry about how to keep the kids safe (Ben
and Sammi plan to move to NY this summer, w/Ben starting a grad program in data
science at NYU), how to keep my students safe, how to keep the next generations safe.
The scenes of looting in my hometown, a few blocks from my mother's apartment, are
particularly painful to watch. What's happening to our beloved country is awful to
witness.
In the meantime, I'm here. And I'm excited about Sunday's upcoming Stride and Thrive
event to benefit Hopkins' Kelly Gynecological Oncology Service. My team, #willapower,
has 14 runners/walkers, and I've raised more $ than I thought for this cause that is a
matter of life and death for so many women. The weather looks promising, we'll take
group photos in the t-shirts I had made, and I look forward to a joyous and meaningful
day. Please consider making a contribution in the next few days if you're able. You'll find
complete info in one of my recent blog posts. Thanks. 
Photos
                       462 / 1.901
                       463 / 1.901

June 4, 2020 - Better news/less good news
  by Willa Silverman, June 4, 2020  
Yesterday's PET scan turned out to be time consuming. I spent three hours at Gray's
Woods: they were running an hour late, then I had to wait an hour after consuming a
liquid that makes problem areas 'light up' in the imaging, the actual imaging took awhile,
and then I had to wait again for them to burn a disc for me so I could send it to Dr.
Beavis. The scene was somewhat chaotic: as the medical center is undergoing
construction, I was led out back to a *trailer* for the imaging, but the staff was quite
nice. By the time I was done, I was running late for my 3 p.m. appointment at the car
dealership, where I spent about an hour with the finance person going over a dizzying
mountain of information concerning my new car's operation, financing, warranties etc.
As I had barely eaten all day (I fasted for the procedure plus was still on a semi-liquid
diet to relieve my intestinal blockage) I was pretty much running on fumes by the point
(and was also radioactive lol). But I did speed off from the dealership in my very snazzy,
sporty, sexy METALLIC BLUE CRUSH Toyota SXE!
I spoke to Dr. Beavis for about 45 mn today. I'm detailing what she told me partly to
                       468 / 1.901
cement the myriad details in my own mind (she actually asked me to repeat back to her
the gist of what she had told me to make sure I understood what she was saying,
including the main takeaways). If this is tmi for you please feel free to skip ahead: She
said that she was "suspicious but not confirmatory" of a recurrence, based on the PET
scan images, which a Hopkins radiologist also read, plus the other evidence from the
blood work, especially the doubling of the CA125 marker. The areas that lit up on the PET
scan were around my colon and on my right side, somewhere near both a muscle (don't
remember the name of it) and my liver. But if there is cancer near my liver, it appears to
be on it and not *in* it, which is good. My entire colon lit up, which is unusual, but Dr.
Beavis thinks that several things may be going on there, not all of them possible cancer
growth (eg inflammation, scar tissue, potential infection etc.). Whatever is going on has
been caught early, also good. So, because nothing with this disease is straightforward, I
need now to have two more tests to explore further: an MRI and a stool sample to test
for C-diff (a bacterium causing chronic diarrhea, which I have, and colitis). If the MRI, in
turn, does not prove conclusive, I'll have another CT-scan six weeks after that. 
If there's been a recurrence, which I'm now expecting there has been, it will mean more
chemo, either as part of a clinical trial at Hopkins (if I'm eligible), with details re logistics
etc. to be worked out, or here. The drug regimen will be different from the last time, and
apparently I won't lose my hair (ok, I guess I can go get my hair colored now). I really
don't know more about that regimen yet (ie length, side effects etc.) as I'll await the next
round of test results and "confirmatory" news.
I told Dr. Beavis that it seemed to me the cancer had recurred relatively soon: I've been
NED since last November, ie 6 months. Apparently, a recurrence after six months is
exactly the tipping point between being "chemo sensitive" and "chemo resistant." About
50% of women fall on each side.
I also asked her if she thought I could fight this and she said absolutely. If/when I get to
the point where she feels chemo will no longer be effective or recommended, she'll let
me know; but as far as I can tell we're nowhere -- repeat, nowhere -- near there now. She
reminded me (as I reminded myself) that in the best case scenario ovarian cancer is a
chronic disease (and I can live with that, no pun intended). I have the most common
type, high grade serous, but it's an aggressive type and a small part of my particular
cancer is particularly aggressive (carcinoma sarcoma). So, for now, more periods of
treatment alternating with more 'honeymoon periods' are likely in store.
I asked her about staging, ie would I be 'demoted' to a stage IV if the cancer has spread
outside my pelvic cavity. Dr. Beavis told me that with ovarian cancer you never 'budge'
from the stage at which you are diagnosed, in my case IIIC (quite common); you simply
have recurrences.
I felt SO much better after speaking with Dr. Beavis. Not only is she patient, plain-
                       469 / 1.901
speaking, brilliantly skilled, and empathic (while remaining consummately professional).
But by virtue of her devising a solid, logical plan along with Dr. Patel, my State College
oncologist, she has also given me *much more hope* along with utter confidence that
she is 'on it.' Hence, I've been snatched from the morbid place I found myself yesterday
while my body absorbed the contrast liquid I had to drink before the PET scan: I closed
my eyes for an hour and planned the details of my funeral (so at least I can check that
off my 'to do' list - a bit of gallows humor there :)) as well as last missives and adieux to
friends and family. Today I'm back to working, trying out all my new Clinique makeup,
fixing a batch of rhubarb compote, planning to buy a new couch etc. Physically, I really
don't feel badly at all. And mentally/emotionally, I'm back on track. So please get on that
track with me, and not on the pitying/fearful track. Cancer can be scary, especially when
observed from the outside I imagine, but once you're 'in it' it simply becomes woven into
your the warp and woof of your life.
At the same time, I don't deny that, objectively, this whole cancer situation sucks big
time. And that I'd rather be in Paris.
Speaking of tracks, I'll be walking the track at the Military Museum in Boalsburg this
Sunday with at least part of team #willapower (now fourteen strong and growing). I'm so
delighted to have thus far raised over 5K to help women like myself (and the
phenomenal doctors and staff and Johns Hopkins) and so humbled by the generosity of
family, friends from grade school, college, grad school, colleagues, former graduate and
undergraduate students (child cancer survivors among them), fellow 'teal sisters' (other
OC survivors), State College friends and others who have so generously contributed. It's
not too late to join/donate (see details in a previous post).

June 8, 2020 - Stridin' and Thrivin'
  by Willa Silverman, June 8, 2020  
Here's the medical update: I'm having an MRI on Friday and will have a stool sample
collected by mid-week to help Drs. Beavis and Patel confirm or not the diagnosis of a
recurrence of my ovarian cancer. Tomorrow I have an appointment with Dr. Patel (and
port clean), which just happens to be my regularly scheduled, every three month
'surveillance' appointment. I have a list of questions for him, including: What is
preventing him and Dr. Beavis from confirming their suspicion of a recurrence at
present? What are they on the lookout for? If more chemo is in store, what are the
potential side effects of the drugs I'll be receiving?
And the thing of it all is that I feel fine. I have some lingering discomfort on my right side
and my bowels continue to be 'messed up,' which may signal the presence of some
bacteria (this will be tested). But otherwise, I feel well, physically and mentally (I
continue to worship at the altar of Lexapro). I've been dressing cute, brightening my face
                       472 / 1.901
with the Clinique gelee, chubby stick for cheeks and Sangria lip gloss, and have my first
mani-pedi in ages booked for next week. Unfortunately, though, cancer couldn't give a
hoot about such efforts. :( And oh my goodness chemo is debilitating. I am apprehensive
as hell about being 'felled' once again by the chemo drugs, although I did bounce back.
Why was yesterday's Stride and Thrive event one of the best days I've had in a long
time, maybe (is this too hyperbolic?) in my life?
1)I raised over $7K to help fund research, fellowships, and followup treatment for 'below
the belt' cancer patients and survivors treated at Hopkins. And that feels fantastic.
2)Over 90 of my friends and family members contributed to my fundraising efforts. I am
overwhelmed by the outpouring of generosity not just from those I would expect to
contribute but also from many of my former and current graduate students,
undergraduate students (some of whom wrote touching notes and tributes), friends of
Ben's and their parents, and an adored 'benefactress.' The effort also brought together a
beautiful chorus of names and faces from all the 'eras' of my life: grade/high school;
Harvard (college); NYU (grad school); Penn State/State College; others. Former grad
students ran for me in Michigan and North Carolina and Philly; dear college friends
dedicated their runs to me in New Hampshire and Baltimore and Tokyo, while a grad
school bestie and my dear PSU department colleagues also walked in my honor (and
sent pics!); my brother and family, meanwhile, bedecked themselves in #willapower
'gear' (swag? I guess I'm a brand now...) for their walk in Riverside Park. There is good in
the world! I know (I just changed this from: "I have to imagine..." No. I *know*) that all
these dear folks care about me and/or care about combating cancer. And that feels
fantastic.
3) I am grateful that I still have the 'stuff,' ie the organizational chops, motivating force
(ie #willapower), creativity (#willapower t-shirts!), energy, commitment, and
purposefulness to pull something like this off. Our team came in sixth in fundraising
efforts out of forty teams. And we won the spirit award from the organizers (always the
'model student,' no surprise I'm gunning for being the model cancer survivor/fundraiser
:) )
4) A gorgeous day; a great group of local women including two of my dear "teal
sisters"/'IIICs' (I was delighted to introduce each of them to one another, w/one result
being that we may now be morphing into a social walking group, at the suggestion of
one of my friends); an invigorating walk around the pretty grounds of the Military
Museum in Boalsburg; a fit, smiling and kind group of five young adults (including Ben,
Alex and Nikhil, buddies since kindergarten - a precious scene beholding these strapping
young men of 25 along with their wonderful girlfriends Sammi and Julia), setting off to
run a 5K along a route Ben had devised; a post-walk/run coffee in the sun at the Pump
Station Cafe and relaxed lingering on this glorious Sunday morning. The fun and
                       473 / 1.901
fellowship and good vibes felt strong enough to elbow out a deadly disease, at least for a
bit. And that felt fantastic.
5)A community of survivors and caregivers emerging throughout the day from the
livestreamed opening and closing ceremonies in Baltimore (the event was virtual this
year) and from a steady stream of photos and videos posted on social media. Dozens of
survivors, each with her own journey. Several women 'liked' my FB/Instagram posts, a
few 'friended' me. I am one of them, I am not alone, and it felt empowering. As I said to
my friends in State College when we split up after our time together: "Next year in
Baltimore." And THAT felt fantastic. Please join me then!
[Please forgive any typos or other errors. I'll return to clean up all these entries at some
point.]

June 10, 2020 - Never a dull moment...
  by Willa Silverman, June 10, 2020  
As several friends have reached out to me with much caring for an update following my
visit with Dr. Patel yesterday, here's a brief one for now: we had a good visit in that he
spent quite a bit of time with me and seemed completely on top of how everything has
evolved in the past few months. We also had a very candid conversation about how I
might approach work-life balance and, in that context, quality of life issues going
forward, which I very much appreciated.
He admitted he was 'confounded' by the abnormal liver function numbers (but guess
what folks? I had more blood taken yesterday and now my liver numbers are completely
                       479 / 1.901
normal, an encouraging sign). [Btw, the other recent 'better news' that I forgot to
mention in a recent post is that the partial blockage of my small intestine, which was
causing me belly aches, has resolved. A few days on a liquid diet did the trick].
Dr. Patel feels that I am headed towards more treatment, given the corroborating
evidence from the bloodwork (CA125 number has doubled) and imaging (CT and PET
scans). I'm not sure whether it was Dr. Beavis who pushed for another round of imaging
[mistakenly wrote 'imagining' - ha] (ie MRI), but in any event it will allow the doctors to
take a closer look at what's going on inside my pelvic cavity. It is not clear where exactly
the cancer on my right side might be (muscle? on the liver? lymph node? duct?). The MRI
imaging might provide a clearer idea.
If I have more chemo it will take place once a month, for an unspecified duration,
combined with regular testing of my blood (and maybe scans?) to assess the
effectiveness of the treatment. The drug regimen is carboplatin (which I took last time)
and doxil (which I didn't). Dr. Patel seemed to feel the side effects would not be too bad,
but I'll reserve judgment for now and think positive. One effect might be 'hand-foot
syndrome' (some sort of rash on hands and feet). Another might be cardiotoxicity
((in)ability of heart to pump blood well and/or damage to heart muscle); this is what I
need to know more about, because it sounds worrisome. I hope he didn't gloss over this
risk... He sent me off to have an echocardiogram (like a sonogram of my heart), to make
sure, I guess, that my heart is functioning well, which it is (and may it continue to).
Chemo could start next week. Whatever they are detecting has been caught early. There
are no big masses or anything like that.
While I'm nervous about the side effect I just mentioned, I am currently feeling *fine*
(well, in fact). After a two-day freak out I described in a previous post, I am feeling strong
and resolute, mainly after convos w/some key players (Dr. Beavis, my fellow survivor
friends, family). I was told to expect a recurrence from day 1, and at least one of my
survivor friends here in State College is doing well twelve years out after at least four
recurrences.
Onwards to definitive (?) confirmation of a recurrence once my oncologists will have read
my MRI results, probably Friday or Monday. If their read is, once more, not definitive, Dr.
Beavis suggested we'd do another CT-scan in six weeks. 
I realize that it's been over a year since I began writing this journal. In a future post I
hope to write about that fact, including my thoughts on what kind of 'narrative structure'
I could ever hope to impose on -- or see emerge from -- the events of the past year
(Bildungsroman? Picaresque novel? Odyssey?). For now, all that's coming to me is: it's
been one big, dizzying SWIRL.

June 16, 2020 - Careening, OR My Incredible Shrinking World
  by Willa Silverman, June 16, 2020  
                       481 / 1.901
                       482 / 1.901
Well, the MRI, as not unexpected, confirmed a recurrence. I could tell that Dr. Beavis was
waiting a bit to let that news sink in before we continued the rest of our 45 minute
teleconference yesterday. As always, she was *perfect* - calm, clear in her explanations,
patient, caring. She said my bright purple turban looked great on me (it's hiding a mop of
unruly gray hair that will be 'tamed' next week). She explained that the MRI picked up
3-4 small (1 cm or less) 'implants' on (not in, which is good) my colon. There may well be
other, microscopic bits of cancer in other areas (like on my side, near my liver) but the
MRI did not pick them up and the upcoming chemo will target them too. The colon is a
typical place for a recurrence of ovarian cancer. As I likely explained when I dealt with
'first line' chemo, something that might be compared to 'dandelion fluff' blew off the
cancerous ovaries (now removed, of course) and landed on other nearby areas of my
pelvic and abdominal cavities. That is why I had to have a small piece of my liver
removed during my ginormous debulking surgery last May. And please remember,
everyone, what I've written several times: OC is, in Dr. Beavis' words, a "chronic
relapsing condition." A recurrence was always expected, although I'm still a bit surprised
it showed up so soon. I asked Dr. Beavis if that is an indicator for future recurrences and
she said that usually *less* time elapses between successive  recurrences. However, she
is not at all certain this will be my case because I had several complicating factors --
infection, fistula -- during the first go-around. She suspects that the cancer on the colon
*may* be related to some of my current digestive/bowel troubles. The fact that the
implants/tumors are small is good; chemo tends to be more effective on a number of
small amounts of cancer in one location as opposed to bigger masses in several places.
It is also good that no cancer was detected in or near my lungs, which would mean that
the cancer had traveled through the blood stream, which would be (really) not good.
Equally bad, I think, would be cancer found to have penetrated inside organs.
Nevertheless, the thought of insidious, stealthy cancer cells attacking me from within is
scary indeed.
More chemo is in my near future. I'll have six rounds, one every four weeks, with a CT
scan after rounds three and six and my CA125 number tested every round. I am likely
not eligible for the clinical trial at Hopkins that Dr. Beavis had mentioned. The drug
regimen I'll receive will consist of carboplatin and doxil. Dr. Beavis says that most people
tolerate a second round better (each session will also be shorter than the last time, when
chemo was almost a full-day activity). I might develop a rash on my feet and hands, I
might possibly develop an allergy to the drugs, and I have a *1%* chance of developing
a heart problem. Apparently my hair won't fall out. As for nausea, vomiting, fatigue - who
knows? I'll take all of it *as long as the drugs are effective,* which is my foremost wish.
Unfortunately, no one can be with me in the chemo room, due to COVID. That's a
bummer for sure, but it's ok too.
We talked a good bit about work. As I currently have no idea of how this round of
                       483 / 1.901
treatment will affect me, it's hard to make decisions and plans. However, with the help of
colleagues I'm trying to figure out some contingency plans that will allow me to acquit
my responsibilities and do the work I enjoy doing while having firm backup plans in
place. And it seems even more imperative to me than before that I'll likely need to work
from home, to protect myself from a potential chemo/Covid whammy. Penn State's plans
for reopening are complicated, but I presume they will include provisions for people with
underlying/complicating conditions.
So now I have to wait for my insurance company to pre-certify my treatment. Dr. Patel's
nurse said this could take 7-10 days! Aargh! And I need to meet with Dr. Patel
beforehand to further discuss the treatment and its potential side effects. So this delay
likely suits my approach/avoidance m.o., but the 'approach' side of my brain tells me
that we need to get this show on the road. 'Onwards,' as I said to Dr. Beavis yesterday --
with a sigh.
...and did I mention that I feel and look FINE?
After I spoke w/Dr. Beavis, I went out for a walk to process the news. As I passed my
favorite, just-blooming gingko tree I found myself blurting out loud, to no one in
particular: "My world is shrinking!" The daughter of one of my best friends in France is
getting married in Burgundy on 2 August. I'd love to go, but Americans may not even be
allowed into France before mid-July and then will likely have to quarantine. And now
there is my vulnerable immune system to consider. So that part of my 'world' that is in
France -- a big part, in fact -- seems more and more like a mirage. I very much want to
get away for a few days before school starts, w/a strong preference for a place I can plop
myself down on the beach w/a few novels. "See how you're feeling after a few rounds,"
said Dr. Beavis. "So....much....uncertainty...," I said to her, sighing (again). "I really wish I
could provide more certainty," she replied, empathically. "But unfortunately I can't."
As usually happens, I'm feeling more chipper today, having slept better last night than
the one before. I had a very productive work day, making good progress on both my
Vever editing and an article (about food, of all things...). Went to farmers market
(rhubarb, strawberries, zucchini, melon) and will make something tasty for dessert
tomorrow at a friend's house. I took a peaceful drive out into the countryside on Sunday
in my new car (moon roof open all the way; soul music on Sirius); so gorgeous here in
June (see pic). Amish kids were having fun on their kick scooters while the older ones
were taking their buggies out for a spin.
Thanks for your dms, texts, emails and calls of concern. Thank you for walking with me
on this challenging road. Grateful that Ben and Sammi will be here for two (?) more
months (!) before moving to NY.  So grateful for my support network. I will continue to
lean into it. 
  
                       484 / 1.901

June 19, 2020 - Hold the presses (or the IVs)
  by Willa Silverman, June 19, 2020  
Another brief update: I didn't have chemo today. I arrived promptly at 9:45 mentally and
physically prepared, lunch in one tote bag, other supplies (hand cream, ear buds, book,
stationery for thank you notes, ratty pink PSU hoodie I always wear during chemo) in a
second. I had blood drawn and saw the nurse to check vitals. Unfortunately, though,
when I then met Dr. Patel, I balked at the fact that he had not resolved with Dr. Beavis
whether or not I should receive Neulasta (white blood cell booster) after my treatment,
as I had after my previous treatment, which began last summer. He had said previously
that I would not (it turns out that Neulasta is not always used with this particular drug
regimen), yet I was fairly certain Dr. Beavis had recommended it (indeed she had, in this
case, because of COVID). And *I had written to both of them beforehand, asking them to
please resolve the issue between themselves before my first treatment.* They had not
done this. And my additional 'read' on the situation was that Dr. Patel didn't want to get
into the weeds with my insurance company over whether or not the Neulasta would be
covered. So he hadn't contacted Aetna. And he didn't seem to me to have a solid
contingency plan in the event that my infection-fighting white blood cells dropped
significantly after treatment. As I was getting a bit agitated, he finally said "Let's play it
safe" (thank you.....) by (his) requesting precertification for Neulasta from Aetna. But this
means waiting until early next week for chemo to start. 
Dr. Patel's office manager apologized to me for not having had this resolved before
today.
....and did I mention that a woman in Dr. Patel's waiting room was hacking away with a
deep chest cough? I noted her mask, but was still imagining those droplets spraying out
from under and over it. Grrr!
Will hope to salvage the afternoon and get back on track w/this change of plans.
Onwards. 
Shabbat shalom.

June 23, 2020 -All systems go
  by Willa Silverman, June 23, 2020  
After a mind-boggling few days of trying to make sure that my Neulasta had been
approved for coverage by Aetna (at one point they misfiled my paperwork - don't ask...);
that my surgical and my medical oncologists were on the same page; and that I could
move an important appointment on Friday to next week, I *finally* got my chemo
rescheduled for this Thursday afternoon. At this point I am simply *relieved* that I don't
have to send any more messages to my doctors and their staff to get us over the hump
and am eager to get going. I feel fine, am working well, enjoying the sunny yet hot
weather and ready for the next phase. More than anything, I want the chemo drugs to
kick my cancer's butt and get me back into remission.
More anon.

June 26, 2020 - One Done
  by Willa Silverman, June 26, 2020  
I made it through round 1, but not without a complication. A piece of good news is that
my blood counts looked fine. One of those troublesome liver marker numbers has come
down into the normal range, the other is a bit elevated still but not far off normal. White
and red blood cell counts, platelet count etc. all look good. Based on that encouraging
report, we were able to proceed to chemo.
Since my last stint in the chemo room (July-Nov. 2019), now due to COVID, no visitors,
hand-holders or milkshake-bringers are allowed in. It's very quiet in there. It feels a bit
lonely w/out the company, but I managed (wrote thank you notes, sent texts) and the
entire treatment is shorter this time (2 hours total, but actually about an hour longer if
you count the blood work and then waiting for the results). I know the nurses by now,
and some of them are really nice, caring. And thankfully there were no vociferous
Trumpiacs or other trouble-makers to contend with.
1/2 hour of fluids (glucose solution) - check. 1/2 hour of carboplatin - smooth sailing. 1
hour of doxil (the new drug for me) - about 5 minutes into it I began to feel distinctly
unwell. Flushed, light headed, my chest started constricting and I began to feel searing
pain in my back, seemingly along the sides of my spinal cord. I believe the nurse was
right next to me (frankly, I don't recall) but I managed to mumble something like "I...
don't...feel... well" and just remember blurting out a string of epithets to deal w/the
increasing pain. Luckily, the nurses sprung right into action with the emergency protocol,
testing my bp and oxygen (both plummeting rapidly), pumping me with steroids and
benadryl, and letting me know that what they were doing would reverse the allergic
reaction. Dr. Patel also rushed in immediately and began checking my pulse, heart rate,
lungs etc. Fortunately, they were able to get the reaction under control pretty quickly, at
which point I was sort of loopy from the meds. We waited about 25 mn. then restarted
the doxil, this time with no complication for the rest of the hour. It was quite scary, but
the anti-allergy meds kicked in so quickly and almost knocked me out completely so my
fright response was quickly tempered. And the nurses were on it, thankfully; if not, it
could have been much worse. I suppose I'll have to receive those meds now every time. I
had been told that an allergic reaction was possible but it apparently doesn't happen
that often with doxil. Again, my bottom line is: may the chemo work! (May the force be
with me, in other words!).
I was so zonked when I got home around 5 p.m. (my neighbor Janis kindly took me to
and from, with a pit stop at Meyers dairy afterwards for the now ritual during or post-
chemo milkshake) that I slept for an hour or so, then heated up some tomato basil orzo
                       494 / 1.901
soup (courtesy of Wegman's) and crashed in front of the tv, where I've become
engrossed in the Israeli series (on Netflix), Shtisel. Between watching the tube longer
than I should have, some additional screen time, getting involved in a lighthearted text
exchange with a friend, and still being somewhat agitated from the day's events - and
despite having all that Benadryl in me -- I had much trouble sleeping and only squeezed
in a few hours. Will try to correct that tonight with an earlier bedtime and less screen
time.My wonderful friend Helen brought me not only a delicious lunch (chicken salad
bowl - lots of good protein) but also a "Nourishing and Brightening Oil Sheet Mask"
(100% Camellia), which seems exactly what's needed tonight.
I feel tired today and mildly nauseous (am taking anti-nausea meds) but not too bad
really, all things considered. I've had a relaxing day writing thank you notes (close to 100
donors to my cancer fundraiser, so it's taking a while but I'm getting there!) and
responding to emails. So far I'm not feeling anything like the crushing fatigue that I had
last time around. Ditto for any of the ghastly doxil-related symptoms (skin turning brown,
mouth sores etc.) that women write about on a Facebook page that seems to trade in
catastrophizing and hysteria (and misspellings) so I try to stay off it, even though there
are kernels of helpful info mixed in. Much more useful to me are the carefully curated
postings of the Hopkins' Kelly Gyneologic Oncology Service, where I am grateful to be a
patient.
Off now to get a shot of udenyca, a Neulasta biosimilar that will help boost my white
blood cell count. This is the shot that I nearly had to sell my firstborn for in order to have
my insurance company cover, so it better work!
Sabbath peace to all, and love. Many thanks for the chorus of support. It's such good
medicine.

June 29, 2020 - Coming around again
  by Willa Silverman, June 29, 2020  
I understand that my post-chemo pattern now will likely entail a rough weekend followed
by gradual recovery, unless the rounds become increasingly hard for me to handle (last
time, in July-Nov., some rounds seemed to hit me harder than others). On the whole,
though - and for the time being - this go-around does not seem as debilitating as the last
one. So far, no crushing fatigue, no seventeen-hour sleeps, no needing to lie down every
time I pass my bed. The day after chemo I took it easy, but had no problem showering
and getting dressed, making breakfast, shooting off a bunch of emails and staying up
until my normal bedtime these days of about 10 p.m. Ditto for the following days - over
the weekend, I shopped at the farmers market, took a long country drive, went clothes
shopping, whipped up a beet and goat cheese salad and some garlic scape pesto etc.
And today I had a pretty much normal work day, making some progress on two projects,
attending to correspondence etc. 
My symptoms have included fatigue (I can feel 'in my bones' that my body is craving
sleep), nausea (not debilitating, abating each day, and handled with Zofran and
Compazine), mild headache, some tenderness in my neck (perhaps lymph nodes?) and
neuropathy in my toes and, mildly, in my fingers. I must be very vigilant when I get out
of bed at night or simply rise from a sitting position so as not to lose my balance and fall,
as I did in January, resulting in a broken bone in my ankle. And last night I noticed that
one of my big toenails appeared to be 'jiggling' a bit, loosely. Then I remembered that
chemo can adversely affect finger and toe nails (I wrote Dr. Patel's nurse to see what she
recommends but have not heard back yet; of course I fear infection if the tissue becomes
exposed). I also remembered all the awful, undignified, sci-fi-ish side effects that chemo
can provoke. Losing my hair was of course the one that most made me feel like some
sort of alien; whether or not it will happen this time is unclear. Thinking positively, I have
an appointment with my hair stylist Sarah tomorrow for the first time in almost four
months! I cannot wait. My hair has grown in curly so we'll see what she can help me
                       497 / 1.901
come up with.
My mood has been generally ok, not super-buoyant but fine, with some teary moments
usually late at night, first thing in the morning or in the shower. I was veering towards
self-pity (never a constructive emotion for me), imagining that people were starting to
think of me as "doomed girl" (aka "recurrence girl") or, conversely, "heroic girl" (an
equally pressured role to fill). I got out from under that cloud pretty quickly, somehow.
As ever, texts, msgs and emails from friends and family help immensely, even if I can't
*see* most of these folks (very hard, more on that another time). My OC-survivor friend
Deb reminded me in a msg today that treatment for her several recurrences (and
zapping the cancer early each time) has given her twelve years of good quality of life so
far. Hopefully, I'll be able to get out for a socially distanced walk or coffee with a friend or
two this week, and there's a nice lunch on the horizon too. And Ben and Sammi are back
from D.C., having completed Phase 1 (getting their stuff out of their D.C. apartments) of
their move to NY in August. They are quarantining for a few days at Michael and Sue's,
and took a COVID test as well, simply as a precaution because they've been away from
State College for a while. I expect they are fine, but it will be a few more days until they
can stay here. We're already, though, formulating some holiday weekend plans to get
out to one of the pretty state parks nearby for some kayaking or canoeing, picnicking
etc. I would love to eat a grilled hot dog.
On Wednesday I'll be (re)passed the baton for the department headship. Obviously we're
at a critical juncture right now working to help implement Penn State's plan for
reopening in August. I'll be working from home and will have backup on hand from
trusted colleagues if needed.
May you live in interesting times.

July 13, 2020 - Life is Good
  by Willa Silverman, July 13, 2020  
I haven't written in a while. That is both because all is well for now and because I've
been very busy with headship business -- in particular, making sure all of our
international students can remain in the States following the very draconian and
inhumane directive from ICE targeting them. It feels good to be busy, useful, helpful. I'm
                       499 / 1.901
cautiously optimistic that I made the right decision returning to the headship -- as long
as my health remains stable. Right now, I feel pretty well overall. My energy is good, my
appetite healthy, I'm sleeping well on the whole and I think I look ok. The week after
chemo, I didn't feel great but in the three weeks after that I really rebounded
impressively. My stomach and digestive system have a mind (and nervous system) of
their own and always seem to be a bit 'off.' I guess that's what happens when you say
goodbye to two parts of your colon and two of your small intestine.
I feel so well, in fact, that on Wednesday, rather spontaneously, I'm going on vacation! I
have not been out of Dodge, except for treatment (read: surgery) at Hopkins since
December, when I was in NY and on a wonderful retreat with three of my best women
friends at Kripalu Yoga Center in the Berkshires. I'm heading back to MA, this time to the
Cape! I have been craving the ocean (seeing it, bathing in it, maybe doing some yoga by
it, reading something engrossing with my toes dipped in the water etc.). One of my best
travel buddies, Ben, enthusiastically agreed to come with me. We took him to the Cape
when he was little, but he doesn't remember it. We're staying in a wonderful hotel with
lots of amenities, the Chatham Bars Inn, which I fell in love with ten years ago during a
fun stay at the home of a college friend in Chatham. My friend Denise and I took a walk
around the property at that time and sat on some comfy lawn chairs out front. The hotel
has a private beach, a pool, several restaurants, fitness center, and spa (have already
booked a facial and manicure). I'm hoping for lots of beach and pool time, some drives to
nearby towns, walks and lots of reading (I have two books lined up and am trying to
settle on a few others), plus some yummy seafood. I will be careful, but my stomach
tolerates fish quite well, and I don't see how a lobster roll - or two - could do harm - just
need to avoid fried and/or spicy stuff and alcohol (does not mix well w/my chemo) - well,
maybe just one fried clam will be ok.
Any suggestions for a book on tape and/or good podcast for the long drive there and
back, which Ben and I will split? 
Otherwise, the summer days have proceeded tranquilly (well, except for the continually
worrisome backdrop of COVID and national politics; still we live in a peaceful little bubble
here). I've been working hard, doing a lot of cooking and baking, getting out for walks,
watching Netflix, reading, seeing a few friends here and there and keeping in touch with
many others. I fully realize that all of this could turn on a dime, though -- I could have a
bad reaction to my next chemo or, worse, the chemo might turn out not to be effective
(a scan in about two months, plus bloodwork before that should reveal any telltale
signs). It is possible, then, that while I calmly go about my business cancer cells might be
continuing to multiply and spread. So...much...uncertainty. But my default mode is
positive thinking and savoring the moment or, as my friend David Rothman (who knows
of what he speaks...) puts it, squeezing each drop of sweetness out of every moment as
if it were a cell of honeycomb.
                       500 / 1.901
Sammi and Ben found a rental apartment in Park Slope and will be moving in mid-
August. I will miss those two tremendously, but it's time for them to get on with the next
phase of their lives. Ben may, in the end, wind up taking all his courses at NYU online
and Sammi will continue to work remotely, but at least they'll be 'launched.' Nice that
the whole immediate family will be in NY. I'm missing the city, but I suspect that the vibe
might seem unfamiliar these days...
As it was my father's yahrzeit last Friday (three years), I virtually attended service so I
could say kaddish. The rabbi offered a somewhat differently worded version of the
prayer for healing than the one I'm used to, and it resonated with me. The prayer invited
"healing, strength and enlivening" to *surge* (apt verb) both "towards and within me,"
investing me with "spirit, holiness and continuing possibilities." I think we also sang the
Debbie Friedman version of the "Mi Shebeirach" (prayer for healing) that asks a higher
power to "help us find the *courage* to make our lives a blessing." Sometimes it does
indeed take *courage* to make our lives a blessing; one cannot be passive about this
endeavor - at least not in my experience.
Back on the 21st, just in time for chemo on the 22nd. Be well, everyone.

July 23, 2020 - Through with Two
  by Willa Silverman, July 23, 2020  
I would like to share a bit about our wonderful week on Cape Cod, but thought it best to
first share a health update. We arrived home (after a nine-hour trip from MA, with Ben
doing perhaps 2/3 of the driving and me 1/3) late Tuesday night and I was at Dr. Patel's
office for chemo the next morning (fortunately having benefited from a good night's
sleep, as I was exhausted on our return).
Per the normal routine, I had my blood work done first, to make sure that none of the
results would prevent me from receiving chemo. My hemoglobin was a bit low (expected)
and my liver markers still a bit elevated (their erratic nature is still an unresolved
mystery to me), but not enough to warrant holding off on chemo. The CA125 (OC
marker) result usually comes in the next morning. My vitals were all fine; I seem to have
gained a few pounds, had to be those lobster rolls...
I had a good meeting with Dr. Patel and feel closer to him now than initially. I sense a
genuine concern on his part and feel that he is finally 'seeing' me as the total person I
am. He seemed quite on top of my treatment, and said he felt I was "doing well,"
perhaps in part because I am so active and have not recently (or ever, really)
experienced any worrisome symptoms like vomiting, blood in stool, headaches, falls etc.
My stomach remains a bit quirky but may have settled down a bit recently. It feels 'stiff'
in the morning (likely due to adhesions), but after I move around a bit it feels more
supple.
I was of course concerned that I might have another allergic reaction to the chemo
drugs, as I did last time, but the nurse pumped me full of Benadryl ahead of the
treatment and I was fine. My nurse, who came over (temporarily or permanently) from a
Geisinger center in Lewistown, seemed to be having lots of trouble with the equipment --
or perhaps the equipment was simply faulty (or perhaps she was a bit faulty...). Every
5-10 minutes or so it would start beeping and she had to restart it, perhaps because of
air bubbles in the tubing through which I receive the chemo drugs. Then she knocked
over a very large tray of medical equipment that clattered noisily to the floor. This really
started stressing me out and added a lot of extra time to the treatment. Oh well.
Nevertheless, I got through it and my friend Helen kindly picked me up, with the now
traditional vanilla milkshake from Meyer Dairy in hand. My caring neighbor Janis had
driven me to chemo in the morning.
Unfortunately, I slept poorly last night: a bout of nausea woke me up at one point and I
was fretting over my soon to be revealed CA125 number, which I'm always highly
                       504 / 1.901
anxious about uncovering (either through Geisinger's online portal or via Dr. Patel). So I
was immensely relieved to learn (via the portal) that my CA number had decreased from
50 last time to 31.2 this time, putting me back within normal range (at the somewhat
higher end of normal, but definitely *normal*). Dr. Patel wrote me to say that this
gradual trending down was encouraging. It makes me hopeful that my treatment is
working, which is my bottom line hope. I'll know more when I have my CT-scan at the
midway point after round three, in late August.
Today I returned to Dr. Patel's office for my shot of Udenyca (a Neulasta biosimilar),
which boosts white blood cell count. I don't mean to complain, but the (same) nurse did
not inspire confidence. She could not pronounce the name of the medication, making me
unsure if I was receiving the same medication as last time. She had me look at her
computer screen to see if I could pronounce it. And once again she seemed not to be
able to operate the equipment, this time to take my blood pressure. Like yesterday, she
was stressing about this (getting flustered and sighing heavily) and that was in turn
making me nervous. I will follow up with the nurse manager to let her know that since I
feel so vulnerable before and during treatment, it's crucial for me that the staff remain
calm, composed, skillful and confident. The Udenyca can cause bone pain, so soon I will
take a Claritin, which can help counteract that potential side effect.
Today I feel tired (from the treatment itself and the poor sleep following) and very mildly
nauseous, but am thankful not yet to have experienced any other pernicious side effects
of Carboplatin and Doxil: bad rash on hands and feet, mouth sores, a worsening of
neuropathy (fairly bad in my toes already), and in rare cases, heart problems. Despite
my fatigue, I had the stamina to spend the day responding to and writing emails that had
piled up during my vacation -- during which I made the decision to keep work at bay to
the extent possible so that I could recharge for a week.
My latest Netflix obsession is a documentary series called "Lenox Hill," which follows the
lives of several doctors at New York's Lenox Hill Hospital. It is very sensitively done, and
the stories are compelling. One of the doctors is an experienced neurosurgeon, Mitch,
who in the course of the series is diagnosed, ironically, with advanced neck cancer, ie a
type of cancer familiar to him from his specialty. Aside from not sharing an iota of this
doctor's professional expertise, I found myself relating to him intensely on a personal
level, from his telling his associates, when he reveals his sobering diagnosis to them,
that he doesn't want a 'pity party' or even sympathy, to a poignant scene where he
attends an annual retreat with the other neurosurgeons (about five of them, all men), at
the weekend home of one of the doctors (looked perhaps to be on the Long Island
shore). The guys sit around drinking, casually dressed, fishing poles and tackle scattered
about -- the bond and the love among them is palpable, as is their desire to marshal all
their expertise to help their colleague (who in the end may not want treatment because
it would likely involve removing part of his *face* traversed by a major vein). In any
event, surrounded by his friends/colleagues, Mitch is clearly in the 'be in the moment,
                       505 / 1.901
live every day to the fullest' mode, and says something like "and this day has been 
great." I found myself fist-pumping the air and just yelling: "YES!" It's amazing how low
my threshold for happiness is these days. Any day that I wake up alive, feeling
reasonably well, and able to work and pursue most of my normal activities, I am simply
ecstatic.
More on the vacay when I'm able. Thanks to many friends who remembered I had chemo
today (I don't even remember sharing the day with many of you!) and checked in w/me
via message or text. I am so touched. I appreciate your care. It uplifts me.
  
Comments
Welcome back, Willa! So good to know you made it past this week's chemo with
encouraging numbers and only mild side effects. On to more pleasant activities for the
next few weeks! XO, K
  —Kathryn Grossman, July 23, 2020  
  
July 26, 2020 - Summer blahs
  by Willa Silverman, July 26, 2020  
                       506 / 1.901
                       507 / 1.901
Sometimes things get worse before they get better. After two post-chemo days
(Thursday/Friday) feeling relatively chipper -- I put in a good eight-hour work day on
Friday, including attending a tense department heads'/deans' meeting devoted to plans
for Penn State's reopening next month -- the weekend's been rough. In a "déjà vu all
over again" scenario reminiscent of last summer (and not in a good way), I fell asleep for
several hours on the couch in the late afternoon two days in a row, awaking at 8:30 p.m.
(and I'm not a napper....). I still felt tired after a ten-hour sleep last night and thus ceded
to the temptation to get back into bed to snooze some more after late breakfast. The
familiar fatigue-nausea combo has beset me, accompanied by an upset stomach, loss of
appetite, some tenderness in my neck etc. UGH. My physical weakness tends in turn to
frustrate and depress me (that niggling feeling that I should be up and about, or working,
or simply doing something compounded with missing friends and family not in State
College when I'm feeling low). As I've found from previous experience, though, in the end
I simply need to give in to the fatigue. I am taking anti-nausea meds, meds for my upset
stomach, Claritin for potential bone pain, and a Tylenol here and there for headache --
and I'm trying to stay well hydrated. Ben and Sammi were kind enough to grocery shop
for me and water my plants. And a gorgeous bouquet from my mother's best childhood
friend and her son, plus another lovely bouquet that Ben and Sammi brought back from
a friend's garden in Pittsburgh, were well timed to lift my spirits. Ditto for a few
messages exchanged with friends, always part of the cure. Hoping that I'll start
rebounding soon. 
Hard to imagine that I felt so energetic during our vacation on Cape Cod, including the
nine-hour drive to and from. That gives me hope. It was a memorable, relaxing, lovely
week at the Chatham Bars Inn- just perfect. Weather was a bit mixed. Surrounded by
magnificent hydrangeas and lulled by a gentle, fragrant sea breeze, we spent entire days
at the pool (where I dug into a few fun reads, _French like Moi,_ by a colleague, Scott
Carpenter, and _L'Appart_ by one of my fave American French food gurus, David
Leibovitz); indulged in the great seafood purveyed by casual shacks along the coast
(fried clam bellies! clam chowder! lobster roll! fish tacos! oysters! fish sandwiches!);
walked to the sweet town of Chatham for a blueberry muffin, juice and coffee each
morning; took a day trip to Provincetown. Ben golfed (including with one of his best buds
from State College, who now lives in Boston, and his girlfriend) while I swam in the spa's
private pool, followed by a facial one day and a manicure the other (three different hand
treatments!). Our room was spacious with high-grade bed linens, a lovely view of the golf
course etc. It was all very much an indulgence in terms of how I usually travel, but as it's
ostensibly my only vacation this summer I decided to splurge. And I'm definitely in that
carpe diem mode. I had a great, totally sympatico time with one of my favorite travel
companions, and we had a belly laugh watching seagulls swooping down to devour the
expensive poolside lunch just bought by a couple sitting next to us.
                       508 / 1.901
[Btw, the hotel was quite COVID-safe -- as safe as one can be these days, I imagine --
and everyone seemed to be adhering to regulations about masking and distancing. While
we did take off our masks at the pool and when dining outdoors, we seem to have
returned healthy. I certainly hope so].
As I had the luxury of some unstructured time to allow my mind to wander "where it will
go," I found myself trying to figure out what constitutes a perfect day for me (I even
brought this up to Ben, but as he's sometimes a man of few[er] words his answer was
succinct: golf). I settled on the following: my perfect day involves an out of the ordinary
space-time continuum. Time is 'elastic' and just flows. There is usually some movement
through space (ie a long walk or several activities in a day that seem to flow naturally
from one into another). There's always at least one other person involved, perhaps a
dear friend. And nature and the weather cooperate. One example would be the very long
walk I have taken for many years on arriving in Paris during the summer -- most often
with my dear grad school friend Randy, but it could also be with my equally dear college
friend Mitchel (or both of them - or any number of friends). It's a ritual that has
maintained its spontaneity. We meet up in the Marais for brunch or coffee and then just
take off walking around Paris, stopping perhaps in the Tuileries to sit and chat by a
gorgeous reflecting pond, then checking out a show in a gallery that we come upon, then
it's time for a cold drink or maybe an ice cream or gelato, then more walking (we'll sit in
one of those adorable little parks that dot Paris), talking, sharing, laughing, gossiping,
catching up, people watching, window shopping until all of a sudden the day's coming to
a close and it's time for an apéritif and maybe a falafel before we part ways. What is so
perfect about these perfect days? The flow and the harmony, the feeling of well-being
and happiness. And equally as perfect, as Montaigne famously puts it in his essay, "De
l'Amitié" ("On Friendship"), is the following: "parce que c'était lui, parce que c'était moi"
("Because it was he*, because it was me"). [*or she - or them].

August 8, 2020 - "One must imagine Sisyphus happy"
  by Willa Silverman, August 8, 2020  
                       514 / 1.901
                       515 / 1.901
I suppose I'm motivated to write more than I've been doing recently when I'm in crisis
mode. But happily things have, overall, been good recently (let's leave aside my
consternation over the state of the country - and the world). A few weeks removed from
my last round of chemo and feeling well, I'm trying to squeeze every ounce of time and
energy, for both work and play, out of these 'good' weeks, with round 3 -- debilitating
like all the others, no doubt -- coming into view on August 20th. Work is of course really
heating up with the start of the semester just two+ weeks away. So I'm trying to keep on
top of all the department head, admin work (usually in the mornings), then switch to
some combination of preparing my fall graduate seminar and my own research in the
afternoons. So far, I'm afloat. And feeling productive and useful = feeling upbeat. And
my energy level this week has been good, as I try very hard to get the sleep I need.
Further, I enjoyed three lovely lunches with friends this week (all of them at the Ale
House, where one can dine on a pleasant shaded outdoor deck), and have a visit with a
friend and a morning walk with three other friends to look forward to tomorrow (this new,
welcome 'tradition' grew out of the June 'Stride and Thrive' cancer walk for which I
organized a team; it was so much fun that several of us now meet up once a month for a
walk, gabbing and post-walk refreshments - #willapower t-shirts optional!). I've bought
outdoor chairs, some decorative planters, and a colorful orange, yellow and blue Mexican
oilcloth tablecloth for my little back patio, so for the first time I can really use it for
entertaining.
Ben and Sammi will come over tomorrow and stay until they leave for NY next Saturday.
Ben's just returned from a golf vacation in Michigan with his dad. He will have been here
since March 16th and Sammi since April 4th. Oh I'm going to miss those two... Well,
maybe more on that another day.
Recently, the myth of Sisyphus came to mind in relation to my own condition. I
remember reading the text by Camus in high school French class I believe. We spent
hours in class debating the meaning of it, which seemed so very 'heavy' to my sixteen-
or so-year-old self. While I don't feel at all as if, like Sisyphus, I've been 'punished' by the
gods or any other power (chalk my cancer up to just plain 'ole bad luck, a random
cellular mutation), I can relate to Sisyphus pushing that boulder up the mountain, almost
reaching the top, only to have it come crashing down again. Then I remembered -- and it
resonated with me as I contemplate my own 'Sisyphean' fate -- the final line of Camus'
text, summing up Sisyphus' paradoxical combination of acceptance of his fate and yet
rebellion against it. "Il faut imaginer Sisyphe heureux." Yes, "one must imagine Sisyphus
happy."

August 15, 2020 - Gone baby gone
  by Willa Silverman, August 15, 2020  
                       517 / 1.901
                       518 / 1.901
Ben and Sammi left this morning at 5:30 a.m., after five months here as my 'quarantine
roommates.' I miss them and feel emotionally exhausted today. Their presence was a
blessing and the silver lining in the midst of the COVID gloom, turning our home into a
happy, harmonious cocoon. I will simply miss having them *around:* an early riser, Ben
would always be working in my study when I rolled out of bed around 8:00; he'd come
into the kitchen (where I had transferred my work station) c. 10:00 to make himself
breakfast; we'd often share a quick bite together at lunchtime. Sammi would return from
working at Michael and Sue's around 6:00. I'd start preparing dinner around 7:00 or so,
often with the kids' help (my passion for cooking and baking has been reactivated over
the past five months as I loved cooking for all of us; we'll see what happens going
forward). We'd enjoy a lovely dinnertime together and then Ben and Sammi would
faithfully clear the table, wash the dishes and tidy the kitchen while I crashed in front of
the t.v. or went for a walk. Before 10 Ben would come into the t.v. room to say
goodnight, leaning his head down so I could plant a kiss on its top. It was wonderful too
to spend so much quality time with Sammi, whether around the house, driving out to an
Amish market in the countryside or discussing how to spruce up my t.v. room and back
patio (both of which I made good strides on this summer, thanks to Sammi's sharp
design sense). They were both also great helpers to me, not only keeping the kitchen
neat but lending a hand with grocery shopping, assembling a new t.v. stand, figuring out
which type of new car I should buy, getting me set up with a better internet server,
occasionally preparing me a gin and tonic (I scarcely drink these days), and of course
pitching in when I was wiped out after chemo. [They're] leaving home, bye bye...
I suppose I should have learned by now, from having cancer, that impermanence is a a
fact of life, but having them leave is still hard. Yet I also feel immensely grateful!
After Ben and Sammi left at 5:30 this morning (Ben came into my room to give me a
final hug w/those long strong arms of his), I fell asleep again and had an extremely
involved dream about my college reunion, the details of which I won't recount now. Next
year is slated to be my 40th but it's going to be virtual. I feel sad about this too, because
it's been a huge uplift to reconnect 'in the flesh' with my college classmates at five year
intervals, although I see and/or am in touch with many of them more often.
I slept in, went to the farmers market, and in the afternoon took a relaxing drive out into
the countryside -- buggies, cows, farms, farmstands (where I bought peaches and dill
pickles), rolling hills -- and way too many Trump signs (and a Confederate flag......) for
my taste (I did spot one Biden sign). I love driving my new car while blaring (windows
closed, a/c on) and singing along to my tunes.
Fortunately -- I suppose -- I have plenty of work to keep me busy with school starting the
week after next. I really can't conceive of what it will be like to conduct the entirety of
                       519 / 1.901
my work from home and am apprehensive about getting lonely, or feeling like I'm
drifting away from all the forms of sociability I'm used to etc. I know that I'll need to have
regular get-togethers (walks, outdoor coffees and lunches etc. for as long as the weather
stays nice) with friends to keep myself sane. I am also a bit apprehensive about staying
on top of things work-wise during the 'bad' week following chemo (my next round is this
coming Thursday), but I've been discussing ways of keeping this manageable with
friends and family. I also need to be 'ok' with not giving 120% at least (as I'm used to
doing), if I'm unable to. This is a difficult reality for me to face as I've always been so
driven in terms of work, but there may be days when I simply have to ease up on the gas
pedal. I'm thinking of setting up a meditation area in Ben's bedroom upstairs. On the
other hand, I am glad to be productive, working, helping, connecting, flexing my
creativity (when not mired in administrative minutia). I've been feeling well the past
three weeks or so but with chemo (and then likely a CT scan and possible
echocardiogram) looming, that boulder's likely going to come rolling down that hill again.
I've already tentatively programmed in ample rest next weekend should I need it before
school starts. And I'm of course praying I won't have to deal with any 'curveballs' in
terms of my health. I continue to be very well surrounded -- another blessing. Two
friends checked in on me today, intuiting that I'd be sad after B and S's departure (they
are safely in Brooklyn now, and Ben has scouted out a 'real deal' Brooklyn pizza joint for
their dinner). One friend proposed a walk tomorrow, and I'm looking forward to it. 
Shavua tov ---

August 20, 2020 - Halfway!
  by Willa Silverman, August 20, 2020  
Just a quick update before I go make dinner. Everything went smoothly with today's
treatment. My wonderful friend Helen picked my up bright and early (before 8:00 a.m.)
and it was lovely to be able to enjoy her company for the short drive to the Geisinger
medical facility. We joked that we had both made the effort to put on make up and dress
nicely for each other :). I had blood drawn, which I then reviewed with Dr. Patel. Some
counts were slightly high (liver markers) or low (hemoglobin) but overall things looked ok
and there was nothing so out of range as to delay treatment. Tomorrow I'll learn what
my CA125 number is and pray that it will have decreased even more from 31.2 (normal)
or else will have remained stable; if it went up since last time, I'd feel worried. We looked
at the results of my last PET (I believe) scan (maybe it was a CT scan) and saw the spots
on my liver and in a lymph node that we are targeting during this round of treatment.
That image was a rather sobering reality check and draws me temporarily back into that
dark place where cancer reigns. It was simply an 'UGH' moment. I'll have a PET scan
soon as we're at the halfway mark and it's appropriate to take a look inside and see if
the cancer has regressed (hope so). My vital signs were very good (100% oxygen rate,
good blood pressure on the lower side, weight around 130 lbs, which is a weight that
feels very comfortable and healthy for me). Dr. Patel said: "You're doing good."
Treatment went smoothly and took about three hours. The nurse again pumped me up
with Benadryl to prevent another allergic reaction to Doxil; that immediately made me
quite drowsy. Then I received an anti-nausea drug, then Carbo followed by Doxil. Smooth
sailing. I mainly texted friends and family and, as ever, was extremely grateful for check
ins and well wishes (thank you mom, Ethan, Ben, Helen, Jackie, Gay, Maria, Clare -- and if
I've missed anyone please excuse me in my grogginess). My kind neighbor Janis picked
me up and she knew to drive me right to Meyers Dairy for the now ritual post-chemo
milkshake (chocolate toasted almond - so good and refreshing and comforting). I was
very tired when I got home so I crashed (ie slept!) for about two hours, then sat outside
in the delightful 'back to school' weather, then wrote a bunch of work emails. Now I'm
going to make dinner (likely some haddock and zucchini and taboulé. My potassium is
low so I need to stock up on bananas, melon, raisins, etc.
Tomorrow I hope I won't be too tired to make it to my hair stylist's for a 9:30
appointment. Then at 2:00 I have to return to Dr. Patel's for a shot to boost my white
                       524 / 1.901
blood count, after which I'll go down the hall to my dermatologist's to have stitches
removed from my head (she had biopsied tissue from a bump on my head that, as she
suspected, turned out to be benign - whew - from a pilar cyst). Exciting, eh?
The weekend will pose the challenge of needing to rest as much as possible combined
with needing to keep up with admin./head work to the extent possible and polish off my
syllabus and prepare for graduate seminar on the Dreyfus Affair on Tuesday evening (I
feel like the class part is in pretty good shape; almost done w/syllabus, have been
thinking a lot about format of first session and what I want to say). I need to avoid stress
but I'm also happy to feel purposeful and productive. So I'm praying that the chemo
effects aren't too harsh but there's no guarantee. Based on the first two rounds, I can
expect acute fatigue, nausea, body aches, cramps etc. Praying that mouth sores, bad
rash don't kick in. Good wishes, good karma, prayers, mantras all welcome going
forward.

August 23, 2020 - Pushing through...
  by Willa Silverman, August 23, 2020  
The weekend's been rather rough, as predicted. Saturday morning I woke up with the
now familiar body aches. It seems like every part of my body is sore to the touch, even
my head. My neck, arms, ribs etc. all seem sort of puffy and sensitive and it hurts just to
move. Otherwise, I have some relatively mild nausea and significant fatigue, which I tried
to combat by getting at least nine hours sleep both Saturday and Sunday night and lying
down a few times during the day. Today my body feels no worse (although it doesn't feel
distinctly better either) and I'm hoping tomorrow I might start to turn the corner
(incidentally, I never learned my CA125 number on Friday so I hope -- and don't hope --
that that test result comes in tomorrow). I laid low at home over the weekend, enjoyed a
mocha chip milkshake my friend Jackie was kind enough to bring me, watched Netflix
(_Father Soldier Son,_ a sobering NYTimes documentary), and worked calmly in my
office, which turned out to be fairly relaxing. I had to detach when I began stressing over
a frustrating hour spent trying to scan documents, fruitlessly.
I felt anxious knowing that despite my discomfort I had to try to push through to finish up
my syllabus and prepare a number of admin. tasks for the beginning of this week, as our
semester starts tomorrow. And goodness knows I'm not the best organized nor the most
efficient admin., but I did make an effort to get as far as I could this weekend. This
means that I will have the morning tomorrow to deal with whatever headship stuff might
arise, and then the afternoon to prepare my class for Tuesday evening; I've already
given the first session a good bit of thought, so I just need to sit down and chart it out.
Tuesday morning we have our College heads and deans meeting. I'm still wagering on
the notion that feeling productive and purposeful will actually be good for me, as long as
I stay calm and healthy. Maybe I just want sympathy. We'll see.
I had quite the back to school anxiety dream last night, this one likely compounded by
                       526 / 1.901
the fact that I have in fact been out of the classroom for an entire year, including a
medical leave last fall. In this dream, I had returned to wrap up an undergraduate class
for the last session. I had missed the second to last session without letting the students
know where I was, and apparently in my absence things had gone downhill (in reality, I
*did* miss the second to last session of my undergrad class in Spring 2019, because I
was in Danville meeting with a gynecological oncologist; my wonderful intern took the
class for me that day and I think some of the students were concerned about my sudden
absence). In any event, when I got to the class I felt that I needed to let the students
know where I had been, so in my best 'teacher voice' (ie volume pumped way up), I
explained to them that I had been travelling to Russia, Germany and Iceland. I was sort
of gesturing aimlessly into the air as I was saying this (almost expounding on it) -- but
none of them were listening to me; I was completely irrelevant. The students were slated
to do group presentations that day, so I tried to get that going, knowing that we would
not have time to complete all the presentations and not having really figured out a
solution (perhaps I thought vaguely about having them come do the presentations for
me at another time). We were in some sort of space that gradually became darker and
murky looking, with a strange glow. I could hardly see the students, but they seemed to
be interacting with another. One of the group presentations was about Gyp, the author I
wrote my dissertation about whom I'm also incorporating into my Dreyfus Affair seminar
this fall. It had an almost surreal or fairy tale quality about it, with the strange glowing
light and flashes of gold in whatever space we were in. End of dream.
In this 'plague season,' I've had a number of dreams about travel. Dreams are wishes...
Hoping and expecting a more successful first class than in my dream, I'm taking the
evening off to chill and will get back to work tomorrow.

August 24, 2020 - Yes!
  by Willa Silverman, August 24, 2020  
I can take dozens of emails, a nationwide Zoom crash, and a very full day of work in
stride in light of the good news re my CA125 number today, which has decreased from
50 (before round 1) to 31.2 (round 2) to 19.7 (round 3; ie within normal range, by most
assessments). Dr. Patel notes an "overall encouraging result." YAY! I'm hoping this
indicates that my treatment is working, which is my fervent prayer. And the result has
given me a boost at the outset of the semester, just when I need to rally and focus my
energies and concentration.
At the same time, I realize that I'm running a marathon not a sprint, that I'm in it for the
long haul, that technically my disease has no cure but that I might still set my sights on
long-term remission (statistically not likely, although I know several women who have
beaten the odds and thrived), that recurrences are likely yadda yadda yadda. But I will
*gladly* cling to the result of this lap like a totem, hoping I might *will* (willa?) more
good luck undergirded by excellent care and my own strength.
En avant!
