September 9, 2020 - Fluctuat nec mergitur?
  by Willa Silverman, September 9, 2020  
                       531 / 1.901
                       532 / 1.901
I haven't written in a while. The first three weeks of school have sped by and I'm caught
up in the frenzied pace. My graduate seminar on the Dreyfus Affair appears to be going
well. I'm certainly enjoying it - and the students -- and feel energized to be teaching
again after a year away from the (now virtual) classroom. While admittedly the first
nearly three-hour session (5:30-8:15 p.m.) drained me physically, last night I still felt
energetic enough afterwards to cook dinner (and then to plunk down in front of the t.v.,
only to watch an utterly saddening Frontline focusing on three children living in poverty
with single mothers, navigating the pandemic, mothers' job losses, and the impact of the
Black Lives Matter movement).
It's a stressful time to be an administrator. The number of COVID-positive cases
continues to rise alarmingly on our campus, which means that colleagues have been
confronted with cases in their own classes, and I need to help our faculty navigate these
crises. I often have to supply data to the College (for example, about the modes --
remote, in person, mixed -- in which our classes will be taught next semester) on very
short notice. Major budget cutbacks are looming, in the Libraries for example, but not
just there. We anticipate a poor academic job market for our graduate students this year.
And campus and town just seem so ..... quiet. Being able to do all my work from home is,
on the one hand, a privilege and time-saver yet it also makes 'community building'
within our department harder, to say the least. At times I feel isolated but otherwise I'm
grateful to be 'in the mix,' 'in the room where it happens' (to quote from _Hamilton_).
And it heartens me to try to be helpful, to work with students and colleagues to help
them achieve goals, to move the department forward, hopefully, even in these stressful,
straitened circumstances. And even while combating cancer. Maybe I'm like Paris,
according to her motto: Fluctuat nec mergitur/She is tossed by the waves, but does not
sink.
I certainly felt tossed by a 'wave' today at 6:20 a.m., when I dragged myself out of bed
the morning after teaching my three-hour seminar (when I usually let myself sleep just a
bit later) to commence what turned out to be a six-hour stretch of tests (and prep for
them)  -- my mid-cycle check to see if/how the chemo is working. I've already found out,
via Dr. Patel, that this morning's echocardiogram shows "normal cardiac function." Thank
heavens, as there was always the risk, while slim, that this combo of chemo drugs could
damage my heart. I see (just now) that the results of my PET scan are in as well, but I'm
way too nervous to look at them, and I often need the results translated into laywoman's
terms, and interpreted for me (is cancer making quick work of me? or do I have reason to
feel encouraged?). For this brief moment, ignorance is bliss. I'll wait until tomorrow to
have Dr. Patel (and perhaps Dr. Beavis, if I can get her the imaging tomorrow) parse the
scan results for me. Amazingly, I had a bit of energy to work when I got home, and will
do the same tomorrow while taking it fairly easy (easily?).
                       533 / 1.901
Overall, I'm feeling pretty well. Energy level is good. My stomach continues to be 'wonky'
-- the new normal after removal of two pieces of my colon and two of my small intestine?
My hair has grown back -- curly! It's healthy-feeling.
I needed a day to recharge last weekend so I took all of Saturday off -- took a lovely
walk/talk in the arboretum (pic attached) w/my friend Maria followed by dinner at Barrel
21 (the long, relaxing gab fest did me a lot of good). Sunday I visited with my friends Mar
and Jessica in their beautiful backyard, then enjoyed lunch on Monday (a generally
'laboring' Labor Day for me) with my friend Kathryn in the peaceful outdoor oasis of the
Ale House. It's imperative for my sanity -- and being the extrovert that I am -- that I see
friends 'in the flesh' (outdoors and masked for the most part) from time to time -- no
avatars, no icons, no simulacra. Real people, the best kind.

  by Willa Silverman, September 10, 2020  
Thrilled to share the news below - "encouraging," indeed! Thank you, potentially heart-
damaging, nausea- , neuropathy- and body ache-inducing yet ultimately life- sustaining
toxins for doing your work! I've been granted yet another 'reprieve,' and though chemo
continues (next week in fact), I am breathing a bit easier and even allowing myself to

I reviewed your PET-CT scan done on 9/9/2020:
- Previously noted right pelvic lymph node showed interval decrease in the size and
metabolic activity. Now it is measuring around 7 mm. (It was around 1.2 x 0.8 cm in the
previous imaging study). More importantly activity has gone down significantly, SUV
was around 12.3 earlier, now it is around 4.25 suggest good response with the
chemotherapy.
- Previously noted metabolic focus close to the right hepatic hilum is no longer seen.
- No other new suspicious findings noted anywhere else.
Overall encouraging PET-CT scan findings noted. Will go over with her regarding the
images when I see you on 9/17/2020.
Nilesh A. Patel, MD
Hematology/Oncology

September 17, 2020 - Four down, two - or five? - to go
  by Willa Silverman, September 17, 2020  
Chemo went smoothly today. My kindhearted neighbor Janis drove me to the Geisinger
medical offices before 8:30, and my equally kindhearted, dear friend Helen picked me up
at 1:15, Meyers mocha chip milkshake in hand (love to have the cool, creamy goodness
massage my insides, the chips providing just the right amount of texture, and by 1:15 I
was hungry!). Per routine, I had blood taken, then headed downstairs to Dr. Patel's. Per
my own private ritual, I haven't yet looked too closely at my bloodwork numbers (if they
had been out of whack Dr. Patel would have cancelled today's chemo treatment),
including my telltale CA125 number. Frankly, it takes a lot of mental/physical energy for
me just to gear up for chemo, so I'll hope that Dr. Patel will share the numbers and his
interpretation of them tomorrow. Vitals all fine, thankfully. Dr. Patel showed me the
imaging from my last two PET scans and I could see that cancerous activity in the two
areas of concern - a lymph node in my pelvic area and on the exterior of my liver -- has
decreased. I asked whether the same holds true for the colon, which had been identified
to me as the primary area of recurrence; he told me that the colon is harder to see on
the PET-scan but since activity in the other areas has decreased he presumes the same
holds true for the colon. No other cancerous areas noted, specifically in the lungs and/or
the bones -- which would be bad news.
Of course, he reiterated to me - when I queried him on this - that eliminating all the
cancer cells is virtually impossible. They are lurking and will continue to do so. So that's
the less good news. But the better news is that I'm feeling generally pretty well, my
                       538 / 1.901
energy is good (put in a 10-hour work day the other day), and this treatment appears to
be effective -- so much so, in fact, that Dr. Patel may propose three more rounds of it
after I finish the six initially prescribed. Past nine rounds, he says that I may start to
experience a worsening of my neuropathy -- already bad in my toes, which feel numb all
the time (leading to a fall in Jan. resulting in a broken ankle), but thank goodness not in
my fingers, essential 'tools' for my work. He'll talk to Dr. Beavis and I'll see what kind of
plan they come up with. I trust them. Dr. Patel now seems much warmer towards me --
we joked about how he's a terrible typist because his father encouraged him to learn
languages instead and I learned that both his parents live with him and his family.
"You're doing very well," were his parting words.
The Benadryl drip made me so tired today that, without the benefit of morning coffee to
boot, I dozed during chemo, which wasn't unpleasant. My favorite nurse, Tracy, took
good care of me, and we chatted about the challenges of online teaching/learning for her
two high-school aged sons and my own graduate students. And I had an additional 'mini-
snooze' when I got home, then went to a local farm stand to pick up some Honeycrisp
apples (my favorite) to make chicken salad (from the chicken soup I made last night),
plums (I'm thinking compote), zucchini (to stuff sometime soon) and a decorative
pumpkin. On the way home I stopped at Lupita's a great local, authentic Mexican joint in
a Unimart, to pick up some paletas (ice pops in enticing flavor like walnut and coconut).
I've spent the past few hours answering/writing work emails.
My French colleague and friend Dominique Kalifa took his own life a few days ago, on his
63rd birthday. Devastating, shocking news. He had written a chillingly elliptic message --
"Au Revoir" - on his Facebook and Twitter accounts right beforehand (like others, I
imagined he was taking a social media break). A renowned, pathbreaking historian, he
was always incredibly generous to me, inviting me to speak in his seminar at the
Sorbonne and to contribute an essay to his last edited volume; writing a long review of
my latest book in the French mass daily newspaper, Libération; and taking time to
brainstorm with me about my research. He was brilliant, charming, and had a wonderful
ability to federate colleagues from all over the world in a spirit of professional and
human exchange. Conjecture about the cause of his suicide has been making the rounds
among my friends/colleagues; no need to repeat it here. In trying to have even the
dimmest idea of 'why' -- from the outside he seemed to lead a charmed life, full of
worldwide travel, friends, prestigious acknowledgements of his work etc. -- I know that I
too, have at certain points in my life, have experienced so much psychic pain that I
simply wanted it to *stop.* I've also had to make a few decisions (fortunately not many)
that I *knew* were going to hurt the people I loved most, yet I willfully chose to put my
own needs first. Given my own life situation right now, though, it is at the same time
very difficult for me to understand Dominique's act (this being said, I certainly do *not*
judge it). I'm fighting to stay alive, and am doing just about everything in my power to
*will(a)* both maximal quantity and quality of life. A strong survival instinct seems
hardwired in me right now (and in me generally, I would say...). And the love and support
                       539 / 1.901
of family and friends is, in itself, more than enough to keep me firmly *here.* Of course, I
may/might evaluate this differently when/if I get to a very bleak point medically. But I'm
nowhere near there. So I keep on fighting. "Reviens très vite parmi nous" ("Come back to
us [in Paris] very quickly") Dominique wrote me when I emailed him about my cancer.
Caring words. I wish I could say the same to him, but I can't.
On a more positive note, I was delighted to welcome Vinni, my bff from graduate school
(and Professor of French at Wellesley College), to my graduate seminar Tuesday night
for a most interesting Zoom talk. We have strongly intersecting research interests, as we
have had since grad school at NYU, and we've collaborated on many conference panels
and publications over the years. It was so much fun to team up with my friend of nearly
40 years again. "We have to carry on the torch," I wrote her after Dominique's death.
And now Ben has started his M.S. program at NYU. The circle of life. Round like the round
challah I hope will arrive from Zabar's tomorrow in time for erev Rosh Hashanah
tomorrow night (yes, I splurged big time on some 'the real deal' eats). 
I will try to write another update tomorrow. 
Thanks for your well wishes, everyone.
Love, Willa

September 18, 2020 - Happy birthday to the world
  by Willa Silverman, September 18, 2020  
This is the second New Year I've been able to welcome in since my "alive day" last May. 
So -- and because I'm a bit rushed right now getting ready for the holiday -- I will, for the
first time, post a 'reprint' from last 29 September. So much has changed since then.
COVID has upended our lives - irrevocably? My mother and I have enjoyed many a Rosh
Hashanah here together: she comes up to State College, we cook up a storm, go to
services followed by a nice lunch, then tashlich, marked by a pleasant stroll in Walnut
Creek Park with other congregants. This year I'm solo -- I'm sad to be without my family,
but I'm ok. And traditions must continue! Last year, as I recall, I felt very worn out (I was
undergoing my first course of chemo) but still managed to whip up a brisket with
pomegranate sauce. This year I'm feeling stronger -- undergoing "second line" treatment
for a recurrence, but I seem to be responding quite well. No hair loss, better energy,
working full time. I had chemo yesterday but still had ample energy to make chicken
soup, honey cakes and a plum compote w/vanilla and cardamon. For the rest of the meal
I splurged and ordered a big boxload of goodies from Zabar's -- matzah balls, chopped
liver, herring in cream sauce, noodle pudding, gefilte fish and a round challah (a lovely
fellow congregant also brought me a round challah today - so kind of her).  I think I'll
dress cute, putting on a new skirt I ordered from Anne-Elisabeth in Paris, my favorite
shop for clothes.  At 8 I'll Zoom into services w/my congregation; ditto for tomorrow
morning. And if I have the energy (I often go into a post-chemo crash after two days), I'll
perform tashlich beside one of our pretty local streams.  I hope I can make it.
I am fine. And I received the good news this morning that my CA125 level has dropped
two more points, to 17 from 19 - still trending in a good direction. I think I'll have a glass
of wine to celebrate the birthday of the world. Let's hope for a better 5781 than the year
before. We need it.
Blessings to all.
Last year's post:
Today is the birthday of the world, Jewish tradition teaches, a time of renewal and hope
for the year ahead. We've fully entered the month of elul, which coincides with early
autumn, and the "Days of Awe:" Rosh Hashanah, on which our fate for the new year is
written, and Yom Kippur, on which it is is sealed. Our lives are depicted as being in the
balance during these days before the 'gates close:' "who shall live to a ripe old age and
                       541 / 1.901
who shall lie dying on a bed of pain?" It's an existential state; we're truly 'on the narrow
bridge.' We beat our chests as we catalog the sins that we've been guilty of the past
year. Yet we are told that teshuvah (repentence or return), tefillah (prayer) and tzedakah
(charity) can temper the harshness of God's decree.
Having had to confront my own mortality over the past few months, the spiritual side of
my journey has come into fuller relief, including during the holidays. I'll welcome the
opportunity at dinner tonight, while blessing a round challah, symbol of the cycle of life,
and later at services, to tap into feelings of hopefulness, renewal, and immanence. To
Emily Dickinson, hope is "the thing with feathers-/That perches in the soul-" that can be
heard in "the chillest land-/And on the strangest Sea-" I've indeed felt glimmers of hope
in the 'chillest land' and 'strangest Sea' where I've found myself struggling over the past
few months. As for my fate, it surely lies somewhere at the intersection of the designs of
some nasty, aggressive, microscopic cancer cells, the skills of my medical team, and my
own fighting spirit. 
I am spiritual, yet agnostic. I apologize if this offends any believers who may be reading
this. But I do firmly believe in the manifestation of 'godly' qualities in people, animals,
and nature, whether it be loving kindness, graciousness, mercifulness, or compassion. I
have seen these attributes displayed time and time again since my diagnosis, whether
through friends coming to spend time with me, text or call me, send me thoughtful gifts,
volunteer to do errands for me, cook for me, drive me to Baltimore, or just 'hold space'
for me. It is quite wondrous. 
It is a wonderful holiday this year because my mother and Ben are here. My mother and I
have been cooking up a storm; I'm not quite sure how I managed to pull it off as at the
beginning of the week I was completely wiped out from chemo, but I was searing brisket
and frying onions in pomegranate molasses early this morning. I was hoping that Ben
might take some interest in the holiday cooking (he certainly does in the eating), as I'm
not sure who will continue the culinary traditions after my mother and me.

September 21, 2020 - Rolling in the deep (again)
  by Willa Silverman, September 21, 2020  
                       543 / 1.901
                       544 / 1.901
As I often do, I marshaled all my strength, put on a cute outfit, jewelry and makeup, and 
donned my game face for the holiday, which I willed into pleasantness and some
semblance of normalcy. By Saturday, my post-chemo crash was in high gear, per usual:
exhaustion, nausea, headache, stomach ache (beginning of a stomach blockage? hope
not -- two hospitalizations on that score were more than enough for me), entire body
sensitive to the touch (and not in a good way; pained me even to touch my head lightly).
Every time I walked past my bed, it seemed, I had to crash, missing out on most of some
beautiful days. Ditto Sunday, although the fatigue and feeling crappy became layered
over w/stress as I dug into my heavy workload for the week. Today's just slightly better.
The body aches are not as intense, but I've had a headache all day and nausea that
caused some vomiting, which actually made me feel better. Chicken soup is the only
food that appeals. Luckily I was able to cry my eyes out to my therapist online - combo of
feeling crappy, work stress, being physically alone for the holiday, social media overload
following RBG's death, and pandemic-induced isolation all feel overwhelming today. 
When I say that chemo 'went well,' what I mean by that is that I had no repeat of the
horrifying allergic reaction that sent my blood pressure and heart rate plummeting a few
treatments ago, as my chest constricted rapidly. It means that I succeeded in
summoning the psychic energy to allow toxins to penetrate my body for several hours. It
means that I accept that the treatment is melting away some cancer cells but leaving
others lurking, to cause their ravaging damage at will. It means I didn't spend all night
vomiting into a trash can.
Please understand the herculean effort involved in being a cancer patient, especially as I
try to do a credible job with my work, my mothering, being a friend, and with all the
other things I do. Even for one as practiced as myself in 'pulling it all off' artfully and
graciously, it's not easy by any means.

September 27, 2020 - My soul in the balance
  by Willa Silverman, September 27, 2020  
Who shall live and who shall die,
Who shall reach the end of his days and who shall not,
Who shall perish by water and who by fire,
Who by sword and who by wild beast,
Who by famine and who by thirst,
Who by earthquake and who by plague,
Who by strangulation and who by stoning,
Who shall have rest and who shall wander,
Who shall be at peace and who shall be pursued,
Who shall be at rest and who shall be tormented,
Who shall be exalted and who shall be brought low,
Who shall become rich and who shall be impoverished.
I don't have time to write at length as I'd like to, as I'm readying for Kol Nidre, but this core prayer from the
Yom Kippur liturgy has of course had special resonance for me the past two holidays, and it has always seemed
ominous to me. My life's in the balance tonight. Call me a bad Jew, though, but I know it can't all be in God's
                       551 / 1.901
hands (those cancer cells have a mind of their own). And while we're taught that study of Torah/prayer,
repentance, and charity can temper God's harsh decree, I'm hoping that living a virtuous, meaningful life
defined in my own terms will be its own reward. On this day of atonement, though, I did write a friend who I
know I hurt recently through my words and actions. I'm hoping they'll realize that my intentions were good, but
that I mishandled a delicate situation and acted maladroitly. The blessing is that they told me I had hurt them,
paving the way for a not entirely pleasant but productive path back towards one another.
Who shall live and who shall die? While I've had a not great week health-wise -- something if off w/my
digestion and a nearly a week of a liquid diet has not seemed to help so I'll be calling my doctors again
tomorrow -- my gut (no pun intended) tells me that I'll still be here next year. Again, not to take anything away
from the Almighty but rather just acknowledging the realistic odds and my recent good response to this round of
chemo. I won't be fasting, of course (although in essence I am!), because of my health, but I'll still hope to clear
out a good mental space for contemplation over the next day and a half.
More when I have time. Now where did I put my tallit?

October 1, 2020 - Wrestling with Angels
  by Willa Silverman, October 1, 2020  
                       553 / 1.901
I'm just emerging from what I hope is a health blip (and nothing worse), which
nevertheless landed me in the ER for most of Tuesday. I had mentioned, I believe, that
since a few days after my last chemo treatment, my intestines and stomach had been
feeling 'wonky,' as they often do.  I'm sure it's somehow related to the lingering issues
from this past March's fistula repair surgery. The symptoms are not pleasant, but they
felt reminiscent of my three previous intestinal blockages, two of which resulted in
hospital stays and one of which I was able to resolve on my own by observing a liquid
diet and massaging my abdomen. On Dr. Beavis' advice I recommenced a liquid diet,
which didn't really seem to alleviate the symptoms. Further, I began to feel quite weak
from not eating (although I tried to ingest some high-calorie liquids like milkshakes) and 
quickly dropped about six pounds. I also had agonizing leg and foot cramps at night,
from being dehydrated (even though I was drinking as much as I could) and low on
potassium. One night the cramps woke me up about once an hour -- torturous. Each time
I had to do some combination of walking around, applying a heating pad, and massaging
the cramped area until the cramp(s) resolved. By the time the last cramp shot me out of
bed at around 6 a.m. I was so exhausted and in so much pain that I broke into a cold
sweat, vomited a few times, and just crumpled on my bed, with that Carrie Underwood
country song going through my head: "Jesus, take the wheel." Je n'en pouvais plus.
Monday I called my PCP, Dr. Damaske, hoping he could see me, but he was also booked.
I also called Dr. Beavis, who said she'd place an order for me to have an abdominal X-
ray. The order wasn't ready when I called Hopkins and in fact was never emailed to me.
The next morning, my PCP's office called to see how I was doing and to say that Dr.
Damaske suggested I go immediately to the ER (which Dr. Patel had suggested as well),
to make sure I didn't have a blockage (which needless to say, if it bursts, can be
extremely serious). I powered through an important monthly meeting of deans and
department heads, to be followed by a second department heads meeting for our School
of Global Languages, Literatures and Cultures. By the time I got to that meeting and was
telling one of my colleagues (also a cancer survivor) that I wasn't feeling great, he and
the other school heads began urging me to skip our meeting and go straight to the ER.
So I did.
My kind neighbor Janis drove me to the ER. I had packed a bag with a few days' worth of
clothes and my laptop, as I fully expected to be admitted for a blockage and was
anticipating having an NG (gastric) tube inserted. I had hoped to avoid the ER like the
plague because they have been treating COVID patients. The young doctor (I could
swear he was the doctor who broke the news of a malignancy to me when I dragged
myself to the ER last Easter Sunday), nurses and techs took good care of me and
administered all the tests (EKG, blood, vitals, urine etc.). To my great relief, based on the
scans taken in the ER I do *not* have a blockage: there is some colitis and a potential
intestinal infection (don't have the results on that yet). And some of my symptoms
remain puzzling to me. I am seeing my PCP next Tuesday -- he's a compassionate guy
who gave me his personal cell phone number when he learned I had cancer, in case I
                       554 / 1.901
need to contact him quickly. I hope we can puzzle through some of the symptoms
together. Maybe I need to further rethink my diet (have been reading recipes for cancer
smoothies). Maybe I need a reset of some kind. Maybe my digestive system is not
absorbing certain nutrients well, or correctly Surely I was burnt out from not eating, so I
feel tired and find myself needing some extra sleep. So...much...uncertainty. Cancer
sucks.
To my regret, because I am ultra-conscientious when it comes to work, I had to cancel
Tuesday night's grad seminar as I didn't think I'd be home in time to Zoom (I wasn't).
We've already figured out a plan for moving forward. Equally to my regret, I did arrive
home in time to watch the debate aka horror show aka assault aka Trump unhinged,
while sipping soup and trying to relax (not the best plan). I.can't.even. Grotesque bully.
Shameless demon. Ominous boor. Asshole. I was still shaking the next morning.
Last night my dear friend Maria spontaneously invited me to join her for a bite, so we
headed to one of our favorite spots, Barrel 21 (it's a distillery). We sat outside in their
patio area on a chilly night, but we were kept toasty with big outdoor heaters, the kind
that make Paris cafés so pleasurable in the winter. Our friend John joined us for a while.
Various immune system-compromising medical issues are keeping him holed up in a
barn on his property, while his wife and one son sleep in the main house and the other
son quarantines at his grandmother's because he's daily exposed to other college
students. How dramatically COVID affects the fabric of our social and familial relations. I
ate something very mild and enjoyed a delicious fruit-juice based, healthy 'mocktail,'
prepared by B21's bartender extraordinaire, Josh. So very grateful to be back from the
precipice enjoying the evening with friends.
Thank you, Jackie, for your many kindnesses including cancelling your dentist's
appointment so you could drive me home from the hospital! Thank you, Ben, Ethan and
Mom for your care and concern. Be well, everyone.

times. Your friends love you! Xoxo

October 10, 2020 - Rebounding (yet again)
  by Willa Silverman, October 10, 2020  
                       557 / 1.901
                       558 / 1.901
Because my last report was so grim, I wanted to write briefly to assure everyone that I'm
doing much better. My digestion seems to have returned to semi-normal (or as normal as
it ever gets for me), I'm eating sensibly, and I regained the few pounds I dropped
precipitously during the week I went on liquids. I had an appointment with my PCP this
past week and he prescribed a daily dose of potassium (my level is within normal range
but on the lower side), a daily probiotic, and an another appointment with a nutritionist,
this one specializing in both cancer patients and digestive issues. I will follow up.
Meanwhile, it was a busy week at school with some big projects starting to pile up.
Seminar went quite well (always a pleasure to teach about the Dreyfus Affair, so
relevant...) and I led a faculty meeting and attended a host of other meetings etc. So
very grateful for my rewarding, secure job yet undoubtedly we're traversing a difficult
period in academia, as in so many other fields: the job market for our graduate students
seems bleak this year; our library has been hit with v. significant budget cuts targeting
the humanities in particular (this occasioned pushback in the form of a letter to the
Provost from the humanities' department heads); Penn State IT abruptly laid off thirty
employees; some colleagues (and especially female ones) who are balancing work
w/overseeing their kids' remote learning seemed totally maxed out; etc. We have a
wonderful, empathic dean in Liberal Arts who is  trying to keep us all afloat and moving
forward as best he can, but he's stressed too. We all are.
Given all this -- ie the strains and just plain weirdness of the moment, the dismaying
national backdrop etc. -- in addition to my health challenges, I try to be extra gentle with
myself to the extent possible. This morning I went to the farmers market with my friend
Helen. I started to feel momentarily light-headed (a 'thing' that can happen to me
sometimes when I'm dehydrated or have a slight stomach ached) but rebounded after
sitting down for a while. Then treated myself to a manicure at a local day spa, followed
by clothes shopping (bought one top) and then a mocha chip ice cream cone from
Meyers Dairy. Yesterday, I enjoyed a lovely lunch outdoors at the Ale House with my
friend/former colleague Kathryn, then moved on to my hair stylist's (my hair continues to
grow out but is unruly because of the haphazard way it's come back in). Tomorrow,
weather permitting, I'll walk a few loops at the Boalsburg Military Museum with a group
of wonderful women (these monthly walks grew out of the ovarian cancer fundraiser I
organized this past June). Then back to work and prepping for a week of meetings, with
big admin tasks to tackle.
Chemo this Wednesday, undoubtedly followed by up to a week of feeling like crap. As
long as I don't wind up in the ER again. 
Currently have two women facing cancer (one at the beginning of her journey, one
towards the end) in my prayers.
                       559 / 1.901
If all goes as planned, Ben and Sammi will come home for Thanksgiving. I miss them.
Michael and I are trying to coordinate a joint family meal, as we did last year (pre-Covid),
but of course it's challenging as not everyone's been 'podding' together all along and
there's a certain amount of risk involved. So it's possible we might have to have two
dinners on consecutive nights, one with each family unit. I'm also sorry I can't go to NY
and celebrate with my mother and Arnold, Ethan and his family, but that too is risky right
now. Complicated times (sigh). Meanwhile, there's a new Borat movie to look forward to!
Let's get our laughs when and where we can.

Horizons
  by Willa Silverman, October 15, 2020  
Chemo went smoothly yesterday. Dr. Patel was not there as he's getting board
recertified this week, but the nurses took good care of me. My favorite nurse, Tracey,
                       561 / 1.901
administered my treatment and I was further delighted to see that another very kind
nurse (Brianne), who had come to my home several times as a visiting nurse, is now also
working in oncology. The chemo room was bustling but as soon as I was pumped full of
Benadryl I started to doze, which was actually quite relaxing. A new chemo room will be
opening in January. It will be sparkling new, with spiffy recliners, new equipment and -
best of all - windows (sorely lacking in the current configuration). At that point, I am not
sure what my chemo status will be. I may be taking oral chemo exclusively. But it's nice
to know of this improvement. Being in a windowless environment during chemo,
especially on a lovely fall day, is dispiriting.
My dear friend Helen drove me to chemo, and passed along a yummy brownie that one
of her daughters had kindly thought to share with me. My equally dear neighbor Janis
picked me up and we stopped at Meyer Dairy so I could get a mocha chip malted
milkshake. So comforting, such a cooling treat.
Today I was slightly deflated to learn that my CA125 number had increased ever so
slightly, from 17.5 to 17.7. Both Dr. Beavis' and Dr. Patel's nurses urged me NOT to
worry about this, though, insisting it is considered stable and still very much within
normal range. And Dr. Beavis' nurse did put the NOT in capitals! But of course I was
hoping for another drop - psychologically, it makes a difference. But I will try my hardest
to take it off my 'worry list' for now.
I feel ok today, slightly nauseous per usual. And I expect the very unpleasant symptoms
to hit tomorrow. Had an important meeting w/our Graduate Dean, which went well, and I
need to run and get my white blood cell booster shot now, before dinner (later) and a
Zoom meeting for my condo association at 7 p.m.
And all this on about 5 hours of sleep. Strangely, I awoke at 4 a.m. and was up for
several hours, my mind overloaded with a minutia dump -- what should I put on my
grocery list for the young woman who shops for me every week? How can I best get
organized for the meeting w/the Dean? But somehow broader horizons were opening and
constricting during this hour, as the French call it, "between chien et loup" ("between
dog and wolf;" apparently, according to a former therapist, this is the hour when most
suicides occur, but I can assure everyone that this was *nowhere* near my mind early
this morning!).
Opening horizons: a new couch I had been awaiting for several months finally arrived
and looks lovely in my sun room. Texting a friend about this arrival, I mistakenly wrote
"son room" (paging Dr. Freud, etc.), because my *son* and I have spent many hours in
the sun room over the last decade, watching t.v., talking, chilling. So I've been moving
furniture and photos around, opening up new physical (and mental?) spaces, trying to
make my home more like, in Ben's girlfriend Sammi's word, my 'oasis.'
                       562 / 1.901
And meeting (via Zoom) some new people who have led, and are leading, interesting
lives -- another horizon opening. Fascinating, complex, textured journeys -- enough to
keep me up at 4 a.m. just contemplating them!
Constricting horizons: sometimes I get griped by fear about my health. That fear was
also 'visited' upon me at 4 a.m. What's my horizon? 2 years? 5-8? 8-10? More? I read a
post this morning from an admirable seeming woman who 'friended' me on Facebook in
June but whom I've never met -- she is also treated at KGOS (Kelly Gynecological
Oncology Service at Hopkins) and we 'met' at the time of the Service's big annual
fundraiser (my #willapower turn). Her ovarian cancer has now spread into her lungs (I
worry about this too but for now it's 'just' the exterior of my colon that's affected) but
she's warrior-ing on. So many brave women fighting this accursed disease. 
Grateful today for the gorgeous fall colors, kind texts and emails from family and friends,
grateful to have plenty during this awful time (number of Americans below poverty line
has increased by 8.000.000 since May -- what becomes of them, dear God?!). Life is
good today. And that's reason enough to be grateful. Off to my condo association
meeting to talk about fall leaf collection, landscaping and other blessed mundanities. 
Be well, everyone.

October 18, 2020 - Back from the brink
  by Willa Silverman, October 18, 2020  
Thank you to all who checked in on me and/or thought about me over the weekend. I'm
always slightly amazed that I can rebound given that two days after each of my current
chemo treatments I feel like I'm succumbing to the worst flu imaginable plus an achy
lower back and abdomen. Like clockwork, on chemo day + 2 my entire body, but
especially my head and neck area, begins to feel very tender and painful to the touch,
accompanied by nausea. I simply feel *sore.* On chemo day + 3 I am completely
useless. Yesterday (when I reached the bottom of the abyss,) I slept until about 11 a.m.,
then had barely enough energy to drag myself to the couch, where I spent the rest of the
day, dozing and later watching some t.v., pumped up with anti-nausea meds, Claritin to
counteract bone pain, and Ibuprofen. I felt sad and slightly depressed not being able to
enjoy the gorgeous autumn day but knew I simply had to renounce any plans
whatsoever. Admittedly, my new couch is very comfy and I was cozily wrapped in a
lovely pashima shawl (a gift from my friend Melissa - I owe you a thank you!), with a
heating pad plopped on my stomach. My friend Helen was kind enough to bring 'Jewish
penicillin' aka chicken soup, plus apple cider, Hagen-Dazs vanilla ice cream and some
tasty feta/caramelized onion appetizer bites from Trader Joe's, out of which I concocted a
small meal last night (although I hardly ate much at all during the day, perhaps one
yogurt). Drifted in and out through the day, the sun washing over me, knowing that the
only way out of this painful morass was through. Might have benefited from some psalms
or other 'inspirational' literature (encouraging fortune cookies?) but scarcely had the
energy to lift a book, iPad or even iPhone. Geez, I sure hope these super-strong drugs
are at least melting away more cancer cells. And next round *may* be my last before a
scan and then (?) oral chemo (parp inhibitors). I need to get the lowdown from Beavis
and Patel.
Slept deeply and at length again, my father appeared in my dream, which rarely if ever
happens - we were in disagreement about something. Miraculously, feel today like I'm
just starting to round the bend, was able to sit at my desk and work for a while, while still
feeling worn out. Took a little drive (while I was absorbed with my pain, somehow late
fall seems to have made an early-ish arrival). Hoping for more improvement tomorrow,
as the work week begins. Much to do. The couch may be calling my name again this
                       564 / 1.901
evening.
Thank you, Jackie, for the mocha chip malted milkshake and good cheer, to Ben, Ethan
and mom for frequent check-ins, to Michael for texting a photo of a huge "Vote Him Out"
sign in our neighborhood (yes, that did lift my spirits!), to Mar and Jessi, Clare, Monique,
Vinni, Julie,  Mary, Melissa and a few other pals for checking in.  It really helps. Illness can
be so isolating. But I got my tribe!

October 30, 2020 - Rainy Days and Fridays...
  by Willa Silverman, October 30, 2020  
                       566 / 1.901
                       567 / 1.901
Everything's ok. It's been a busy week, and I've worked hard, so am treating myself to
Thai takeout tonight (mildly flavored dishes) and an evening curled up on the couch
watching t.v.  -- my reward for six hours straight of zoom meetings today. The meetings
were not uninteresting: first, an annual four-hour meeting with the other heads of Big
Ten foreign language departments to discuss our common concerns (many, given the
circumstances; COVID + the xenophobic policies of the current administration are having
dire effects on academic institutions) and brainstorm solutions. Then a long department
meeting that I organized with a facilitator present to begin discussing a host of issues
related to DEI (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion) as they affect our department. The meetings
required much focus and mental and emotional energy>I'm beat!
I am feeling alright. I get fatigued, but you probably wouldn't know it observing what I
sometimes accomplish in a day or week, including teaching a three-hour seminar every
Tuesday night. And my digestive system still has a mind (or stomach) of its own. I am
meeting again with a nutritionist next week. I've woken up a few nights with leg cramps
but I've also enjoyed some delightful sleeps. Next chemo on Nov. 12th. After that round
there will certainly be a scan. I'm not sure what follows, perhaps some oral
chemotherapy (parp inhibitors).
This morning, for some reason, I made the mistake of reverifying the prognoses for
ovarian cancer, which I hadn't done in awhile. According the American Cancer Society,
the five-year survival rate is 50%. Full stop. I don't know how the effect of my already
having had one recurrence inflects this statistic; I do remember Dr. Beavis telling me
that she felt my recurrence was a bit anomalous, perhaps related to the host of fistula-
related problems I experienced earlier this year. She has also told me that part of my
cancer (the 'sarcoma' part I suppose) is particularly aggressive. Conversely, statistics for
Hopkins patients, I was told (also by Dr. Beavis) may look somewhat better than the
averages. I took this info into the shower with me and had a good cry, coupled with an
anxiety attack. Then I put on a nice blouse, a cute hairband, and some make-up and
went about my meetings. Yet those numbers stick in my throat. On which side of the
50% will I fall? I *do* know long-term survivors (but were their cancers as aggressive as
mine?). Given my potentially shortened life expectancy, should I be going about my
business as usual? Or hitting my bucket list? Ok for me to have Thai take-out or should
the entirety of my nutrition be geared towards starving those cancer cells in any way I
can? I think I'm generally taking good care of myself, but can I do more? Trade-offs.
Uncertainty. Anxiety. Ugh. "You must go on. I can't go on. I'll go on."
I look forward to a relatively low-key week-end although I'll need to turn to work by
Sunday, if not before. I foresee some soup-making (butternut squash bisque and creamy
tomato tortellini). Trying to puzzle through the challenge of how to see my friends safely
now that it's turning colder. Ugh.
                       568 / 1.901
Awaiting Tuesday with trepidation. Will vote on 'the day,'  braving a long line if
necessary. Fingers crossed, folks, that the end of our four-year national nightmare may
be in sight.
Today this picture of my favorite mummy made me smile. This was the one 'homemade'
costume I ever ventured to make for Ben, and it was a success (although requiring yards
and yards of gauze!). I always felt somewhat 'mom-shamed' by all the incredible
handmade costumes I saw kids sporting on Halloween but this one made me feel at least
somewhat vindicated! Ben was having so much fun trying to look 'spooky!'

November 12, 2020 - The best laid plans...
  by Willa Silverman, November 12, 2020  
                       570 / 1.901
                       571 / 1.901
I couldn't receive my chemo this morning, as planned. My blood work revealed that my
hemoglobin level is very low (7.6; normal for women is 12.0 to 15.3 grams per liter).
Apparently, my level has been trending downwards for the past several months.
Apparently too, this is a fairly common effect of chemo. Dr. Patel's concern was that if he
treated me, my hemoglobin level might drop so low that I'd need, in his words, "a bag of
blood." He ordered another lab test to determine whether my low hemoglobin level is
due to the chemo or, rather, to an iron deficiency (from diet, for example). If it's due to
chemo, he can give me an infusion of iron through my port. If it's due to diet, I guess I
need to eat more iron rich foods or maybe take an iron supplement. He seemed to
hesitate about whether we should go ahead with treatment today or wait a week
because, as I pointed out, there's no guarantee that in a week's time my hemoglobin
level will have risen if the trend has been downwards for several months. In the end,
though, he said: "Let's play it safe." Part of me wanted to insist a bit about receiving
treatment today because waiting a week means that I'll barely be starting to rebound for
Thanksgiving, Ben and Sammi's long awaited visit, and a whole mess of holiday cooking
I've been anticipating (with pleasure). Now I have to rethink my cooking schedule and I'll
surely need to enlist the kids' help. Oh well. Is it what it is. The best laid plans, yadda
yadda...
The next problem was getting me on the schedule for next week. Everyone wants to
have her/his chemo finished before the holiday. I scheduled for next Thursday morning
(the only available time), knowing that this means I'll have to miss a fairly important
meeting. Perhaps it can be Zoom-recorded for me. There was a moment when I started
to feel overwhelmed -- between the difficulty scheduling the appointment to uncertainty
about whether I need to go back to the lab for another blood test to being unsure how I
would get home from Dr. Patel's office as my friend Helen had kindly driven me there to
feeling upset that I couldn't receive treatment today. I sunk down onto a bench in Dr.
Patel's office and my eyes started stinging with tears, but I regained composure pretty
quickly. I called my neighbor, Janis, and she was able to pick me up. We immediately
launched into chat about how happy we were with the election results (she said her
pastor had delivered an ambiguous sermon about the results, as most of her fellow
parishioners are Trumpiacs...).
Well, now I may better understand why I felt so winded this past weekend on walks with
my friends Chris (Saturday) and Mary, Jackie and Clare (Sunday). And why I've generally
been feeling very tired recently (I had chalked it up to work stress and the effects of
having pushed through twelve weeks of the semester without a break). And perhaps why
I was craving a hamburger this morning (I did, indeed, treat myself to a delicious, juicy
hamburger with sweet potato fries for lunch!).
It remains frustrating and stressful for me to cope with things beyond my control, like
                       572 / 1.901
today's false start. As for my future treatment, that too remains unclear for the moment,
although the likelihood is that I'll be put on maintenance therapy, ie oral chemo that will
hopefully, I suppose, keep my cancer in check and has been shown to have success with
patients like me who have both had a recurrence and do not have the BRCA mutation
(remember that my cancer is the result of a random, non-inherited mutation, the [bad]
luck of the genetic draw...). I asked Dr. Patel how long I would need that treatment and
he said he really couldn't tell me. It will depend on how I respond, to be assessed
through periodic scans and bloodwork. So...much...uncertainty. The "oh great" news with
these parp inhibitors (the equivalent of my current treatment's causing heart damage in
a small number of patients) is that it can adversely affect bone marrow, also in a limit
number of patients. 
I am, as always, so grateful for the well wishes, offers of food, cards and many other
kindnesses that come my way before (and often during and after!) each treatment. They
really lift my spirits and help me warrior on. Yet I felt so wiped out when I got home
around noon -- again perhaps the effect of the low red blood cell count + a very busy
Monday-Wednesday at work + the anxiety around the blip this morning -- that I had to
nap/rest a good part of the afternoon. Feeling a bit better now, still tired.
Also: my hair continues to morph as it grows in. I saw my stylist, Sarah, yesterday
(below) and she did a good job. I'm also experimenting with scarves and turbans. And
makeup works wonders. I bought a lot of new clothes the other day. I try to convince
myself that if I look ok, I'm ok. Magical thinking, I know, but it works at least some of the
time.
 
p.s. **I do need to retain that Dr. Patel said I've done well with this treatment. At least as
of last month, my CA125 number was in the normal range (I'll likely have this month's
results tomorrow). That is a good thing indeed.
God grant me the serenity
to accept the things I cannot change;
courage to change the things I can;
and wisdom to know the difference.
Living one day at a time;
enjoying one moment at a time.
                       573 / 1.901

November 14, 2020 - Playing it safe
  by Willa Silverman, November 14, 2020  
I've often found 'playing it safe' challenging, much like 'adulting' in general, sometimes.
Yet these strange COVID times, compounded by my immunocompromised state, demand
it. So Dr. Patel decided we should 'play it safe' by delaying my chemo one week. Here's
the update since then: additional blood tests revealed *no* deficiencies in iron, folic acid
and B12. So what's the deal with my severe anemia? Blame the chemo, Dr. Beavis wrote
me. It kills both (bad) cancer cells and (good) red blood cells. Likely no amount of
oatmeal with raisins, salmon, dried and fresh pineapple, spinach and calves liver (all of
which I've eaten or will eat within the next few days) will boost my red blood cell count
significantly, although it can't hurt. Nor will an infusion of iron. So we have to hope that
an extra week off from chemo will allow my body a bit more time to rebound. Crossing
my fingers that my treatment can proceed as (re)planned this coming Thursday.
CA125 number is 18.2. Over the past three months, it's inched upwards from 17.2 to
17.5 to 18.2, but is still well within the normal range of 0-35. Dr. Patel's nurse considers
                       578 / 1.901
it 'stable.' This is good news (my bad memory of my o.c. marker trending upwards before
I was diagnosed with a recurrence is still very much with me, but I'm presuming this
small an increase is still deemed negligible). Drs. Patel and Beavis conferred by phone
the other day and here's the plan: I'll have the final round of chemo, then a scan. Then
I'll have a break (not sure how long) so that my body can recoup before being started on
a parp inhibitor, ie oral chemo for 'maintenance.' This relatively new (?) treatment has
proven effective in patients (some? most?) who do *not* have the BRCA mutation but
who have had a recurrence (this is my case). I do not know how long I'll be on them nor
what the potential side effects are. I am not yet at a point where I can process that
information, especially if it contains worrisome elements (the potential for bone marrow
damage was already sufficiently anxiety-provoking, thank you very much). So I'll get
myself mentally prepared to discuss the next step with Dr. Patel (and perhaps also Dr.
Beavis) this coming week. For now I'm focused on receiving my last round of chemo and
turning the corner by Thanksgiving, after exhaustion sets in next weekend.
And in "Playing it Safe" news, Part II: I'm very disappointed that Ben and Sammi will not,
in the end, be coming home for Thanksgiving this year. All of us were starting to feel
increasingly alarmed by the rising COVID rates all over the country, and testing and
quarantining are not foolproof guarantees against infection, especially taking into
account travel, contact with new germ pools etc. The thought running through my head
recently, which I had been getting ready to share with Michael: "If anything happens to
the kids, I'll never forgive myself." So we're playing it safe. Of course, I love
Thanksgiving, revel in the cooking and sharing of my 'standards' (cranberry chutney,
sweet potato casserole, jalapeno cornbread etc.), enjoy gathering with family. This year
COVID has conspired, though, to dislocate families and ramp up a sense of familial and
social alienation. Many friends will likewise be separated from loved ones at the holidays
this year. So in 2020 we'll have a modern family meets COVID Thanksgiving with a twist:
ex-husband and I will split the cooking (Michael excels at cooking the turkey, so he's in
charge of the bird) but enjoy the feast in two different households; since I'll be physically
alone, my mother (also alone), Ben and Sammi, and I (and anyone else who wants to
join) will (hopefully) gather virtually via Zoom. We'll make it work. It truly sucks, but
COVID oblige...
I hope we'll figure out a way to get together over the December holidays. We'll see how
things are looking COVID-wise in the city and elsewhere and how I and everyone else
involved are feeling. I'm missing the city so maybe I can contemplate a visit involving/an
airbnb rental. So much of this is out of my control. We'll just roll with it.
I was feeling so overloaded by all these blips that I got in my car and started driving,
which is what I often do these days to settle myself. I headed out into the country on
winding roads, past farms, buggies, trees shedding their last autumn leaves, creeks,
farm stands -- and plenty of Trump signs, still defiant. I straightened the house, cleaned
the kitchen, and had a piece of jewelry repaired. Now it's time to pay bills (exciting,
                       579 / 1.901
huh?) and see if I can find a good flick or Netflix offering this evening. Back to work
tomorrow.
Stay safe, everyone.

November 20, 2020 - Breathe
  by Willa Silverman, November 20, 2020  
                       581 / 1.901
                       582 / 1.901
I completed my last round of IV chemo -- for now -- yesterday. Grand total: twelve rounds
with about a three+ month interval between them when I was (relatively briefly) in
remission. I am not currently in remission but at least the Beast is at bay -- for now. And
overall this second line of chemo has been effective: CA125 number is within normal
range, apparently there's been no further spread (which a CT scan on 12/9 will either
confirm or deny), my bloodwork looks ok overall (although I'm still low on potassium and
iron, despite eating calves' liver nearly every night last week, plus iron-rich oatmeal,
dried fruits, spinach etc.). I have awful neuropathy in my toes -- can hardly feel them,
and I don't expect that to dissipate. But, as my former father-in-law Seymour used to
say, mock-sighing heavily: "I'm still vertical" (actually, if chemo fatigue progresses as
usual, I expect to be horizontal for nearly the entire weekend).
Unlike last week, everything proceeded smoothly yesterday. My hemoglobin level had
increased from 7 to 8 (still low), so we proceeded with chemo. Tracey, my favorite nurse,
took good care of me. Pumped full of Benadryl, I took a snooze. The whole process takes
about five hours (including having bloodwork and then waiting for results). Dear friends
Helen and Jackie transported me to and from, Jackie bearing the ceremonial 'chemo's
done' milkshake that I crave afterwards (mocha chip with malt, so soothing...).
Since I know that I'm likely to crash tomorrow, I try to use the 1.5 days in between
chemo and crash to power through my to-do list. Yesterday and today that entailed
some holiday cooking (I returned from chemo to cook up a veritable *vat* of cranberry
chutney); putting out fires at work; other work-related emailing; scanning readings for
my grad students; picking up a prescription; throwing together a pot of chicken soup for
both myself when I'm couch potato-ing this weekend and a friend who will need some
too; getting my follow-up shot; and enjoying a glorious *outdoor* lunch with my friend
Kathryn on this 60-degree November day. All this after a wretched sleep when my mind
was spinning, consumed with petty worries about the center of my cornbread being
undercooked, the pile of dishes in my sink that needed to be washed and the dishwasher
unloaded before my housecleaner arrived, the potential overhaul of one of our core
graduate courses -- and more. Hoping for a better sleep tonight.
I treated myself to a pair of dangly Art Deco-looking earrings (via Etsy) for finishing
chemo and I might also indulge in a pair of low black suede boots.
Relieved to have a 'chemo break' for now, while my body recoups and strengthens for
the next stage. I'll see Dr. Patel on 12/17 to discuss the oral chemo that I'll take next. Dr.
Beavis says that "it's worth a try," ie we'll see how I do with it and whether I can handle
the side effects (I have chosen not to inform myself about them yet; I just need to
decompress and chill for a while before I get back on my chemo horse). The goal, as Dr.
Beavis sees it, is to maintain as good a quality of life for me as possible. If it turns out I
                       583 / 1.901
can't handle the effects -- well then, I think the plan might be to wait for the return of the
Beast, whenever It chooses to attack me again. I need to regroup and find out more
about next steps but not...just...yet.
When the drug company called me today to set up delivery of the likely medication
(Zejula) -- I told them I didn't want it delivered until I had discussed the treatment plan
w/Dr. Patel -- I initially nearly fainted of sticker shock -- something about an $1800
copay. However, I then learned that there is some sort of prescription card I'll receive
that will reduce the co-pay to... $0. And my insurance will cover the rest. What happens
to the women who are uninsured??
Sad I won't be with family this year for Thanksgiving but at least there's Zoom. We had a
lovely and delicious holiday last year at Michael and Sue's -- several of Ben's boyhood
friends dropped by for delicious pie that Ben had brought from Buttercream Bakery in DC
-- and I look forward to being reunited with family next year. 
Am also looking forward to a Zoom apéro (likely herbal tea for me) on Sunday afternoon
w/my bffs from graduate school -- Vinni, Shanny, Isabelle and Doris (in Paris) - aka "les
filles." Laughs guaranteed.
Stay well and safe, everyone, and err on the side of caution for the holiday.

November 22, 2020 - On Cue...
  by Willa Silverman, November 22, 2020  
Just a quick post to let everyone know I'm doing ok at the close of  my monthly weekend
from hell. I was certain that Saturday I'd wake up with the worst flu-like symptoms
imaginable, and as if on cue...: body aches; head, neck and back tenderness; nausea;
diarrhea; mild headache; loss of appetite; no energy etc. I went to bed Friday night by
about 11:00 and didn't get out of bed until Saturday at 4 p.m., and only then to ingest a
bowl of oatmeal, and later some homemade chicken noodle soup. Dragged myself into
bed again last night around 11 p.m. and got out of bed close to noon. I've spent the past
two days in a twilight haze -- in the gloaming. It's all about pushing through. At some
point I was on the couch watching a Netflix documentary about a gospel choir, a heating
pad plopped on my stomach.
                       586 / 1.901
I feel marginally better today and know that I'll likely start to slowly rebound tomorrow. I
did manage a long Zoom call (unfortunately I was on speakerphone as my internet was
acting out) with my grad school besties, with Doris joining us from Paris. So restorative,
so comforting, so relaxing, so much fun to catch up with these dear friends of nearly
forty years, whether we're comparing notes on our kids (we have five young men and a
young woman among us), venting about work, or trading Thanksgiving plans. The
precise topics matter less than the powerful connection.
I miss New York and my family this holiday week. The picture below was taken two years
ago in the city, after our Thanksgiving meal at an Italian (if I remember correctly)
restaurant on the UWS.  The restaurant bustled and we were all in good spirits, happy to
be together, and healthy. Who knew we'd be caught up in a maelstrom over the next
year or two? At the risk of sounding Pollyanna-ish, I'm grateful for the sweet memories
and for all these dear folks.
Thanks to those who checked in on me, brought milkshakes, and shared words of good
cheer this weekend.

November 28, 2020 - Thanksgiving memories
  by Willa Silverman, November 28, 2020  
                       588 / 1.901
                       589 / 1.901
This year's 'Zoomgiving' was more pleasant than expected. Even though I was solo, I
rallied for the holiday cooking (cranberry chutney, jalapeno corn bread, balsamic glazed
brussel sprouts, sweet potato casserole, apple crostata w/homemade whipped cream,
while Michael was kind enough to bring over some delicious turkey, which I traded him
for sides). And it was warming to zoom with Ben and Sammi, Ethan and his family, Mom
and Arnold (and Michael, briefly). Ben and Sammi cooked up a feast themselves
(featuring lamb from a Park Slope butcher) and are starting their own traditions. L'dor
vador. Physically, I was feeling ok -- I'm still quite tired from the cumulative effects of
chemo/low hemoglobin. I may even have been feeling better a year ago on the holiday
when we were at Michael and Sue's; I was undergoing chemo but had not yet had my
second operation (fistula repair). But I'm alive, and for that I'm thankful. A friend who is a
'wine person' brought over four bottles of wine for me to sample! Kind of him. I'm still
working my way through the white Bordeaux, which is delicious, and paired perfectly
with the turkey. Another friend brought over a French apple tart, made by her daughter.
And I received lots of texts and emails from friends and family - thank you for them.
To my surprise, even after all the cooking, I didn't sleep well Thanksgiving night. My
mind starts going down paths where I remember things from the past and begin really
digging into all the crevices. I've been leaning into memories quite heavily during this
era of COVID and cancer, and sometimes they keep me up at night. A couple of wakeful
hours, then, were spent mentally writing the story of a memorable Thanksgiving from my
past, which Ben said he wanted me to tell him sometime. So Ben, this one's for you (and
for all of you who wish to read!).
Une Fête de Thanksgiving à nulle autre pareille
Dear Ben,
In 1984 I was exactly the age you are now, twenty-five. Like you, I was in graduate
school at NYU, in the third year of my doctoral program in French Studies. Yet unlike you,
I was living not in Brooklyn but in Paris, attending classes at French universities. Your
‘aunties’ Vinni and Shanny, and I, shared an apartment in the rue Vineuse, a pleasant
street near the place du Trocadéro in Passy, a very upper crust, fairly snobbish
neighborhood in western Paris, to which many upwardly-mobile Parisians had flocked in
the nineteenth century. Unlike Park Slope where you live now, Passy was dead at night,
but during the day the long rue de Passy bustled with expensive commerce and elegant
tea salons; we felt somehow ‘fancy’ living there. How did three American graduate
students afford such tony digs, with heavy antique furnishings and a chandelier in our
living room (one day I came home to find the saucer-shaped ornaments decorating it
overflowing with water, like a fountain; our upstairs neighbor had left her bathtub
running, and compensated for the huge mess she had caused by offering us Opera
                       590 / 1.901
tickets)? Ronald Reagan was president and, although I instinctively distrusted him as a
Republican, he had done wonders for our economy: our dollar had hardly ever been
stronger abroad. Vinni, Shanny and I kept our fridge stocked with champagne, bought
jewelry, clothes (and books) with abandon, and garnered a reputation, we three 
américaines, for throwing fun, salon-like dinner parties.
Which is what we decided to do for Thanksgiving. We were missing the meals we’d be
having at home and wanted to impress our new French friends – smart, interesting and
lively young men and women about our age whom we were meeting in our classes and
elsewhere – with our culinary savoir-faire. We soon discovered, though, that fixing an
‘American’ Thanksgiving, at least in 1984 Paris, was easier said than done. First step:
where to find a turkey? Turns out, no frozen Butterballs in the supermarket. So we
headed to a butcher shop in the rue de Passy, which in November had all sorts of freshly-
killed game (pheasants, partridges, rabbits etc.) hanging from its window. Might they
also have a turkey, we inquired? The butcher went into his freezer, and returned holding
a large turkey, still covered in its feathers, by its *neck.* Our mouths dropped, but
realizing we would have no other option, we consented to return the next day to
purchase it. As we entered the butcher shop, we found the boucher singing off the
turkey’s feathers (the bird’s neck, head and feet were nowhere in sight…).
Next problem: where, oh where, to find cranberry sauce? Not the kind of product we
could find in our local supermarché and it was well before the vogue of ‘American’ style
restaurants and grocery stores in Paris. As I recall, though, we were able to procure a
few cans of sauce at Fauchon, the très chic specialty food store on the place de la
Madeleine. Perhaps a parent sent us a few other provisions? I don’t remember. Shanny
made a delicious apple pie from The Silver Palette Cookbook, although I also don’t recall
if that was the time she mistakenly added salt instead of sugar to the recipe, an epic fail.
And photographs remind me that there was also homemade pumpkin pie, corn bread
and, I think, my aunt’s cranberry, Granny Smith apple, cashew and arugula salad with a
lime vinaigrette made with extra virgin olive oil (we were in the early years of the EVOO
craze). I don’t remember the actual cooking of the dinner but Vinni and Shanny look
quite relaxed in our kitchen with our holiday turkey. As we took turns hosting dinner
parties in New York during our first two years of graduate school, we were all, by this
time, budding cooks (like you!) who enjoyed getting creative in the kitchen.
I have to imagine that our friends enjoyed our feast. The photos remind me that we had
our apéro in the heavily-draped living room before moving into the dining room for
dinner. Around the table we gathered Shanny’s always smartly-dressed friends Joel and
Annick, a woman I don’t recognize and François, the then boyfriend (later to be husband,
then ex-husband) of our dear friend Doris. I don’t remember if anyone else attended.
I don’t seem to have a picture of me at dinner. That’s probably because, just like today, I
was the one documenting the event with my camera. So here’s a picture of your mom at
                       591 / 1.901
one of our other dinner parties, with a very nice guy named Didier, whom we met
through other friends. Didier was just starting a successful career in the French
administration; I see now that he's the CEO of a major European energy company. I have
no idea why there is a big bottle of Italian Strega on the table next to me; it’s not
something I usually drink. Perhaps I had bought it when visiting my father in Venice the
month before? As you can see, Shanny, Vinni and I loved buying clothes and jewelry in
Paris (that strong US dollar!) and we seem to all have been accessorizing w/faux pearls
and other types of bling for the occasion (I was wearing this low-waisted scarlet velvet
dress that I adored). I wonder what Didier was saying that was making me laugh?
If this whets your appetite for more stories, another time I will tell you about our landlady
in the rue Vineuse, foreign-born Madame Rose (who constantly got her French pronouns
mixed up and who, after many months, revealed to me that she was Jewish; fearing anti-
Semitism [?], she always told us cryptically and in hushed tones, when planning a trip to
Israel, that “je vais à la campagne”). Or I’ll tell you the one about my upstairs neighbor in
Mme Rose’s building. Of all the buildings in Paris, how did the son of my mother’s best
friend, Jon Harber, whom I had babysat when he was little, wind up in mine during his
study abroad semester and turn out to be quite the partyer?
 
 
Photos

                       593 / 1.901
                       594 / 1.901
                       595 / 1.901

December 5, 2020 - The Thanksgiving story, part deux.
  by Willa Silverman, December 5, 2020  
                       597 / 1.901
                       598 / 1.901
 
 
 
 
 
                       599 / 1.901
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                       600 / 1.901
I am doing ok, probably a bit more than ok since the effects of my last IV chemo
treatment are wearing off. I am grateful for this reprieve. But now of course I'm gearing
up for my CT scan this coming Wednesday, which always makes me awfully anxious
(what have those sneaky cancer cells been up to? Lying dormant? Multiplying? Hanging
out?). The following week, I'll see Dr. Patel and likely start on Zejula, a 'parp inhibitor'
that I'll take daily for maintenance. Worst possible Scary Side Effects include certain
types of cancers, compromised bone marrow due to lowered white blood cell count etc.
So I'll be monitored closely for the first month or so, with weekly (I think) bloodwork and
daily heart rate and blood pressure checks (I'll need to get a cuff to assess my b.p.). I
hope I can handle the drug. Dr. Beavis said it was "worth a try." I still need to get clearer
about what she meant exactly, but I believe she meant that if it doesn't work out (ie if I
can't handle the side effects), we will simply stop the treatment. In that case, I suppose, I
hang out until I have another recurrence,  setting in motion 'third line chemo.' I am
heartened to see that a fellow Hopkins patient I have come to know via Facebook,
recently given a discouraging prognosis, has had a very good result with Zejula, and her
CA 125 number has gone down.  This gives me hope.
Meanwhile, we're gearing up for the last week of the semester and then exam week. As
my graduate seminar was small, my workload will be manageable, but I have a small
slew of other tasks to complete before we break for roughly a month around Dec. 18th.
Sometimes I honestly can't believe I accomplished all I did this semester in terms of
teaching and administering -- sadly, not in terms of research but I have high hopes for
winter break, as finishing up an article that just needs a bit more work before I can send
it off. Ben will come home for a week in early January! As for me, I'll likely stay put,
waiting out the COVID storm. But sorely tempted by that loft apartment on W. 15th
street that cousin is offering to lend me while she and her husband are holed up at their
country home in Hudson.
*****
But let's turn to something more pleasant, shall we? Having read my account of our Paris
Thanksgiving in 1984, Vinni jogged my memory in an important way, reminding me that
we hosted not one but *two* Thanksgiving dinners that year (this was corroborated by
her [future] husband, Steve, who was also studying abroad in Paris in 1984-1985);
presumably we could not fit the entire membership of our growing coterie around our
table and our French friends were clamoring for a taste of an 'authentic' American
holiday. Since Vinni and I brought our memories into focus via text a few days ago, I
have unearthed another crucial piece of evidence in my 'private archives' (one of my
most prized possessions): an aérogramme to my mother and brother describing the
                       601 / 1.901
event itself! Here's what I wrote on 1 December 1984:
Dear Mom & E,
It was so nice to talk to you on Thanksgiving. I hope you had a nice holiday - tell me
about it. As I told you, our (2) Thanksgiving dinners were a great success. I guess turkeys
are pretty exotic here - the butcher had to de-plume them, cut off head, limbs, clean
them - in front of us - he seemed to enjoy that! We stuffed them (chestnut and olive
stuffing), made mashed sweets (I invented a recipe), corn bread, green beans in
bechamel sauce, cranberry salad, gravy + pumpkin pie + apple pie. Cranberries +
pumpkin could only be found at Fauchon, the fanciest specialty store. Thursday night, we
invited Doris and her boyfriend François, 2 friends of Shanny's (Joël + Annick), a friend of
Vinni's. Friday night William and his brother Jérôme + 2 friends from school, Sam +
Steve -- that was a lot of fun but a big job. I really sympathize with you, Mom - I don't
know how you made all those dinners for so many people!
A photo(on the back of which I've written "Thanksgiving 84 - (Very) rarely am I
surrounded by so many men," reveals our dinner guests that second evening. Left to
right: Sam Thorsen, a friend of ours from the Institute of French Studies at NYU, yours
truly, Steve Bold, another friend from NYU French Department; two French brothers
whom we had met through our friend Isabelle (I think). Shanny had a thing for Jérôme
(Brother 1), an ultra-smart young intello now a media studies prof at Tel-Aviv University.
I had had a thing for (and with, in New York) William (Brother 2), an equally brilliant and
articulate young attorney, now a prominent human rights lawyer, but in Paris we were
just buddies. Vinni and Steve wound up marrying (as did Doris and François), but the
sparks (unless I missed something?) were not yet flying in 1984. Sam was a dear soul
and a bit of a lost soul, struggling with his coming out at a time when many gay men still
remained closeted. He had a lovely Georgia drawl (he hailed from Savannah) and was
droll and a great companion and confidant. One night around midnight I heard pebbles
hitting my bedroom window; Sam was in the street below (our genteel
Passy quartier was deserted at night), stumbling and calling up: Willlaaaa! Willlaaa!
(think Stanley Kowalski bellowing: "Stellaaa! Stelllaa!).  He came upstairs and sort of
crumpled in my living room, smelling of sweat and alcohol and cigarettes. I think I just
held him, or I like to think I did.  We lost him to AIDS in 1991.
I'm wearing a fabulous deep navy velvet jacket with ornate beading that I had found in
one of my grandmother's closets in her brownstone on E. 94th street. I loved to
rummage through her dozens of hatboxes, jewelry cases and fifth floor closets to find
hidden treasures (once I found a $20 bill crumpled up in the toe of an old pair of ice
skates), such as this very 1940s looking jacket (boxy padded shoulders), which I liked to
wear low-cut, loosely pinned up and tightly belted. I think I look pretty happy here,
tottering between a gamine and a slightly hot mess, surrounded by the guys. I still have
the jacket but the purple net lining is all torn and the beading is coming undone. May be
                       602 / 1.901
time to have it repaired.
"These fragments I have shored against my ruins."
Photos
                       603 / 1.901
                       604 / 1.901
                       605 / 1.901

your system! XO, K
  —Kathryn Grossman, December 5, 2020

December 9, 2020 - Scanxious (yet again)
  by Willa Silverman, December 9, 2020  
Everything went as smoothly as possible with my CT scan this morning (routine scan
following three rounds of IV chemo), although it's certainly not fun. I had to wake up at
the ungodly hour of 7 a.m. (I know, I know), which might have been tolerable had I not
been so very tired from hosting a zoom speaker event the night before in my graduate
seminar on the Dreyfus Affair. I was so beat afterwards that I barely had the energy to
prop myself up on my couch, eat a bowl of tomato tortellini soup, and watch reruns of
"Beat Bobby Flay."
(One of) the worst part(s) of the entire scan experience (there are several) is the
interdiction against food and drink for four hours beforehand. This might not be an issue
if I didn't wake up every morning feeling so thoroughly dehydrated. In any event, per
usual, I had to drink two large bottles of contrast liquid on arrival. The revolting taste of
the barium (resembling greasy melted chalk) initially made me gag, then I willed myself
into pretending that it was a fine Châteauneuf-du-Pape or equivalent, going so far as to
softly intone to myself "Mmmm...." after each rotten swig.  The rotgut swilling took about
two hours while the scan itself went fairly quickly. I know most of the technicians by now
and they're quite nice. The unpleasant aspect of the scan itself is receiving an additional
contrast dye via IV, which nearly instantly fills my mouth with a nauseating warm
salty/metallic taste. I threw up twice at Hopkins when being pumped with this stuff so
                       607 / 1.901
now I always ask to hold onto a container of which I can avail myself if I feel the urge.
And that was my morning. 
I popped into Wegman's to pick up a few items after I left the medical center, then
treated myself to a large cappuccino at the Pump Station Café. When I returned home I
lay down for an hour or so as I felt wiped out.
I managed to make a dent in my backlog of emails in the afternoon  while pinging and
ponging back and forth on the phone between the pharma company that will be
delivering my new oral chemo med (Zejula) and the company supplying me with a card
to reduce my copay. During about three of these calls I was (still) told that my copay per
month would be $1800 -- which produces the effect of being stunned with a cattle prod
or laser each time I hear it. My patience was really wearing thin as I was tired. By the
end of the day, though, word had arrived that my copay, thanks to this miracle card, will
indeed be $0 (thank goodness for small miracles). Good news. Less good news: I must be
home from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. to sign for my medicine whenever it's delivered. I can
handle that. Question mark: Will I be able to tolerate this new medication? Will it wreak
havoc on my body? Bigger question mark: what will my scan show? Maybe I'll find out
tomorrow. Or maybe not until I see Dr. Patel next Thursday. Or maybe sooner, via the
radiologists at either Geisinger or Hopkins. So....much...uncertainty.
I dreamt last night that I was in a crowded public place, indoors (perhaps a wedding that
I had been invited to or that I was at least viewing, although I wasn't dressed formally).
Yet it appeared that everyone there (not just the wedding guests but crowds of people
walking in or near the indoor venue) had tacitly decided, collectively, to no longer wear
masks. I was alarmed by this, not really panicked but surprised and worried.  COVID-era
dreams... And then this morning I was swigging my greasy melted chalk (I hear 2020 was
a notable vintage) when I realized that this entailed my taking off my mask, indoors, for
the duration of the swigging -- and that made me a bit nervous. And then this morning,
too, I read a long NYTimes article about how hospitals, especially outside urban areas
(Altoona, PA, was mentioned), are full to maximum capacity with COVID patients. MUST
NOT GET SICK!
 
 
  
Comments

                       608 / 1.901
time on the phone was also well worth the bother. May your scan results bring good
news, worth celebrating with a glass of the real thing!
  —Kathryn Grossman, December 9, 2020  
Thank you, Kathryn!!
  —Willa Silverman, December 9, 2020

come up so far short and I complain far more. I agree, reward yourself with the real
thing! Do you have a Châteauneuf du pape in your wine cellar?! ;-)
  —Janet Horne, December 9, 2020

will show. All topped with how hospitals are full to maximum capacity! Yes, a time to
circle the wagons and "jouer la carte de la solidarité!" We are with you every minute,
thanks for sharing! Xoxo
  —Marianne Freed, December 9, 2020

and look forward to kicking up our heels again when it is safe xo
