December 11, 2020 - Schehecheyanu
  by Willa Silverman, December 11, 2020  
Blessed are you, Adonai, our God, Sovereign of the Universe, who has kept us alive,
sustained us, and brought us to this season.
So blessed to have been brought to this season and therefore to be able to recite the
Schehecheyanu. Last year I was in D.C. for part of Chanukah, or perhaps just afterwards,
and feeling pretty well. I treated myself to a room at my favorite hotel there (Mandarin
Oriental) and had a lovely time w/Ben and Sammi and also w/my friend Jeff, w/whom I
                       609 / 1.901
enjoyed a coffee and catchup outdoors in the sunshine at La Colombe (Blagden Alley) on
New Years Eve day. And a year ago today, actually, I was at Kripalu Yoga Center in
Lenox, MA, w/grad school bffs Vinni, Isabelle and Shanny, reveling in a memorable,
wonderful reunion (and in delicious, healthy food, lots of yoga, and spa treatments!).
Those pre-pandemic days seem far away..
Dr. Patel had a cancellation this morning so I was able to talk to him about both my scan
results and my upcoming regimen of Zejula. He spent about 45 minutes with me and I
was grateful for his time.
The results of my scan seem not much changed from the last time (September), which is
certainly not bad news. No new masses, nothing pertinent in my lymph nodes to report,
no new findings of significance. There is a 1.1 cm 'structure' in my right pelvis that was
also noted in September that is at present 'indeterminate.' It might be nothing or it
might be something. The doctors will keep an eye on it. A PET scan may have showed
more but Dr. Patel explained to me these have to be 'rationed' as after a certain point
the insurance company won't cover them :(. So the CT scan was the fallback this time
around. He says he spends hours on end w/the insurance companies trying to advocate
for his patients, often to no avail... Healthcare coverage in America - don't get me
started...
I need to have a routine port flush the final week in December.
And next week I'm to start on Zejula (my plan is to start next Friday after an important
professional presentation that I need to be in good shape for; Dr. P. said this was fine
and I have the medication on hand). We went over some of the (numerous) potential
side effects. The one that he is anticipating concerns my blood counts; they are likely to
drop (both hemoglobin and white blood count). Dr. P's office will be testing my blood
often (once weekly for the first month, then once monthly) and I'll need to monitor my
blood pressure and heart rate at home (I'll purchase a wristband that can measure both).
In anticipation of some of these side effects, I'll be starting off on 200 rather than 300
mgs daily. As he can be rather brusque sometimes, Dr. Patel seemed a bit impatient with
all my questions. While I explained that they stem in part from anxiety, he encouraged
me to not get bent out of shape over things I cannot control (generally sound advice),
reasoning that we'll deal with my particular symptoms and reactions (should I have any)
once I start on the medications. He even conjectured -- somewhat jokingly? -- that the
reason I may be fatigued is because I have so many questions (and hence worries)
swirling through my brain. Lest you think he is too abrupt, let me underscore that in the
end I have come to appreciate his 'no nonsense' approach and practicality as well as his
skills as an oncologist. I've definitely grown to trust him in the year and a half or so since
I've been his patient.
So here's the bottom line, per Dr. Patel's 'straight talk express:' a)given how very ill I was
                       610 / 1.901
last April, and the seriousness of my cancer, I'm currently doing as well as can be
expected. And that's a blessing; b)the parp inhibitor has the potential to buy me some
time. And whether that be a month or a year, I'll be grateful for it; c)"Enjoy your life, and
don't focus on things you can't control. Do things you enjoy." "I am enjoying it, that's
why I don't want it to end!" Sounds good to me.
About to light candle #2. I'll not recite the Schehecheyanu after the first night of
Chanukah, but I'll repeat it again here (while silently crediting, too, my own #willapower
and the expertise of my medical team as well as some higher power:
Blessed are you, Adonai, our God, Sovereign of the Universe, who has kept [me] alive,
sustained [me], and brought [me] to this season.
Wishing you abundant light in these darkest days of the year.
  
Comments
Wishing you lots of light, and will power, year after year after year .... !!!
  —Monique Yaari, December 11, 2020  
Wonderful news overall, Willa! Feeling the bright, hopeful light that you generously
emanate upon all of us who love you and hold you extremely dear! Wishing you a strong
and serene year to come ... in two-thousand twenty-one! xxxooo
  —Julie Eagle-Cardo, December 11, 2020  
Thanks again for sharing your good news, amazing spirits, and light! Wishing you all
strength and love and joi de vivre!
  —Heather Bryant, December 11, 2020

once I start on the medications. He even conjectured -- somewhat jokingly? -- that the
reason I may be fatigued is because I have so many questions (and hence worries)
swirling through my brain. Lest you think he is too abrupt, let me underscore that in the
                       612 / 1.901
end I have come to appreciate his 'no nonsense' approach and practicality as well as his
skills as an oncologist. I've definitely grown to trust him in the year and a half or so since
I've been his patient.
So here's the bottom line, per Dr. Patel's 'straight talk express:' a)given how very ill I was
last April, and the seriousness of my cancer, I'm currently doing as well as can be
expected. And that's a blessing; b)the parp inhibitor has the potential to buy me some
time. And whether that be a month or a year, I'll be grateful for it; c)"Enjoy your life, and
don't focus on things you can't control. Do things you enjoy." "I am enjoying it, that's
why I don't want it to end!" Sounds good to me.
About to light candle #2. I'll not recite the Schehecheyanu after the first night of
Chanukah, but I'll repeat it again here (while silently crediting, too, my own #willapower
and the expertise of my medical team as well as some higher power:
Blessed are you, Adonai, our God, Sovereign of the Universe, who has kept [me] alive,
sustained [me], and brought [me] to this season.
Wishing you abundant light in these darkest days of the year.

December 11, 2020 - p.s.
  by Willa Silverman, December 11, 2020  
I forgot to make a few points in my previous entry, which I want to add before I forget
                       613 / 1.901
them. It seems evident to me that I repressed the final point:
1)By many measures, I'm doing better than I was in April-May of last year, when I was
first diagnosed and had the mother of all debulking surgeries.
2)Zejula (and other parp inhibitors) have been shown to work better in women with the
BRCA mutation, which I do not have. However, a number of studies have shown (and Dr.
Beavis even sent me an article on this from a medical journal) that parp inhibitors can
also prolong life in patients without the BRCA mutation, which is my case, who have
advanced recurrent ovarian cancer (my case too). Hence her assessment that Zejula is
"worth a try." I'm game.
3)Dr. Patel cannot at this point endorse my receiving the anti-COVID vaccine. As yet
there are no FDA nor other guidelines for the (safe) administration of this vaccine to
cancer patients, no hard knowledge, as far as I understand it, about potential side
effects, potentially risky drug interactions etc. So instead of being closer to the front of
the line I appear to be, at this moment, at the back of the line, perhaps not even in line.
What a disappointment, and yet another example of how COVID has been extra-
challenging for those of us with cancer, for myriad reasons [insert long list here]. But
there's nothing I can do about it except receive the vaccine against my oncologist's
advice, and I don't think I'm willing to take that risk. And hopefully guidance from 'the
authorities' will be forthcoming before too long. I'm sure the small army of us cancer
patients/survivors will demand it!

December 20, 2020 - Girding my loins
  by Willa Silverman, December 20, 2020  
                       615 / 1.901
                       616 / 1.901
Just a short note to ask everyone to direct some healing energy my way as I start on my
new chemo regimen tomorrow morning. I'll take 300 mg of Zejula daily, in the form of
two pills. I spoke at some length with the Geisinger pharmacist (or perhaps she was a
nurse?) who will be working with Dr. Patel to oversee my 'day to day' during this
regimen. For example, she will likely review (weekly, then monthly) results of blood work
with me, make sure my blood pressure is not out of bounds, and check in on me
regularly. Since I am most nervous about the potential side effects, she confirmed that
the likeliest of these will be fatigue; high blood pressure (which might manifest itself as
dizziness, nausea); and lowering of white and red blood cell counts. I bought a cuff with
which to measure my blood pressure and heart rate and hope it will work well (and that I
will work it well). I have nausea meds. My local pals are on call. And fortunately I've just
about finished my grading (awaiting one straggler...) and have a few weeks off before
spring semester starts on Jan. 19th. So I can sleep in, eat well (I see soup making in my
future), take walks (although I'm really cold-averse!) and replenish. Above all, I'll keep in
mind that each pill is potentially prolonging my life. That will provide motivation, but if
the side effects impact my quality of life too negatively, I will need to rethink.
In grad school, I had a professor named Jindrich Zezula and I can't help thinking of him
each time I reach for the Zejula!
A highlight of the weekend was a somewhat impromptu Rezoomion with about eighteen
former housemates from Currier House, the Harvard residence where I lived, loved,
cried, partied, studied, danced, made friends, and learned lots of valuable life lessons
over forty years ago. The impetus for the reunion was a photo I posted on Facebook of
my Currier-mate David Gifford and me reconnecting in Paris several years ago at a fairly
swanky café/bistrot across from the Parc Monceau (David was served the most gigantic
mille-feuilles known to man; restaurant patrons were staring at it, agape; David, who had
just arrived from Japan, downed most of it after the two of us had indulged in an equally
decadent, buttery slab of paté de foie gras with some delicious large crystals of salt
sprinkled on it). A few comments on this photo led David, my friend Chris Ahmadjian and
I to put together the reunion, which was a lot of fun! It was a two-hour nostalgia trip,
which jogged my memory about certain forgotten details: that *tree* in the middle of the
Currier House dining room (apparently no longer there); the grill where we bought cheap
and greasy late-night snacks to fortify our studying; that resident pre-med tutor who was
also a skilled musician; and oh yes, x really was dating y. Those were good (although
angst-ridden) days and I'm grateful to still have some of my Currier friends along for the
ride.
Was also happy to zoom with my mother and then my aunt, who both celebrated
birthdays this week (my mother's 84th and her sister Marlene's 87th! - the Medjuck
women are schooling their kids and grandkids in graceful longevity). And to zoom with
                       617 / 1.901
Ben of course - he'll be here for a week in early January and I'm sure lots of cooking will
take place.
I was also a discussant Friday afternoon during a conversation with an author about her
new book (concerning women collectors of Japanese art in the late 19th c.). This zoom
event was organized by a professional society I belong to (Nineteenth-Century French
Studies) and attracted about 100 people. I had not 'presented' in this type of setting
since my diagnosis and was glad to realize that I hadn't lost my mojo. It was a lot of fun,
the kind of professional activity I revel in, although truth be told I was very tired
afterwards.
Blessings for the solstice, when new light emerges from the dark. Such a wonderful,
mysterious time.

December 23, 2020 - So far so good
  by Willa Silverman, December 23, 2020  
                       621 / 1.901
                       622 / 1.901
Day 3 on Zejula and I'm happy to report no notable ill effects so far. I've experienced
some mild nausea but a pill helped with that. My energy level has been fine; after a full
day yesterday I whipped up three cranberry orange nut breads. So far my bp and pulse
are normal; Zejula can notoriously trigger high blood pressure. As for my blood counts
(Zejula can also notoriously make red and white blood cell counts plummet, in rare cases
causing blood cancers), I'll know more when I have my blood tested on Monday and then
once a week thereafter for the first month. It is possible that the side effects of Zejula
don't manifest until one has been taking it for awhile (I don't know that for a fact, I'm just
imagining). Yet Dr. Beavis told me that she currently has a patient who has experienced
no side effects from Zejula, except for mild fatigue in the beginning - this is encouraging.
For now, I pray that I will continue to feel generally well. Sure beats IV chemo so far.
I may have mentioned that I likely can't get vaccinated against COVID yet. Both my
oncologists tell me that there is not enough data to know how it might affect cancer
patients currently in treatment. I hope that soon more will be known but for now I have
to remain very patient -- and very careful, especially if my white blood cells are
suppressed.
I turned my grades in on Monday and put the semester to rest. Ecstatic to have a bunch
of days of completely unstructured time. I've been writing holiday cards, a relaxing
yearly ritual. Tomorrow I'll probably write them while listening to to traditional Christmas
hymns, which I love even though I don't observe Christmas. I like the 19th century ones
like "O Come, O Come Emmanuel," sung by a splendid choir like that of King's College,
Cambridge, or medieval or Renaissance hymns and carols. Such meditative, soulful,
trancelike music and words. Also enjoyed a long phone call and a Zoom chat with two
different friends (plus a long Zoom with my aunt), and watched cooking shows on t.v.
Speaking of which, I think my next read will be David Chang's new memoir, _Eat a
Peach._
Also went to my hair stylist's, where Joe (the owner) worked wonders. He's been
compassionate and discreet all along, crafting a short bob for me when my hair was
starting to fall out last year. It's taken a good year, but now my hair is back in earnest!
It's still short but feels healthy and I have some curls in the back for the first time in my
life (it grew in that way). There's enough length now that Joe was actually able to style it,
freeing me from the bizarre-looking mop of hair I've been sporting (and disguising with
cute headbands, scarves, clips etc.) as my hair inched (or rather centimetered) its way
back.
I was so happy with the effect of this cut hat I posted my pic on a Facebook page I joined
called Sisterhood of Ovarian Cancer Survivors. Because the comments on this page
always scream solidarity, I received many affirmations from this army of 'sisters.' The
                       623 / 1.901
one I like best: "Beautiful lady! Warrior Goddess!"
Willa the Warrior Goddess. ��

December 28, 2020 - Pick your poison
  by Willa Silverman, December 28, 2020  
"Quand le ciel bas et lourd pèse comme un couvercle"
Some days I feel like I am thriving, others striving, others yet merely surviving. Today
began with 'surviving,' but improved as the day went on. Zejula, as predicted, is messing
with my blood pressure. The diastolic bp number has been inching upwards all week, to
the point where this morning it seemed alarming to me based on the range I had been
told was normal (it turns out that that range has recently been expanded, unbeknownst
to me, one of the many confusions of my day). Should I go to the ER (a place, by the
way, which I wish to avoid like the plague)? Am I adjusting the bp cuff correctly? Should I
take my bp again (I did this three times in succession, yielding very different results each
time, which only made me more anxious)? I lay down on my bed for a while, curled into a
fetal position, then texted my brother who, as he habitually does, provided some
sensible input and helped calm me down (thank you, Ethan). I then decided the optimal
path would be to call the pharmacist to whom Dr. Patel is handing off this part of my
care (anything to do w/my Zejula regimen); she works with him and specializes in oral
chemo drugs. But she is frustratingly hard to reach: each time I call I need to go through
a long phone tree, only to be put on hold and leave a voice mail each time. I can also
contact her through Dr. Patel's nurse's mailbox in the Geisinger portal, but not directly
through the portal. Complicated! I also decided to see if one of Dr. Patel's nurses would
check my blood pressure when I had my bloodwork done at Scenery Park; that was
quickly agreed to. In the meantime, I did receive emails from the pharmacist basically
telling me not to worry, that the bp was still normal (whereas she had told me to go to
the ER if my diastolic bp number was over 100, now she was telling me that both
numbers, upper and lower, needed to be in abnormal range for there to be cause for
concern).
 
When I went to get my blood taken, the technician had no idea how much blood to draw
and for which tests; there were no notes about that in my chart. Oh. This problem took a
little while to get sorted out. Then I went downstairs to Dr. Patel's office, where Regina,
one of the nurses, checked my blood pressure, which she found to be normal, but when
we tried twice more with my cuff we again got very different results, one of which
seemed very high. Dr. Patel was not in the office and Kayla (the nurse who assists him
and sort of oversees all the other nurses) was tied up. So I had no one to voice my
frustration to except Regina, telling her that I felt I wasn't being well cared for at the
moment and worrying out loud if I was going to have a heart attack. I had all sorts of
                       626 / 1.901
questions about my bp that she couldn't answer. Normally I probably would have burst
into tears at that point but as I'm on Lexapro so my affect is pretty flat much of the time.
Probably for the best.
I was sort of turned around when I got home (c. 2:30) -- I had had great plans to dive
back into my research today -- so I just lay on my bed for a while and read. Anna (the
pharmacist) called me and imparted some welcome news: my bloodwork looks good!
The Zejula has laid off my red and white blood cells and platelets for now. She also
reiterated that I shouldn't worry about my bp (which of course stress can cause to
elevate) and that they'd be concerned about consistently high numbers (ie over a three-
day period) - that was news to me, but ok, good. She also said that her protocol was to
call me once a week to go over everything, leaving me a bit concerned about who I
should contact if I felt anxious or if something acute transpired. I don't think she gave me
a direct answer but she did make clear (albeit nicely, even overly nicely) that it shouldn't
be her.
A message from a friend in France arrived au bon moment and motivated me to look at a
project that we might collaborate on, so I reread most of the manuscript (140 pages), my
transcription of a fascinating unpublished diary from 1878 set mainly against the
backdrop of the Opera and the Opera ballet as well as the Paris World's Fair of that year.
While rereading was fairly 'low hanging fruit,' it did get me reconnected to my work and I
look forward to continuing tomorrow. And it kind of got my off-kilter day back on track.
The crappy day further redeemed itself when an unexpected bouquet of bright yellow
flowers in a vase was delivered -- sent by someone at Penn State who is thoughtful, kind
and humane. It was *exactly* what I needed and brightened my day considerably. I felt
the anxiety I had been holding all day start to dissipate.
On another note, I am still writing holiday cards! If you haven't received one from me yet
(especially if you were kind enough to send me one), I am still working on them. They'll
be more like New Year's cards this year. 
Hope I'll be back to thriving soon. I'd even be ok w/striving.
 
 
 
 
  
                       627 / 1.901

December 29, 2020 - Good news
  by Willa Silverman, December 29, 2020  
More from this crazy roller coaster ride...
>BP back in normal range this morning.
>CA125 level on this reading: 15.7, down from 18.2 last month and well within normal
range (0-38.1). This is *the* all important number, the marker for ovarian cancer. This
means, at the least, a)that things are stable as far as my cancer is concerned and b)the
Zejula is perhaps (?) starting to take effect by killing cancer cells. In any event, I am
                       628 / 1.901
relieved and thrilled, and will gladly (well, perhaps that's a bit of an exaggeration) bear
the mild nausea, fatigue (but also insomnia), stomach upset and bp blips that the
medication is causing in order to maintain this level.

December 29, 2020 - Less good news
  by Willa Silverman, December 29, 2020  
....and did I mention a roller coaster?
Dr. Beavis (my wonderful gyn-onc from Hopkins) just called w/the Hopkins' radiologists
reading of my recent CT scan. From a cancer perspective, things look overall good.
There's some 'nodularity' in my pelvis that they are watching. But the radiologists also
saw what they believe to be two tiny blood clots, one in my lung, one in my leg. The
Geisinger radiologists here in State College had not picked that up. That was of course
concerning because of the danger of an embolism. So I have to (re)start Lovanox (blood
                       630 / 1.901
thinner), twice a day, by injection (ie I inject myself - not fun, but I know how to do it).
This should take care of the problem, and the clot will be absorbed back into my
bloodstream. The radiologists recommended that I have another CT scan now to see
whether the clots have changed in size etc. but Dr. Beavis felt we should proceed
straight to treatment. The clots' formation is cancer-related. 
In other news, I'll take the Zejula as long as my CA125 number is stable. If it starts to rise
that could indicate a recurrence. Dr. Beavis reminded me that if a second recurrence is
to occur, it usually does so after the same interval as the first recurrence. In my case this
was barely six months. However, she reminded me that all the problems related to the
fistula could well have been an aggravating factor. So we'll see. We agreed that we will
cross that bridge when/if we come to it. In the meantime, the plan is to enjoy every day.
In better news, she now thinks that I should be able to receive the COVID vaccine when it
becomes available to me. The oncology community is hoping that there will be CDC
guidelines regarding the vaccine and cancer patients, but it is not available yet.
Voilà. Never a dull moment.

December 29, 2020 - Annus horribilis redux
  by Willa Silverman, December 31, 2020  
Last year on this date I enjoyed a coffee outside with my friend Jeff at Café La Colombe
in Blagden Alley (D.C.) on a sunny day, then snagged Ethiopian takeout from a great
place near Ben's former apartment before hunkering down at his place for a peaceful
evening watching t.v. and chilling while he and Sammi were in New York. The next day I
took a commuter train to Baltimore in the hopes of having a fistula between my
abdomen and intestine 'plugged' at Hopkins, thereby eliminating the need for a second
open surgery. When I awoke from that procedure (I was under light anesthesia), Dr.
Holley (an interventional radiologist) said to me: "It didn't work. I'm sorry. There's
something else going on. There's nothing more I can do for you."
The failure of this procedure next led to my having a second major open surgery in
March, to repair the fistula (and snip out other pieces of my intestine and colon in the
process). That operation, which lasted about nine hours I believe, went well. A few days
into my recovery, the news channels started to be blanketed by coverage of COVID and
the slew of emergency measures being put in place in NY and elsewhere. It was
alarming. The next day, out a window near my room in the hospital, Ben and I began
seeing Hopkins employees in full Hazmat suits stopping each vehicle arriving at the
hospital, for questioning. The day after that, the hospital barred all visitors , so my
mother and Ben could no longer spend time with me. And the day after that, the surgeon
who had performed my operation, Dr. Sandy Fang, came into my room and said: "You
seem to be doing pretty well and it turns out we're going to need the beds." I was
discharged the next day.
As some point not long after that, my cancer recurred, which is to be expected with
ovarian cancer. I had been NED (no evidence of disease) for barely six months, which is
sort of the tipping point between what is considered a quick recurrence and a 'not quick'
one (there are technical terms for this but I can't recall them right now); the time lapse
before a first recurrence can be a predictor for the timing or 'rhythm' of subsequent
recurrences.
                       632 / 1.901
And that was only the first few months of the year..
I won't dwell on how the COVID-cancer double whammy made for a second 'annus
horribilis' in a row for me and I won't enumerate the many many things - activities,
places, travels, people, sensations, routines -- I miss, just like everyone else.
Instead, I choose to focus on the bright spots. There were indeed a few:
*March-August: The day I was discharged from the hospital in March, Ben drove me back
to State College -- and didn't leave for five months. A while after that, Sammi came to
join him/us. Both of them teleworked from here, using both my home and Michael and
Sue's as office and living space. Thankfully, we had plenty of room to accommodate
them. My memories from that time are of trying out lots of new recipes for our convivial
meals (and not having to clear or wash the dishes!), working on jigsaw puzzles, sprucing
up my house thanks to both Ben and Sammi's input re new furniture (and their skill in
assembling some pieces), long talks about everything, including the unprecedented time
we were living through, and just a deep sense of comfort from being together. Grateful
for this unusual yet wonderful interlude, that spanned late winter, spring and summer,
and for my COVID 'roommates.'
*June: The Stride and Thrive fundraiser for the Kelly Gynecological Oncology Center at
Hopkins was both uplifting and rewarding. Our State College team (perhaps 15 of us,
including Ben and his buddies,) 'strode'  around the Military Museum trail (or ran a 5K)
on a glorious June morning, wearing the #willapower t-shirts I had made for the
occasion. Better yet, I raised over $7K for KEGOS! The event is usually held in Baltimore
and I'm hoping to be sufficiently 'thriving' for a reprise of this year's performance! Who's
with me?
An offshoot of Stride and Thrive has been a  monthly get-together with up to seven
wonderful women friends, some of whom participated in the June walk. We meet at the
Military Museum early on a Sunday morning to the sound of nearby church bells, walk,
chat, catch up and finish with a coffee at a nearby café.
*August (or was it July?): Wonderful trip to Chatham, MA, with Ben for a week of pool
lounging, reading, lobster roll eating, spa going, and relaxing. The change of scene was
so welcome after months of cabin fever, I was feeling well, and the long drive to/from the
Cape in my new car was part of the adventure, as we listened to lots of music and
podcasts (one about the genesis of Bob Dylan songs). I love nothing better than a fun
road trip with a great travel companion, and this one was memorable.
*August-December: I enjoyed being back in the (virtual) classroom for the first time in
over a year and hope the graduate students learned as much as I did from our seminar
on the Dreyfus Affair.
                       633 / 1.901
*The brightest spot this year, again, was the astounding kindness shown me throughout
the year by family and friends. My family has been extraordinarily caring, not just
because they are family and they love me but because they are, I've concluded,
exceptional people that I'm lucky enough to be related to! Friends from all phases of my
life continued to email, text, call, zoom, cook, make me laugh, read and comment on my
blog, lend an ear, give advice, and help keep my spirits up in countless other ways. 
I want to especially thank those friends (and of course family members) who have not
feared, consistently, to step into the 'ring of fire,' as I call it, ie the darkest moments, the
reports after scans and procedures, the times when I'm in physical pain, the emotionally
and mentally fraught periods, the messy places. I understand how unpleasant and
frightening this can be and how it might easily trigger an avoidance mechanism.  But the
ring of fire is a ring of light! For those of you who have 'gone there' with me, I hope you
might feel, like I do, that there have been moments of grace in the face of extreme
vulnerability, raw human connection, and love. Thank you for having the *courage* to
make your life and mine a blessing.
From the existential to the mundane: today I feel pretty well. I woke up early (for me) as
I thought a repair man was coming (he can't come until Monday, it turns out), stocked up
on groceries for Ben's visit, picked up some wine for a dish I'm making, stopped at Tait
Farm and lastly for a cappuccino. I'm adjusting -- I think -- to the new oral chemo
regimen + taking my blood pressure (showing normal readings now) + giving myself two
injections each day + figuring out how to deal with the insomnia Zejula can cause (I slept
pretty well last night). I am content to have a quiet night at home with a movie (I
watched "Dawn Wall" last night, a gripping documentary about free soloing) and a nice
dinner (I'm thinking linguine in lemon cream sauce). These days I try to 'dedramatize'
NYE, plus I have Ben's visit to look forward to on Sunday!
Wishing everyone good health, happiness, personal prosperity, creativity, laughs, and
blessings in the new year. 
***********************************************
And this is what I wrote a year ago today:
Happily ensconced in Ben's bedroom in the row house where he lives on M Street,
overlooking the small housing project and the huge white church that takes up almost a
city block (the United House of Prayer for All People of the Church of the Rock of the
Apostolic Faith). Ben and Sammi are in NYC for NYE, but I am here, cozily on this mild
day, winding down the year (and decade). My friend/ex-bf Jeff met me for a while to
select some goodies at Buttercream Bakery, before sitting outside in the sun at La
Colombe cafe in Blagden Alley, catching up and trading tales as we like to do (see pic).
                       634 / 1.901
Headed to Baltimore at some point tomorrow. The PET-CT scan on Thursday, the results
of which I will discuss that day with the interventional radiologist (Dr. Holly), will
determine whether the procedure to repair my fistula laparoscopically can go forward
the next day. If the scan reveals significant fluid collection, for example (that niggling
stomach abscess...), the procedure may well be off, to be replaced by an open surgery at
another date. There are no guarantees. I hope for the best outcome, but need to be
prepared for a different one. I am not certain if the PET will also screen for any new or
residual cancer, but I presume it will. I'll also meet with my gyn onc, Dr. Beavis, on
Thursday afternoon.
In no way has cancer been a 'blessing,' in no way am I 'grateful' for having this disease.
In no way do I feel that "God does not give you more than you can handle" and/or
"everything happens for a reason." I understand that this counters the belief of several
religious traditions that find value in suffering. In no way was spending the night before
my 'mother of all surgeries' retching into a garbage can in my hotel room while my
family looked on helplessly a redeeming experience, nor was the crushing post-chemo
fatigue that had me waking up from seventeen-hour slumbers in a stunned stupor, nor
was feeling so overwhelmed I could scarcely make myself a cup of tea, nor was the fact
of missing at least three friends' weddings and a long-planned trip to France with Ben,
nor was having my entire life come crashing down around me, leaving me to grapple
with the possibility of a shorter than hoped-for lifespan.
And yet...
I will simply echo the measured words of my rabbi, David Ostrich, during a visit he paid
me shortly after I returned home from my three-week post-surgery stay at Hopkins: "You
may find that this experience offers some opportunity for learning:"
*I am stronger than I thought, both physically and mentally. It surprised me to learn that
some cancer patients, even at early stages of their treatment, feel they simply can't
continue with it. Except for a few rare instants when feeling particularly debilitated and
overwhelmed, this has never been my attitude. I'm still feeling well enough, and tough
enough now, to say "bring it on." I will keep fighting if need be (and it may very well be,
given the likelihood of a recurrence...)
*Goodness exists, and it is powerful. At the risk of sounding pollyannaish, and while fully
conscious of the fact that evil, ugliness, and mean-spiritedness also exist in spades
(examples too numerous to mention here, and in our faces every day), let me quote
Anne Frank: "It's a wonder I haven't abandoned all my ideals, they seem so absurd and
impractical. Yet I cling to them because I still believe, in spite of everything, that people
are truly good at heart." One friend brought me a hamsa (protective hand symbol) that
her mother had blessed at the Kotel in Jerusalem; another came by my house to check
on me when Ben and Michael were worried because they couldn't contact me (I was
                       635 / 1.901
deep into one of the aforementioned post-chemo big sleeps); another prepared a picnic
and drove me to sit beside a calming creek on a gorgeous summer day; another drove
me, twice, from State College to Baltimore; three others came to spend weekends with
me, to help out with whatever was needed; others ran errands, made chicken noodle
soup, borscht, quiche, rice pudding (the prodigious Meal Train kept me fed for months...),
texted, called, emailed, sent cards, gorgeous floral arrangements, and other thoughtful
gifts (one friend, envisioning me in a hospital gown, sent a colorful, elegant scarf),
prayed, visited, drove me to doctors' appointments, slept over when I was feeling shaky,
sat with me during chemo, brought me milkshakes when that was virtually all I could
stomach, invited me on outings as I continued to improve, took care of everything I left
hanging at work when I had to schedule surgery on short notice, added encouraging and
perceptive comments to this page. My family members have continued to provide rock
solid love and support, accompanying me to Baltimore, providing strong arms to lean on
when my post-surgery 'walks' extended to the house next door, and keeping up a
courageous front despite their fear. ETC. Goodness is restorative (and really beautiful
and pure!). It manifests itself in countless ways. It continues to be an essential element
in my recovery. I do feel privileged to have witnessed so many instances of grace.
Perhaps, in some ways, I have learned to be a 'better' (ie kinder, more empathic) version
of myself, too. I would be glad for that.
*As I wrote earlier about my upcoming procedure, there are no guarantees. But I think I
really understand this now. It's become easier to say "I love you" -- and mean it -- to
friends and family. And I hold those hugs for longer, and squeeze tighter. No filter. No
b.s. No day but today.
*I am intoxicated by life, and unready to leave it.
That's what I've learned so far.
Wishing everyone a healthy, happy, successful, fun, peaceful, loving and blessed new
year.
Love, Willa

January 10, 2021 - Status quo
  by Willa Silverman, January 10, 2021  
                       638 / 1.901
                       639 / 1.901
I haven't provided an update in a while so I just wanted to assure everyone that health-
wise things are status quo for now. The Zejula makes me slightly nauseous (in which
case I pop a Zofran) and has elevated my blood pressure a bit (but not into dangerous
territory, which is good). My last round of blood work revealed some 'renal insufficiency' -
my kidneys are working hard to flush out all the toxins and it is crucial for me to stay
hydrated. I think my liver numbers looked a bit 'wonky' as well for the same reason. I'll
have more blood work done on Tuesday, including a test targeting kidney function. On
the whole I've been sleeping better than a week or so ago, when I contended with a bout
of bad insomnia. Also somewhat troubling is a huge black and blue mark as well as quite
a few smaller ones where I've injected myself with Lovenox (blood thinner) twice daily
(I'm doing this because my last CT scan revealed two tiny blood clots, one in my lung the
other in my leg - these were *overlooked* by the Geisinger radiologists but fortunately
the Hopkins radiologists identified them). As I'm far from an expert in giving myself
shots, I am likely not doing it perfectly and it's probably causing some mild trauma to the
injection sites. When I showed my beat-up looking legs to the nurse practitioner last
week (as well as a few spots where the injection site also felt slightly swollen) she told
me it was nothing to worry about. However, tomorrow I'm going to send a picture of my
'not ready for swimsuit weather' gams to Dr. Beavis' nurse and see what she has to say.
Perhaps because of the blood thinner I'm more susceptible to bruising. More battle scars!
I was overjoyed, of course, to have Ben home this week. We had a lot of fun just hanging
out, watching a movie ("City of Gold," an intriguing documentary about the late LA food
critic, Jonathan Gold), taking a drive, eating nice home cooked meals etc. Wednesday we
were riveted to CNN, watching the ghastly, dismaying, unbelievable events unfold at the
Capitol. I still feel traumatized by having witnessed such desecration. Friday night I felt
compelled to try to usher in 'sabbath peace' (shabbat shalom) and to glean some Jewish
perspectives on the tragedy, so I streamed the service at Sixth & I, a well-known
progressive synagogue in D.C. The rabbi spoke about the power of the visual, of 'seeing
is believing,' comparing Moses' shock and anger at witnessing the Israelites worshipping
the Golden Calf when he descended from Mt. Sinai to the horror many of us felt faced
with such abhorrent images. We're starting the book of Exodus now: things got worse
before they got better...
In any event, Ben is here (actually at Michael's) until Tuesday and I hope to see him
briefly tomorrow. He is doing well and it was comforting to know that he was sleeping in
his 'lair' upstairs. He will meet up with Sammi for a few nights' getaway in the Poconos
before they return to Brooklyn and to work and school.
...I will be doing the same this week, getting my syllabus ready for the first week of class
(beginning the 19th) and taking care of department business, while also pressing ahead
on a writing project.
                       640 / 1.901
My monthly walk at the Military Museum w/my #willapower friends (five of us today), on
a brisk yet sunny January morning, was lovely. We were all so worked up about politics
that there was hardly time for other catch up, but that's what's preoccupying us right
now.

January 18, 2021 - "Where do we go from here?"
  by Willa Silverman, January 18, 2021  
The briefest of updates as I haven't written in a while. Our semester begins tomorrow
and I've been busy preparing while continuing to take care of department business. I'm
teaching my undergraduate course on France and the Holocaust in Film and Literature,
which is always a meaningful experience for me (and hopefully the students). No trip to
Paris over spring break in conjunction with the course this semester, however (sadly). In
fact, because of COVID concerns we don't even get a spring break this term, but three
'wellness days" instead (I will need them, for sure).
I am feeling alright, pretty much status quo. Dr. Patel lowered my dose of Lovenox (blood
thinner) b/c it was thinning my blood too much. I am still giving myself two injections per
day in my thigh or belly, and those areas still look beat up, black and blue. I should be
                       643 / 1.901
able to switch to Coumedin or some other blood thinner soon, which can be taken orally.
I am not even sure why my oncs opted for injections now; perhaps they are more
effective. As long as they have successfully resolved the two tiny clots the CT scan
showed up.
The Zejula (oral chemo med) still makes me slightly nauseous (Zofran helps with that)
but the worse/worst side effect is insomnia, especially now that the semester is starting.
Calming music, regular bedtime routine etc. do not seem to help (but must avoid screen
time....). I'm switching to taking it in the morning in the hope that some of Zejula's
intensity may have worn off by bedtime. Grrr.
I'll have my blood checked tomorrow or W and I guess it will be time for my CA125
number to be checked too. And perhaps my kidney function too. I undergo so many
'checks' that it's honestly hard to keep track sometimes, esp. w/everything else going
on. This is where my sometimes less than stellar organization skills fail me, but I am
trying to keep on top of things. 
The title of my post today is of course the title of MLK's last book, _Where do we go from
here?: Chaos or community._ This question has been resonating with me, of course on
MLK's bday but also in light of all the recent turmoil in our country. Let's hope next time I
write we'll have a new president and VP in place, and that the transition will have been
peaceful. Good riddance to the wicked man. 
I expect to have news to share soon.
On a lighter note (see YouTube clip): Heigh-ho!

January 24, 2021 - VERY BIG NEWS
  by Willa Silverman, January 24, 2021  
I have some very big news to share: in June of this year I'll be retiring from Penn State,
after thirty-three years of service.
It all started one day last semester, when I surprised myself by blurting out loudly, when
I was at home alone: "I want to retire and move back to New York." As this seemed a
directive shooting directly from my unconscious into my conscious state -- much like the
experience of waking up with a start from a half-dream and yelling something out loud --
I thought I should listen to that voice.
But in fact it took me months to figure out how to respond to that it. On one hand: I love
my job, adore teaching, my colleagues, my department, university settings, academic
life, walking briskly through a bustling campus as classes change, schmoozing in my
colleagues' offices. Being an academic is part of my core identity, and Penn State has
been my safe space since I was 29. 
Wouldn't it be ill-advised to give that up?
On the other: I am battling advanced ovarian cancer that may well recur (necessitating
another course of debilitating IV chemo). It's become nearly impossible for me to
marshal the necessary time and physical and emotional wherewithal needed to give
myself the best shot at maintaining the best possible quality of life for as long as
possible while carrying on the various parts of my job (teaching, research, department
headship) with the intensity and focus they deserve, and require. Stress is particularly
wearing on me as a cancer patient, as are the side effects of my medications, the many
medical appointments I must keep, the blood tests and CT/PET scans, and all the rest.
For months both my oncologists have been encouraging me to consider retirement. Dr.
                       645 / 1.901
Beavis said: "I think it will be better for your mental health, which in turn will be better
for your physical health." Shouldn't I give weight to the recommendations of my medical
team?
Of course, but isn't focusing my energies on a job I love and find meaningful equally
therapeutic?" Don't many cancer patients continue to work? Can't I just 'tough it out' and
'power through' as I've been doing for decades?
In the end, I think it's time for me to be realistic about my situation. The decision,
though, was agonizing.
"...and move back to New York." I'm not sure when I might follow through on that plan,
as the voice told me to do, but I do know that I also want to ensure that I have a "post-
Penn State chapter" to my life. I am aware of the odds against long-term survival of OC
(although I continue to be inspired by the stories of women who have thrived for years
with the disease, effectively beating it). The other day, I posted an envious comment on
a friend's Facebook photo of Nathan's Famous Hot Dogs in Coney Island, where my
friend had stopped for a few of those mouth-watering dogs and some fries after visiting
his mother. "Next time you're in the city," he responded, "let's meet in Coney Island and
go to Nathan's. The hot dogs will taste better there." The luxury of spending a sunny
weekday in Coney Island with a friend -- strolling on the boardwalk, dipping my feet in
the ocean, enjoying the guilty pleasure of a dog w/kraut and extra mustard -- makes me
positively giddy with excitement. To further encourage pleasurable forward thinking, my
recently-retired friend and former colleague Monique sent me a series of tantalizing
images: a lavender field in Provence; an open-air seafood restaurant, perhaps near the
Cape, at sunset;the Eiffel Tower.
Another fear: does retiring mean that cancer has 'won,' that it eventually wore me down
to the point at which I could no longer devote myself single-mindedly to my professional
life? Or, conversely, does it mean that I am making a mindful choice to take on this
fucking disease in optimal conditions?
Of course, there is fear of the unknown, of sea change. It's in a way comparable to my
divorce (but much less traumatically so) in that the future seems a blank slate, defying
my attempts to fully envision it. It's a 'down the rabbit hole,' 'through the looking glass
moment.' But the next chapter will be mine to write (w/apologies for that trite image).
...but speaking of writing, I do intend to remain an active researcher/writer (w/more time
to devote to those pleasures), will remain at the helm of the doctoral committee that I
chair and member of several others of which I'm a member; will attend conferences and
campus events; and hope to stay connected in other ways.
I'll miss my colleagues (esp my those who are *friends*) terribly. They are my tribe.
                       646 / 1.901
Another fear: finances. over the past several months my financial advisor and I have run
the numbers several times as has my TIAA-CREF advisor. I should be more than ok,
meaning that I should have at least as much to live on per month as I do now. That's a
reassuring thought. But it's more or less a finite sum. And it's strange to imagine not
having income (although I hope some short-term teachings gigs etc. will eventually come
my way). I'm bad with budgets, and enjoy a free-spending lifestyle. I'll need to manage
my finances better, and curtail my frequent impulse buying (which should not be hard,
as I have *plenty* of everything).
I can't wait to travel again as soon as it's safe, and hope to spend more time in the city
with friends and family. I like the idea of coming full circle. I've been transfixed by
descriptions and images of the cool apartments I could rent (let's hope that the rents
stay as reasonable as they have been, due to New Yorkers leaving the city during
COVID). There's a new building on the LES (Essex Street) atop a fabulous foodie heaven
market, boasting an exercise room full of Peloton bikes and a rooftop pool. I think I could
picture myself there, on a high floor with views of the East River and the bridges. It's
magical at night.
But I'm getting ahead of myself. There will be an adjustment period I'm sure, and I'll
more than likely take ample time to downsize, purging my boxes and boxes of files, class
notes etc., and to get used to the new normal.
It's been wrenching to share the news with colleagues. Tears have been shed all around.
The Dean has been very supportive. I feel emotionally drained.
I hope I am making the right choice and that a higher power (and my own fortitude) will
grant me the good health to enjoy what lies ahead.
In other news, if all goes as planned I'll be receiving the first does of the COVID vaccine
this Friday!

January 28, 2021 - A Good Day
  by Willa Silverman, January 28, 2021  
Good health news today: my CA125 level (OC marker) is 13 this month, down from 15.7
last month. Anything over 38 may be a warning sign. I was *overjoyed* and energized to
receive this news. This means that the Zejula (chemo pill that I take daily) appears to be
working. May it continue!! In my mind "I'm only as healthy as my last CA125 test or CT-
scan," but at the very least this means I have another 'reprieve' for a month. I'll take it!
The full blood panel returned numbers that are also 'stable.' That's good too. 
Tomorrow I'll get my first COVID shot at a hospital in Lewistown, about 25 miles from
here. That's another piece of good news. I will be grateful for this extra layer of
protection. Of course, I hope nothing untoward happens (eg allergic reaction), but if does
I'll be in the best possible setting to be treated.
I've been telling Penn State people little by little about my retirement. I want to tell as
many people as I can in person (albeit virtually). Today I shared the news with our
graduate students. They were extraordinarily kind, caring, and gracious. Several were
crying and others wrote me touching notes afterwards. I want to be able to be 'in the
moment' to the greatest extent possible, to be present for this outpouring of compassion
and honesty. I'm trying, but to be honest it's emotionally overwhelming, as this entire
process of decision-making and its aftermath has been.
A few more random thoughts on my retirement (I'm sure there will be others going
forward):
>It's rather a shame that I'm 'going out at the top of my game,' so to speak. I hope this
doesn't sound vain, but in many ways, I feel like I'm at the apogee of my career in terms
of expertise, skill and experience in the classroom, sharpness of critical thinking and
creativity etc. I really feel like I'm nailing it in the classroom this semester, partly out of a
desire, I suppose, to 'leave it all on the floor' before I go. I don't know if there's a causal
link, but the students seem highly engaged. Maybe I just got lucky with an excellent
class. And the Zoom format is really not bad. I learned how to use some new tools that
                       651 / 1.901
the students seem to enjoy (including one that lets the entire class annotate a document
together). Although nothing can substitute for F2F teaching, Zoom is not the horror I
imagined it might be.
Perhaps it's good, though, that I'm leaving 'at the top of my game.' As my friend Cheryl
Glenn wisely pointed out, I'm leaving on my own terms. The wheels are in motion
because of my decision. ('m being proactive (although I arguably could have made the
decision before Fall semester, for example, but clearly I wasn't ready yet). No 'epic fail'
like two springs ago, when everything fell to pieces when I was diagnosed in May 2019
and literally had to run out of the office, leaving papers and files and books strewn
everywhere, to start scrambling to get treatment set up.
>A minor point, perhaps (and completely unrelated to my last one), my financial advisor
and friend, Deb Guerrero (who has been immensely helpful during this entire period)
reminded me that my investments will continue to generate income. Financially, this is
not a zero sum game. Further reassurance that financially things should be ok for me.
>Having made my decision, I am actually starting to feel better physically (and
mentally). Perhaps it's the Zejula working its magic, but I am also simply feeling
progressively 'lighter' as I begin this countdown period (26 class sessions to go). I will
probably be a mess on the last day of class. It's all so bittersweet.
Be well, everyone and THANK YOU for the many supportive comments on my last entry
(in addition to emails and texts). I will *try* to respond to your posts if I can.

February 8, 2021 - 'Steady as she goes'
  by Willa Silverman, February 8, 2021  
                       654 / 1.901
                       655 / 1.901
Things are basically status quo, which is a good thing, but I thought I'd give a quick
update anyway. I say' basically status quo' because I was feeling somewhat under the
weather today. I've had a headache for the past two days, which I just managed to rid
myself of by lying down for a while. The headache in turn made me quite nauseous; I set
out for the supermarket this afternoon to pick up a few items but actually decided to turn
around and return home as a wave of nausea overtook me. My right side (ie my 'bad'
side, on which I was operated last March to resolve a fistula) is feeling slightly sore,
which always makes me nervous. I have a big welt on my right thigh where I had been
giving myself injections of blood thinner until about two weeks ago. Is it normal that it
hasn't gone down yet? Finally, I don't have much appetite so I'm just going to eat a
baked sweet potato for dinner.
I wouldn't describe any of these symptoms as acute, and as I'd been feeling pretty well
for the past week or so I'll wait and see what happens. I did query Dr. Patel's nurse about
the welt. It's very easy for me to become anxious and dive into worst case scenario land
(recurrence? another fistula?) so I need to try to stay grounded in the present. I think
getting over the retirement decision 'hump, which involved very honest, authentic yet
emotionally-charged conversations with colleagues, staff, students, administrators etc.,
has been rather draining. I'm increasingly at peace with the decision but enacting it is
hard work.
In better news, I did get my first COVID shot. Had to drive about 25 miles to the hospital
in Lewistown, but the setup was excellent, very professional. I told the pharmacist who
inoculated me to be quick to act if I had an allergic reaction, but everything went
smoothly. The staff keeps an eye on everyone who's just been vaccinated for half an
hour afterwards, to make sure no one falls ill. I'll have my second shot on Feb. 26th.
Strangely, I spent most of my weekend obsessively researching my family's genealogy.
I've conducted this type of research for many years in the context of my own work, and
definitely have the skill set to dig deep. It's odd that I've never used these skills to learn
more about my own ancestry (I'm addicted to Henry Louis Gates' show, Finding your
Roots, and fantasize about being his 'ordinary person' guest one day!). I think part of my
motivation derives from wanting to come full circle somehow, to reconnect with my roots
during this 'existential' phase of my life (it's akin to my desire to return to my
hometown). Anyway, I unearthed all sorts of documents (ships' manifests, divorce
records). I learned that my great grandfather William Goldberg (a 'card-carrying
Communist' in Vilna, according to one genealogy site), after whom I'm named, was
actually born....David Cohen (all the names were changed when the various strands of
the family arrived in the States from E. Europe). I also confirmed that at least one of my
great-grandmother's sisters, as well as my great-grandfather's first wife, died in a
concentration camp. So many questions. Writing all this up as a kind of 'memory book'
                       656 / 1.901
seems an attractive retirement project.
Finally, for the second year in a row I hope to participate in the Kelly Gynecologic
Oncology Service's (Johns Hopkins) "Below the Belt" Stride and Thrive fundraiser, a 5K
run or 1K walk that will take place on 6 June 2021. The event will again be virtual this
year (instead of taking place in Baltimore), so I hope State College friends will join me
again (we had much fun last year) and that others may consider running/walking
wherever you may find yourself on that date (or come join us in Happy Valley, if the
COVID coast is clear[er]). You can make a donation at any point to my team,
#willapower, via this link:https://runsignup.com/willapower
And you can sign up to join my team here (I
think): https://runsignup.com/RaceGroups/70197
I'm looking ahead to June with hope. This cause means a lot to me. For better or worse,
'cancer survivor' is now a core part of my identity, and if I can pay it forward and help
other women combat this awful disease, I'm all in.
Pic on right is my great-grandfather David Cohen aka Willy Goldberg!
Photos

XOXO

February 20, 2021 - Checking in
  by Willa Silverman, February 20, 2021  
I haven't written in a while. I'm stable right now - not much to report. No news is good
news. I didn't feel terrific this week, though. Discomfort on my right side (my 'bad' side)
and a kind of 'twinge' in my abdomen warranted a blood test, which revealed elevated
liver marker numbers. Three nights of awful insomnia did not help. But my visit with the
nurse practitioner yesterday was reassuring: the liver numbers are, apparently, not
worrisomely high, and a follow-up bilirubin test Dr. Patel ordered yielded normal results.
Moreover, the nurse practitioner felt nothing abnormal on palpating my entire abdominal
area. This was a reassuring report. This morning I slept until 11 a.m. and feel *much*
better. The next 'fingers crossed' moment will occur on W, when my all-important CA 125
level will be assessed via bloodwork. Next Friday I'll receive my second dose of the
                       658 / 1.901
COVID vaccine.
We've been in a deep freeze for several weeks -- lots of snow, sleet, subfreezing temps.
Enormous icicles hang from the exterior of my house. The icicles have icicles! I'm longing
for warmer weather. Hoping to absorb some of that powerful energy I feel when the sun
moves into Pisces, which means that my birthday is around the bend!
I had a strange dream last night, during my deep eleven hour slumber. A notable aspect
of it was that it was 'framed:' I was recounting a story to someone, which then played
out in the dream. I was in a house with other people, but some sort of dangerous 
situation prompted me to flee. I then found myself outside the house, in a snow-covered
landscape at night, trying to escape along with a PSU colleague from Jewish Studies,
Daniel F. [footnote 1]. We were running together through the dark cold snow, headed
towards a forest, when a large wild boar ran across our path and startled me. We made it
into the forest, when I turned and saw a huge black (or brown bear) a few yards from
me. I stayed in place and screamed several times, hoping it would scare the bear away.
That didn't work. I'm not sure what happened next, but Daniel figured out a way to
escape the scary situation by *flying* off on some sort of contraption (like an individual
flying machine). I don't know what happened to me but presumably I escaped too.
The next part of the dream was different. I was also in a house but with a handsome man
whom I didn't recognize. Perhaps he was visiting me. I strongly wanted to be with him,
but my desire was thwarted by a phone call from Gail G., a friend from college [footnote
2]. I hadn't spoken with her in a long time, and felt it would be rude to cut the call short.
She launched into a very detailed account of the union work she was doing (in real life
she is, indeed, a labor advocate and organizer), describing in minute detail the types of
projects she was currently working on for several unions. That's all I remember.
footnote 1: Daniel F., a colleague from Jewish Studies>> a) I am currently teaching my
cross-listed FR/JST course on France and the Holocaust in Film and Literature. Mass
killing, death from disease and starvation, and other horrors are often on the agenda.
The material is very much present with me, obviously seeping into my subconscious life
as well; b)Daniel F. did not attend our JST faculty meeting on Thursday, as he usually
does, but here he was in my dream, fully present; c)Daniel F. recently lost his brother
and parents (to COVID) in quick succession. That's a lot of death to deal with. 
footnote 2: Gail G. >> College friend with whom I'm in touch from time to time and have
seen several times since graduation (in PA and Cali), but still very much connected to my
college years. My dream may well have pointed towards the zoom reunion in which I
participated tonight with some classmates who lived in the same dorm as me in college
(it's our reunion year, but sadly we can't be together in Cambridge so a bunch of virtual
events are planned). 
                       659 / 1.901
It's crazy how intertwined life and death, desire and death, Eros and Thanatos, the
coming spring w/its vitality and promise of rebirth and this long 'winter of my soul' are
for me these days. Both are my companions, in often shifting balance. I think my dream
was trying to tell me that but did not give me clues about how to balance these forces.
At least that's how it feels to me. [note to self: must stay off the Facebook page for
women living with ovarian cancer; it's way too scary].
On a more prosaic note, I am greatly enjoying my teaching this semester! I have some
wonderful students. And I'm very busy with department work and thinking about the
(probably virtual) lecture I need to prepare for May, at the Virginia Museum of Fine Art.
And looking forward to several events being planned around my retirement!

February 25, 2021 - Good news/slightly less good news
  by Willa Silverman, February 25, 2021  
The good news from this month's bloodwork is that my CA125 number -- the ovarian
cancer marker that I await with extreme trepidation each month, steeling myself to open
the message containing it -- is steady at 13.4 U/ml, up from 13 last month. THANK GOD,
as the number indicates that the parp inhibitor I take daily for maintenance is working.
The .4 is insignificant; the number would have needed to have increased by at least 50%
to cause worry. And as a reminder, any number up to 38.1 is within normal range. So I
have a month's 'reprieve' before I need to start worrying again. YES. Every day a
blessing.
The slightly less good news is that my hemoglobin level is low: 8.1 g/dL whereas it
should be a minimum of either 9 or 12 (I was presented with two slightly varying
numbers). This may explain why I have sometimes felt a bit winded recently on minimal
physical exertion: my red blood cells are not receiving ample enough oxygen.
Consequently, I need to stop taking the Zejula (parp inhibitor) for now, and will have my
blood tested again next week. Anemia is apparently quite a common side effect of taking
Zejula, as are higher than usual liver marker numbers (which I have too).
My immediate fear was that those nasty cancer cells would somehow detect that the
Zejula was no longer headed out to beat them up every day up and would say to each
other: "Come on guys, now's our chance!" However, both Dr. Beavis and Dr. Patel's
nurse assured me this is not the case. The medication stays in my blood stream for at
least a week. And many studies have shown that stoppage for even longer than that
does not affect treatment. Many Zejula-takers start and stop and start. Ultimately, my
dosage may need to be lowered. But I'm not there yet. So I'll try to up my iron rich foods
this coming week (I'm not a big red meat eater but a big juicy hamburger may be in my
future); oddly enough, I was told to avoid liver, but I'll snag a few bags of fresh spinach
next time I'm at the store).
Dr. Beavis was quite reassuring and wrote: "Please try not to worry - Dr. Patel is taking
great care of you!"  So I will indeed listen to my oncologist extraordinaire Anna Beavis
and try not to worry. At least for now.
I get my second COVID shot tomorrow!
We've had some lovely sunny days with temps in the 40s and 50s and a slant of light
that hints at spring. After class today I took a long drive in the country to clear my mind,
the farms and still snow-covered fields glistening in the sun and the creeks starting to
                       661 / 1.901
swell. So pretty. 
My birthday is around the corner. Last year it fell right before my fistula-repair operation
(on the 9th) and the onset of the pandemic. I was able to gather friends at a restaurant
we like for drinks and dinner. No such luck this year but I'll think about what might be
arranged.

March 5, 2021 - Back on the roller coaster
  by Willa Silverman, March 5, 2021  
                       662 / 1.901
I had a lovely birthday yesterday, and was literally deluged with social media greetings,
cards, texts, phone calls, zoom calls, flower deliveries, other gifts, and a host of random
acts of kindness. As I wrote on my Facebook page, an advantage (!?) of cancer is that my
bar for happiness is set very low: any day I wake up alive and feeling reasonably well I
am deliriously happy. Yesterday was no exception: every new message or text or card I
read made me smile and I felt very loved! I also received several donations for my
fundraiser for KGOS. Because I also publicly announced my retirement on social media, I
received lovely messages from a number of former students, thanking me and wishing
me well. 
It was a busy day: I had some class prep and grading to take care of in the morning, then
I ran out for about an hour to have my blood checked and to pick up a library book, then
returned for class (which went well). After that, I packed up a cooler and headed to
Spring Creek Park, where I had invited about ten or so friends to gather for a little bday
celebration, w/champagne and cake. Since March was truly "coming in like a lion"
                       663 / 1.901
yesterday, it was windy and cold with an occasional ray of sun piercing the clouds, and
we did our best to hold down the napkins, paper plates and cups flying everywhere. We
stayed no more than an hour but a convivial time was had by all and it was so nice to
see my friends 'in the flesh' instead of as simulacra on a computer screen. And the
gurgling creek and picturesque covered bridge always cheer me.
Although I received an automated message that the results of my bloodwork had come
in yesterday - as well as, truth be told.... -- a phone message from Dr. Patel's office
asking me to call to discuss the results -- I had decided that I would put off any unwanted
news until this morning. As expected (suspected?), yesterday's bloodwork showed very
low hemoglobin levels (even lower than last time), so I'll need to have a blood
transfusion on Monday. I stopped by Dr. Patel's office this afternoon to get further details
from his head nurse, Kayla, who gave me a sheaf of orders to take to the lab at the
hospital lab tomorrow so that they can run further tests on my blood (folic acid, B12,
iron, bilirubin etc.). Monday I need to be at the hospital at 7:00 (I am *not* an early riser)
and the transfusion will take the better part of the day, but the good news is that I'll
likely feel much better (ie less winded and fatigued) afterwards. I'll bring my work with
me and see what I can manage. I'm definitely bummed that in the meantime I can't take
my chemo med -- which is the likely culprit as far as the decrease in hemoglobin goes --
for one more week, two weeks, who knows. And when/if I resume it, it may be at a lower
dose. And that means that much less Zejua in my system to combat my cancer. But the
blood issue needs to be resolved now, before it impacts my bone marrow -- which would
not be good. So back to one day at a time. Ugh.
Dr. Patel was very busy, very harried, as he is sometimes, and was a bit brusque with
me, which I can handle. He was fairly insistent on 'we have to do this first before we can
determine next steps,' so he didn't have much patience for questions I had about 'what
ifs.' He assured me that I should be fine this weekend and that I will feel much more
energetic after the transfusion, which I don't doubt. He has so many patients. I really
wish that Geisinger could hire another oncologist or two.
I'll try to rest and relax as much as I can this weekend but I do have some work to take
care of, with two big reports due this month. Last time I had a blood transfusion I did feel
much better from it, so I hope that will be the case again. I'm of course nervous about
being in the hospital w/so many COVID patients there: I'm about a week out from my
second COVID shot so the antibodies are still kicking in. And there are always risks
w/transfusions, but I know the blood will be scrupulously screened beforehand -- and I'm
thankful to whomever donated it.
I did take a long drive today to clear my head. The sight of cows, horses, barns and fields
in this last stretch of winter helped me relax.
I hope to individually contact everyone who sent birthday greetings. I so appreciate the
                       664 / 1.901
well wishes. It just must take me a little while. XO
Photos
                       665 / 1.901
                       666 / 1.901

March 8, 2021 - Pumped
  by Willa Silverman, March 8, 2021  
My transfusion appeared to go well today. It did not take as long as expected, as I was
done by about 12:40. My wonderful friend Maria was kind enough to drive me to the
cancer pavilion at the hospital for 7 a.m. while my equally wonderful friend Helen picked
me up afterwards and drove me to pick up a cappuccino. This gave us time, coming and
going, to dish about the Harry-Meghan-Oprah interview and catch up on this and that.
Maybe I've been spoiled by Hopkins (and even Geisinger here), but the care at the
hospital seemed subpar to me. They had no records regarding my prior transfusion at
the hospital, my medications, previous surgeries etc. At one point, the nurse didn't seem
to know whether I had received one bag of blood already or two. Worst, while adjusting
my chair, the nurse *twice* yanked on the syringe connected via a needle to my port,
through which I was receiving the blood. The second time, she yanked so hard that the
needle came flying out of my port (which is inserted underneath the skin on my upper
chest) along with the entire dressing covering it. It hurt like a mofo and I just had to
scream *F***!* at the top of my lungs. The needle had to be reinserted, the syringe
cleaned out etc. Nor terribly reassuring, when I was really looking forward to having the
nurses take care of me. Oh well. The bottom line is that I was pumped up with two bags
of fresh, healthy blood that will hopefully energize me and ensure that my body's getting
sufficient oxygen. I think I feel a bit better now but I'm not entirely sure: I'm tired
because I didn't sleep well, or much, last night. We'll see what tomorrow brings. The
nurse said it might take a day or two for me to feel better. She noted that my color was
improved when I left the hospital; apparently, I looked somewhat ashen on arrival.
I'll have my blood tested on Thursday and Dr. Patel will assess the hemoglobin levels. I
don't know when I'll be able to start taking the Zejula again. Dr. Beavis reassured me by
letting me know that studies have shown that it can be just as effective if taken at a
lower dose, which is what may be in store for me.
I dozed on the couch for a while and did some work after that. The weather is turning
more spring-like and I want to be able to take walks and maybe some short hikes. The
health issues are very frustrating but I need to take one day at a time. 
                       668 / 1.901
My longtime housecleaner, Liz, brought over (at my request) a tray of eggplant
parmigiana made by her husband, Phil, a phenomenal Italian-American home cook. The
perfect comfort food for tonight. Hope to get back on track tomorrow, and look forward
to a 'wellness day' on Thursday (ie one of three days we are off from teaching this
semester in exchange for losing our spring break to COVID concerns).

March 19, 2021 - It's all in the scheme of things
  by Willa Silverman, March 19, 2021  
It's been a very chaotic week-ten days and I feel wiped out. I think I did not report here
that last week (or perhaps ten days ago), a few days after my transfusion, I walked into
my kitchen in the morning and noticed that a medium sized patch on the ceiling above
the fridge was wet and 'bulging;' it looked like a water-filled 'sac' of paint had dropped
down and was about to burst. I called the managing agent for my condo complex
immediately and two of their guys came over; they reported that my water heater was
busted and leaking into the kitchen ceiling (as I do not have a basement, my water
heater is in a utility closet on the second floor). They recommended two plumbing
companies, which I called immediately; as the first was tied up for several days, I made
arrangements for the second to come assess the damage and hopefully do the repairs.
In the meantime, I also called the construction company that I had used the previous
time this happened (leak from upstairs bathroom...) and my insurance company. I am
thankful that the benefits of my transfusion were starting to kick in and I had the
wherewithal, for the most part, to handle the aggravation.
Long story short: I had to endure five days of of cohabiting with three ginormous
dehumidifers that made it feel and sound like a blast furnace in my home; am out $3K to
pay for a new hot water heater (insurance won't cover it but it does enhance the value of
my home a bit); and had to deal with plumbers who were both incompetent and total
*gonifs:* their work was so awful that they had to come back the next day and redo it
entirely; the hot water in my kitchen sink is no more than a trickle, so I'll need to have
them return next week. And the owner of said plumbing company (Allied Mechanical and
Electrical: State College friends, do *not* use them!) promised me pie in the sky (free
inspections for several years; a stern talking to the plumbers who messed up; no extra
payment; and all of this in writing -- which I've yet to receive). So I will definitely be on
the phone Monday morning w/stern words and demands.
Oy.
Maybe this is the universe telling me to move to NY (or stay here) and become a renter.
I have a lot of work as we get towards the end of the semester, not just for my class but
for the department (evaluations of colleagues, all sorts of reports, budget stuff,
proposals to be submitted before I retire etc.). I'm running a bit late on some tasks partly
b/c of the chaos of the past ten days. And taxes!
Oy.
                       670 / 1.901
A friend with whom I took a walk on Sunday with a group of other lovely women (we
meet once a month) tested positive for COVID, along with several family members. I feel
terribly for her. This prompted me though to hastily schedule a COVID test for this
morning. Even though I'm fully vaccinated, even though we were walking outside and my
friend was fully masked (I took my mask off a few times to inhale some extra oxygen), I
want to be extra careful for *Ben's* sake, as he's coming home tomorrow to spend a
week here. I'll get the results in 2-7 days. Further, I queried both my PCP and my
oncologist here; both consider me 'low risk' to either contract or transmit COVID. The
CDC guidelines confirm this: vaccinated people (vaccinatees?) apparently can be around
people with COVID if they follow precautions (masking etc.). The CDC would only advise
testing if I became symptomatic.
But it's all in the scheme of things. There is better news:
Did I mention that Ben is coming home tomorrow for a week??! Which means, among
other things, that we may be able to have a little seder together, like we did last year,
for Passover. He'll be very busy with schoolwork, as will I, but it will be terrific to have
him here!
Of course as all this chaos is occurring I am also running weekly to the lab for bloodwork,
sending messages to Dr. Patel's nurse via the Geisinger portal, debriefing about my
bloodwork with the pharmacist who works with Dr. Patel and who calls me every time
new results come in (she's specializes in cancer meds such as Zejula), setting up
delivery times for my Zejula ETC. ETC. A job in itself.
So Annie (the pharmacist) called shortly before I both went to get my COVID test and
greeted the contractor assessing the kitchen ceiling damage. Thank God my numbers
are still stable overall, despite being slightly low or high here or there. My hemoglobin
level is inching back up to normal range (it had cratered as a result of my taking 200 mg
of Zejula [which caused me to be very winded], now cut in half to 100 mg daily). My
kidney function number was a bit off but we both feel certain that it was because I was
dehydrated; I distinctly remember leaving my drink in the car by accident as I walked
into the lab and thinking to myself: "I'm thirsty, and I know it's going to affect my
numbers." Next labs in two weeks.
Finally, my all-important CA125 number is considered stable. It's risen from 13.4 last
month to 17.1 this month; an increase of 3.7. Of course I worry about that slight upward
trend two months in a row, but Annie reminded me that anything up to 38 is normal, and
I'm still more than 50% under that. The drs. start to worry with very notable increases
(such as doubling), whereas a slight variation like this can be due to any number of
factors (stress, dehydration etc.). So I will simply decide not to worry about this for a
month, until my next test. Thankfully, all my numbers have been generally stable for the
past 5-6 months. I'll take it. Every day a blessing!
                       671 / 1.901
