October 20, 2021 - Rhonda died/On the Road Again
  by Willa Silverman, October 20, 2021  
Greetings from Baltimore.
My 'teal sister' Rhonda Gold, whom I never met but knew only through social media as
an OC survivor treated at Hopkins, died a day or two ago, in her late sixties, after a six or
seven year bout with OC. I've been wearing the pendant Rhonda sent me bearing the
cancer bow, two teal colored stones, and the words "Chazak ve'ematz" ("Be strong and
of good courage"), from the Book of Joshua. Someone had given it to her one Rosh
Hashanah and she entrusted it to me, as I hope to entrust it, eventually, to another OC
survivor. I wish I had met her. She seemed like an extraordinary, vibrant woman, like me
most 'afilliative' (to use a word my therapist sometimes uses to describe me). On her
                       836 / 1.901
Facebook page today, a quote from the 13th-century Persian poet Rumi: "Goodbyes are
only for those who love with their eyes. Because for those who love with heart and soul
there is no such thing as separation."
I'm in Baltimore for a few physical screening appointments prior to my first treatment
next week (I hope) as part of a clinical trial at Hopkins. This being said, Hopkins appears
to have been very late submitting the precertification request to my insurance company
so it hasn't been approved yet (frankly, I don't even know if it's even been submitted).
Aetna needs to clear everything by next Wednesday, when I have a biopsy (I agreed to
enroll in a second study that involves studying tumor samples). Aggravation.
Let me apologize off the bat to those whom I might have 'left hanging' as I try to work
out complicated logistics for the next month, when I'll be travelling to Baltimore once a
week for treatment, most likely from New York. My focus has been on getting the first
one or two weeks set up (a complicated endeavor in itself) but I promise to be in touch
asap with those most generous family members and friends who have offered rides,
accompaniment to Baltimore, housing, and meals/errands/miscellaneous. Much as I
treasure my independence, I unfortunately can't make the next month (or more) work
without help, so I am extremely grateful for the generous responses. Thank you.
I also owe some emails and will try to get back to everyone asap!
Plans, plans, plans. Plans will keep me busy this next month. And busy-ness is a bulwark
against anxiety, depression, and worry. Dr. Beavis said: "I can't give you a cure, but I can
give you a plan." So I grasp at plans and their myriad components, hopefully. "These
fragments I have shored against my ruins."
I am feeling ok, with some slight discomfort in my abdomen/pelvic area and back. I am
very eager to begin treatment before my cancer has any more time to grow/spread, and
equally eager to assess whether treatment is working as soon after that as possible. If
it's not, we're on to the next plan. That *might* be a clinical trial at Memorial Sloan-
Kettering, if they can offer me a potentially (more) effective treatment or trial. Since I
will spend most of November in NY, Dr. Beavis suggested I schedule a consult there,
which I find a great idea. She has already sent a gyn onc surgeon she deems 'terrific' my
information and I hope to contact her asap. I'll see Dr. Beavis tomorrow and she can
advise.
I had such a pleasant drive down here. It's really not arduous at all: perhaps 3.5 hours
driving time. A gorgeous fall day with the foliage colors becoming deeper, more vibrant
and varied the further south I drove. I stopped for lunch at Alvaro's (alvarobread.com), a
'real deal' Italian bakery that has long been my midway point/pit stop between State
College and Baltimore/DC. It's a small place on a corner in the historical downtown area
of Harrisburg (which I think they call 'Uptown?'), casual, full of state government
                       837 / 1.901
employees and locals who appear to be regular customers. A few tables with umbrellas
outside. The 'nonna' holds down the fort in the kitchen, producing the mouth-watering
daily specials; I dug into delicious soft meatballs in sauce with a side of homemade bread
that I dipped in the sauce, then bought stuffed shells and sausage to take with me for
dinner tonight, along with a hefty portion of pastries (a cannoli, an eclair, a mini
sfogliatelle and a few cookies). It is always shocking to see the housing inequities in
Harrisburg (and of course Baltimore, much of it right near the JH Medical Center), block
upon block of dilapidated houses along with lovely renovated Victorians and a glistening
Susquehanna waterfront.
I'm back at my 'home away from home' here in Baltimore: the Marriott Residence Inn
Johns Hopkins Medical Center, where I've stayed many times. Many JHMC patients stay
here and the staff is kindly, the rooms ultra-clean and quiet, the free breakfast copious.
The top floor restaurant with the great view (my friend Sandy, mom, Ethan and Ben will
remember it) apparently did not survive the pandemic, but I ordered a small salad from
the bar downstairs. While I'd prefer not to remember some of my previous post-surgery
or post-procedure visits here, tonight I am feeling strong physically and mentally, ready
to move forward. I continue to be blessed to "walk with good companions."
If all goes as planned, I'll drive back to State College tomorrow and can't wait to hug Ben
and Sammi, who will be arriving for the weekend on Friday. I'll return here next Tuesday
for my biopsy Wednesday morning and treatment and other appointments on Thursday.
As promised, I will be in touch asap (certainly once I return to SC) with the kind
friends/family members who have offered me rides to/from Baltimore as well as help 'on
the ground' (I must have a 'caregiver' with me for the biopsy and likely for treatment as
well). Then back to SC for  a few days before driving to New York with my friend Deb, to
stay until.... Thanksgiving? That's the tentative plan, although it's always possible I may
only go so far with the trial if it doesn't prove effective. If I have adverse side effects,
moreover, it is also possible, that we might stop the trial for a week or two and then
restart. So...much...uncertainty. But in the meantime....plans!
Go figure that just as my cancer progresses my social/friend life in SC starts to get
interesting, maybe more interesting than it's been in years as I always felt that my 'real'
friends were elsewhere -- in NY, or Paris, or Boston etc. But the past months and, I
suppose, 2.5 years have brought some wonderful people into my PA life and have helped
solidify existing friendships. Wonder if that's coincidence -- or not (I think not). A jaunt to
Duncansville PA along gorgeous backroads with my 'antiquing posse' was lots of fun last
weekend, as was a visit from and great convo w/Mark, a State College friend who moved
to Cali, as was Thai take-out lunch in a cute park in Lemont w/my friend Maria, as was
dinner with three smart, stylish, kind women friends, Kathryn, Cheryl and Sandy (a Paris
trip was discussed....), as was a long catch-up visit with my friend/colleague Benedicte
(don't have my 'accent-friendly' keyboard with me), who brought me a vintage Witman's
candy box adorned with a Mucha image of Sarah Bernhardt -- which B. had loaded up
                       838 / 1.901
with all sorts of sweet treats (VIchy pastilles and such) from France. Looking forward to
(her) bday lunch w/my friend Helen on Monday. And did I mention lunch outdoors at the
Ale House, in the mellow sunshine, w/ex-bro in law Bruce?
I'm a lucky girl. :)
Photos

                       842 / 1.901

October 26, 2021 -- Comings and goings...
  by Willa Silverman, October 26, 2021  
                       846 / 1.901
                       847 / 1.901
Just a quick update: I am back in Baltimore to begin treatment this week, if all goes as
planned. My main hopes for the coming weeks are that a)the treatment is effective in
stabilizing or reversing my cancer growth (this will likely only be ascertained in eight
weeks, when I have a scan, provided I do well in the trial>see b] and c]); b)the side
effects of the treatment are not too harsh, debilitating, and potentially irreversible (I'll be
monitored very closely here); and c)related to b]: I can withstand the side effects without
undue delays in my treatment.
I think I'm 'just' anxious. I've never participated in a clinical trial, never had chemo
administered at Hopkins, never done this weekly commuting thing, never had my
treatment become *such* a full-time job, never met any of the staff associated with the
trial etc. The presence, physical or virtual, of 'good companions' (angels?) helps
immensely.
My friend Sandy and I gabbed for 3.5 hours in the car to Baltimore, so the trip went very
quickly. We reminisced about two previous times she drove me to Baltimore, including
our getting lost trying to find a lunch spot in/near Harrisburg and winding up at a very
strange sandwich shop ("Sandwich Man") on the outskirts of the capital that was pretty
much a dump but that had very attractive, Maxfield Parrish-type prints on the wall in
beautiful frames -- a weird contrast!
I loaded up a Zabar's freezer bag with food this morning to tide me over for my three
nights here. As I mentioned in a previous blog, the hotel restaurant closed as did my
other go-to place around the corner, Atwater's. The neighborhood's sketchy and I don't
feel like going farther afield, although I've discovered a few good restaurants during my
previous trips.  I can't eat anything past 5:45 tomorrow morning in preparation for my
biopsy, to which my college friend David will escort me, picking me up after the
procedure (he's also 'on duty' on Thursday). Despite (because of?) the circumstances, I
am looking forward to seeing him! He nicely came to visit me in the hospital after my big
debulking surgery in May 2019. 
Nurse Justin left me a voicemail this afternoon to let me know that Aetna has approved
coverage of my treatment at Hopkins - phew.
I'm comfortable in my 'home away from home,' the Marriott Residence Inn Johns Hopkins
Medical Center. The staff is especially kindly as many of their guests are Hopkins
patients. Although there always seem to be a few things awry (today: no tv remote, no
makeup remover wipes, no antiseptic wipes), the rooms are clean and quiet, and I'm
comfortable here.
It was wonderful to see Ben and Sammi this past weekend, albeit somewhat briefly (I'll
                       848 / 1.901
see them soon in NY). Michael grilled hamburgers and hot dogs for us on Saturday night,
an annual tradition. The kids came for brunch on Sunday and helped me with a few
things. They went to the football game on Saturday; there were multiple overtimes and
apparently PSU played miserably. I listened to a few mn of the game on the radio, while
driving around the countryside looking for fresh apple cider and maple syrup (both of
which I found).
Thanks to the 'angels' who sent me texts this a.m. w/well wishes. I appreciated the
sendoff. 
I'll end with a video of Dr. Beavis, whom I write so much about. She lived in England until
she was twelve, and has retained a slight British accent. I won't see her this trip but will
be examined by the oncologist running the clinical trial, Dr. Stephanie Gaillard (I believe
she is French, or of French heritage! We'll soon find out).
Dr. Anna Beavis | Gynecologic Oncologist - YouTube

October 27, 2021 - Guinea pig
  by Willa Silverman, October 27, 2021  
                       851 / 1.901
                       852 / 1.901
Today felt a bit 'unproductive' as the biopsy I was scheduled to have as part of a second
clinical trial did not go forward as planned. The nodule that was to be biopsied,
pinpointed on both a sonogram and then another type of scan to get a better view, was
too small to be useful (of course, I was not unhappy to learn about its small size!). There
are other nodules/tumors in my abdominal/pelvic area, but their location was too
problematic to be of use: one is right near my bowel (which makes me anxious), another
near 'surgical clips' placed during one of my surgeries. While I appreciated the prospect
of helping other women, even myself, by contributing cancerous tissue to this clinical
trial (to be injected into mice along with different types of anti-cancer medications), I
was also extremely relieved that the interventional radiologists were not about to take
any chances trying to perform a needle or core biopsy on me. As the no-nonsense, fifty-
something woman radiologist reminded me, in an appealing accent of some sort
(Iranian?): "First do no harm. That is our guiding principle." She explained that
proceeding would not be "productive," as the team would not be able to obtain the
needed sample; this does happen sometimes. Thank you, Hopkins radiologists, for not
risking my health by jabbing at a cm or so large nodule or risking a biopsy near a
sensitive organ. And this type of wise, skilled care is why I make seven hour round trips
to be treated by the world-class physicians at JHMC!
In the context of my visit, it's more important to me, though, that my actual treatment,
scheduled for tomorrow, go well: four appointments beginning at 7:45 (!). I feel
somewhat anxious. Fingers crossed.
The day was salvaged by spending time with my college friend David, who nicely came
and met me at the Residence Inn, waited (briefly, it turned out) while I was prepped for
the biopsy, and then walked me back to the hotel after we had coffee (and, for me, the
first meal of the day as I was off food and drink as of 5:45 this morning). We had such a
nice conversation that ranged over his interesting family history (a great-grandfather
who was an artist of note in Spain, whose fortunes were buffeted by both the Spanish-
American War and the Spanish Civil War, which led him to time in Paris), Harvard
reminiscences, retirement plans, work, family, COVID, Baltimore and more. We have
known each other since we were eighteen! I found his presence comforting; a clinical
psychologist by training, he's a kind, empathic, and steady person. He may meet me
again tomorrow if I feel I need a shoulder to lean on returning to my hotel after a day of
treatment -- I may, though, be able to get an Uber or even walk if I feel up to it. I have no
idea how I'll feel, but fatigued is a safe bet.
I rested for a while when I returned to the hotel around 2 p.m. and then Ubered to a
great Italian bakery (you may have picked up that I have a strange obsession with old
school Italian pastry shops), Vaccaro's, in Baltimore's Little Italy. I enjoyed a delicious
cappuccino and bought a few cookies. I'll try to get to bed early to rise by 6:30 or so
                       853 / 1.901
tomorrow.
Photos

October 28, 2021 - Guinea Pig II
  by Willa Silverman, October 28, 2021  
                       857 / 1.901
                       858 / 1.901
A brief update on today's events while I still have a bit of energy left. I'm tired from not
sleeping well (nor much) the past two nights and, I suppose, from treatment today.
Things went smoothly. I roused myself (with difficulty!) at 6:30, dressed, ate a banana
and some cottage cheese, and walked to the Viragh Building (for outpatient procedures).
It was a lovely, mild, sunny autumn day and with all my comings and goings today I
walked well over a mile, maybe two. A super friendly, dapper man in a sharp gray suit,
Jesse, whom I might call the 'concierge' or 'maitre d'' or 'mayor' (as I heard others call
him - writing /w/out accents here) of Viragh greeted me, helped me check in at a kiosk,
and pointed me towards my first appointment, telling me to 'keep up my smile' and to
'have a great day.' Slightly hokey, but this cancer patient for one welcomed his affability.
He only confirms my belief that Hopkins staff members are almost universally awesome!
I first went to the lab for blood work. This being my first day of treatment, I actually had
my blood drawn *four* times (and vital signs assessed several times as well), at 8, 10,
noon, and 3! I began to wonder if I'd have any blood left.... The tech, Kia, did not know
whether she should take the blood from my port or a vein in my arm so I called Justin
(my chemo nurse) to ask him and he was able to instruct Kia. I was trying to put my
finger on my feeling/s being around so many very sick people, from skin and bones older
folks supporting themselves on walkers to patients w/oxygen tanks, to a floppy little girl
being moved from a van into a wheelchair. So many feelings: empathy, camaraderie (ie
these are my people), smugness ('they look much sicker than I do'), awareness of
possible denial ("they look much sicker than I do, but my disease is advanced and
metastasizing, so who am I kidding?'), to fear ('this is what's coming??'). Approach.
Avoidance.
After the 8 a.m blood draw I walked back to my hotel to hang out until the next one at
10, stopping at Starbuck's (the only gig in the area for decent coffee) for a cappuccino. I
switched out a few items in my dragonfly-covered tote bag, sent a few texts, rested for
about twenty minutes. I then returned to Viragh to have more blood drawn at 10. After
that, I headed upstairs to the 10th floor, where I met Justin to go over scheduling,
procedures and more. As I suspected from talking with him, he's extremely nice,
answered all my questions patiently, seemed knowledgeable, helpful and
accommodating (eg he helped me switch a few appointment times that conflict with
events I have plans to attend in NY and Baltimore in November). He gave me my first
dose of Fostaniparib (I'll take two pills twice a day, every day), along with a 'diary' in
which to record each dose I take and any comments about side effects. He confirmed
that the two most prevalent possible side effects of this medication are diarrhea (could it
possibly be worse than what I experience now?! Oh my...) and high blood pressure.
Imodium and blood pressure meds can help w/those symptoms.
                       859 / 1.901
Dr. Gaillard came into the examination room while I was speaking with Justin. She's the
medical oncologist running the clinical trial and she was to examine me today as Dr.
Beavis was too overloaded with patients. Another impressive physician: forties (?), full of
energy, friendly, smart (trained at Hopkins, then taught at Duke before returning to
Hopkins as an asst. prof) -- and French! She spells her first name 'the French way'
(Stephanie w/the accent aigu over the first e); like Dr. Beavis, she spent part of her
childhood abroad, in France, as her dad is from Burgundy. Unlike Dr. Beavis, she did not
retain a French accent. We exchanged some words in French for fun; she speaks fluently
w/slightly (American-) accented French, which she also uses when she can with her son,
Luc.
She told me a bit more about the trial. She explained the science behind it quite clearly,
but I'm so scientifically illiterate that it's still a bit challenging for me to understand. Even
though I've taken Taxol before and it lost its effectiveness eventually, taking it with the
Fostaniparib somehow 'resensitizes' the Taxol (Taxol produces a protein that Fosta acts
on directly - I think?), so that the Taxol should become newly effective for me (my
oncologist friend Steve Sherman could undoubtedly explain this better in layperson's
terms). She stressed that the combo of the two drugs *may* be more effective than
taking Taxol alone (which has a 30% effectiveness rate) -- or it may not. Some women,
she told me, have done well on this trial (meaning that their cancer remained stable or
shrunk), others did not. Not knowing in which camp I will fall really sucks (sorry, but
that's the word that seems most appropriate here), esp given the very significant time,
energy and monetary investment involved. A scan after eight weeks should offer some
evidence of whether the treatment is working, provided I continue to tolerate the
treatment well. So.much.uncertainty. Must remain hopeful, or at least sanguine.
I went down to the lobby after my appointments with Justin and Dr. Gaillard, sank into a
comfy chair, ate some curried chicken salad I had brought with me, sent a few texts and
began reading a one-act, Pulitzer Prize winning play (1995) by Margaret Edson called
_Wit,_ about a 50 yo English literature professor with advanced metastatic ovarian
cancer (!). Am only about a third into it, but I like the way the playwright interweaves the
poetry she has spent her life studying (such as Donne's sonnet "Death be not Proud")
w/her treatment and the many issues it raises for her (one of her physicians happens to
be one of her former students, for example). It's thought-provoking, and I hope to gather
some ideas for the piece I've been contemplating creating.
A chemo nurse called me to let me know that I could start my infusion early if I wished.
So I headed upstairs to the 6h floor around 1 p.m. or so. A newish nurse plus a more
experienced one took good care of me in a private chemo bay (a nice change from being
in full view of at least ten other patients in the chemo room at Dr. Patel's, although I
don't really mind that). They administered, through my port, pre-meds (Benadryl, pepcid,
Tylenol?, and something else), followed by the Taxol, which ran for about an hour. There
are many possible side effects so it's wait and see (right now I simply feel tired, but
                       860 / 1.901
that's likely from the Benadryl; I fell asleep and when I awoke was disoriented, thinking it
was tomorrow morning already). The side effects usually accumulate the further one
advances into the treatment.
Before leaving Viragh, I wandered into the Meditation Room and flipped through some
books about spirituality from various faiths and 'humanistic' perspectives. Then I just sat
for a while and tried to clear my mind. It's a small, spare room with chairs lining the
walls, which glow with a soft blue-green light. Peaceful. I want to contact Rhonda, the
wonderful chaplain of the Kimmel Cancer Center at JH, whose visits brought me much
comfort after my operations. She's Methodist (I believe) but her perspective is
ecumenical and her prayers always succeeded in articulating my own fears and hopes.
It is not lost on me that today I was supposed to be attending the nineteenth-century
French studies conference about an hour away from here, in D.C., but instead I'm at
Hopkins receiving cancer treatment. I can think of many ways to rationalize this fact to
alleviate my disappointment and maybe even depression over not seeing colleagues
who are friends, presenting my research and learning about theirs, organizing a "Penn
State dinner" at an excellent restaurant as several of us often do, etc. but what seems
most helpful for me right now is simply to tell myself that 'this is what I'm doing right
now' and it's necessary. This mantra keeps me focused on the present at least and helps
me direct my energy towards trying to stabilize my health, my priority right now. I'm
certainly bummed, though, but c'est la vie (lol).
The only dreams I remember from my stay here have been college-related (Harvard and
PSU; me as a student, me as a professor): a)a dream involving a guy named Jonathan
Cahn, who I believe was in the class ahead of us, lived in Currier House, and was quite
good-looking and b)anxiety dream: I have to write an exam for my French culture/history
class on very short notice. I feel confident that I can cut corners, for example by cutting
and pasting from some previous documents, but when I realize that this really won't be
possible, and when I further realize that 1)I've focused nearly exclusively in the course
on World Wars I and II to the detriment of nearly everything else I was supposed to cover
and 2)I may not even have shown up to many of the class sessions I was supposed to
teach, I start to panic. During all of this, I'm also supposed to go to the office of a (real-
life) colleague in the English department, Carla M., but I can't find her office.
Back to SC tomorrow with my friend Martina who is nicely driving down to pick me up (i
look forward to some giggles), then I'll have one day to pack for NY, leaving Sunday
morning. And this is what I'm doing right now...
Photos
                       861 / 1.901
                       862 / 1.901
                       863 / 1.901

November 6, 2021 - "Nothing in Life is Simple"
  by Willa Silverman, November 6, 2021  
                       865 / 1.901
                       866 / 1.901
The last week has been a blur for me but – now that I’ve procured a ‘hotspot’ from AT&T
enabling me to access the internet from my cousin Claudia’s place – I will try to recap as
best as possible.
My State College friend Deb kindly drove me to the city last Sunday – her husband Tony
had packed up some delicious smoked salmon sandwiches for us to enjoy along the way.
We chatted the whole time and the four++ hour drive zipped by; fortunately, traffic
wasn’t bad getting into the city. She dropped me at my mother’s place and continued to
her place in Chelsea.
I actually don’t remember much about what I did Monday-Wednesday (a blur, as
mentioned, compounded by pretty awful insomnia, my mind working overtime like a
machine I can’t turn off…). I wrote a few letters of recommendation and caught up on
emails. I met Ben briefly twice, once in Union Square, the second time when he helped
me transport most of my stuff to Claudia and Jorn’s loft on Wednesday. My mother and I
went out for thin-crust pizza at a great place in her neighborhood, Posto. We also took a
walk up to Kalustyan’s, an iconic New York international store, where I bought some salt
(they sell dozens of varieties of salt from all over the world) and my mother bought some
halvah (Israeli marble halvah, one of dozens of varieties they sell). We also went, in
“Curry Hill,” to a wonderful store crammed full of clothing, home décor and much more
from India. Somehow I had gotten hooked on the idea that a fitted quilted sleeveless
reversible Indian vest w an attractive pattern would make a nice addition to my
wardrobe, and I indeed found what I was looking for (I was enthralled by the beautiful
shimmering wraps, skirts and jewelry that Indian women wear for their weddings in the
most gorgeous “Monsoon Wedding” colors but felt that it was best to simply admire
those items from a culturally appropriate distance!).
Everything went smoothly at Hopkins on Thursday. I woke up at an ungodly early hour
(for me) to catch an Uber to meet my brother, who kindly agreed to accompany me,
outside the new Moynihan Station that is replacing (or enlarging?) Penn Station. After a
few sips of cappuccino, I perked up enough to notice how spectacular this station is,
harking back to the grand 19th century stations of steel and glass but with a sleek,
modern, open, airy feel. Much less dreary-creepy than timeworn Penn Station. The train
was very comfortable, and I believe I dozed through a good part of the nearly three-hour
trip; when I awoke sunlight was glinting onto Chesapeake Bay. Ethan had packed up
some goodies from New York that supplemented my much more modest few items, and I
was grateful for the bagels w/cream cheese and smoked salmon and some yummy tuna
salad from Absolute Bagels on the UWS.
We Ubured to Hopkins where I first met with Dr. Beavis and Justin, the nurse ‘assigned’
to me for the duration of the trial. He’s an excellent nurse, totally focused on making
                       867 / 1.901
things go as smoothly for me as possible. He always answers my emails within a few
minutes, and is thorough, caring, and knowledgeable. Vitals checked, everything fine,
fortunately no high blood pressure as anticipated with the Fostamatinib. Dr. Beavis
briefly examined me (lungs, mouth, abdomen/pelvis) to make sure I was ‘good to go’ for
treatment (apparently, I was). She issued new prescriptions for a few of my meds that
were running low; we talked about how to best deal with my insomnia and dehydration
due to diarrhea. We also discussed logistics for trying to get me in to see a gyn onc
surgeon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering for a consult. Dr. Beavis suggested this initially both
as a ‘foot in the door’ measure if I were ever to need urgent care while in NY and as a
way of assessing whether MSK might be running any promising trials for me down the
road. This is one of many points that have proved complicated in recent weeks (my
initial call to MSK, last week, was met with the news that I can’t schedule a consult there
until I complete my current trial at JHMC – this turns out not to be the case…I think…).
There have been more ‘hiccups’ than I can even count and I need to remain very
proactive to stay on top of the myriad details involved in my care. I’ll allude to some of
these hiccups here, but can’t get into all of them in detail, including a dilemma about
attending, in my immunocompromised state, an upcoming family bar-mitzvah in
Baltimore at which numerous folks with whom I’d love to visit will not have been
vaccinated. I used to have a pillowcase depicting a cat from the Boynton comic trying to
jump over the moon – unsuccessfully – and the slogan: “Nothing in life is simple” – an apt
motto for me these days…
I next went to the lab in another building to have bloodwork to determine whether I
could proceed with treatment. I had actually messed up semi-big time with this as I
forgot that I was supposed to have the bloodwork done the day before, in New York (for
some reason this had totally slipped my mind). It turned out to be ok, simply delaying
treatment quite a bit until all the results of the bloodwork could be processed and my
chemo meds ordered and mixed. I was mad at myself for this slip up. Fortunately, my
blood counts were all sufficiently robust enough to not raise any red flags and I was able
to proceed to treatment.
Treatment lasted about 2.5-3 hours. A big blast of Benadryl made me quite groggy but
didn’t put me to sleep and the Taxol (chemo) took an hour to administer. Ethan sat in the
chemo room with me while I was attended to by two nurses, Sarah and Nicole. I think we
finished up about 5:30.
Of course, I have no idea of whether the treatment is effective and will not know until I
have a scan – my hunch is that won’t be until towards the end of the year. It is possible
that all this poison is being pumped into my body for no effect. As mentioned, Taxol has
about a 30-32% effectiveness rate, which may or may not be improved by the additional
med (Fostamatinib, a drug used for autoimmune conditions) that I am taking per my
participation in the clinical trial. My last CA 125 number was 33, technically considered
‘normal’ (up to 35) but slightly high for me; it appears, though, that we are basically
                       868 / 1.901
ditching this number as a barometer of my cancer, and instead going with the scans,
which have proved more revealing. So it’s wait and see. I can decide to leave the trial at
any point but…for what alternative? My current plan is to stick with the trial until a)my
doctors determine the treatment is not effective for me (ie cancer has progressed)
and/or b)the side effects become unmanageable (so far they are manageable).
After treatment I felt well enough to walk back to the hotel (1/3 mile), especially after
having been cooped up all day. Somehow I was ravenously hungry, so I suggested to
Ethan that we Uber to an old school Italian restaurant I like a lot, La Scala. I was so
hungry (or perhaps it was pent up energy making itself known) that I ate a hearty bowl
of homemade spinach fettuccini with Bolognese sauce (delicious) preceded by half a
grilled Caesar salad and followed by a huge piece of tiramisu, my favorite dessert (I had
said to the waiter, when he brought it over, “I fear you may need to bring me a box for
me to take half of this home.” When he brought the box over: Guess what?). I apologize
for seeming gluttonous; I don’t entirely understand the nature of the deep hunger I felt
after my day of treatment. Something is going on with that. All the uncertainty is
perturbing and it is sometimes difficult for me to remain calm.
It was so nice to have time to catch up with Ethan over dinner and throughout the day,
to trade news of our kids, our lives, to check in with each other. If the reason for my trip
to Hopkins was sobering, I declared the opportunity to spend quality brother-sister time
together “even fun!”
As I mentioned in last week’s blog, the quality of the service at our go-to hotel has
definitely descended several notches. This time there were stains on the towels and
bedding, sofa bed was not made up etc. They were likely hard hit during the pandemic.
The staff remains lovely. However, I am contemplating trying to make next week’s trip in
one day, if possible.
Did not sleep very well but Ethan had nicely gone to Starbuck’s before I got up and had
my coffee waiting for me. Ubured to Penn Station, a pretty Beaux-Arts station from 1911
that would be a suitable movie set for a film set in that era. Return train very crowded
w/weekenders and some likely NY marathoners.
Somehow things decomposed once we arrived back in NY – nothing horrible but enough
annoyances to precipitate a mini-meltdown on my part. The glorious November weather
invited walking, so I walked from 32nd and 7th to Claudia and Jorn’s place on W. 15th.
Somewhere along the way my right shoe began to chafe against my toe, sending searing
pain through my foot as I walked. I plunked my stuff down in the loft, then set out again
to pick up the prescriptions Dr. Beavis had ordered from a CVS near my mother’s
apartment (about ten blocks from the loft). I was also hurrying so that I could get to my
mother’s in time to have her help me bring the rest of my stuff, which I had left at her
house, back to the loft with me. The CVS episode was an epic fail: apparently my
                       869 / 1.901
insurance for medications was rejected and they couldn’t fill my prescriptions (several of
which have run out and I need them…); I was able to buy potassium at full price (I will
not be able to do this w/the blood thinner Eliquis, which costs $500 without insurance). I
called my CVS in State College to try to find out what was going on and could not get the
info I needed; I’ll need to make some more phone calls. Meanwhile, the pharmacy in NY
was very crowded and the pharmacists were both truly unpleasant, yelling at me in front
of all the other customers! By that point I was in nearly full-blown meltdown and so I left
the store, forgetting to pick up the Benadryl I need to sleep (I stopped at another place a
few blocks away to pick that up, along with some toe guards to alleviate the searing pain
in my foot). It was too late for my mother to help me so I packed up my remaining stuff
in her apartment and took an Uber back to the loft, even though it’s walking distance –
between my throbbing foot, my very heavy bag, and my fatigue I was spent! I ordered
some too-salty Udon soup via Door Dash, which did not help w/my dehydration.
Claudia and Jorn’s beautiful loft provides wonderful respite for me. Still, it took me
forever to fall asleep last night but once I was out I slept soundly and late. Still felt some
‘decrepitude’ this morning – is my hair starting to fall out again? another inner mouth
sore? – but tried to ‘right’ myself. My mother met me at Breads Bakery for coffee and
rolls/pastries and then nicely accompanied me to AT&T to get my hotspot set up; to
DSW, to buy myself some unattractive but comfortable and functional Sketchers to
replace the offending pair of shoes that wreaked havoc on my feet; and to the farmers
market to buy a few healthy items to eat/cook the next few days (eggs, cheese, veggies,
fruit). Union Square was bustling; I had rarely seen the farmers market and surrounding
stores, restaurants, cafes etc. so lively and packed. New York is back? The grand
weather and Marathon weekend fever certainly helped.
The next few days will be a mix of rest and seeing a few friends and relatives – an
advantage of being in the city. Looking forward to brunching w/my friend Shanny
tomorrow. Will write more about plans for next Thursday’s Hopkins jaunt soon. Despite
the preceding account (I feel sheepish for whining but needed to vent), the bottom line is
that I’m feeling pretty much ok, well enough to plow through everything I’ve just
described.
Thanks very much to everyone who has sent emails and texts of support from near and
far. Your words lift me up! Missing all my friends in State College. It is nice to spend
some time with dear ones in the city, though. XO
Photos

                       876 / 1.901
November 10, 2021 - Nothing in Life is Simple Part II
  by Willa Silverman, November 12, 2021  
Recent dreams both take me back in time: 1) people (students) are sitting against the
wall in the long hallway running through the apartment I grew up in, in Gramercy Park.
They are taking a math test or exam. I am supposed to take the test too, but don't have
it in hand, and can't see anywhere to sit. I finally obtain the test and proceed into the
large living room in our old apartment to find a seat; I'm the only one in the room.
Trepidation about taking a test in math, a subject I'm notoriously bad at.
2)Standing on a sidewalk watching a car go by, and realize that the driver is a very
young (age 4-7) Ben! I am amazed/anxious to see him at the wheel of a car. I feel that I
must tell him that the age for procuring a driver's license is eighteen!
The past few days have had their stresses and frustrations -- [update: but things
improved as the week continued]. Thankfully, I am feeling pretty ok physically. I don't
know if it's even worth describing the insurance nightmare that engulfed me for three
days, sparked by my being banished from a CVS on 22nd st. twice because the mean
pharmacists said my insurance claim had been rejected, preventing me from buying two
medications I badly needed and that I had to forego taking for about five days. While I
paid out of pocket for potassium and vitamin B12, Eliquis (blood thinner) costs $500 sans
insurance and Lexapro (anti-depressant) costs close to $60. Suffice to say I held off on
purchasing both these meds. This problem, which of course I had to resolve one way or
another, set in motion about 20 (?) phone calls on my part to a)the medical insurance
company (Aetna); b) the insurance company covering my prescriptions (Caremark/CVS);
c)Lifetime Benefits Solutions (billing company for Aetna and Caremark) and d) Penn
State Human Resources. A) would send me to b) would send me to c) would send me to
d), like a ping pong ball, and being off my anti-depressant did not help during those mind-
numbing waits, navigation of phone trees etc., when I could practically hear the veins in
my temple and neck pulsing loudly. I believe the reps I spoke to truly wanted to help me,
and were all pleasant, but it took a long time to untangle the different strands of the
problem (my insurance policy was listed as 'expired,' leaving me with no medical or
prescription coverage).
Again without going into equally mind-numbing detail, it turned out that I had been
delinquent on payments to my insurance company (news to me; something about the
mode of payment apparently changed when I retired and I didn't get the memo). So I
certainly accept responsibility for this and have now set up my post-retirement insurance
policy payments to be withdrawn directly from my bank. I am not positive, however,
whether it was my lack of payment that precipitated all my coverage being cancelled,
but it appears that this may have been the culprit. Once I paid up over the phone, to the
                       877 / 1.901
billing company (which I did immediately, of course), I was able to get Penn State to
reactivate both my medical insurance and prescription coverage, in concert with both
Aetna and Caremark. I *think* the medical part has been reinstated now as I once again
'exist' as an entity on Aetna's website (ie my id card has reappeared there), and am
waiting for the prescription coverage to kick in again as well. [update: as of yesterday,
the entirety of my coverage has been reinstated! Cost for my Eliquis and Lexapro at
Hopkins pharmacy yesterday: $.0. Insurance doesn't cover the pricey mouthwash I will
take to deal with chemo induced mouth and tongue sores, but I'll cough up - no pun
intended - $40 for the stuff].
Update: I realize that as an American, I complain about insurance coverage from a
position of privilege. A dear friend who just lost her brother to cancer in Beirut, a city in a
country in dire shape, reported that her family had to pay for his cancer care out of
pocket because of the country's financial/economic crisis. And even in this country so
many go without adequate insurance. I am extremely lucky to benefit from such
excellent care and more than adequate insurance coverage.
The second major 'pain' of the first part of the week revolved around my needing to have
labs drawn in the city, with the results to be faxed to Hopkins. I located a Quest
Diagnostics lab near the loft; their claim to take appointments both by phone and on line
being apparently false, I walked over there a few days ago to make sure that I could
indeed have my blood drawn there. In reality, they only take walk ins. I returned there
the following day and waited for a very long time. The place looked dirty to me and did
not inspire confidence. When I inquired about whether they had a record of my having
signed in, the technician barked at me: "Silverman? We called your name several times
already." The fact was that the technicians do not even enter the waiting room to call the
next client but simply announce the name barely audibly from a room around the corner
from the waiting room. Oh well. Unfortunately, the technician either did not pinpoint my
vein accurately and/or did not apply enough pressure after removing the needle. As soon
as I left the lab and crossed the street, I felt something cold and wet leaking into my
jacket arm. I removed my jacket and saw blood covering the entire inside of the sleeve
and seeping into my shirtsleeve as well. Somewhat panicked, I sat down on the ledge of
a shop, found a tissue in my bag and began applying pressure as blood continued to turn
the tissue red. This was my 'breaking point' and I began sobbing loudly as I tried to stop
the bleeding. Granted, I was five days off Lexapro, lacking sleep, and more 'unregulated'
than I suspected. Despite my sobs, the midday crowd on 22nd street surged blithely past
me, engrossed in their cell phones; the only person who continued to stare at me with
concern as she walked by was a little girl. I flagged a uniformed man who looked like a
police offer ("Are you an officer? Could you help me?"). He turned out to be a traffic
officer but said he would get a police officer to come over. No one came. By this time, I
had calmed down a bit, stopped the bleeding, and headed into the store whose ledge I
was crumpled onto, which happened to be the large newish Harry Potter store where my
niece works; I had intended to stop by to visit her after my blood draw. It was strange --
                       878 / 1.901
and probably helpful in some way -- to go from this awful experience into the alternate
universe of Slytherin and Griffyndor, where you can buy a magician's wand for $38. The
design of the shop is actually quite cool and it was packed. It took me quite a while to
find Eve -- it's a large, two-floor shop -- but eventually I located her in an attractive room
with Harry Potter wallpaper that sells graphic art inspired by the series. Fortunately she
had a bandaid on her and we were able to chat and have a co-worker of hers take
pictures of us in front of a faux fireplace. Despite my mood, it was lovely to see my dear
niece and give her a hug.
Nothing in life is simple: the Boynton pillowcase I alluded to in a recent post features, of
course, a *cow* trying unsuccessfully to jump over the moon, not a cat. Duh.
The second half of the week improved. I will post some pictures illustrating that
statement in a next post. 
My Hopkins trip yesterday went smoothly. I decided to experiment with going and
coming in one day, and foregoing having someone accompany me on the trip, although
my former bro in law Bruce had kindly offered. A one-day trip is tiring, I found, but
entirely feasible. I felt slightly 'befuddled' at times when I was there simply because it
was such a relatively rushed day but the entire staff is so unfailingly pleasant and
professional that it put me in good spirits. Despite my early wake up time, I made it to
Moynihan Station slightly after 7:30, had time to grab a Starbucks and make the 8:10
train. It was a pretty day, the late autumn foliage glinted shades of bright orange and
red, and the sight of houses with docks leading right onto Chesapeake Bay was lovely. In
perhaps a last gasp from this 'week from hell,' I had an unnerving cabbie drive me to
Hopkins. He kept defending himself energetically and loudly from (my??? no!)
insinuations that he might be cheating me somehow, a strange stew of references to
Holy Books, the fact that his parents raised him right, and a mind-numbing repetition of
the random phrase "Experience is the best teacher." After telling me it was fine to pay
by credit card, he somehow messed up my payment, and began chiding me for not going
to a cash machine before getting into his cab (there is no cash machine in the station in
Baltimore). Next time, I'll take an Uber; at this point, I think their drivers definitely have
the edge on the cabbie. Oh well.
I arrived in ample time to have more blood drawn. As mentioned in a previous post, a
dapper, emphatically friendly man named Jesse (photo next time?) greets patients in the
lobby of Viragh Building and helps register them, printing off their itinerary if they need.
He remembered me from previous visits and told me to keep smiling (under my mask!).
We also compared the purples in our clothing. I told him I was a "purple person" and he
then showed me his amazing purple striped socks and classy, pointy, crisply polished
dress shoes. My technician for the blood draw, Natasha, was also kind and friendly. We
talked about her twin daughters and how bored they are working and living in suburban
PA (Lebanon). She expertly drew the blood from my port and set everything up for my
                       879 / 1.901
receiving chemo through my port in the afternoon.
When I finished in the phlebotomy lab, Justin (the nurse assigned to me for the duration
of the trial) was waiting for me, as promised. As mentioned, Justin is an exceptionally
good nurse, completely on top of my care, efficient, kind, empathic. He shared the
results of the blood draw from Quest Diagnostic (thankfully, the lab did fax him the
results!), showing me which counts were slightly high or low. Fortunately, though, the
overall picture remains good enough for me to continue treatment at this point. Justin
then directed me to the cafeteria (even telling me about an app allowing patients to find
their way in the huge, and to me confusing labyrinth that is JHMC). He went off to attend
to a few details of my care (I think?) and then met me at the cafeteria, where I was able
to ask him some questions on the way to Dr. Beavis' office. He joined Dr. Beavis and me
at her office, both of them collaborating on different aspects of my care (eg possibly
lowering my dose of Fostamatinib if my bad diarrhea continues; coordinating the
handover of treatment beginning in December with Dr. Patel, with whom Justin had
spoken by phone). I told Dr. Beavis that sometimes I can feel the tumors in my pelvic
area ache when I wake up; she said this is normal but does not necessarily indicate
growth, shrinkage etc.; the aching could be coming from the tumors or scar tissue, but I
definitely feel them. I've been walking a lot in the city, and she encourages that. She
examined me briefly (chest/breathing, vitals, mouth, pelvis/abdomen) and nothing
warranted withholding treatment. I also told her (and Justin) -- thinking it superfluous but
it actually is not, at all, as central to the question of quality of life -- that, providing I'm
still feeling up to it, I'd like to travel to my 'happy place' for a week or two, likely in
January, with a few fabulous women friends from State College. Dr. Beavis and Justin
both seemed supportive of that idea and can apparently work with me to tweak the
schedule slightly if necessary. Dr. Beavis thought it was high time to think about booking
plane tickets to Paris. So I need to get on this asap.
In the midst of my appointment i got a call from Caremark to say that any restrictions on
my prescription coverage had been lifted. Relief.
Justin had also printed out a schedule for me going forward. Next Thursday I'll be at
Hopkins for blood work (collection of samples for the clinical trial, I will not have to
retraumatize myself at Quest Diagnostics again this week) and to briefly be examined by
Dr. Beavis; I won't be having treatment that day (a scheduled break in the treatment
after three sessions). The following week I'll be off completely for Thanksgiving. I'll return
to Hopkins, likely from State College, once in early December for bloodwork/Dr. Beavis or
Dr. Gaillard/treatment. After that, Dr. Patel will begin administering my treatment and I
will travel to Hopkins once a month to be examined and have a check in, blood draw etc.
I will have a scan at the very end of December, which the Hopkins radiologists will
analyze. This will likely tell us a lot about the effectiveness - or not - of the treatment.
Accordingly, my treatment plan may or may not need to be modified; it's likely, though,
that I'll at least start the third cycle of treatment in early January.
                       880 / 1.901
After meeting w/Dr. Beavis and Justin, I walked back to Viragh Building for treatment. My
college friend David Miranda, who lives in Baltimore, had kindly reached out to me to see
if I needed help 'on the ground,' as he had done the same for me two (?) weeks ago.
While I was having treatment David - my 'care partner' for the day, in Hopkins' parlance
(and he received the badge to prove it) -- picked up my prescriptions and a vanilla bean
yogurt for me, and then returned to the treatment room where he found me loopy from
being pumped full of Benadryl (it took me about 20 minutes to post a picture of Arnold
marching in the NYC Veterans Day parade in his original WWII uniform when normally it
would take me 5 minutes). Because I was groggy from the treatment (administered
expertly and compassionately by Nicole, an infusion room nurse), David accompanied
me in an Uber back to Penn Station Baltimore, where I was able to exchange my ticket
for one on an earlier train. Once he made sure I was solid enough post-treatment we
parted ways. What an angel and how pleasant it is to chat w/him and learn about each
other's lives. I'm so grateful that we've reconnected, even under these circumstances.
One of the mini-silver linings. At the same time, I send prayers and healing wishes to
another classmate, Brenda, whom I never knew in college but whom I've met virtually in
the past year or so due to our common OC journey. Brenda is struggling right now. I
hope her health improves.
Train was crowded back to the city around 5:40, but comfortable. A guy sitting behind
me was coughing and incessantly blowing his nose for the first hour and a half, so much
so that I inquired whether he was ok. After that his honking and blowing and coughing
stopped and he launched into a very loud cell phone call (to whom??) during which he
announced that "A fun fact about me is that I have nine brothers." Life can really suck
sometimes, to paraphrase something my friend Shanny wrote a few of us the other day.
Fortunately, she noted, at other times it can be joyful and funny and absurd. QED.
Will write a second post w/photos of some of the recent "joyful and funny" moments of
the past week.
Rereading my post, I realize that my 'mot du jour' appears to be "mind-numbing." While
it's a great word (imho), please know that the past week has not been *completely* mind-
numbing! Perhaps it's balanced by my other 'mot du jour' (which I know I overuse...):
"lovely." 
 
 
 
  
                       881 / 1.901

Being caught in even one phone loop is frustrating at the best of times, and so is
needing to intervene in an insurance coverage snafu! So glad you triumphed!
  —Christopher Walker, November 12, 2021  
  
November 12, 2021 - Pictures with people
  by Willa Silverman, November 12, 2021  
                       882 / 1.901
                       883 / 1.901
For many years, every time I attempted to take a picture of a pretty landscape or
building or animals in my beloved, late ex-mother-in-law's presence, she would snap at
me: "No pictures without people!" Eventually, even she, sometimes a bit of a
bossypants, realized how over the top this statement was, and we came to joke about
(it's remained a bit of a family joke since). However, obeying Annette's dictum, I present
to you..."pictures with people!" Specifically, some of the people who have brightened my
days during the past week or so.

November 12, 2021 - Pictures with People II: Every Day a Blessing
  by Willa Silverman, November 12, 2021  
                       890 / 1.901
                       891 / 1.901
All these pictures were taken at the opening a few nights ago at the National Arts Club
on Gramercy Park (a stone's throw from the building in which I grew up; I used to take
piano lessons in the NAC) of the exhibit of photographs by my friend, Laurent Badessi.
The exhibit, "Age of Innocence," is about children and gun culture in America. When I
was 22, I taught English as an assistante at the Lycee Theodore Aubanel (sorry for
missing accents) in Avignon, France. Laurent was my 18 or 17 year old student. He came
from a family of photographers and was dreaming of becoming one himself; he was
already experimenting with his friends, and I have photos he took of me forty years ago
and over the years (including for the jacket of my first book). I came to know his late
grandparents quite well, staying at their beautiful home in Villeneuve-les-Avignon, and I
know his parents as well. We have cultivated a very special relationship over the past
forty years. I'm hoping that soon he'll create a portrait photograph of me on a 'vanitas'
theme (I have ideas...). The opening was full of impossibly chic New Yorkers and was lots
of fun.

November 14, 2021 - Ophelia
  by Willa Silverman, November 14, 2021  
                       906 / 1.901
                       907 / 1.901
My current treatment may be starting to become a harder slog for me. I feel tired, and
today at least need to lie down for a while every two hours or so. Aching in my pelvis
woke me about 4 a.m. the other night (that 'witching hour' 'entre chien et loup'
('between dog and wolf' when reputedly most suicides occur, a 'fun fact' that has
remained lodged in my brain since a former therapist shared it with me); before I knew
it, I was trying to settle myself by getting to "Genius" in the NYTimes "Spelling Bee" and
reading through all the Sunday "Vows" accounts. I feel nauseous some mornings, usually
resolved with an anti-nausea med, Compazine or Zofran.  I have awful diarrhea, which
may result in our having to reduce the amount of Fostamatinib (clinical trial med) I
receive each day, after we attempt to control it with another anti-diarrheal med aside
from Immodium (of which I now take eight per day). I'm constantly battling dehydration.
My hair is falling out in handfuls, big clumps, for the second time. It took well over a year
for it to grow back. While Katherine, my trusted 'wig lady' in State College, has promised
to make me look beautiful, I wonder how many times my body can regenerate in this
way; I have in mind a poem about Ophelia, in French, by the Belgian Symbolist poet
Georges Rodenbach I believe, which describes Ophelia's hair disaggregating in the water
and becoming one with the surrounding weeds, reeds, foliage, ferns and other plant life
in a very natural way, all dissolving and melding into one organic swirl. I wish I could
locate that poem. The hair loss this time feels less traumatic than the first but perhaps
more agitating, exhausting (>the concern about the effort it will take to keep up my
appearance, which somehow still matters to me as fairly central to my identity), 'here we
go again'-ing. I'm likely most concerned, actually, about not shedding hair around my
cousin's apartment, so I've revived my collection of soft caps for the occasion (I even
brought my wig from State College, but it looks a bit timeworn). 
I often lie awake at all hours and worry about my cancer. What if the current treatment is
not working? What if I'm not among the lucky 30% -- maybe more with the added clinical
trial medication -- that will benefit from this treatment? What does the nausea mean, the
pelvic aches (they could mean something or nothing, according to Dr. Beavis), the
fatigue? What risks do I run by perhaps letting my cancer go untreated for so long? What
if errant cancer cells make a break for it, sneaking into my lungs or brain? 
Ok, back to the mantra: "One day at a time." Focus on the breathing. Listen to a guided
Yoga Nidra meditation on YouTube. Being surrounded by family and friends in NY the
past few weeks has been grounding, a blessing. So comforting to text my mother in the
late morning and ask if she wants to meet at Breads Bakery in a half hour for coffee and
a croissant, before we pick up a few items at the farmers market; yesterday we walked
three miles around the Village, winding up at Veselka for delicious mushroom barley
soup (I took home equally delicious borscht for dinner). Lovely to have Ben drop by after
his classes are done. Calming to spend time with old friends.
                       908 / 1.901
I responded to a slew of emails today but have more to catch up on. I am so very
grateful for the emails, texts, voicemails, dream interpretations, gifts (thank you, Helen,
for the tea!). Please be patient with me while I do so. I often have the best intentions but
then become overcome with fatigue and need to lie down. Yesterday this turned into a
four-hour nap!
PS: Despite my reference to the hour when most suicides occur, please know that I am at
no risk of this! I might only consider this if I were to be in truly unbearable physical pain
-- and I am nowhere *near* that point -- although I remain convinced that such pain can
nowadays be managed with meds. I could certainly write more about this, but those who
know me well understand that I have a very strong spirit that is buoying me during this
cancer journey. Moreover, I am eminently well surrounded by 'good companions.'

It’s so reassuring to me, strange as that sounds, as I follow so closely and feel concern
for you, dear Willa, to hear your voice so clearly in all you write. Your entry is surprisingly
free of anxiety though the facts are, of course, all there. But so are the honest, tender
and humanized(?) details you describe so well. .It’s simply about the actual living of it all,
right now. I can’t tell how much I’ve wanted you to return to the city before now abd how
glad I am that you have! Please know that the symptoms you describe are all
attributable to the poisons that are determinedly at work attacking cancer cells. The GI
lining cells turn over quite frequently and that makes them ready targets of chemo
drugs. They are unintended casualties and, not surprisingly, their upset shows up as
nausea or pelvic area pain (which very well could be the lower parts of your intestines).
Please know the symptoms you feel are all perfectly expected results of a feisty chemo
regimen making battle. Not to worry. And the fatigue is how drained your body is to keep
up with the havoc the chemo is causing. They are poisons, my friend, as is needed.
Though cutting down in the size could help the diarrhea and the fatigue that causes by
keeping you on the verge of dehydration. I’m so happy you can meet your mother for
Russian Jewish food! As for your hair, I can’t imagine, but I do know how central that
keeping your beauty alive can feel. The drugs have different plans. And heck I’ve come
to learn, ones beauty can shine through without hair, too. It must feel dreadful and
discouraging though. What an unpleasant process to see clumps of ones hair fall out.

 November 19, 2021 - Back from Baltimore (rinse and repeat)
  by Willa Silverman, November 19, 2021  
                       911 / 1.901
                       912 / 1.901
Yesterday I completed my fifth (I think??) consecutive trip to Baltimore in as many
weeks, and the second in a row organized as a one-day round trip. As expected, it's been
a tiring proposition but overall it's gone smoothly, and my decision to make NY my home
base for the better part of the month was a good one.
Same drill as last week: I awoke at 6:30 (preceded by a miserable sleep that had me
waking up *hourly*), ate half an almond croissant from Breads Bakery and some
delicious labne mixed with apricot jam from Kalustyan, threw a few items into a tote bag,
Ubered to Moynihan Train Hall, grabbed a cappuccino, and boarded the 8:10 train to
Baltimore. The under three hour ride is easy and relaxing and pretty: I enjoyed seeing
big bodies of water (Chesapeake Bay) that are unknown to us in landlocked central PA. In
Philly, sculls were cutting ripples into the Schuylkill as they rowed by, as I observed from
above while we crossed a bridge. The late autumn reds and gold still abounded on this
sunny day.
Ubured to the Viragh Building for my blood work (nice driver: we talked about benefits of
life in the country, where he wants to retire with his Black Labs, Jericho and Simon, v. the
city); all went according to plan. I showed the technician the hematoma now covering
the entire inside of my elbow, the mark of the technician at Quest Diagnostics in NY who
not only harmed me during  a blood draw gone wrong but, to add insult to injury, got
angry with me for apparently not hearing her when she called (whispered?) my name
when she was ready for me. The Hopkins technician/phlebotomist brought over a woman
who looked like a supervisor -- perhaps a physician, RN or more experienced
phlebotomist. She examined my arm thoroughly, parsed the different parts of the wound
(hematoma, adhesive burn, vein etc.), and recommended applying bacitracin and
covering loosely, scrupulously avoiding using that arm for any blood draws in the near
future. She gave me all the supplies needed to care for/cover the wound. Although
relatively 'low hanging fruit,' this is precisely the type of expertise, thoroughness and
superb patient care I have come to expect from Hopkins.
I then had time for a very quick lunch in the cafeteria at Hopkins before my appointment
with Dr. Beavis. The massive medical complex still seems like a labyrinth to me and I use
an app to navigate. At least I get some exercise walking from one end to the other.
Justin met me at Dr. Beavis' with orders for my next blood draw. I had vitals taken (bp
still good!). I first met with Dr. Schneider, a fellow (?) working w/Dr. Beavis, then with
both Drs. Schneider and Beavis. Without going into graphic detail, I can share that some
of the convo centered on peeing and pooping! Suffice to say that some of the
medications can prompt difficult side effects, paradoxically both diarrhea from hell and
urinary *retention* (I wondered if this might be the result of a tumor pressing on the
bladder but Dr. Beavis strongly suspects the medications and did not feel anything
                       913 / 1.901
during her physical examination of me). Dr. Beavis is very skilled at tweaking the
dosages of my meds and hopefully we'll get things sorted out. As an update, Justin called
me this morning to tell me to hold the Fostamatinib (the drug I'm taking along with
Taxol, as part of the trial) for two weeks, until my next appointment, as my neutrophil
count (white blood cells) is low; this is the recommendation of Dr. Gaillard, the medical
oncologist running the trial. It is not uncommon for dosages of meds to be reduced/
increased/stopped during treatment and Justin thinks I'll be likely to resume the
Fostamatinib in early December. Dr. Beavis and I briefly discussed a range of other
issues, from sleep problems to a toenail that appears to be darkening and loosening
from chemo to whether we should increase my Lexapro to help me cope w/the
understandable anxiety that comes with being an ovarian cancer patient; on that note, I
am very happy to have reconnected with Rhonda Cooper, the chaplain for the Kimmel
Cancer Center at JHMC, to whom I wrote a few days ago. Rhonda, a Methodist minister,
provided much comfort following my first operation; I found praying together for healing
and strength, for myself and my loved ones, very powerful and I am looking forward to
seeing her during my December trip to Hopkins. Dr. Beavis and her husband are loading
up their bikes onto their car (they're both avid cyclists) and are off to celebrate the
holiday with friends. We realized that the next time I see her it will be Chanukah (her
husband, Josh, is Jewish).
I was finished before 2 p.m. so I Ubured back to Penn Station, Baltimore, and exchanged
my ticket for one for a train leaving an hour earlier; that one, however, was half an hour
late so my net time gain returning to the city was only half an hour! The train (w/a
terminus in Boston) was quite crowded and seemed to be transporting many college
students returning home for the holiday I am *so* glad not to be travelling for
Thanksgiving, as I'm returning to State College on Sunday, with Ben (Sammi will arrive
on Tuesday).
I was very tired when I reached to the city but also hungry and, realizing I had little food
in the apartment, spontaneously stopped in Koreatown to have some galbi (had a
craving for beef). The meat was tasty but also rather greasy; the sides were so-so; and
the soup wasn't good. I don't think I picked the best place, but it was ok. I also felt a bit
overcome by the throngs of people, the congestion and the noise, including that blaring
from a huge Korean BBQ place on the corner of 32nd and 5th, called LOVE. I know this is
hardly written "like a true New Yorker" but I'm realizing that there are certain
neighborhoods in the city I have to avoid! I love the city of course and am at home here
but feel much more relaxed in more residential or mixed, 'throng-free' neighborhoods.
I was so tired when I got back to the apartment, which I had left twelve hours earlier,
that I crawled into bed with a _People_ magazine. I experimented with no sleep meds at
all and...guess what? I slept better than I had in quite a while. It wasn't perfect -- I fell
asleep fairly quickly and only awoke about two times during the night -- but I am going to
continue to further experiment with med-free sleep and better sleep 'hygiene.' To this
                       914 / 1.901
end, I thank my brother for the analgesic balm from China, in a lovely bottle to boot, that
feels relaxing when rubbed into the temples.
My stay in NY is winding down. My mother, Ethan and I shared a NY coffee shop lunch
yesterday (fat tuna salad sandwich on rye toast + good fries); can't remember the last
time the three of us did *that.* Such a nice moment. Later that day, Ben popped over for
a visit and I enjoyed the added bonus of being able to briefly chat with my cousin Claudia
in her apartment as I was returning and she leaving. I wish I had been able to spend
more time with her over the years but we're making up for lost time!
A highlight of the week was also seeing my *grade school* friend, Sarah. It's safe to say
we have known each other for about 56 years, and we hadn't seen each other in at least
ten if not more! Since I graduated in a class of about (?) thirty women, I've remained
close or at least kept in touch with the majority of them. It's a blessed sisterhood. Sarah
(who looks the same!) was kind enough to take the train in from her home in CT to have
a great Mexican lunch with me at Rosa Mexicano. As she works in an independent
bookstore in New Canaan (Aunt Marlene, you must know it, on Elm St.?) and is an avid
reader, she also recently sent me a book that I am looking forward to digging into soon.
We talked about everything including news of our classmates, memories of our
classmates' parents (the one who wore a fur coat; the one who smoked cigarettes from a
long holder; the one who smoked pot; the one who broke barriers for women in law
school) and our older and wiser perspectives on our Nightingale days. Sarah, who is now
a grandmother (!), seems to enjoy a wonderful life and I'm so happy for her. Sarah, Eva,
Jill, Jane, Zia and Lisa, thank you for reading my blog and especially for your friendship; if
I've left anyone out *please* know that it's due to a senior moment and is not
intentional!
Looking forward to seeing a few more dear friends in the city before I leave on Sunday.
 
 
Photos
                       915 / 1.901
                       916 / 1.901
                       917 / 1.901
                       918 / 1.901

 December 1, 2021 - Chanukah miracles (not)
  by Willa Silverman, December 1, 2021  
                       920 / 1.901
                       921 / 1.901
I'm back in Baltimore for treatment (and other appointments) tomorrow, having driven
here from PA earlier (easy drive, with stop for lunch at Alvaro's in Harrisburg). After
tomorrow, I'll be able to receive chemotherapy in State College, while travelling to
Baltimore once a month (and not once a week) for a checkup. My next trip here is slated
for Dec. 30th (anyone wanna come with me?).
I was hoping for my own private Chanukah 'miracle' -- perhaps like in a Hallmark movie
or _A Christmas Carol_ or _It's a Wonderful Life_ -- where the 'spirit of the season'
envelops the main characters in goodness and light --when I finally got up the courage to
look at the results of my bloodwork from yesterday, and especially my Ca125 number.
Alas, that number has more than doubled in the past two and a half months, jumping
from 22.7 in September to 45.1 yesterday. I am almost certain that a result from
October, though, was not recorded; as I recall, it was in the low 30s. Anything above 38
is considered high. Even though Dr. Beavis has told me that we need to consider the
abdominal/pelvic/chest scan (currently scheduled for Dec. 27th) as more
revelatory/predictive than the CA125 number, as any number of factors can distort that
number (ovarian cancer marker), I can't help but feel bummed by this result, the highest
since August, when it hit about 51. Does the result suggest that the current course of
chemo is not effective? And if so, what are the implications of that? Is this a preview of
the scan? Or should it be disregarded? Taken with a grain of salt? How do I interpret it in
light of feeling relatively well the past weeks and even months? Ovarian cancer can be
*very* insidious. So...much...uncertainty. All I could do when I read the results (in my
hotel room in Baltimore) was to clutch at the medallion the valiant Rhonda Gold gave me
("Be strong and of good courage"), feel the tears stinging in my eyes, and watch the
candles flicker in the little menorah I brought with me from home in order to be able to
obey the commandment to light them.
I'll be able to provide a more detailed medical update after tomorrow's appointments. My
list of questions is at the ready. I am looking forward to seeing Rhonda Cooper, the
chaplain for the Kimmel Cancer Center, tomorrow morning. I contacted her a week or so
ago and will visit with her between my other meetings. My lovely college friend who lives
in Baltimore, David Miranda, will reprise his role as my 'care person' during my infusion.
His presence is calming and comforting. As I'll be pumped full of Benadryl, he'll make
sure I return to my hotel in one piece.
My cancer saga continues to unfold against a backdrop of truly lovely moments; perhaps
I'm simply living out my priorities, as I've often said that if I knew (know??) that my life
span might be shorter than anticipated, I would definitely want to prioritize time with
family and friends. My decision to spend most of November in NY while travelling weekly
to Baltimore was definitely a good one, as I was able to alternate my treatments with
'quality time' in the city. This included a fun tapas lunch at Boqueria Flatiron with my
                       922 / 1.901
college friends Denise and Mike Reiss and Richard Bashner and a heartwarming visit with
one of my dearest friends, Mitchel, on one of his annual visits to the States from France,
where he now lives. Mitchel and I met in a class on Proust when I was a freshman (the
only one in the class!) and he was a sophomore. We became fast friends, in 1980
travelling all over Italy together (I remember wearing a shimmering red/pink-gold colored
jumpsuit while dancing to "Funkytown" in a disco in Florence...), then winding up as
around the corner neighbors when he was in law school at NYU and I was at NYU's
Institute of French Studies, also for grad school. Even though we hadn't seen each other
for 2.5 years (the last time was in Paris, on my birthday, when Mitchel, our dear mutual
friend Randy, and I went out to dinner), we immediately started yapping away as if not a
moment had passed. It did me so much good to see him.
At the end of my NY stay, Ben arrived in a rental car and we drove back to PA (I always
value those long car rides as rarely do I get to spend so much uninterrupted time with
my son!). Ben spent the entire week at home, and Sammi arrived a few days later.
Despite how much I loved being back in the city, I appreciated the fresh air, quiet and
calm of my house, and was happy to be able to cook my own meals as well. Ben, Sammi
and I spent several days cooking for our Thanksgiving celebration at Michael and Sue's.
That too was most pleasant, relaxing, celebratory and delicious, from the oysters, scallop
ceviche and Cava served as an appetizer to the tasty pecan and pumpkin pies Ben and
Sammi made (I contributed the crust) for dessert. I seem to be able to experience joy
rather spontaneously these days -- compounding my natural disposition, which I'd say
tends towards joie de vivre. Grateful for that.
The Saturday after Thanksgiving I greatly enjoyed a visit with the wonderful Christi, a
former grad student who has become a cherished friend. We went straight for the 'no
b.s.' convo about survivorship, work, motherhood, families, spirituality and more. And as
always we shared lots of giggles too, especially remembering a rather burlesque
experience (or series of experiences) at a conference in Paris about ten years ago. Got a
peek for Christi's husband, DJ, and her adorable (yet, that day, weary) seven-year-old,
Misha.
I have a new wig (see pictures). The 'Hair Lady' (per the name of her business),
Katherine Fagan, a very nice woman a bit younger than me, knows how to make women
(and men too I suppose) look good and feel attractive. I'm quite happy w/my new look. A
sweet male student (I presume) came up to me in Starbucks the other day and
exclaimed: "I love your hair!" [At the farmer's market in NY a week or so ago, when I was
wearing my previous wig, a woman came up to me and said: "You *must* tell me where
you get your hair cut! It looks terrific."]. Go figure.
If all goes as planned -- health? Omicron? - I am planning to go to Paris next month, for
two weeks! This plan was hatched over a dinner or two with a group of fabulous women
friends in State College, all of whom work or have worked for the University. One of them
                       923 / 1.901
has been taking French classes and would like to use her newfound language skills,
another vacations fairly regularly there with her husband, a third has never been but has
been eager to go. All of them had suggested that it would be fun to go with me, given
how well I know the city as well as our common love of pretty things, good meals, wine
and conversation, and much more. I invited my friend Helen to join me, Cheryl and
Sandy -- a fab foursome for sure. We (myself, C and S) will be staying in a hotel in the
Marais, and will arrive just as the winter 'soldes' (sales) begin (!). There are a few
exhibits I'm eager to see, including one at the Fondation Louis Vuitton showcasing the
stellar collection of a famous Russian collector. I'm hoping that the second week, and
maybe a bit during the first, I'll be able to spend time with friends (Paris friends: I'll soon
contact you about this, but am being a bit cautious about not 'jinxing' my trip given
everything I've written here). I have not been to Paris since March 2019, right before I
was diagnosed, when I took students there in the context of my course on France and
the Holocaust. I was supposed to return over the summer as a 60th bday present but
was recovering from debulking surgery and so Ben and Sammi went in my stead. I hope
that that scenario won't be repeated this time. Dr. Beavis has no objection and said that
we could shift things around for the two weeks I'm away. I realize that I will likely not be
able to gallivant around Paris with my usual gusto, but I'm prepared to make some
modifications to my usual high-energy schedule. I get excited thinking about the
prospect of returning to my 'happy place.' I even booked a seat, for the first time ever for
me, in business class, ticking off one item on my very short bucket list.
