December 2, 2021 - Hugs
  by Willa Silverman, December 2, 2021  
                       931 / 1.901
                       932 / 1.901
A brief update from Baltimore on today's appointment: after a week of improved sleep
(all sleep meds eliminated in an attempted 'reset'), I slept (for a few hours) miserably
last night, my mind racing and spewing random thoughts, anxious about the following
day's appointments.
Awoke early, Ubured to Dr. Beavis' office for an 8:45 appointment for which she was over
an hour late (good thing my next appointment wasn't until 10:30). A resident who works
with her, though, met with me beforehand and answered many of my questions. I always
feel that my meetings with Dr. Beavis go well, simply because she is so knowledgeable,
talented, compassionate, and capable of answering my questions thoroughly. Once she
is with me, moreover, I have the sense that she is fully *there* and not looking at the
clock or thinking about her next meeting. She sits close to me, fairly casually dressed
(usually a dress from Boden over leggings because she bikes to/from work every day).
She did not seem overly concerned, at this point, about the rise in my CA 125 level. Even
though that level has been trending upwards the past two or three months or so, that
period is marked by the start of my participation in the clinical trial. In other words, she
still thinks that it may take another cycle for the results of this new treatment to be
reflected in the CA 125 number. Further, she noted that the increase has been 11 points
(September to October), then 12 points (October to November). She'd be much more
concerned, she said, if she'd seen a more significant leap in the number (which can top
1000; mine was well into the hundreds initially, if I remember correctly). The scan on
Dec. 27th, as I've mentioned, will be much more conclusive. She encouraged me, again,
to try not to project too far ahead and to be fully in the moment, a goal she encouraged
me, also again, to continue to pursue with my therapist (while she acknowledged its real
difficulty). 
I now have another short 'reprieve' until my scan on the 27th. I look forward to a low-key
few weeks.
I asked her (and have also discussed at length with my therapist) what to make of the
many, many compliments I've been receiving lately on my outward appearance and
affect, while knowing that I am battling incurable advanced metastatic cancer. I've
decided to simply accept these compliments graciously, while privately holding the
knowledge that one can look and feel well and still be fighting an awful disease. My
apparently healthful-looking appearance is not necessarily a 'sign' that I may be winning
the fight. Nevertheless, as Dr. Beavis noted, if I were confronting the final stages of my
disease I would likely 'look sick' (thin, wan, weak etc.). Perhaps I'm simply outwardly
embodying a mantra that my friend Isabelle recently coined: "Less attitude and more
gratitude"  -- yeah!
                       933 / 1.901
I confirmed with Dr. Beavis that other treatments are still available to me (including,
perhaps, a trial at Sloan) if/when the current one proves unsuccessful. Her response was
unequivocally affirmative. I asked if there were other approaches I could be trying, other
things I could be doing. She responded that the three keys for me remain a)good
sleep/sufficient rest (I *seem* to be rounding a corner on that); b)activity/exercise (need
to work on this; I dislike walking outdoors in cold weather but will push myself to do so);
and c)eating well (no problem there, although I want to rethink my overall plan for
eliminating excess sugars from my diet and privileging healthy foods; it's soup season,
methinks, and fortunately the NYTimes recipe app provides a staggering trove of recipes
for tasty, healthy eats).
Dr. B. also recommended a zinc supplement to ward off the very slight cold I felt I might
be coming down with (but of which she saw no signs in my throat, sinuses, glands etc.).
The gyn-onc resident said (when I asked) that it wouldn't hurt to try acupuncture, and to
continue it if I sensed benefit from it, but that their practice remained neutral regarding
its use.
As a small token of thanks, I gave Dr. Beavis and her nurse, Kelly, a jar of something
good from Tait Farm, my favorite store in State College (sour cherry jam, cranberry
chutney). Kelly gave me one of the first of several warm, tight hugs I received that day,
one of the highlights of my day in fact.
I next walked through the labyrinth of the hospital to Weinberg Building, to say hello to
Rhoda Cooper, the kind, friendly chaplain who had brought me comfort and compassion
after my operations. Rhonda is a warm, outgoing woman of 67, with long hair, whose
offices in the "Family Services" section of Weinberg abounds with healing/religious
imagery from various faiths (a menorah, Russian icons, maybe some Buddhist mantras
etc.). We caught up a bit (she remembered that the 60th bday trip to Lyon I had planned
for 2019 with Ben had to be aborted, but that Sammi and Ben were able to go in my
stead; I remembered a transcontinental train trip she was about to take with her
husband, also cancelled due to COVID). I asked her if she would pray with me, and she
crafted the most beautiful prayer (which I wish I had recorded), distilling and weaving
the various strands of our conversation (healing, Ben, my upcoming trip to Paris, my
support team etc.) into a series of wishes addressed to a higher power. A comforting
moment during a hectic and at times stressful day. Grounding.
Here's a YouTube clip featuring Rhonda: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j41GjOi9AFQ
Rhonda walked me to the Viragh Building for treatment. On the way, she introduced me
to Moira Bucciarelli, a second chaplain recently been hired to work with cancer patients.
At Viragh, I was delighted to see Jesse, a 'greeter' who helps patients check in, prints out
their itineraries if needed, provides directions etc. Rhonda told me that he had been a
                       934 / 1.901
van driver at Hopkins for years. A dapper gentleman (he modeled when he was younger,
he told me), Jesse's warm greetings have brightened my chemo days the past month or
so; he seems to understand the vulnerability and anxiety accompanying many visitors to
this clinic. He's so popular that when he has a day off, patients routinely ask: "Where's
Jesse?" Jesse's a rock star! This time I remembered to ask for a picture of him, which
Rhonda took. As you'll see in the pic, Jesse embraced me in a welcoming, protective side
hug (he also smelled good!). Rhonda escorted me to the 10th floor for chemo; before we
parted, we also embraced: hugs #2 and 3 for the day!
Chemo proceeded smoothly. The Benadryl really knocks me out (I felt like I was slogging
through quicksand, and my mind was very slow in making connections, articulating
thoughts...). My wonderful friend David took a break from his work to come sit w/me
during chemo and we caught up on our holidays, travel, the challenges of David's new
work project, gender neutral pronouns and much else. At one point I was so tired though
that I had to ask David if he wouldn't mind if I closed my eyes for a few minutes. As soon
as I did, I felt myself drifting towards sleep (I was lying on a hospital bed as all the chemo
rooms with lounge chairs were taken). As soon as I fell asleep, however, Ann, the nurse
affiliated with the clinical trial, stopped by briefly to bring me a new bottle of
Fostamatinib (trial drug that I had been taking along with the chemo but had to stop
when my white blood cells started to decrease) at a new, lower level. I will begin taking
these and will see what happens. Nicole, the chemo nurse assigned to me during my
previous visits, was busy with other patients but stopped by to say hi (can't say enough
good about the Hopkins staff). I finished my treatment in about two hours. David got his
car from the garage next door while I sat outside in the sun on this mild day, then drove
me back to the Residence Inn (I would have enjoyed the fairly short walk, but felt quite
woozy still). He too gave me a warm hug when we parted (hug #4!). He kindly invited
me to stay with him and his husband, Peter, on my next trip to Baltimore (scheduled for
the 30th), a gracious invitation I will strongly consider.
The service at the Residence Inn has declined markedly (new affront this visit: no soap in
the bathroom). However, I will cut the hotel some slack as I surmise that they may be
understaffed. The personnel is resolutely friendly and many of the patients, I presume,
are here for appointments at Hopkins -- people in wheelchairs (young man with a spinal
cord injury?), a man with impressive bandaging over his eye and a large part of his face,
me in my chemo cap. We interact compassionately with one another in the elevator or
the lobby, our tacit understanding of one another's travails buoying us. It's a safe space.
Speaking of kindness and compassion -- shortly after my return to the hotel, my first
cousin David (our mothers are sisters) dropped off dinner for me, heeding my request for
some deli food if possible. His care package will last me throughout the weekend I'm
sure: chicken noodle soup, four large pieces of stuffed cabbage (looks delicious), potato
latkes for Chanukah, and an enormous sandwich with both pastrami and corned beef (I
ate half of it, and some latkes). So kind of my cousin (a lawyer), who is a real mensch
                       935 / 1.901
(and, if she had anything to do with it, his wife Ilene, mother and grandmother
extraordinaire to a large family). Thank you, dear cousins!
I fell immediately into a deep sleep at about 4 p.m. When I awoke at 7 p.m. I thought it
was 7 a.m. the next day and I prepared to wake up, go get a coffee, and hit the road. I
found it strange that I was still in my clothes, hadn't taken off my earrings, and that the
NYTimes Spelling Bee was not featuring a 'clean' puzzle, as it does each day. I finally
realized that Friday had not yet arrived. So I regrouped, watched CNN and had dinner
while writing this journal entry. Hope I can sleep tonight after this long nap!
Onwards.

December 10, 2021 - On course
  by Willa Silverman, December 10, 2021  
                       937 / 1.901
                       938 / 1.901
No more weekly trips to Baltimore for now; those were the condition of my participating
in the clinical trial, during which time I was to be monitored closely by the physicians and
staff at Hopkins. From now until whenever I will no longer participate in the trial (a CT
scan on Dec. 27th will be telling in that regard), I will receive at least two treatments per
cycle here in State College. While I continue to take my Fostamatinib pill twice daily (at a
lower dose than originally, as it was impairing my white blood cell count) -- the pill is the
'extra element' that is the focus of the trial -- I will receive my chemo drug (Taxol) as an
infusion here in State College, in addition to the pre-meds (Benadryl, a steroid, an anti-
nausea med, and something else that I've forgotten).
So this week I was back at Scenery Park for my blood draw (Wednesday), then met with
Dr. Patel on Thursday before treatment. It was so nice to see him; I've really grown quite
fond of him. He reviewed my blood work (nothing warranted treatment being withheld,
thankfully) and, like Dr. Beavis, tried to sway me from fetishizing my CA125 number,
which, as I noted previously, had risen by 11 and then 12 the past two months and
currently stands at 45 (anything above 35-38 being considered outside normal range).
What Dr. Patel asserts is more important to focus on are cancer-related symptoms, of
which fortunately I have very few: no vomiting, extremely minimal nausea (I rarely take
anti-nausea meds), healthy appetite and stable weight, no advance in neuropathy, still
present in my toes but not my fingers, thank goodness, no mouth sores to speak of (I've
had a few, which disappeared quickly with a special mouthwash), stable, normal blood
pressure. The only symptom I still struggle with is diarrhea, but the right dosage of two
anti-diarrhea meds is helping; that dose just needs to be tweaked occasionally. Still, that
niggling CA125 number....has to mean...something...right?
Dr. Patel, like Dr. Beavis, is completely behind my going to Paris next month. He
understands what an important mood lifter it will provide for me, how much I miss my
friends there, how I love that city so, how excited I am to be travelling with three
outstanding women friends. He shared with me how a recent trip to visit friends in Des
Moines, IA, where he used to live, had the same uplifting effect on him. My chemo
schedule can be tweaked to accommodate the two weeks I'll be away. Now crossing my
fingers that nothing (Omicron, my own health) confounds our plan. It will have been 2.5
years since I've been in Paris. I had to cancel my last trip, to celebrate my 60th bday, as I
was recovering from debulking surgery.
Dr. Patel's parting shot to me: "You're doing well." Yeah.
My infusion now lasts (only) two hours, one for the pre-meds and one for the chemo. I
was happy to see the wonderful nurses in the infusion room, several of whom I feel close
to, and who are all highly skilled, supportive, friendly and compassionate. One of my
favorite nurses, Brynn, took care of me: although Christian (isn't everyone around
                       939 / 1.901
here?), she's 'conversant' w/Jewish culture (I forget how; there's a reason), asked me
about my Chanukah celebrations, requested (for a second time!) my chicken soup recipe
(which I *will* copy for her, now that I've written it out for Ben, with all my tips). Like
Michael and me, Bynn's parents are amicably divorced and spend holidays together, so
we always catch up on that. She and her wife are raising a little girl, and we trade news
of our kids as well. Several other nurses who I now know fairly well stopped by to say
hello. Somehow it all felt very comforting. I am pumped so full of Benadryl before the
chemo infusion that I conked out immediately, and did so after each minor interruption
to start a new med etc. There is *no way* I could have driven myself home safely after
chemo, so I'm grateful to my friend Jackie for driving me to Scenery Park in the morning
and my friend and neighbor Janis for picking me up, with a pitstop at Meyer's dairy,
where I treated myself to a delicious small butterscotch sundae and promptly left my
credit card in the reader as I was so loopy (I retrieved it today). Conked out again as
soon as I returned home.
My energy today surprised me, given that I had just had chemo the day before (although
one hour v. several makes a difference). I ran lots of errands, then took a 50 mile drive
to buy maple syrup from an Amish farm. Caught up on emails. No nap.
****
I also wonder at how a highly-driven, consistently motivated professional with a laser-
sharp focus on her career for decades (ie me) can currently feel nearly zilch motivation
to pursue my academic work, while a book review, a book manuscript review and several
other projects await. It actually amazes me. At least two retired colleagues have shared
with me their perception of this post-retirement phase as particularly productive and
fertile for them. I admire them for this, but it's not me. At least not now. I have an
instinct, though, that motivation for academic work will return. At some point.
Things I am motivated to do right now: spend time with family and friends, lots of it.
Cook, especially for other people. Take long drives in the countryside. Write my blog.
Finish up a few (autobiographical) stories I've been working on. Cultivate spirituality.
Fundraise for the Kelly Gyn-onc Service at Hopkins. Find time for the 'little things' I
barely had time for before: concocting creative gifts for people; writing holiday cards;
giving the 'gift of time' (the phrase 'the gift of me' sounds terribly self-aggrandizing...)
Retort: "You devoted yourself single-mindedly to your successful career for close to thirty-
five years, were a chaired professor at a major research university, wrote three books
(one that obtained a prestigious award, another nominated for two awards in France),
edited a fourth, edited a special issue of a journal and produced many articles, taught
hundreds of students, directed a dozen dissertations (whose authors are all thriving in
their careers) and have a few others en cours, served your department as graduate
director for five years and as department head for two, and went out arguably at the top
of your game. Surely you can rest on your laurels now and turn to other pursuits in
                       940 / 1.901
retirement if you care to? AND you have cancer, for chrissake. Go easy on yourself, girl!"
Me: Yes, cognitively I understand this, but please understand that all these
accomplishments do not diminish the sense of loss or worth or identity I am feeling (the
word 'slothful' also comes to mind...). And it's hard to know what to do about that, as it
makes me feel aimless and frustrated, lacking tangible goals. And I like to have goals.
Imagine how a talented athlete -- or simply anyone used to being active -- feels after a
devastating injury. I can certainly ascribe much of this feeling to the double whammy of
retirement and cancer. And I'm sure COVID fits into the equation somehow. As does, to a
lesser extent, the absence of an identifiable 'reward structure' (via raises and other
forms of symbolic 'legitimation'). I also feel the loss of professional colleagues who had
become friends through common conference attendance over many decades, meet ups
in Paris, collaboration on projects etc. It makes me sad to think that I might lose these
friendships if my conference attendance and other forms of visibility in the professional
realm remain irregular. Or perhaps professional friendships are a different kind of beast?
I became very jazzed watching a Ken Burns documentary about the Bard Prison
Initiative, through which prisoners receive a college-level education (Associate's degree
or BA/BS) with classes taught largely but not exclusively by Bard faculty. This motivated
enough for me to check out the website and see how professors could apply. I've always
been intrigued by teaching in prisons and wonder if this is something I might pursue (but
with weekly chemo treatments?...); I think my course on France and the Holocaust could
be a hit.  The prisoners in this documentary were *extraordinary,* great minds, highly
motivated. I had also envisioned work for the Peace Corps as another exciting post-
retirement possibility. But I may have to adjust my horizons. Or maybe not.
So...much..uncertainty about what I will and will not be able to undertake going forward.
Perhaps it's simply a time to explore the possibilities that radical *freedom* entails:
testing the limits of old and new relationships or imagining new ways of being in them;
making memories; trying out new modes of being, doing, saying. "Freedom's just
another word for nothing left to lose [?]"
Was delighted to have lunch this week with my "III Cs," our erstwhile OC survivor group
(reinvigorated this week by the presence of a new member, Mitzi, whose company I
enjoyed and who is also treated at both Hopkins and by Dr. Patel in State College). This
did my heart and soul good!

him of how much he had accomplished, how he changed the laws of West Germany so

don't fret the things that appear outside your realm right now. You are doing G R E A T!

December 22, 2021 - Staying the course (more or less)
  by Willa Silverman, December 22, 2021  
                       942 / 1.901
                       943 / 1.901
It's been almost two weeks since I've written. Since last Saturday I've been in NY, hoping
to avoid the dreariness and loneliness I often feel in State College around the holidays,
when most everyone clears out. Maria and Greg were heading to the city Saturday for a
brief vacation and our road trip sure beat the long train ride that I had booked myself on.
On Sunday the immediate family, nine of us, enjoyed a wonderful 85th birthday
celebration for my mother, at home, a NY Sunday brunch extraordinaire with all the
fixins' (Absolute bagels, paper thin smoked salmon and sable and various types of
herring from Russ and Daughters, cream cheese spreads and salmon roe and olives and
gherkins and pickled butter beans from Zabar's, and a to-die for chocolate mousse cake
from Veniero's. And Moet :) We continued our quinquennial tradition of asking my
mother questions (from the matter of fact, "Tell us about your ideal New York day," to
the existential: "Do you have any life lessons for us?"). Throughout the many hours we
spent together, toasts were offered, presents given (mine was a photo collage put
together by a local framing place, reaching back to capture my mother at a sweet 16
party and then forward to the present), photos taken.
Perhaps because of the feasting on Sunday -- but who knows? - I've been feeling off
since then, with an upset stomach compounded by fatigue. So I've needed to rest a lot,
which is what I suppose my body is calling for. Consequently, I feel somewhat weak and
get easily winded walking a few blocks. I've been in touch with Justin, my superb nurse
at JH (ie I emailed him to let him know what's up and he called me *five minutes* after
that), who has made some suggestions (reduce anti-diarrheal meds) and wants me to
keep in touch with him.
Admittedly, the anxiety of potentially needing to go to the ER or Med Expres (which I'm
not anticipating at this point) in the midst of the resurgent plague adds to my stress. It is
a very strange, muted time and everyone seems slightly depressed. I hear about more
friends/acquaintances with COVID every day. The city seems quieter than usual, but for
the swelling lines of people waiting to get tested. Nearly everyone is adjusting holiday
plans. How long will it be possible to hold out before the virus invades our homes and
those of our loved ones, as well?
Until Monday of this week, though, I felt on course. My latest infusion, in State College,
proceeded smoothly -- once it started. Because I had taken a COVID test in light of my
upcoming travel (all nine of us agreed to do this before gathering on Sunday), and
because this was noted on my Geisinger chart, Dr. Patel's office did not want to proceed
with my chemo until the results (negative, in the end) came in, for fear that I might
transmit the virus to other cancer patients in the infusion room. I had to explain that I
was completely asymptomatic and was taking a test as a precaution before I was
allowed to proceed with chemo. I also did not know that I needed a magnesium drip that
                       944 / 1.901
day, which added two hours to my treatment. In the end everything worked out fine, and
I actually felt relatively energetic the first two days post-chemo. I believe, though, that
the amount of chemo meds progressively accruing in my system is starting to wear me
down -- at least that's how it seems to me. 
Thanks to my neighbor/friend Janis and my friend Monique for transporting me to/from
chemo. I was super loopy from Benadryl, but I believe that Monique and I stopped at
Meyer Dairy after my chemo so that I could indulge in a mini-butterscotch sundae.
I'll return to State College on Saturday (Xmas) on the Megabus. I reserved both my own
seat and the one next to mine as a kind of 'buffer' (this is a 'thing' one can now do on the
Megabus), and in the hopes that the bus will be well-ventilated. My
pelvic/abdominal/chest scan is scheduled for Monday; I'm anxious. When I'm sitting I feel
some pressure on my pelvis where I know tumors are located (ie at the top of the
vagina). Uncomfortable. Then I need to go to Baltimore on the 30th for treatment and to
be examined by one of the doctors (Dr. Beavis will be on vacation in CA). I am hoping to
be able to drive as long as the weather cooperates; if not, I'm not entirely sure what I'll
do -- perhaps see if the reliable driver I've used before, Mohindr Singh, is still available
for this type of (costly...) work. I liked it when his wife accompanied him and she shared
her recipes for Indian rice pudding and other treats. I need to contact my friend David
Miranda who nicely offered to put me up in Baltimore (I'll need to stay both the 29th and
the 30th). I may, then, wind up driving back to State College on the 31st, which seems as
forlorn as my upcoming Christmas Day Megabus ride. I'll need to try to shift this
paradigm a bit in order to not get swallowed up in bleakness. Of course, an encouraging
scan result would compensate for a lot!
In better news, I've been sleeping amply and soundly. And I did savor some alone time in
the city with Ben, Ethan and my photographer friend Laurent (w/whom I discussed ideas
for a portrait of me that I'm hoping to commission from him, with a vanitas theme).
Photos

                       946 / 1.901
                       947 / 1.901
                       948 / 1.901
                       949 / 1.901
                       950 / 1.901

with a version of 'storycorps' right in your apartment. Hoping that the bus isn't crowded,
that you can drive to JH, and that the scan brings good news. Will be sending loving
thoughts your way tomorrow and reminiscing on the 31st of many a NYEve past. xoxo
paula
  —Paula Golombek, December 26, 2021  
  
December 30, 2021 - Better news AND A Night Spent in Hell OR
Pivoting
  by Willa Silverman, December 30, 2021  
                       951 / 1.901
This is a good news, bad news tale. I'll start with the good, or at least better, news. Given
how tired and generally unwell I've felt recently, I had convinced myself beyond a
reasonable doubt that my recent scan (which itself went smoothly; the technicians at
Geisinger Gray's Woods are very pleasant and know me by now) would show
progression, as my last one had. The radiologists' reports (from both Geisinger and
Hopkins) sat in my message queue in my portal for a day or two, sending my anxiety
through the roof. The combination of technical medical language and the possibility of
receiving devastating news (eg spread to other organs etc.) kept me paralyzed, frozen.
So I was grateful when Dr. Beavis called me, as I was in my car in the parking lot at
Scenery Park about to have my bloodwork done, to discuss the results. 'Grateful' does
not actually describe the tears that welled up when she called because a)I thought she
was in California for vacation and didn't expect to hear from her and b)I was having an
awful day (more on that awful day in the 'bad news' part of the story). The good news,
then, is that my scan shows that my cancer is 'stable.' The existing tumors have
remained more or less the same size as before. A good number of cancerous lymph
nodes have *decreased* in size. There are some 'non-specific' spots on my lung(s?), but
at this point we don't know what they are; it could be cancer or perhaps something
completely different. There is no new cancer in liver, bones, other organs. I will continue
with the trial and will be scanned again in eight weeks -- an eight week reprieve, then,
from having my mortality in my face constantly. Fifty-six days, each a blessing. The
result also makes me place some hope in the clinical trial; we'll see if these results can
be sustained. Yes, this was not the *best possible result,* i.e. regression of the cancer,
but it is not progression. Holding steady. And that's a good thing. The 'cherry on top' is
that my CA level dropped from last month's 45 to this month's 35, back into normal
range. Yay.
The bad news is that I spent Tuesday night in the ER. 'Bad' not because there is anything
seriously wrong, beyond my cancer, but simply because a night spent in Covid Central
was traumatizing. In fact, I think Centre County set a record that day for the number of
Covid cases. [By the way, my friend David will perhaps feel slightly less badly about  not
being able to host me in Baltimore this week -- although I know he'll feel badly for what
happened to me instead -- as he and his husband were exhibiting Covid symptoms;
David, I did shift my hotel reservation until next week!]
                       952 / 1.901
As I write this, I'm unsure of what I want from you. Perhaps some sympathy (but never
pity). Perhaps I simply want a record of what happened, as for much of this journal. I do
feel some urge to embellish, to sink my writerly chops into descriptions of a hellscape.
More challenging to convey the emotions I felt, the sad thoughts that took hold of my
mind, and the extent to which I hate being in the hospital as it reinforces my sense of
illness. The hours spent staring into space like a zombie. The crying jags. The broken and
lost feeling. I try to be  tough ("Be strong and of good courage") but after a multi-hour
wait for a room (five hours? six? seven? eight? I lost track), my nerves felt frayed.
I do want to assert categorically that the staff at Mount Nittany Medical Center took good
care of me. They are doing the best they can while totally overwhelmed (one doctor said
to me: "It's a crisis.").  I was impressed with the two doctors who tended to me. This
being said, I never got out of the ER into the hospital (simply no beds in the hospital so
an ER room became my de facto hospital room). In some ways I think this was a blessing
as ER nurses are unflappable. It's just another day of crazy for them.
I had been spiking some fevers and feeling generally unwell so Dr. Beavis recommended
I go to the ER (she feared that suppression of my white blood cells was causing a fever,
which can be quite serious). Truth be told, though, I am not completely certain my
thermometers were giving accurate readings as they were reporting astronomically high
temperatures. Both at Dr. Patel's office (where I stopped by to have my temperature
read by a nurse) and in the hospital, my temps were more or less in the normal range, a
bit high. So I sheepishly feel that my rush to the hospital may have been cloaked in a
false premise. What is undeniable, though, is that I needed what I call a 'tune up.' The
chemo destroys so much good stuff along with the cancer cells that I can get very run
down, which I think explains why I wasn't feeling great part of the time in NY, very
fatigued, very winded. In the ER, then, I received a blood transfusion; a three-bag
magnesium drip; extra potassium; antibiotics in case of infection; chest X-ray,
bloodwork, blood cultures etc. I was also swabbed for COVID and am relieved to report
that I DON'T have it.
The waiting room was the hellscape; the first image above (or below?) came to mind
immediately: Michelangelo, "The Despair of the Damned." Absolutely packed to the gills,
people coughing, lots of sick kids, no sense at all of when I would be called. As most of
the Covid patients at MNMC are unvaccinated, I presume that many in the waiting room
were too. The lights are dim and the walls an icky dull green-gray color. To complete the
ghoulish tableau, several manacled prisoners in orange jumpsuits, closely guarded,
marched in, ankle chains jangling (I can only presume that COVID is running rampant in
prisons, although these guys may well have been here for some other reason). Marley's
ghost came to mind, here to warn us of....what? Once I saw the triage nurse for five
minutes, after several hours, I was sent to another de facto waiting room, also
completely full, to wait for a room in the ER to open up (conversation between a man
                       953 / 1.901
and woman across from me: "I've been waiting six hours." "I've been waiting eight."). Oy.
After several hours (?) and a brief screening with a doctor (very nice; impressive), a
room in the ER opened up. Thankfully, I only had to spend one night there. To all my
peeps: please avoid the ER/hospital at all costs if you can!
Thank you, Helen, for dropping off a chocolate milkshake for me just as I told the nurse
that I had a hunger headache (dinner Tuesday night: chips and a candy bar). Thanks,
Jackie, for all your concern, good humor, kindness, grocery shopping etc. And Maria,
thanks for picking me up! Thanks, Julie, for texting. And gratitude to my family of course.
If you contacted me and I didn't mention you here, my apologies. I was really strung out
and may have some selective amnesia regarding my hospital stay.
I look forward to a calmer 2022. I had a feeling 2021 would not go gently.
I look forward to renewing my commitment to my wellness.
I will try to write again tomorrow.
As my friend Isabelle recently said to me, I think 'pivot' is *the* word for 2021. And if it
isn't it should be.
Back to Baltimore next week.

December 31, 2021 - A new year
  by Willa Silverman, January 2, 2022  
2021/2022: my third new year since my diagnosis in Spring 2019. In some
                       956 / 1.901
ways, that fact amazes me. I attribute my survival to medical and scientific
advances (parp inhibitors; clinical trials) deployed by a stellar medical team
in Baltimore and State College; the consistent, loving support of family and
friends near and far; and, I suppose, my own tenacity.
In early post-diagnosis conversations with Rabbi Ostrich, he and I agreed
that, although cancer is by no means a "blessing" (as some would have it),
it might offer me the possibility of learning a thing or two. This I have, about
friendship for example (or perhaps about an area  between 'friendship' and
'love'), mainly because others have modeled it for me time after time. I
thought about this when reading a quote from the recently-deceased
Archbishop Desmond Tutu (a personal hero): "Your ordinary acts of love and
hope point to the extraordinary promise that every human life is of
inestimable value." "Ordinary acts of love" (so powerful, so precious) have
been manifested to me countless times during my cancer journey, in turn
leading me to learn more about gratitude. I'm sure I've gleaned other
lessons too, for example about my own unexpected toughness, but these
are a few of the main take-aways.
In a low moment, my brother, I believe, instructed me to "think happy
thoughts." This prompted me to return to some of my most memorable New
Year's Eves: "I have more memories than if I'd lived a thousand years,"
writes Baudelaire in "Spleen," comparing his memory chambers to a "heavy
chest of drawers cluttered with balance-sheets,/Processes, love-letters, verses, ballads,/And
heavy locks of hair enveloped in receipts." Herewith, then, some of my mental clutter:
1981, Vienna: Because why *wouldn't* one spontaneously book a train trip to Vienna from
Paris for the last week of the year, imagining that the city must look fairytale enchanting at this
time of year? No matter that one does not speak German, has never been to Austria, is travelling
alone. Woke up in my couchette to thrilling views of the snow-covered Alps; the dining car had
linen table cloths and I warmed myself with gulashsuppe.  While I was dutifully photographing
a church in a quaint square the day after my arrival, M., a medical student my age who had been
contemplating me through his bedroom window, became intrigued, and left his apartment to
find out more. We spent the whole week together. I don't think we slept much. The week
culminated on New Year's Eve at a large club, Kulisse, packed with young people, where at
midnight we danced to waltzes by Strauss! I felt like I was floating on air (yes, I felt every inch
this timeworn cliché!). I was twenty-two and having the time of my life! (Cue Frank Sinatra:
                       957 / 1.901
"When I was twenty-one, it was a very good year...")
1984, Paris: New Year's Eve dinner at a swanky 'floating restaurant' on the Seine, l'Ile de
Kachmir. A Franco-American affair with about a dozen of us, Vinni, Doris, Rosalie and I, some
of our new French friends met in our classes at Sciences Po, and friends/partners of those
friends. I see from the photos that we are dressed festively (although I'm not in any of the
photos), the food as I recall was excellent, the Eiffel Tower glittered for the réveillon. My date
book reminded me that Vinni and I had just returned that day from a week's vacation in London,
where we had been theatre-goers, museum hoppers, sale shoppers (Selfridge's), and tea
drinkers. We had also met for tea with the head of our program at NYU, Nicholas Wahl, whose
British girlfriend's son just happened to be the future prime minister, Boris Johnson! Vinni also
reminded me, just yesterday, that the meal made a sizeable dent in our grad student finances,
despite the very strong American dollar of the mid-1980s (one thing to thank Ronald Reagan
for, I suppose). I was twenty-five years old and having the time of my life!
1985, Madrid: I wish I had a picture of this epic evening, the culmination of a week Vinni and I
spent in Madrid, mainly in the company of a friend of a friend of hers, a delightful guy named
Philip, half-British half-Spanish, who lived in Madrid and reveled in the Madrileno lifestyle that
we, consequently, adopted for a week as well: dinner at ten (he took us to wonderful restaurants
and tapas joints), hit the bars around midnight (always packed, lively), sleep late, a museum or
two in the afternoon. Philip was smart and I have recollections of a week's worth of intense, non-
stop conversation. On New Year's Eve Vinni and I were to first swing by Phillip's apartment:
this is where the now legendary part of the story -- since then recounted many times to our sons
-- about the two of us wandering cluelessly around a bullfighting ring on a freezing December
night, comes in. There were no cell phones, of course, I don't even think we had a map but
eventually we found P's place. We wound up at a smallish yet packed *French* restaurant, in
full NYE's mode: great food and drink, over the top conviviality, waiters partying with the
patrons (or perhaps I embellish here?), silly hats and noisemakers at midnight. Vinni may be
able to add more details. I was twenty-six and having the time of my life!
Between 1988 and 1993 (?), Pittsburgh: Before there were mortgages, before there was tenure,
before there were kids, before Michael and I were even married (I think?), we spent a New
Years in Pittsburgh with our dear friends Michael and Paula, with whom we celebrated many
holidays and milestones, always over excellent food and drink. We had dinner at a small
restaurant that someone must have known about (unfortunately, I did not record the name in my
datebook, but perhaps Paula remembers). Everyone teased me because I was adamant about
                       958 / 1.901
getting back to our borrowed apartment to see the ball drop in Times Square. In the taxi there,
in a mood of mild hilarity (and closely eyeing the clock as midnight approached), someone
(me?) asked the cabbie what was the strangest or most memorable thing anyone had ever done
in his cab. He replied (if I'm not mistaken), "Took a [xxx]." New Year's Day, on our way back
to State College, we received a speeding ticket in a town called Gallitzen, PA (pop. 1500). I
think Michael was driving. I was in my early thirties and loved our couples' adventure in
Pittsburgh.
2011, State College: First Night in State College -- ice sculptures, a drink at Zola, a concert by a
folk duo in a church -- followed by late-night dinner at home (pasta and scallops in lemon
cream sauce, and champagne) with D. A romantic grown-up evening, far from the slightly
unregulated hijinks of my twenties. D. was a bit of an old soul, so Donny Hathaway fit the
mood of the evening. I was 52 and enjoying a wonderful evening.
2018, Paris: At my bff Randy's studio, with an acquaintance of his (a bit of a wise-ass, who
enjoyed being gratuitously provocative). Randy cooked a delicious stuffed guinea hen (pintade)
from Picard along with some other dishes; I brought champagne and some pâté (?). That night
the guys introduced me to the British comedy series "Little Britain" ("Computer says no"),
which I found uproariously funny. We laughed uncontrollably most of the evening. I was 59
and appreciated the laughter and camaraderie.
Many other new year's eves were spent in New York, Washington, D.C., France, or State
College -- content or depressed or sick or festive or some/none of the above. Sometimes solo,
sometimes with others, sometimes at long-gone local restaurants (The Governor's Table in
Bellefonte). On Y2K, we stayed up until midnight to make sure the earth wouldn't explode; five-
year old Ben made it until midnight! Another year, we navigated First Night and big snowdrifts
with a stroller in freezing weather. 
This year's festivities were lovely: a friend invited me to a small gathering on the early side at
her home, along with five other folks (all vaccinated). I had just been discharged from the ER
the day before and was eager to put that traumatizing experience behind me and ditch my yoga
pants for a pretty skirt from Anne-Elisabeth.  Over a delicious meal (fondue and a variety of
veggie dishes c/o NYTimes), we laughed heartily about a stinkbug circling the dining table,
several glasses of spilled champagne (or 'mock' champagne) and poppers that wouldn't pop. The
perfect gathering for me this year. I had a great time.
Grateful for the all of it.
                       959 / 1.901
Wishing you good health, happiness, success (however you define or
measure it) and tranquility in 2022.
 
Photos
                       960 / 1.901

                       962 / 1.901
                       963 / 1.901

January 7, 2022 - Back from Baltimore
  by Willa Silverman, January 7, 2022  
I'm back from my monthly trip to Baltimore, with Ben in tow. I should say, rather, that
Ben (with some minor grumbling that I found perfectly understandable given the ask!)
kindly agreed to meet me in Baltimore yesterday afternoon (he traveled by train from
NY), stay overnight in my hotel (Residence Inn Johns Hopkins) and drive me home today,
staying over here in State College until he returns to Brooklyn via Megabus tomorrow.
This was a very big boost to me psychologically and emotionally as I didn't feel like I had
to take on singlehandedly the myriad details involved in my trip and multiple Hopkins
visits. Although he didn't accompany me to the Medical Center itself (which was fine), it
felt great to see him when he picked me up after chemo!
Earlier in the week, I had met with my PCP (Primary Care Physician), Paul Damaske, a
very sweet, relentlessly upbeat person and good, youngish  doctor who always has
worthwhile suggestions about my general care despite not being as specialized as Drs.
Beavis and Patel. He reminded me that when I was first diagnosed, prior to any surgery,
treatment regimen etc.,  we were completely in the dark about my future, prognosis etc.
and he seemed quite enthusiastic about seeing me doing generally well going on three
years. He asked if he could give me a hug at the end of our visit, and I consented, an act
of "ordinary goodness" that felt quite caring and confirming!
I also met (virtually) with my therapist on Tuesday and she remarked (in the course of
conversation) that I seemed to have a much sounder sense and broader knowledge
about my medical condition now than I did at the outset -- which is true. I guess that
knowledge has empowered me to some extent in coping with the entirety of my
situation.
My drive down to Baltimore was smooth. Where is everybody? My go-to pit stop location
in Harrisburg, Alvaro's Bread & Pastry Shop, was closed for winter holiday (these folk
work hard and they deserve a break!), so I stopped instead at a funky coffee shop a few
blocks away, Little Amps, for a breakfast burrito, fuel for the second half of the trip. As I
arrived a day early for my appointments (stopping first at a bakery in Little Italy,
Vaccaro's), I took a rest, wrote some emails and texts, relaxed etc. As mentioned, the
service at this hotel has declined: there were no sheets or any type of bedding for Ben's
bed; requests for toilet paper needed to be reiterated three times; and the food on the
limited menu is nearly inedible (I don't say this lightly: hamburger, which I consider a
'safe' item, was very greasy with raw meat, not medium rare as requested; fries needed
to be reordered as very soggy; salad was ok!). I do return, though, because of proximity
                       967 / 1.901
to Hopkins Medical Center (walking distance if I choose); *very* nice staff a large part of
whose clientele is comprised of Hopkins patients (surrounded by folks in wheelchairs,
others with imposing eye patches covering half their face etc., my chemo cap passes
scarcely without notice in what feels like an extremely safe space for me); and high
tolerance (and indulgence) for some 'slippage' in these hard times, when many in the
hospitality sector are leaving their jobs.
Slept so-so, arrived at the dining room a bit too late for breakfast but a very sweet
employee was able to bring me some yogurts and a banana, which I supplemented with
a cappuccino and o.j. from the Starbuck's around the corner. Watched some coverage of
the one-year anniversary of the 6 January events (about which Ben and I listened to an
excellent three-part podcast ["The Daily"] on our return drive).
My appointments went smoothly. Justin met me at Dr. Beavis' office and had me sign a
second consent form for the clinical trial, clearly explaining each section. He is so kind,
thorough, skilled and caring, answering my email queries immediately and calling me
when I was in the ER in State College to see how I was feeling. He suggested that I
increase my daily magnesium dose as my level is low, and chronically low levels can lead
to heart problems, diabetes, high blood pressure. I know the low level contributes to the
searing leg cramps that often incapacitate me temporarily during the night.
I am so grateful for my medical team.
Dr. Beavis was running late but as usual I had her full attention once she got to me
(Justin also attended the appointment). She examined me briefly and I brought up all my
concerns, new and less new, to her. Among the newer concerns: recent headaches
(although really none today). We'll wait a week and if they continue; if they do, she'll
order a brain scan. She does not think it sounds like anything to worry about, and I
concur - although the prospect of a brain scan seems scary. I have no other brain tumor
related symptoms (sharp pains, seizures, etc.). Conversely, I know that a)my new,
stronger glasses can't arrive soon enough; b)I spend more time than I should staring at
small screens; c)I've been having nosebleeds and experiencing sinus pressure recently,
likely in part due to dryness in my home. Among the list of potential medical problems I
worry about, this one is actually quite far down on my list -- for now at least, as cancer
cells can certainly travel from the belly to the brain.
Also, Dr. Beavis confirmed that it's fine to drink the copious amounts of carbonated
water that I enjoy -- it's a good way to hydrate, just need to have my dentist check me
twice a year for any damage from the carbonation (a low risk). She further did not
dismiss Dr. Damaske's (PCP's) suggestion (which I found odd) that a stimulant such as
Ritalin or Adderall, usually used to treat ADHD, could boost my energy level. We talked
about Covid, what to do if I get it. Answer: call her, situation and protocols are evolving
rapidly. Hopkins now features a separate ward devoted to cancer patients w/Covid. On
                       968 / 1.901
the list of medical problems I worry about, this one is high up. A good visit, during which
we also discovered our mutual taste for pickled foods! She said: "You're doing great."
Treatment went smoothly. I received a bag of magnesium along with my chemo (a lower
dose now, because of my low red/white blood cell count). As usual, the Benadryl made
me super groggy and I dozed a bit. Once in the Viragh Building for chemo, I was happy to
see Jesse, the lovely 'concierge' who helps me at the front desk, and whose smile,
dapper dress, kind words and practical help (eg checking me in, calling the elevator for
me and pressing my floor button etc.) brighten all my treatment visits!
Ben nicely picked me up in my car after chemo and we headed to La Scala, a wonderful
place in Little Italy. We had ordered some pasta and a grilled Caesar salad, quite
delicious. My appetite rarely seems to have deserted me, and I've gained back nearly all
the weight I lost in the past 2.5 years (30 pounds, at which point I looked scrawny and a
bit 'caved in'). I'm still fine, normal, and I don't fret a lot about this, but I need to
continue to eat healthily and not use my illness as an excuse to go overboard (as I did
when I was pregnant  (although not an illness, of course!): nightly steamed whole milk
with sweet almond or vanilla syrup>70 pound weight gain). In any event, we enjoyed our
dinner back in the hotel.
Today I feel better than I have in a long time! I slept well, not waking up once during the
night (highly unusual for me). The lower chemo dose obviously helped as did the extra
magnesium. And Ben's presence was certainly a balm. He went out to get me coffee and
picked up some yogurts for me from the dining room. We were on the road before 10
a.m. It had snowed in Baltimore last night so the attendant needed to dislodge quite a bit
of snow from our front and rear windows, but once on the road the highway and main
roads were clear and the trip home easy.
This week I'll have blood drawn Monday (magnesium) and Tuesday (CBC), then have
chemo here on Thursday.
Michael nicely brought over some seafood chowder Sue had made, in case we didn't
have food at home (I had bought a good-looking piece of fresh salmon from Maine Bay &
Berry, but it will remain in the freezer) -- thoughtful and helpful of them. I picked up a
large, crusty sourdough bread from a relatively new baker in town whom I've heard good
things about (Bellefonte Bread Baker) and I'll put together a simple salad. It's very cold
outside (I'm not a winter fan), so we'll spend a cozy evening indoors.
I forgot to add: my friends and I are postponing our Paris trip. It is not the right time to
go. Friends in Paris are even discouraging me from visiting, given the recent Covid surge
and all the new restrictions in place (all laudable, but they are a disincentive to
vacationers).  Three of us have underlying conditions and of course our health is a
concern. I'm certainly disappointed but also somewhat relieved. We will reschedule for
                       969 / 1.901
after this surge has - hopefully - passed and we can enjoy some of our planned
activities.  I spent literally hours on the phone with United to get credit for my flight,
which I can use for up to a year (this after spending literally hours on the phone with my
insurance company, but that's another story). So a Paris trip will be something to look
forward to within the next year. Strange times indeed.
Voilà. Shabbat shalom to all who observe.

January 14, 2022 - It-that-shall-not-be-named
  by Willa Silverman, January 14, 2022  
                       972 / 1.901
                       973 / 1.901
Everything went smoothly with this week's chemo. My bloodwork this week apparently
showed good results: my magnesium level is up (we doubled the number of slow-mag
tablets from four to eight daily; I'm also trying to eat magnesium rich foods such as
avocados; consequently, no searing leg cramps during the night, thank goodness); my
hemoglobin level is also up (for which I credit in part the transfusion in the ER; there is
currently a blood shortage, so *please give this life-giving/sustaining fluid if you can!*).
I've been *trying* to maintain a healthy/healthier diet, accompanied by new resolutions
to take advantage of curbside pickup at Wegman's (ie someone else does the shopping
for me; grocery shopping is actually an activity I enjoy, especially during farmers market
season, but for now this is a time and energy saver) and to make a large quantity of a
soup or other healthy dish a week (last week's choice was Harira, a soup eaten all over
the Middle East with healthy doses of harissa paste [pic included]; this week I may opt
for minestrone).
The promising blood results gave me the all-clear for chemo. Since I'm now having
chemo once a week at a lower dose, the session lasts two hours, one for pre-meds
(Benadryl that, when delivered through my vein, knocks me out immediately; Zofran and
some other drugs), the other for Taxol. Thank you, Helen, for driving me to chemo (and
for delivering soup, an almond croissant, and some NK95 masks for me later) and Jackie,
for picking me up, taking me to Pump Station drive-through for coffee and Meyer's for a
butterscotch ice-cream sundae!! It was great to see both of you and catch up in person,
however briefly. Darn Covid... As usual, I felt pretty peppy the rest of Thursday but tired
today and likely through the weekend, when a big snow-storm is predicted.
Because I told Dr. Beavis that I had been having headaches recently -- daily headaches,
every morning, unlike my usual (infrequent) type of headaches (these can hit in the back
of my head, and also upon exertion, with some nausea, although they remain quite well-
controlled throughout the day with Tylenol while still remaining very low-grade the whole
day) -- she ordered an MRI. I was able to move it up from next Saturday to next Tuesday,
but will be at the Lewistown Hospital (about 25 miles from here, over "Seven
Mountains"). My unfailingly kind friend Martina offered to take me and bring me back
and I'm indebted to her for this; we'll also have a chance to catch up and have a few
giggles along the way. Friends have suggested various roots causes: stress? sinus woes
(it's dry here, and my nose is quite bloodied, chronically, despite regular squirts of saline
spray)?; eye strain (small screens...)?; Covid (I'm asymptomatic aside from fatigue
attributable to cancer, but this is another reason why I'll test)"; all the meds?
My brain's my thing. Without a fully functioning one, or one invaded by sneaky cancer
cells (in her sometimes chipper way, Dr. Beavis confirmed that cancer cells can easily
travel from the belly to the brain), what/who am I (cue frantic, spiraling thoughts here
about my mortality)? "Je pense, donc je suis," and all that, but my professional life and
                       974 / 1.901
identity are predicated on having a pretty good one (brain, that is). So please have a
good thought for me on Tuesday the 18th though about 12:30 [Denis, I will contact you
to rearrange our Zoom meeting, as I was lucky enough to be able to move this scan up
from the 22nd to the 18th]. Meanwhile: stay in the moment, breathe (am thinking about
taking a six-session online meditation course with a local instructor, beginning this
Monday evening), think about the agency I still *do* have as long as I'm here. And I'll
know more next week. Am not really experiencing any other symptoms of brain tumors
(searing, radiating pains, confusion, weakness on one side of the body, personality
changes>am still able to get to Genius most days in the NYTimes Spelling Bee - and to
write this blog...) so hopefully....it's....not that?
I am sending a mi shebeirach this evening tp my college classmate, Brenda Russell,
whom I only met post-graduation (through another classmate, Brenda Prescott) - I wish I
had known both these women better in college, but that's another matter. Like me,
Brenda has OC, stage 4. She texted me last night as she's going back into the hospital
for the chronic vomiting that put her there once before. This time, because of Covid, she
can't have visitors. I know what a difference that can make, emotionally and
psychologically. She asked me to direct prayers in her direction, and I will (as well as to
my cousin, June, and a few others challenged by illness and/or caregiving duties right
now).
Random stuff: am reading _Cloud Cuckoo Land,_ the new novel by Thomas Doerr (whose
_All the Light You Cannot See_ I think I preferred); watched _The Power of the Dog,_ Jane
Campion's new film, with Ben last week and needed to read a few good reviews to
explain the ending to me. Looking forward to Zooming with my NYU grad school besties
in MA, NJ, NY and Paris this Sunday. Covid is making my world smaller right now,
unfortunately, but at least email, Zoom and social media provide ways of staying in
touch. Strange times.
Shabbat shalom. Stay well, everyone.

January 19, 2022 - Willa update 
  by Ethan Silverman, January 19, 2022  
Willa has asked me to pinch hit for her once again, while she courageously fights Cancer.
She hears/sees all of your heartfelt calls, texts and messages, but is unable to respond to
them at the moment (she is also without her computer).
Without sounding overly dramatic, and frightening, Willa was “life flighted - aka, flown by
helicopter” yesterday from PA to John’s Hopkins, after a scan revealed a spread or new
growth in the “back of her brain”.
Done more out of an abundance of caution, JH wanted to be able to reduce her swelling
through steroids, alleviate her headaches/nausea/symptoms, and be in position to
perform surgery in the coming days.
She is comfortable, alert, chatty, but understandably concerned about the unknown. 
She was able to see Dr. Beavis shortly after her arrival last night. Soon-after, Dr Beavis
generously spent some time on the phone with me as well.
I will try and answer any additional questions you might have, but I too have been trying
to collect information and help make informed decisions in a very short period of time.
Best to reach me via text (917-687-2978) or email (emanproductions@nyc.rr.com).

January 20, 2022 - Brain food
  by Willa Silverman, January 20, 2022  
                       981 / 1.901
I thought it might be helpful for people to hear from me directly, for some reassurance.
Writing on my tiny phone screen so might take a while.
Yesterday, my angel, Martina, the dear friend who spent most of Monday and Tuesday
with me, in State College and in the ER at the Geisinger Hospital in Lewistown, PA, joked
about the big guy next to us who kept farting as we recalled a memorable performance
of a few summers ago, when moving in a very densely packed area together at our
summer Arts Fest, a big guy let some huge ones rip, sending the crowd scattering,
everyone looking vaguely horrified, aghast, staring accusingly at one another. We
giggled over this and decided we needed to talk about how we were raised around this
issue, out in the open so to speak. And yes, until I was shoved into a helicopter, strapped
into a gurney, and taken to Hopkins - an adventure into itself that afforded an
unparalleled aerial view of ‘Baltimore by Night’ -we laughed about my driving around for
several days recently with a big jar of pickles to locate someone to open- one of the few
foods I could stomach.
Then ex-hubby Michael and I made brain jokes until that got old. He’s definitely in my
support camp (and Ben’s) - we always did well with coparenting of our nifty left
brain/right brain young man, just back from vacay in Mexico w Sammi, gearing up for
last semester MS program in Data Science at NYU, and buying fish I’ve never heard of at
the Brooklyn Food Coop to cook into some yummy fish curry.
God, let me be allowed a little humor, and some potty-mouthed regression pre-brain
surgery as a coping mechanism. Laughter makes my soul feel better. Love to all.❤️
Medical update to follow.

January 20, 2022 - Willa medical update
  by Ethan Silverman, January 20, 2022  
Gas, is a hard act to follow, butt I will try. For those possibly needing some levity, I’ve
attached an amusing clip (imho) from Mel Brooks’ Blazing Saddles.
I just had a long call from Willa, who asked that I provide a medical update. She had a
sonogram today of her arms and legs to detect any clotting. Results are still pending.
In the meantime, she is taking the blood thinner Heparin, and a cocktail of other
medicines to alleviate head distress et al. Her head pain is much better, mostly
uncomfortable when she exerts or strains herself. 
While she was out for the sonogram, Justin, from Dr Beavis’ team, came by to see her.
Although she missed him (a note though was left), one of Willa’s favorite JH spiritual
advisors (chaplain), The Rev. Rhonda S. Cooper, came for a visit.
A Neurosurgeon/team has not stopped by at this point, but Willa was hopeful for this
afternoon. 
Hence, a date has still not been set for surgery. Unforeseen circumstances or a downturn
would be the only reason for it to occur before the weekend, which is unlikely.
Stay tuned!
Despite Covid, and a slightly reduced staff, she is still receiving superb care and
attention.
                       984 / 1.901

at the hospital, pre and post-op. Unfortunately, only I person is allowed.
Your dings are not going un-noticed. Willa is thrilled to have the support and will reach
out to you when she is able.
Stay well - Ethan

 January 22, 2022 - Brain waves/Updates
  by Willa Silverman, January 22, 2022  
I will try to provide an update. I feel gratified, humbled, flattered by the many texts and
emails I have received. My apologies for not being able to respond to each one
individually; I simply don't have the bandwidth. Know that your thoughts and caring and
concern and well wishes and acts of kindness and love mean the world to me. But I likely
can't respond for a while. I will be 'going away' for a while -- post-op, to where I'm not
sure but there will be some process of working on coordination and I don't know what I'll
be able to do, to take care of. In the meantime, please don't abandon or forget me! I'll be
back!
All opinions and wishes are converging on a surgical option for me, perhaps next
Wednesday. I have a largeish mass (5 cm?) in my cerebellum, at the base of my skull
and perhaps some other stray lesions that need to be dinged out with a gamma knife.
This will be followed by radiation (hopefully in State College). Going straight to radiation
is not an option for me: my tumor is too large. I wouldn't make it past a few months.
Surgery makes sense from all points of view: my overall life expectancy, overall good
health, wishes and desires, including strong desire to be here.  But of course it's risky
(my surgery day is described as 'the riskiest day of my life') because we are entering
ground zero for everything that controls my life, identity and actions. I could have a brain
bleed, and there are many other complications that can ensue. Fortunately, sonograms
reveal no blood clots (common in cancer) that could complicate blood flow, and I'm on an
anticoagulant (Heparin) to replace Eliquis and that will leave my body in a few days.
Dr. Beavis, who is coordinating things and who has been wonderful, counsels surgery. So
does the neuro team of course. From watching videos, it seems that neurosurgery was
pioneered here at Hopkins w/Harvey Cushing (early 20th c.). The brain surgeons are a
different breed -- and they're allowed to be -- all male, supremely confident, not warm
and fuzzy but fantastic doctors. The one I met and spoke with for about an hour, Dr.
                       987 / 1.901
Christopher Jackson, is of this breed - southern accent, young guy, tall and broad
shouldered, courteous, hair parted neatly to one side, deliberate in his delivery. He was
completely a straight shooter with me, which I appreciated, offering me his services next
W (I am on his schedule, as he had a cancellation), but also those of men "with more
grey hairs" should I want. So it is possible that one of the 'higher ups' with more
experience may do the job, if their schedules jive with my time slot for next W. If not, Dr.
Jackson will perform; I don't need to like him tons (as I do Dr. Beavis); he only has to do
good work. He was trained at Hopkins and has many awards and accolades to his name.
It seems that things were a bit touch and go as I was 'life flighted' down to Hopkins
Tuesday night. Pressure was building in my skull, which is why I was having searing
headaches every morning, throughout the day and on exertion, for several weeks. And
they were getting worse. The tumor may have been building for a while, but I've only
recently become symptomatic. The brain MRI at Geisinger in Lewistown on Tuesday
revealed the mets (their ER was great, by the way). My friend David Rothman has written
eloquently and much more technically about this elsewhere, as he's been down this road
before... and is a solace to me right now.
Until surgery, then, pressure in my skull is being relieved mainly by a steroid (Decadron)
and a 'cocktail' of Benadryl, Tylenol, and Raglan. I am stable and feel ok, except on any
type of exertion (like going to the bathroom), at which point I get a searing pain in my
head. Unless anything acute occurs, I should be ok for a few more days. 
For now, treatment of my OC remains off until the brain issue is attended to. And that's
ok as my last scan was stable. I don't know about the modalities of dealing with two
types of cancer. Tbd.
The staff here continues to be terrific, from doctors to sheet changers. They are all kind,
attentive, and skilled. I am being very well taken care of here and am grateful for it.
(Last Monday, Dr. Patel's PA was ineffectual; when I told her my headache pain was a 10,
her mouth formed into a little circle as she whispered "Oh." I thought she would send me
to have a brain MRI immediately, not wait another day. Otherwise, she prescribed a
broad spectrum antibiotic and some Tylenol w/Percocet. I had to come home and lie
down immediately. Lesson: be one's own  best advocate).
I have a few fairy godmothers from within the hospital to thank! Chaplain Cooper
(Rhonda, with whom I've developed a friendship and who always leaves me with a
blessing of invitation to the Spirit and/or of gratitude for the caregivers) brought me,
yesterday, per my cravings, a container of half-sour pickles and a box of cookies from
Vaccaro's -- all from wonderful Italian take out places in Canton. Then Gae, a palliative
care nurse with whom I've bonded around mindfulness, Kripalu, meditation and other
topics (including my work!), also brought me Tiramisu from an Italian restaurant so we
can do a Tiramisu taste test, and some rainbow cookies, which I love. How kind!
                       988 / 1.901
Another dear angel from State College, Helen, and her dear hubby, Greg, also drove
down from State College (3+ hours) to bring me clothes, makeup, my computer and iPad
and other items, plus French pastries.  It's indeed a nice (albeit very cold, apparently)
day to take the pretty drive from SC to Baltimore, while listening to podcasts;
nevertheless, Helen is preparing for a big work trip tomorrow and she and Greg definitely
went out of their way to help. So very thoughtful; Helen did not like thinking of me
without my stuff. So now I'm snug in a pink cotton shirt I like and yoga pants, Kiehl's
serums and avocado eye cream at the ready.
Thanks too to very dear ones Martina, Jackie, Janis, Michael and of course Ethan, Ben etc.
for keeping everything in order for me at home and elsewhere. We are still discussing
which person will be with me next week (>Covid rules: one person allowed in over seven
day period).
Mantras:
>Until I'm dead, I'm living and my life has value.
>Thank you, Josh, for your wisdom from your Kung Fu and karate practice. Always move
forward. The most dangerous position (to the other) by the warrior is when she has her
back against the wall. I'm in warrior goddess mode.
>"Just like moons and like suns,
With the certainty of tides,
Just like hopes springing high,
Still I'll rise."
—Maya Angelou
All spoken like a cancer patient I suppose.
Life is strange and wonderful and mysterious and awful, on occasion. This new 'through
the Looking Glass' phase is certainly odd, but after a little while it becomes normalized --
even with brain surgery involved. All because of some sneaky rogue cells...
I need to be around to continue to raise up the best possible young man, to be a good
                       989 / 1.901
daughter, sister, niece, cousin, aunt, inlaw, ex to an extended family etc. Much as I'd
prefer to be home today baking a flourless chocolate cake and simmering some soup -
minestrone w/pasta, and Parmesan on top - listening to music in my cozy home - here I
am. 
Please forgive any typos or omissions. I'm a bit groggy from the meds.
Be well. XO

January 27, 2022 - Willa’s progress
  by Ethan Silverman, January 27, 2022  
For some strange reason, I couldn’t get Michael Buble’s song Feeling Good (It’s a new
day, it’s a new dawn..) out of my head early this morning. 
But that’s sort of how you need to approach recovery, especially after such a traumatic
experience/surgery.
I was able to spend some time with Willa yesterday in the critical care unit, a mere few
hours removed from 5+ hours of surgery, and again this morning. I thought she was
doing remarkably well.
Needless to say, even her indomitable spirit is being challenged by the physical ordeal
she endured(s).
For now she is resting, spending time away from her electronic lifelines, and letting the
body heal. 
I, her brother, and on-the-ground, temporary caretaker, took some self-care time last
night and met my 2 college roommates/spouse for dinner @ Tavola’s in Baltimore’s Little
Italy (****+). I am rejuvenated now.
It’s a new day!
E

January 28, 2022 - Willa, Day 11 @ JH - Coming Along
  by Ethan Silverman, January 28, 2022  
Good Morning!
I can honestly say that many milestones were met yesterday, especially from the time I
saw her in the am until I left just past 6 pm.
In somewhat of a chronological order:
She began to have an appetite, eating cereal, greek yogurt, tuna salad sandwich
on stale bread and omelette w/potatoes.
She put her glasses on for the first time since just prior to surgery. Vital for
Willa’s existence.
She easily passed all of her neurological, bedside exams of reciting name, date,
bday, and location, as well as touching fingers to nose, etc.
She was moved off the NCCU to the top floor of Zayed (12E), a step down room,
and launching pad towards recovery.
She was able to get off the bed and make it to the bathroom, as her digestive
system was beginning to wake up after lengthy periods of anesthesia and
sedation. 
She received encouraging reports and visits from Dr Bettegowda (who called me
as well) and Dr Beavis, assuring her that everything was “par for the course”and
take it “slow and steady”.
                    1.004 / 1.901
The transfer from nccu (3rd floor zayed) to 12E was uncomfortable, and a bit noisy, as
one would potentially expect. We all tried to minimize the disruption though and it
transpired fairly quickly. I successfully wheeled and moved her luggage, with phone,
laptop, keepsakes in it, that she has yet to use.
She did get taken for an mri (protocol/don’t know results yet), soon after arrival on 12,
which really jostled her and upset her. Fortunately her new nurses and technicians,
eased her back to a comfortable state quickly.
Right before I left, Ben (my nephew!) called and I was able to put him on speaker so that
he and Willa could talk. This was the first time they spoke since Tuesday evening.
Needless to say - highlight of the day hearing them converse.
I’m grateful that I brought a lb. of my Zabar’s coffee, cone, and filter from NYC, for

January 29, 2022 - Whirlwind, Weather, Willa & Walking - Ben’s Arrival
Too
  by Ethan Silverman, January 29, 2022  
Willa is currently in the hall with the physical therapist taking her second walk in two
days. I believe they are practicing stairs, as Willa has a few to negotiate getting into her
house in SC. Her walking with a walker is quite good btw.
As Willa said to me when I arrived this morning, she’s been getting “micro-sleeps”. She
will need much needed rest in the coming days and weeks.
Yesterday was a total blur for me as almost too many moving parts were happening
simultaneously. I called in my resources, and Ben arrived by Amtrak around 11 pm last
evening. Good thing, as he texted me moments ago that the Northeast Regional and
Acela trains were all suspended.
The neurosurgeons have reassured me that they have “addressed the problem”, she is
“in control”, and that there isn’t anything they can do for her at the hospital, that she
can’t do for herself at home. Hopefully the latter will come with much assistance from
qualified professionals and a host of family/friends.
It appears that Willa will be discharged today!
For me this is both an exciting and frightening prospect.
Depending on the hour, we will most likely stay overnight in Baltimore and venture back
to SC on Sunday morning.
Stay tuned/Much love - Ethan
                    1.008 / 1.901

whom she conversed with in French.
