November 4, 2022 - Update II
  by Willa Silverman, November 4, 2022  
Just another quick update: I am sorry if I worried anyone yesterday with my news. Yes, it
is unwelcome, but I also tend to become very anxious when I receive such news of
developments in my condition (although not unexpected), and I imagine I was projecting
                    1.459 / 1.901
some of that -- or perhaps the news itself was simply scary. But it's not dire. My MRI
yesterday went smoothly. Dr. Patel called me this morning to discuss that scan and
confirmed that there are two tiny (mm) spots on my left and right frontal lobes and a few
other spots here and there. He wasn't seeing much bleeding to speak of but he took me
off my blood thinner. I also now have an appointment with my radiologist next week,
most likely to discuss radiating the spots (no surgery will happen). Dr. Patel confirmed
that the spots can return (also not unexpected); that sneaky, dastardly cancer found
some new pathways into my brain. Cancer has also made inroads into my upper
abdominal area (where I was having acute discomfort, sending me to the emergency
room). Armed with Tylenol (every four hours) and Oxycodone (as needed; I don't take it
much), I'm succeeding in getting my symptoms under control. No more splitting
headaches, but I can actually feel the cancerous spots causing me some discomfort at
the front of my head. But I am not at death's door. I am not The Dying Girl and don't
want to  be cast (or cast myself) in that role (is it obvious to restate that finitude is a
reality for all of us?).
I am feeling more emotionally even keel today. I took care of a whole bunch of emails
and texts, esp. with my doctors, then took a nice long drive, which is what I do to clear
my head. Stopped by the antique store and bought an Art Deco-looking vase for.... 84
cents! The fall colors have peaked but they are not completely gone. I'm extremely sorry
not to be in NY this weekend, but feel I made the right decision to stay put. This means I
can see a few friends here, within close range.
I look forward to a good chat with Rabbi Ostrich on Sunday.
No pity party (as my cousin and I always tell each other). I am glad to be alive and
abundantly blessed!
Good shabbos.

November 11, 2022 - "Reports of my death have been greatly
exaggerated" - Part III (?)
  by Willa Silverman, November 11, 2022  
                    1.462 / 1.901
                    1.463 / 1.901
After the hell of last week -- splitting headaches, nausea, vomiting bile, loss of appetite,
acute abdominal discomfort, day in the ER, discovery of new brain mets and of slight
progression of cancer in abdomen, multiple scans and MRI (over the hills Greg Fox and I
went to a rather forlorn Geisinger outpost in Mifflintown, 30 miles from State College),
anxiety-fueled certainty that my death was imminent, lots of unpleasant 'déjà vu all over
again' moments -- on the heels of the hell of the previous weeks (Covid!) -- I am back on
my horse, feeling a good bit better (yet far from perfect) now that I have gotten
symptoms under control with Tylenol every four hours, smaller meal portions, and a
blander diet than normal. Emotionally, I'm on a much more even keel this week.
To recap 'this week in cancer:' Monday: labs (counts a bit out of whack because of what
my body had endured the week before; magnesium count very low); Tuesday: chemo
(Avastin) + magnesium drip. Dr. Patel advises I maintain my current chemo regimen
unless my team decides otherwise. No major side effects from the chemo, just some
fatigue that didn't preclude my running errands, taking drives etc.; Wednesday: early
dentist appointment to repair a chipped front tooth (I was tired from having stayed up
late the night before watching the election returns, yet elated as I had glanced at my
phone at 4 a.m. and had seen that John Fetterman had won the Senate election! and
that our state house had gone blue for the first time in eleven years, which is huge).
On Thursday I met with Dr. Patel (jeune), the radiologist I had worked with after my brain
surgery in January. We 'vibed' better this time; on our first go-around I had found him
somewhat defensive and edgy. He seemed kinder on Thursday, and empathic, and
unrushed. I will receive three fairly high-dose stereotactic radiation treatments,
pinpointing the two cancerous spots that he clearly detects in my brain. There may be
other small cancerous areas but as they are too small (I presume) to be clearly identified
as such, he will hold off on radiating them until next time. Now that those dastardly
cancer cells have found a way into my brain, I presume (and he implied) that they may
return (when? how many? how often? a sobering prospect). The goal, he said, will be to
avoid whole brain radiation, with its attendant risks of Scary Things happening to the
brain (e.g. memory and cognitive impairment). So some decisions will need to be made
at that point. Personally, these may simply not be acceptable risks for me. My brain's my
thing and thankfully for the moment it's still pretty darn sharp. I'll start the treatments
after Thanksgiving. But this coming Monday I'll undergo yet another CT-scan of my brain
and get fitted for my mask (that gruesome Life of Brian meets Silence of the Lambs
contraption that I was buckled into and then buckled onto the radiation table with in
February). Three months later, barring any untoward developments, I'll have a scan to
see whether we've held the cancer at bay. So, again a bit of a reprieve for now.
The 'bleeding in my brain' refers simply to some tiny amounts of blood pooling inside the
new lesions. I do not have a brain bleed. No surgical intervention is necessary.
                    1.464 / 1.901
A pleasant antidote to thinking about all the medical stuff was dinner last night with my
friend Deb at Creekside at the Gamble Mill, a newly-renovated restaurant in what once
was an 1894 mill. It was lots of fun to catch up and check out a new restaurant. So many
people kindly tell me I look wonderful -- a point I do concede for the most part (does that
sound arrogant?). I do not at present look like scary Cancer Girl. I just wish I felt as good
as I look.
Now that all the pieces have fallen into place -- I'm cleared for travel, know that a
consultation is still a possibility etc. - I am headed to TX next week! Unfortunately,
because of the new brain lesions, clinical trials are currently off the table for me. This
took quite a bit of wind out of my sails. Was it going to be worthwhile even to make the
trip, given the fact that M.D. Anderson currently has nothing to offer me (as far as I can
tell)? Nevertheless, I decided that it would be worth it to speak with Dr. Shannon Westin,
a gyn-onc with an excellent reputation, see what might be available *down the line* if I
can ward off a recurrence of new brain mets for at least 6 months-1 year, get on the gyn-
onc team's radar screen, glean information about promising new treatments, have any
preliminary tests needed (e.g. blood work) etc. My college classmate/oncologist at M.D.
Anderson/guardian angel Steve Sherman has also smoothed my path at MDA and I hope
to have dinner with him and his wife there. The trip will also offer an opportunity for Ben
and me to have an adventure as we like'em: he'll meet me Wednesday night in Houston,
having flown from NY (I reserved rooms in a swanky looking new Intercontinental near
MDA because "Why not?"). He'll work remotely on Thursday, following which we'll drive
to Austin for the weekend; I've visited this capital city twice but not for a long time. My
former colleague and friend Jim is nicely lending us his condo and I look forward to
seeing him and meeting his husband, Danny. I have a few items on my Austin wish list --
I'd love to check out a great Western wear shop and a two-step dancing hall and some of
the 'weird' that 'keeps Austin weird' - but I'm flexible and await suggestions. If any of
*you* have Austin favorites - best taqueria? Tex-Mex joint? Q? Shop? Bar?
Neighborhoods? Other hot takes? - please let me know!
And then it will be back here for two days before heading to NY for the holiday -- barring
any unforeseen health hiccups, which I can never predict of course.
I also have made an appointment to meet with Dr. Beavis at Hopkins on Dec. 8th. It's
been a long time since I've seen her in person, and I want to make extra sure our close
connection doesn't dissipate. It's so hard to juggle this many doctors and make so many
important decisions.

song for the rest of his life it would be the Bee Gees' "Immortality" -- I am unabashedly a
Bee Gees fan and have always found them immensely talented -- I have been very taken
with it. Have a listen to this version, a type of prayer by Barry Gibb for his three
                    1.465 / 1.901
deceased brothers and bandmates (and read the lyrics elsewhere if you wish):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Al8acNZzmxI

November 21, 2022 - Don't Mess with Texas - Part I - Houston
  by Willa Silverman, November 21, 2022  
                    1.467 / 1.901
                    1.468 / 1.901
Back c. 10:30 p.m. last night from my Texas adventure. Exhausted on my return after
awaking early yesterday; driving three hours from Austin to Houston's IAH airport; flying
from Houston to Philly; laying over several hours in Philly; flying from Philly to State
College; and finally, driving home. Somehow, though, I managed to power through
(willapower?). Air-travel induced headaches/head pressure caused by the new cancer did
not materialize, thankfully, and I tried to move my legs as frequently as possible to avoid
clots (I think I'm ok on that front too). In short, I squeaked through although the travel
proved somewhat stress-inducing.
Enjoyed a delicious burger topped w/fried poblano pepper, cheese, bacon and
caramelized onions *plus* a margarita in the hotel lobby and chilled out from the trip.
Noted a visible police and security presence milling about the lobby. Turns out the
President of Panama was in residence.
Health update: On the whole, I felt pretty well during the entire trip, but was definitely
making an effort to 'rise to the occasion' for the reunions with friends and adventure with
Ben. My stomach did not always take well to some of the delicious (yet sometimes spicy,
sometimes heavy) tacos, Tex-Mex, and barbecue I was intent on sampling (Ben too!), but
find that reducing my portion size by about half usually helps me avoid an achy stomach
and nausea.
Somehow on the trip down to Houston a brewing UTI hit me full-force. Most thankfully,
the gyn-onc staff at MDA took a urine sample and then prescribed an antibiotic, without
which it would have been a painful and worrisome trip. Whew. In fact, there were a few
initial hiccups that made me hope they weren't omens for the remainder of the trip: Avis
had rented all its sedans, so Ben wound up with a ....pick-up truck. Very Texas, to be
sure, but the thing was really unwieldy to drive, not to mention park. My (cowboy) hat is
tipped to Ben, though, for keeping his cool as he always does. By the end of the week,
he was driving that behemoth like a champ. Understandably, Ben was not in a great
mood on his arrival -- flight delayed, a mountain of work to confront, a full work day
behind him, the car rental snafu -- but there too, the week only improved.
My consultation at MDA went as I had hoped and expected. Dr. Shannon Westin, a highly
knowledgeable, skilled, compassionate gyn-onc about Dr.  Beavis' age -- filled me in on
some of the clinical trials involving targeted therapies currently being conducted at MDA.
She scooted her chair very close to mine as she explained things to me. One trial
involves removing immune cells from the patient, 'ramping them up' so as to better fight
the ovarian cancer, then reintroducing them into the patient's body. Another involves
removing, then reinserting, a small piece of the patient's tumor, again doing something
to it [didn't quite grasp what] to enable the body to fight the o.c. more effectively. She
described how some treatments involve 'putting on the brakes' and others involve
                    1.469 / 1.901
'taking the brakes off' (the immune system, for example). MDA  definitely sets the gold
standard for many of the most innovative clinical trials and treatments these days.
But of course - as I knew - I am not eligible now for a clinical trial as my brain cancer has
recurred. Why is this? The clearest answer I've been able to get is that the medical
facility conducting the trial (or perhaps the drug company sponsoring it, or both) wants
to compare 'apples to apples,' ie select for the trial patients with ovarian cancer *only*
(and sometimes with a particular tumor type or genetic marker). There are often other
restrictions, too, as I experienced at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Otherwise, I presume, the
secondary cancer might interfere with, cause delays in, or react adversely to the
experimental treatment. *However,* Dr. Westin said there is pushback (from the FDA,
physicians and others) against the stipulation that brain mets preclude participation in a
clinical trial. When might this policy be changed? Likely not in my lifetime. Grrr.
Dr. Westin did allude to the fact, though, that there *are* a few trials allowing patients
with brain mets to participate in them. Must follow up on that tantalizing piece of info
with Dr. Beavis.
Echoing what I've heard from other sources, Dr. Westin confirmed that the jury is still out
on whether immunotherapy is an effective treatment for o.c. She did mention two chemo
drugs, however, that I had not heard of and with which I have not yet been treated. I will
also discuss this with Dr. Beavis when I head to Baltimore in early December for an
appointment. Dr. Beavis also mentioned seeing whether Hopkins might have something
to offer me right now. The problem is that I've had an awful lot of chemo, and still my
disease progresses. I was really hoping for a clinical trial but bad timing with the brain
mets; I'll receive three high-dose treatments of radiation after Thanksgiving.
I am grateful to Dr. Westin and her team, though, for conveying a hopeful message:
"There are options." And regret neither this "information gathering mission" nor the
opportunity to get on MDA's radar screen as a potential patient (ie I'm 'in their system'
now). If the planets aligned for me to receive treatment there (I'd need to be free of
brain mets for six months [or was it a year?], and I just don't think that's going to
happen), I'd have to think hard about the feasibility of this prospect, logistically. It's a
total schlep (more like an odyssey) to get there and back, and that fact alone (aside from
expense etc.) gives me pause. But I'm far from needing to make decisions about that;
when and if the time comes...
I shared some of the day's developments with my dinner companions: my college
classmate Steve Sherman, an endocrinologist at MDA who has been so helpful and kind
towards me since I learned of my diagnosis and contacted him in a panic, and his wife
Janine, a registered nurse working in women's health (a lovely person with whom I very
much enjoyed speaking). Despite the relative brevity of our meeting, Steve struck me
much as he did in college: a thoughtful, intellectually sharp guy with a good sense of
                    1.470 / 1.901
humor. I believe he is my only college classmate who was also a dormmate for four
years, first in Stoughton Hall (we reminisced!), then in Currier House. Steve and Janine
seem to be enjoying a wonderful life of travel (often to Italy), time with their three grown
children (one of whom will soon marry), and successful careers. Happy for them! Dinner
at Café Rabelais in Rice Village, finished off with a profiterole for each of us and
accompanied by a tasty Sancerre, was excellent (respecting my 'small portion = no
stomach distress' rule, I brought a good part of my dinner back to the hotel for Ben).
Both Dr. Westin and Steve and Janine thought I looked 'great.' This has now become
something of a tea-leaf reading exercise for me. On the one hand, Dr. Beavis has
maintained that one can 'look great' yet still be quite ill (I remember meeting a
physically beautiful friend of Michael's a long time ago; she had melanoma and died
several months after we stayed with her and her husband in their apartment in
Bloomington, IN). On the other, Steve and Janine suggested that 'looking great' might
manifest a strong, life-affirming spirit, which in turn *might* affect prospects for survival.
Hard to know, yet I try to decode whatever signs present themselves to me, likely with a
good dose of projection involved.  And I am appreciative of the compliments!
Will write about our fun weekend in Austin in my next entry (I hope). Tired now -- and
need to turn around and start packing for New York, as tomorrow is a chemo day and I'm
likely to be worn out when I get home.
Photos
                    1.471 / 1.901
                    1.472 / 1.901

November 24, 2022 - Bounteous gratitude
  by Willa Silverman, November 24, 2022  
                    1.475 / 1.901
                    1.476 / 1.901
Some of what I'm grateful for today:
**Fourth* Thanksgiving since my diagnosis;
*I've been given this day, and am feeling, on the whole, alright;
*A dear friend recuperating well from an operation that should eliminate a host of
troublesome, worrisome symptoms;
*Two of my chemo nurses, Brianne and Tracey. After not having seen me at chemo for a
few weeks,  Tracey, this past Tuesday, planted a big, friendly, affectionate kiss on my
cheek. She had been working the polls during my last chemo session; she, Brianne and I
are on the same page politically and socially, although we've needed to keep those
conversations hushed, because you never know what the reaction might be around here.
Both Tracey and Brianne help keep me grounded in the present -- in the day, the
moment -- even as I experience setbacks. They keep me buoyant with their expert care,
concern, and friendship.
*A wonderful reunion in Austin after about thirty years with my former colleague, my
friend Jim Davis. Jim thoughtfully set Ben and me up in his comfy Austin condo, and
arranged an insider's tour of the city with his friend (of a friend), Craig. Grateful for Jim's
kindness, loyalty, interesting life, and sense of humor that keeps me laughing when I'm
with him!
*My ability to make the trip to Houston and Austin last week, even as travel becomes a
bit harder for me;
*A red tsunami averted by the efforts of the millions of patriots who realized that our
democracy was imperiled. A democratic governor, senator and state house in our
Commonwealth!
*My wondrously compassionate and loving son, Ben;
*My family: Ben & Sammi, mom & Arnold, Ethan & Ronit (and her family), Eve, Isaac,
Julie, Aunt Marlene, Michael (and his family), Ruth, Claudia and my many other cousins in
the U.S. and Canada.
*My beloved friends, some of multiple decades, others of more recent date.
If all this gratitude stuff is too much for you, try to catch Amy Schumer's funny parody of
the notion (and practice). Can't find the link, but saw it on Facebook.
My prayers going out today to the friend mentioned above, recovering from surgery;
another friend recovering from surgery; and a dear friend of many decades, currently
undergoing chemotherapy. Who knew, when we were teenagers shopping for clothes at
Bloomingdale's, lunching on burgers after school ended on Fridays, and having
sleepovers, that this would be part of our shared life journey?
So my Thanksgiving  plans imploded this year. About half an hour before I was to leave
to drive to the Lewistown Junction train station yesterday, my brother -- our host and
                    1.477 / 1.901
chef this year - texted me from New York to say he had tested positive, twice, for Covid
and that he was fully symptomatic (awful cough, chills etc.). That meant, of course, that
Thanksgiving as planned was off, and my main concern remains that my brother feel
better and that his family stay healthy. I then called my mother, who had also received
the news, and learned that she too was feeling under the weather (Covid-negative yet
red, scratchy throat) and was discouraging me from staying with her in the city, as
planned. I next called Ben, asking if I could stay in his apartment while he was in
Amherst, MA, with his dad, aunt and uncle, and Berkman cousins. That way, I thought I
could still have lunch with a bunch of my college friends on Friday, as also planned,
spend Sunday with Ben (ditto), and help out my brother or mother if needed. Ben said
he'd leave his keys with the neighbors, so I threw my bags in my car, and headed to
Lewistown without a minute to spare.
En route to Lewistown (about 25 miles from my house), I began to have a change of
heart as I thought about navigating the city on a holiday weekend, taking the subway
into Manhattan from Brooklyn for my appointments, hauling my heavy bags up the steep
staircases of Ben's walkup, buying groceries, perhaps trying to get myself 'adopted' by
one of my friends for Thanksgiving etc. Cause or consequence, a nasty headache started
to come on, compounded by the fatigue from both chemo the previous day and the
recent trip to Texas, from which I had just returned. I pulled off the road an exit or two
before Lewistown, made my final resolution, called Ben, then turned around and headed
back to State College. I was so mentally and physically exhausted that I slept for several
hours.
So it's an odd, somewhat isolating day, but it's ok. I miss not being with my family, just
as I miss our holiday traditions (chocolate turkeys at each table setting) and special
foods (both cooking and eating them). We all texted one another this morning with
holiday greetings. But no pity party. My brother's health is the priority. And I've enjoyed
many memorable Thanksgivings in the past. Cancer has granted me the serenity to
"accept the things I cannot change" in many different situations. State College friends, I
gave serious thought to contacting some of you who I know are in town to see if you
might set another place at your table for me; I feel confident you would have graciously
said yes. But in the end, I'm opting for a contemplative day, with my Wegman's turkey
dinner and a slice of pumpkin cheesecake to enjoy -- for which I am sincerely grateful! I
am around this weekend, though. :)
Here are excerpts from two poems that have resonated with me recently, and especially
on this day, and at this time in my life:
From Ross Gay, "Catalog of Unabashed Gratitude"
Soon it will be over,
                    1.478 / 1.901
which is precisely what the child in my dream said,
holding my hand, pointing at the roiling sea and the sky
hurtling our way like so many buffalo,
who said it’s much worse than we think,
and sooner; to whom I said
no duh child in my dreams, what do you think
this singing and shuddering is,
what this screaming and reaching and dancing
and crying is, other than loving
what every second goes away? [my emphasis]
Goodbye, I mean to say.
And thank you. Every day.
                    1.479 / 1.901
From Joy Harjo, "Praise the Rain" (w/thanks to my friend Sally):
Praise crazy. Praise sad.
Praise the path on which we're led.
Praise the roads on earth and water.
Praise the eater and the eaten.
Praise beginnings; praise the end.
Praise the song and praise the singer.
Happy Thanksgiving, everyone.

November 26, 2022 - Don't Mess with Texas II - Austin
  by Willa Silverman, November 27, 2022  
                    1.482 / 1.901
                    1.483 / 1.901
In the end, I'm glad I turned around en route to the Lewistown train station, as I've been
enjoying a restful, restorative weekend. I was overwhelmed by the generosity and
thoughtfulness of those who reached out to me immediately on reading about my
derailed plans: Maria called me as soon as she read my post on Thursday to invite me to
join her family for the pies they were about to tuck into; Ben's darling bff from grade
school, Nikhil, dropped by Thursday evening with his mother to hand deliver leftovers
from their Indian-American feast (the best Indian food I've had in a long while!) - let's
hear it for the little boys who used to play basketball together in the Pioneer League
growing into such thoughtful, caring young men!; Sandy delivered to my doorstep an
entire almond-pear tart from The Hummingbird Room (very yummy); Deb and Tony had
me to dinner Friday for delicious Thanksgiving leftovers and interesting conversation;
Monique invited me for dinner last night. I am so humbled. Best.friends.ever. I love the
networks of care that somehow seem to develop easily in smaller communities.
I know many friends were out of town this weekend and never expected such a wave of
kindness.
Meanwhile, my brother, thankfully, is on the mend from Covid, but my sister-in-law just
tested positive...
Health update: I am feeling decent, status quo. I took a long drive in the glorious
sunshine and saw a team of five horses plowing a field; bought some carrots and kale at
a local farm. Tylenol staves off headaches. Keeping my portions small; I have a feeling
that a cancerous lymph node sitting atop my stomach that has increased slightly in size
is also pressing on my stomach. Hoping that Dr. Patel (the younger) will finish up my
treatment plan early next week so I can be scheduled for three radiation treatments next
week and/or the following one, when I will also go to Baltimore for an appointment with
Dr. Beavis. No chemo until next Tuesday. Will meet with my palliative care doc via
videoconference this week; she'll help me fill out my DNR card to affix to my fridge and
discuss other items on my agenda.
A brief report on our weekend in Austin:
Things are *big* in Texas: big hair (did not see any but am assured it's a thing); big belt
buckles and cowboy hats; the biggest plastic travel mugs I've ever seen; big people.
Everyone has guns. Signs at the entrance to many establishments state "no concealed
weapons."
"Keep Austin weird," I am told, has now yielded, by all evidence, to "Keep Austin
gentrifying," with the old mom and pop shops, music joints, and grunge neighboring
                    1.484 / 1.901
Hermès boutiques and Warby Parker outlets. The one taste I got of Austin's weirdness
during a two-day visit was our stop for lunch at Wright Brothers Brew & Brew, which
offers brews (on tap) and brews (coffee). Young crowd. Baristas with tats, long hair, flesh
tunnels and piercings. Is that really all that weird? It seemed like any number of coffee
shops one might find in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, or Boulder.
Music everywhere, every brewery, street corner, two-step dance hall etc. Ditto taco
stands -- in gas stations, food truck courts etc.
Thursday: we arrived from Houston in our pick up truck around 7:30 p.m., stopping on
the way at Buc-ee's, a southern version of Sheetz but with an astounding array of beef
and turkey jerky (which we sampled) and reputedly immaculate bathrooms (an urban
legend?). Headed to a taco truck behind Celis Brewery, Con Todo, that Ben had read
about and brought our food back to Jim's condo: I sampled the spiciest taco I had ever
tasted, full of charred cauliflower, and a tostada with guacamole. Incredibly tasty spices,
yet hard on my stomach. Everywhere we went, the tortillas were handmade, and fresh
and delicious. Love the food truck culture in Austin.
Friday: It was wonderful to see my former colleague Jim and give him a big hug after
about thirty years. I introduced him to Ben, whom he had never met, and he regaled us
with funny stories about how he and his husband, Danny, had come together as a
couple. Jim seems happy in his life in Austin, punctuated by frequent travels, and I'm so
glad for him. He had engaged a friend of a friend of his, Craig, to be our driver and tour
guide for the day. Craig is an actor and acting teacher - and native Texan - who took us
on an 'insider's tour' of the city while Jim and I caught up a bit in between stretches of
sightseeing. It was such a sweet day. We first headed to SoCo (South Congress Ave.), a
popular area w/interesting shops, mid-century modern hotels, bars etc. I loved Allen's, an
iconic Western wear shop, with its dizzying selection of ornate cowboy boots, Stetsons,
and shirts with pearl snaps. The boots looked uncomfortable, but I'm assured that the
leather becomes supple with wear. We stopped for coffee (Joe's), then headed to a food
truck park for yet more tacos (fish, this time), homemade salsas/hot sauces and guac at
Veracruz All Natural Taco, a local chain. After lunch we hit the Texas history museum (on
the UT campus) and saw a fascinating exhibit about _La Belle,_ a French ship
commandeered by Sieur de la Salle on the orders of Louis XIV that hit a sandbar and
sank, but was later excavated along with about 1.8 million objects the French had
brought with them for both trade and settlement. The French incursion into Texas was a
disaster (de la Salle was intent of finding the Mississippi River but was way off in his
calculations), enabling the Spanish to establish a stronghold there. Serves those darn
French imperialists right! Craig also drove us through many attractive neighborhoods
(Arts and Crafts bungalows, mid-century modern houses), past the Texas capitol building
(the Texas flag is the only state flag allowed to fly at the same height as the U.S. flag, a
deal worked out when Texas ceased to be a republic and joined the U.S. in the mid-19th
c.). Around 4 p.m. I started to flag; I had really surprised myself with my stamina and
                    1.485 / 1.901
was relieved to know that I'm able to 'rise to the occasion' when having a great time.
Ben had to work on Friday but we reunited for dinner at Matt's El Rancho, a popular Tex-
Mex place. 'Popular,' in fact, does not convey the pandemonium generated by the
throngs pouring into the restaurant, waiting four deep at the bar, or lining up to add their
names to the lengthy list of those waiting to be seated. We waited about 45 minutes for
a table and were ushered in to one of two gigantic dining rooms. Given the size and the
slightly 'industrial' nature of the place, the food wasn't bad at all. I had a stuffed poblano
with rice, refried beans, and a gravy. Copious portions. I also had a margarita, which
knocked me out; I fell asleep as soon as I returned to Jim's condo!
Saturday was my day to spend with Ben, a fab, laid back travel companion always game
for adventure and good eats. Unfortunately, we awoke to pouring rain and cold temps,
which did not abate all day! We valiantly set out, once again to a Veracruz taco truck, to
get Ben a breakfast taco, and me a fresh drink with fruit and spinach from their juice bar.
Our outdoor plans having been foiled, we headed to the LBJ Presidential Library/Museum
on the UT campus. I had never been to a presidential library, and while its tone was
clearly hagiographic, I came away wondering whether any president today could bring to
fruition a vision of equality and justice like that of the Great Society. As Johnson had
been president when I was roughly 4-8 or nine, ie during my childhood, I appreciated
having that historical context filled in for me, as my memories are hazy (I do remember
RFK's and MLK's assassinations, my parents' opposition to the Vietnam War, and space
exploration, as well as some of the pop culture'realia' on display [troll dolls! 'flower
power' stickers], but sadly the civil rights movement didn't register with me as a young
child). Fascinating. Ben enjoyed it too, especially the hundreds of hours of LBJ phone
calls (w/MLK, for example) available for listening. Our last stop was again Allen's, the
western wear shop, where I bought a cute bandana. We then headed home to rest up
before dinner.
As we were intent on barbecue, we went to a place Craig had recommended, Lamberts.
This place, located in the downtown business district, was slightly upscale, not your
typical Texas bbq smokehouse (which I would have enjoyed too). My baby back ribs -- I
could only eat two or three -- were just slightly overcooked but their sauce was delicious,
sweet and smoky. Excellent crispy coleslaw with cashews, tangy with lime. Biscuits.
House made pickles. Ben had some other form of barbecue (brisket, I believe) and a
tasty local beer on tap.
We left early Sunday morning for the three hour drive to Houston
******'
I've decided to devote December to the pursuit of hygge: homemade soups, comfy
socks, curling up on the sofa in my sunroom with a good book and a cup of tea, hot
                    1.486 / 1.901
chocolate, or mulled cider, old movies, projects around the house, aromatherapy, hot
showers infused with eucalyptus, candles. Come over for some hot chocolate!
But then I start to get the travel bug... New York? Barbados? Turks and Caicos?....

December 3, 2022 - Where to?
  by Willa Silverman, December 3, 2022  
                    1.492 / 1.901
                    1.493 / 1.901
Health update: I started my second course of radiation this week, with two treatments
down, three to go. Exactly like last time (February, I believe), I am bolted down to a table
wearing a very tight-fitting mask that has been molded to my face, while I clamp down
with my teeth on a kind of 'bit.' The area around my nose is clear so I can breathe (!).
Definitely seems like some medieval form of torture, but rather it's analogous in its
curative powers, I suppose, to the 'poison cure' of chemotherapy. Then the neuro-
oncologist and 'The Physicist,' from an adjacent room, beam radiation very precisely
towards the two (I believe) brain spots that they are radiating on this round. Their
precision is based on several sets of imaging that they've gathered both before and
during my session. The treatment takes about 20 minutes. Because it is so
uncomfortable, I just try to relax my body under the warm blanket enveloping me, close
my eyes, and listen to the playlist (they seem to have correctly pegged me for a
1970s/80s gal, hence Stevie Wonder, CCR, and, poignantly this week, Fleetwood Mac.
The technicians are all very kind and reassuring; yesterday they were excited about how
cool my glittery blue eyeshadow looked under the purple light illuminating my head.
No noticeable side effects from the radiation. Some fatigue (I rested afterwards) and low-
grade headaches that cleared up with Tylenol.
I've begun to explore another procedure -- gamma knife treatment -- for my eventual
recurrence. 'Eventual' because Dr. Patel has told me that a recurrence is probable;
currently, he is only zapping two spots (in my right and left front lobe), because he is not
able to visualize the other areas clearly and does not want to radiate anything he's not
convinced is cancer. But there do appear to be other areas that "may or may not be" and
if they turn out to "be," they will need to be radiated too. As Dr. Patel remarked: "We are
trying to save your brain." I still don't know too much about gamma knife treatment
(David R., I may need to check in w/you on this) but it seems to me that it might be a
more 'advanced' technology, capable of zapping many cancerous brain areas; with
stereotactic radiation, there seems a limit to the number of areas that can be radiated.
Our hospital does not offer gamma ray treatment, but many other (major?) hospitals,
such as Hopkins, UPMC in Pittsburgh, and even our larger Geisinger facility in Danville,
PA, do. So I contacted Christie, the nurse working with Dr. Bettegowda, the fabulous
neurosurgeon who removed my brain tumor in January, to see if she could help. To my
great relief, she expressed eagerness to help, suggesting that I might need to have a
consult with a radiation oncologist at Hopkins but indicating that Dr. Bettegowda would
also look at my most recent MRI results and provide feedback. I'm waiting to hear back
from her.
I'm  now feeling that my brain, in the end, might become the real problem area,
overshadowing even my o.c. And if/when it comes to full brain radiation, with a much
higher risk of side effects, there will be choices to make.
                    1.494 / 1.901
Throughout all of this, though, I don't feel too bad - at least not this week. I was able to
get out and about, take care of things, attend a play on campus, work on a project
(assembling my Caring Bridge site into 'book' form -- now close to 700 pages!). Not
sleeping great, but am told it may because of the steroid I'm taking before my radiation
treatments.
Will have radiation next Monday, Tuesday, Friday. Tuesday will bring a 'triple whammy'
with radiation early, then an appointment with Dr. Patel (the elder), then chemo (the
'double whammy' with infusions of both drugs, Avastin and Doxil). I'm sure I'll be wiped
by the end of the day, or maybe I'll just snooze during chemo.
Next week I'll also travel to Hopkins for an appointment I made with Dr. Beavis. I haven't
seen her except on a computer screen in a very long time. I want to have a frank
discussion with her about where things stand and gather her thoughts on the best
treatment plan for me going forward, given the many moving parts involved: recurrence
of brain mets, trip to MDA and input from Dr. Westin, availability of treatments at
Hopkins (???) taking into account that my brain mets now appear to preclude
participation in a clinical trial, progression of disease. I am sure that she'll want to
examine me and feel confident that she will suggest the very best plan possible at this
stage. I look forward to seeing her.
I was so touched that David M., my dear college friend who lives in Baltimore and who
has often been one of my 'carers' at Hopkins (sitting with me during infusions, visiting
me after a surgery, driving me to appointments), offered, this time, to drive me at least
one way between Baltimore and State College, about a 3.5 hour trip! So kind of him; I
had planned to drive myself, but then thought twice on realizing that the day before my
drive would be rough for me (chemo *and* radiation). So David will drive me home from
Baltimore to State College, then likely stay over here Thursday night and depart Friday,
refreshed. His husband, Peter, who runs a successful catering business, is in overdrive
for the holiday season and likely won't be able to join us. My equally dear friend Sandy
took me up on my request to drive me to Baltimore on Wednesday, as she has before
(Sandy also drove me to Newark when I went to Paris in May). What a friend! I selfishly
look forward to some 'alone time' with Sandy and David so I can catch up with them in
the car. The rides certainly make my life much easier. I could have driven myself, but it
really tires me out.
This week I found myself veering from my usual stance of gratitude to
discouragement/depression, and back. I'm particularly discouraged about the recurrence
of my brain mets an the prospect of another recurrence, necessitating further treatment.
I need further clarity about my situation -- options, prospects. I find myself hoping to
make it until my birthday, Ben's birthday, Passover, spring... Perhaps what I can best
muster this week is the muted praise Leonard Cohen deems the "broken hallelujah."
                    1.495 / 1.901
I wonder whether my friends/readers realized what a marathon my cancer journey would
be. Even to me, it seems a bit old. Whereas the first few years, admittedly, brought some
notes of 'adventure' -- every procedure, every chemo session, every surgery was new
and needed to be analyzed in detail -- now my chemo and radiation sessions, bloodwork,
doctors' visits etc., seem routine, simply woven into the fabric of my life. I am not
complaining about this! It's simply a shift in perspective, a view from the long haul.
I teleconferenced with my palliative care doctor, Dr. Vithalani, this week. She helped me
fill out a DNR order to post on my fridge. She reminded me how important it is for me to
take good care of myself these days, and to not pressure myself -- good advice. Also felt
well cared for by my therapist, another important member of my support team.
I hope I won't be abandoned.
I am grateful this week for coffee this morning with a former student I hadn't seen in
twenty years and who is now a professor (of photojournalism) herself. Was gratified that
a course she took with me on human rights has stayed with her. Although the production
of _Rent_ that I saw on campus on Wednesday with my friend Maria had some flaws, I
very much enjoyed it for both its 'message' ("No day but today") and the strong
memories it stirred up in me about the early days of the AIDS crisis in New York, where I
was living at the time. Looking forward to Thai dinner w/my friend Jessica tonight.
p.s. I meant to add: Your comments are so affirming and meaningful to me. A wonderful
chorus. I'm sorry I don't respond to each one; I'd like to. As you can imagine, it takes me
a long time to write each entry (a labor of love). I try to respond to a few comments each
time, but please don't consider my 'non-response' as a sign of neglect. All your comment
are included in my 'book!' xo

December 11, 2022 - The 'brief candle'
  by Willa Silverman, December 11, 2022  
                    1.498 / 1.901
                    1.499 / 1.901
On Thursday Dr. Beavis told me much more directly than she ever has that she feels we
are nearing the end of viable treatment options for my cancer. She shared this as the
physician who, in her words, looks at the "big picture." She was seconded by another
physician (one of her fellows) and a palliative care nurse also in the small exam room
with me, creating a kind of echo chamber. Best case scenario, she said, we'll be sitting in
the same exam room at Hopkins a year from now, just before Chanukah. Or I might die
sooner. Not entirely unexpected, but the prediction of the shortened time  horizon (which
I have now fetishized) functioned, in the moment, like a gut punch.
Any reason to nuance this prediction? Well, I have not yet had a CT-scan since I began
treatment with Doxil and Avastin. This will come fairly soon, and we'll see whether the
cancer has progressed. After this line of chemo, there is one more that Dr. Beavis
recommends trying, with a drug called Pemetrexid (Alimta). We know that with each
successive line, the effectiveness of chemotherapy lessens; the sneaky cancer cells
figure out ways to elude the "poison cure." And I've had many lines of chemo, which of
course are killing healthy cells too. So we're seemingly at a point of diminishing returns.
Further: what if, against all odds, I'm able to stave off additional brain mets for about a
year, thus potentially opening up the possibility of my participating in a promising clinical
trial? Yes, I suppose this would be possible, but unlikely. I have discussed with Dr. Patel,
the radiation oncologist, the likelihood of a recurrence and he has even said, in reference
to potentially cancerous spots in my brain that he's not able to visualize perfectly now,
"I'll get those next time." When I finished my radiation treatments this past Friday, he
said: "I'm going to be honest with you. Your situation is serious. We're really going to
need to assess the next MRI [in three months] closely to figure out what the options are
at that point." Of course, even if I began treatment in a trial and developed brain mets in
the course of it, I'd have to leave the trial. Also of course, in the six months-year that it
would take, hypothetically, for me to be rid of brain mets, another problem could arise: a
mass in a lymph node close to my stomach, for example, occasionally causes serious
abdominal distress and a blockage is always a risk.
Oh yeah, I almost forgot: what about a miracle? When she drives me to chemo every
other week, my kind, churchgoing neighbor Janis (who's at odds with her congregation
because she votes Democrat!), always ends with: "I'm praying for a miracle." Then we
both laugh, because she knows I don't like her saying that but she, apparently, can't help
herself. I simply say to her: "You need to be realistic, but you can pray that I don't suffer
much pain." A 'medical miracle?' Sure, why not? As far as the range of plausible
outcomes go, though, this one's, as far as I'm concerned, an outlier.
The Drs. Patel, being the "on the ground" physicians, have a different perspective from
Dr. Beavis' (although they all work very well as a team): continue to treat, monitor,
                    1.500 / 1.901
assess. At a remove from the 'big picture' (although Dr. Patel the elder has a better
sense of the broad view than his younger colleague), they are hesitant to forecast a
terminus.
I was relieved to hear Dr. Beavis, who hugged me warmly and closely at the beginning
and end of our visit, say she feels that I have done "due diligence" in terms of leaving no
stone unturned.  Over the past nearly four years, I've travelled to Hopkins, Memorial
Sloan-Kettering and M.D. Anderson for consults, and have had a helpful phone consult
with a nurse at UCLA Medical Center. I've talked with many physicians, survivors, nurses,
friends. I've undergone three major surgeries, including removal of a brain tumor, which
my doctors encouraged me to pursue to prolong my lifespan. I've been the patient and
the patient-advocate, a 'carer' for myself. Dr. Beavis will talk to the clinical trials team at
Hopkins one more time to make sure we haven't overlooked anything (e.g. clinical trials
open to participants with brain mets, which she correctly calls a 'confounding factor' in
trials that aim to compare 'apples to apples').
Ovarian cancer is such an insidious disease, as I've said before, the "silent killer."
Hopefully, strides in research will continue to be made, but likely too late for me... I may
well be among the 50% of women with O.C. who don't make it past the five-year mark.
I am not really in pain. The back of my neck is sore from radiation. My stomach can
suddenly be beset by discomfort, which is worrisome. I can't eat too much. I've lost
about nine pounds, but actually feel much better at this weight, well within normal
range. The chemo side effects -- nosebleeds from Avastin, neuropathy -- are annoyances.
In terms of "cognition, nutrition, function," the trio the palliative care nurse told me he
monitors closely, I am not doing badly. Again, Dr. Beavis and co. were oohing and aahing
over how well I looked and how they loved my glittery eyeshadow.
How do I feel emotionally? Strung
out/overwhelmed/scared/angry/nostalgic/defensive/anxious/grateful (a bit less this week,
but the feeling will return)/exhausted/liberated/sad/grief-
stricken/rushed/disappointed/embarrassed, trying to figure out my priorities and how
best to live my life, which is what we're all after, isn't it?
Indeed, I felt quite overwhelmed when the palliative care nurse (a small, compact, jacked
guy named Marc, with a shaved head and arms covered with tats), in an effort I'm sure
to be helpful, started unfurling the laundry list of resources and 'best practices' for
terminally ill patients: support groups/chaplaincy/penning last letters/death doulas/UCLA
Mindfulness app/medication (I was prescribed a sedative) etc. etc. My eyes were glazing
over with so much to absorb, compounding the stress of waiting on Dr. Beavis for about
2.5 hours (!) in a small examination room while I chatted with her fellow (Dr. Goulder)
and Marc, the palliative care nurse, knowing too that I wanted to get on the road back to
PA in ample daylight. Ouf!
                    1.501 / 1.901
I asked Dr. Beavis what she thought about my travelling. She feels comfortable about my
taking a trip within the U.S., as she can easily connect me to medical providers just
about anywhere in this country (including Hawaii!) if I get sick while on the road. She
sounded notes of caution, though, about the Caribbean and about Paris: she's not well-
connected there; the care (not in Paris, but elsewhere) may not be of the quality I'd find
in the States; national health care systems can be complicated to navigate for foreigners
with serious illnesses. Of course, the fact that I may have said 'adieu' to Paris
permanently is an abominable thought as my 'French' self is so central to my identity, a
prospect hard for me to process along with many other disappointments. In fact, I don't
think I am very adept at 'grief work' and probably need to figure out how I'll go about it.
Right now I'm not sure what to do about these matters except feel sad about them:
"Maybe [the dream deferred] just sags/like a heavy load. Or does it explode?"
I am most grateful to my friend Sandy for driving me to Hopkins. We actually had lots of
laughs realizing our conversation had largely revolved around "diarrhea and death" and
the fact that we both hate to exercise. We even indulged in some cattiness, and then felt
badly about it! The laughing felt so good. We made a pit stop at Alvaro's in Harrisburg
but arrived too early for all the pizza and pasta deliciousness so we settled for breakfast
sandwiches and a few cookies.
I am also hugely grateful to my college friend David, who lives in Baltimore, for driving
me back to PA. I told David, who was my dormmate in Currier House for three years, that
I often feel like a 'hot mess' when I see him because several times when I was in the
midst of crises large or small I seem to have inflicted myself on his calm, comforting
presence. David is a therapist by training and I'm so glad that he'll soon be taking up a
part-time therapy position  after working for Medicare for many years; I am certain that
he excels in this. It was a blessing that David was once again set in my path on this trip: I
was totally strung out from the Hopkins visit and needed to vent, process, share, seek
advice. I felt safe doing so with David. "We'll journey together," he said. Thank you, dear
David.
D. and I also made a pit stop at Alvaro's, picking up some yummy Italian meals for
dinner. He stayed over and left refreshed on Friday. We had plenty of time for gabbing,
laughing, swapping travel stories, and discovering new sides of each other.
It occurs to me that, should you wish to contact me, if you too wish to "journey
together," you might choose to do so by gmail (willazahava1@gmail.com) or text
(814-883-6673). Honestly, if I were you, I'm not quite sure I'd know what to say to me.
But do know that until I'm not here, I very much am! And I'm just living my life, doing my
thing, which this afternoon means heading off to the synagogue for a rugelach-baking
class. Isn't it the same for all of us? XO
                    1.502 / 1.901

December 23, 2022 - Keepin' on keepin' on
  by Willa Silverman, December 23, 2022  
                    1.506 / 1.901
                    1.507 / 1.901
I have not written in a while. Apologies if you were concerned. There's been a lot to
process, and I get tired during the day sometimes, and need to take a few short rests.
Otherwise, I don't feel too bad. Some mild headaches, which Tylenol can fix. Reduced
appetite and stomach discomfort from the mass in a lymph node that sits atop my
stomach; the other night I vomited during the night, which I feared might have signaled
a blockage, but for at now at least, thankfully, it appears to be a one-off. This status quo
could change at any time though. Certain activities are becoming a bit harder for me. I
worry that more severe headaches will return when/if the cancer in my brain roars back,
and that abdominal discomfort will intensify when/if the mass increases in size,
effectively blocking the lymph node. But so far, so good. Which makes me want to
'frontload' all sorts of adventures, trips, experiences, while another 'little voice' tells me
to take it easy and cocoon.
So I'm back to the pleasantness of local gatherings with my dear State College friends,
because it makes me happy to spend time with them (and then it makes me happy to
write about it): dinner at the Allen Street Grill (nicely renovated, excellent food) with
Cheryl and Sandy (always an occasion to compare clothes and jewelry with these two
smart, interesting women); dinner and gabfest as we like to do with Maria; abbreviated
chats en route to chemo and back with Jackie and Janis; piping hot ramen on a cold night
and gabbing with Helen (we have our sights set on a little jaunt to Pittsburgh later in the
winter; hope to see a few college friends there, food shop in the Strip district, and
museum hop); and lunch with three of the "IIICs" (the eponymous group of women
diagnosed at this stage, with whom I get together every once in a while). It was, from my
perspective, the 'best' lunch we've had in the several years that we've been meeting;
along with general catching up, we talked -- all pretense stripped away, and from
experience -- about confronting our mortality. I was particularly inspired by Deb, a
fourteen year survivor thanks to nearly constant lines of treatment, some quite
debilitating (she's currently taking a break from treatment in order to prioritize 'quality of
life'). Despite her fatigue and significant neuropathy (both of which I can relate to), she's
committed to experiences that bring her joy -- judging 4-H competitions, spending time
with friends and family, hosting, along with her husband, thirty-eight people (!) for
Christmas. While I admit that I questioned Deb's mother's admonitions to her to be stoic
(I am happy to have my feelings indulged and coddled!), I was grateful for Deb's
example of exuberance and strength against all odds -- envers et contre tout.
I should never have doubted that my friends would know what to say to me, a fear I had
expressed in my last post. After my last Caring Bridge post, I received so many beautiful
emails, texts and calls from people who shared personal details of their lives that I hadn't
known; made me intriguing, uplifting offers (trips! zoom calls! films to view! poems to
read!); and offered support and uplift in so many different ways that I felt I was
enveloped in a deliciously warm, comfortable blanket. I am trying to give each of these
                    1.508 / 1.901
messages its due in responding, and in fact have just a very few to answer, which I will
do in the next few days! Apologies for the delay.
Ben and Sammi's visit on Monday, after they spend Xmas with Sammi's family in
Pittsburgh, will bring more joy. We'll have a belated Chanukah celebration, with gifts,
food (Michael's latkes -- he dropped off a large container full of them, and they are
always delicious; maybe a roast chicken or pot roast, homemade apple sauce and
rugelach), and relaxing. The plan is for us to all drive to NY on the 28th for a few days,
before Ben and I drive back here on 1/2, where Ben will stay/work for a week. Plans are
always subject to change, though, but that's our thinking for now.
The holiday has been light-filled. I had hoped to attend a few Chanukah events (public
menorah lighting etc.), but the snow, sleet and deep freeze have kept me inside for the
past few days (it's neg. 3 degrees right now!). Worth contemplating: the cruse of oil that
should have lasted for just one night when the Jews rededicated the (Second) Temple in
Jerusalem, but that burned in the Menorah for eight nights. Do you believe in miracles? I
do not, but yet every year I celebrate one... Also: the strength of spirit triumphing over
military might and power. The Maccabees leading the rebellion of the few over the many
(Ukraine?), who were imposing Hellenization in the region. The light drove out the
darkness. "Not by might and not by power, but by spirit alone." I believe in the power of
the spirit.
And I love when Chanukah and Xmas converge.
Have a blessed Chanukah, Christmas, Festivus, Chanamus, or (earlier this week) solstice
day.
Matisyahu, "Miracle:"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dom_X7YXf8s 
P.S. I forgot to add something my wonderful chemo nurse, Tracy (who now greets me
with a big big hug every time I see her), said to me the other day when I had treatment:
Focus on the "what is" rather than the "what if." Another way of saying "be in the
moment," "take one day at a time," but somehow that 'formula' resonated with me. All of
the nurses in the chemo room are terrific. Everyday miracles?

 January 1, 2023 - Endings, beginnings - Part I
  by Willa Silverman, January 1, 2023  
                    1.515 / 1.901
                    1.516 / 1.901
Warm wishes to you all for good health, happiness, success, fun, and contentment in in
the new year. Peace on earth.
Conversely, receiving greetings for a personally prosperous 2023, much as I appreciate
the kind sentiments and understand that exchanging them is a social ritual, feels slightly
jolting to me this year, if this is to be the year that I die. It doesn't depress me to receive
these greetings, it simply feels -- as does so much in cancer-land -- *weird.* At lunch
yesterday, my friends and I were again talking about how realistic the possibility of
miracles might be. One of my friends puts some faith in them and that belief helps keep
her afloat: I completely respect this. I respect the notion that different types of beliefs
might help some people and not others to confront challenging (health) situations. I also
understand that, visualized as a bell curve, ovarian (in my case) cancer estimates
concerning life expectancy will cluster in one spot, at the same time as there are 
'outliers.' too. The problem for me is believing in an 'outlier' scenario for which the odds
of success are so slim; one barely has a fighting chance at survival, although the
possibility in extremis does exist. Perhaps I'll feel differently the more precarious my
situation becomes. For now, what is helping me the most to navigate these murky
waters (lots of monsters lurking below the surface!) is the 'one day at a time,' 'what is' v.
'what if' philosophy. Breaking my time into 'manageable' units (days, hours, minutes)
somehow diminishes my fear and encourages agency within the realm of the possible.
Physically, I feel 'meh.' I can observe and feel a decline, but also know that I can 'rise to
the occasion' and that some days are better than others. I get winded easily and need to
rest or sit down. My stomach has been hurting the past few days (a bit of vomiting that
I'll talk to my doctor about on Tuesday, when I have chemo; reduced appetite; ability to
eat only small amounts). My very sensitive stomach did not react well to a few holiday
'excesses,' much as I enjoyed them at the time. I'll have a CT scan of my abdomen/
lungs/pelvis on Jan. 11th, then I'll meet with Dr. Patel on the 17th and we'll assess and
figure out next steps. I think I have a video meeting coming up with my palliative care
doctor here too. Presumably, then, I'll have my last infusion of Doxil/Avastin on Tuesday.
I don't want to avoid talking/thinking/writing about my illness, but I also
don't want to ignore that part of 'aging and dying,' in the words of
palliative care doctor B.J. Miller (whom I've mentioned before) can be --
and is, for me -- a "process of crescendo through to the end." A process of
increased intensity, comprised of beautiful, memorable moments, "If we
love such moments ferociously," says Miller in his 2015 Ted Talk, "then
maybe we can learn to live well – not in spite of death, but because of it.”
The last ten days or so have been full of such ferociously-loved moments:
                    1.517 / 1.901
On Christmas Eve, my friend Cheryl (and her husband Jon) were kind enough to have me
over to spend the (bitterly cold) evening with them, my friend Sandy, and her husband
Ron.  Cheryl and Jon's apartment always feels warm and inviting, with a bit of a
southwestern vibe (evidence of their many stays in Santa Fe).  Cheryl is always solicitous
and gracious (and has many other wonderful qualities). We enjoyed a bottle of Veuve
Clicquot, a delicious meal (beef Wellington) from the Hummingbird Room (I brought
some candied spiced pecans, from an easy yet tasty David Lebovitz recipe that has
become one of my go-tos), a gorgeously decorated table, gifts, and good conversation.
Because it was the seventh night of Chanukah, Cheryl was glad that I brought my
menorah for candle-lighting, reciting the blessings, telling the story etc. The apartment
was aglow!
The day after Xmas, Ben and Sammi arrived for two days, driving from her mother's
home in Pittsburgh. I was so happy to see them! I had not seen Sammi since she left for
Vienna in May (or was it March?). I was able to catch up with her about how her
experience has evolved so far: work at the IAEA (UN-affiliated International Atomic
Energy Association), travel, life in Vienna, new friends etc. Over a champagne and
cranberry shrub cocktail, we exchanged Chanukah gifts a day or two late; enjoyed, both
nights, a pot roast I had made (Wegman's recipe: porter ensured a rich gravy), Michael's
latkes, my homemade applesauce, and my first take on rugelach, with Ben assisting
(tasty dough, but most of the apricot jam, and sugary, cinnamon-y walnut mix leaked out
during the baking!). We ran a few errands; the two days passed quickly. I always love
spending time with Ben and Sammi; they're a great team.  This is proving helpful to
them these days as they continue to navigate the aftermath of a fire in the apartment 
below theirs that caused some structural damage in their apartment. It appears that the
necessary work is being done, and the landlord is on it, but they had to buy a new bed,
replace some items, clean others to rid them of the smoke permeating them. A huge
headache, but they are handling it like pros. And most importantly, no one was hurt.
Another 'ferociously-loved' moment during Ben and Sammi's visit: an acquaintance
who's a local musician/singer (and currently an English teacher at State High), Eric,
texted me after we'd not been in touch in quite a while to see how I was faring. When I
updated him w/the recent not great health news, he asked if he could come sing for me. 
His 'mini-concert,' performed for me, Ben and Sammi, included: Bill Withers' "Lovely
Day" (which, unbeknownst to me, is one of Ben and Sammi's favorites), Marvin Gaye's
"What's Going On," some Richie Havens,  Bob Dylan, "The Man in Me" and one or two
others I can't recall. The final piece was the one I had sent Eric when I was thinking of
turning my blog into a performance piece (an idea I've abandoned now as too ambitious
for my horizons, although I still give it thought...): Laura Wetzler's, "Narrow Bridge:"
https://www.google.com/search?q=laura++narrow+bridge&rlz=1C1GGRV_enFR751FR75
1&sxsrf=ALiCzsZgSkMfVq6wmUrz_Abrl8Sptv6atg:1672620926418&source=lnms&tbm=v
id&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwi9vKbB1qf8AhVrKFkFHUYCDrgQ_AUoA3oECAEQBQ&biw=1242&
                    1.518 / 1.901
bih=568&dpr=1.1#fpstate=ive&vld=cid:c89fb4a3,vid:D3Hhky1yLkM
This song, inspired by the writings of Kabbalah-influenced Rabbi Nachman of Breslau
--"The world, in its entirety is a narrow bridge, and the most important thing is not to
give in to one's fear" - and to which my blog owes its' title, is most meaningful to me. I
was so touched that Eric had learned and arranged it - he even sang parts of it in
Hebrew! I was riveted by his singing. I somehow let drop that I used to be a fairly adept
guitar player, and he wanted me to pose for a pic alongside him, with my guitar.  This
has actually provided a bit of inspiration for me to get back to my guitar playing,
something I am drawn to do every once and again.
It was indeed a "lovely day, lovely day, lovely day, lovely day."
Ben, Sammi and I drove to the city on Wednesday. Thursday I took my brother and
nephew Isaac to Friend of a Farmer for a relaxed, lovely brunch and chat; the weather
had warmed up considerably and we walked a few blocks in the sunshine, stopping to
take a selfie or two to remember the day. In the afternoon, my friend Kay and her
husband Jeff came to visit at my mom's, followed by coffee nearby.  I am so grateful that
I've gotten to see Kay -- my girlhood friend, college dormmate, and retired Prof. of
English at UC Santa Barbara -- several times, in State College, NY, and hopefully in some
warm spot, ripe for self-indulgence, before long. And I am delighted that our nearly same
age only sons also met recently, and hit it off. Kay and I had lost contact for several
years, or rather had remained connected by the barest of threads (biannual emails on
our respective birthdays). I love her insightfulness, quirkiness, kindness, and sense of
fun. I don't think we've exhausted (scarcely) discovering all we have in common; at the
same time, we have a long history and shared memories that form the base of a
powerful bond. Kay's husband (also our college classmate), Jeff, is a neurologist, and
seemed eager to help answer some of my brain mets related questions. I loved my visit
with them 'ferociously.' :
A Part II is coming after I return to State College. I hope this post doesn't seem trivial --
you may well not wish to wade through a blow by blow account of my comings and
goings and doings -- but I somehow felt I wanted a record of this crescendo-like year's
end.

January 8, 2023 - Endings, beginnings - Part II
  by Willa Silverman, January 8, 2023  
                    1.527 / 1.901
                    1.528 / 1.901
Thank you for the many uplifting new year's messages! And for some meaningful gifts,
such as a personalized Spotify playlist (so thoughtful). I am responding to each message
but, as usual with me, it's taking a bit of time. Further, yesterday I was completely
knocked out after receiving my final Covid booster, and slept most of the day! My
apologies for being late w/some responses!
I am still not feeling great. My digestive system seems to be the culprit. Stomach
discomfort kept me awake part of last night. I have nearly chronic indigestion, some
nausea, frequent hiccupping. I really can't eat much without feeling distress; have lost
about 13 lbs.. Believe it or not, I am actually looking forward to my CT-scan on
Wednesday so my doctors can figure out what's going on and determine how best to
treat it.
My palliative care doc, Nikki Vithalani, w/whom I met with on Friday via videoconf.,
suggested Maalox for relief so I'll try that. She also shared something I didn't know: brain
radiation can cause extreme fatigue, of the type I've been experiencing. To combat this,
to jolt me with some energy, doctors, she said, sometimes prescribe Ritalin (?!). To me,
Ritalin has scary connotations, but we'll see what my medical team advises. Finally,
because I don't have much stamina these days, Nikki suggested I get more help to assist
me with daily tasks. While Abby picks up my groceries and helps out around the house
once a week, and while I have my house cleaned every other week, I probably could use
another two hours a day from someone, mainly to wash dishes/straighten my kitchen,
make my bed, pick up groceries, and take care of assorted odds and ends around the
house. I even had an anxiety dream in which my living space was being invaded by mess
(clothes on the floor etc.) I'm going to start working on this.
I wanted to leave a record of the remainder of my trip to the city: On Wednesday (30
Dec.), I took my mother out for a belated bday lunch at Gramercy Tavern. The walk from
my mother's apartment on 17th st. past Gramercy Park where I grew up to the Tavern on
20th bore me along on gusts of memory, archeological strata from the different 'eras' of
my life. There was 24 Gramercy Park, where my acquaintance Ross lived, a handsome,
slightly older boy who occasionally hung out with my group of neighborhood friends on
warm summer nights in the park, to which a key provided access; and the Gramercy Arts
Club, where I took piano lessons for many years with Mrs. Kay Fryer, who rewarded me
for good work with small statuettes of the great composers, and held annual recitals that
always paralyzed me with performance anxiety; and, at 34 Gramercy Park East, the
building where I grew up! A stately 1883 red brick structure in the Queen Anne style.
When I would leave for school in the morning, the ornate entryway provided a
picturesque frame for the park across the street - snow-covered in winter, blooming in
the spring, lush and green in summer, infused with the weather and smells that
accompanied each season. I never tired of that pretty view.
                    1.529 / 1.901
https://www.cityrealty.com/nyc/gramercy-park/the-gramercy-34-gramercy-park-
east/4850
Gramercy Tavern is an iconic New York restaurant that I had been to once before
perhaps twenty years ago, with Michael and his family. I might describe its style as 'haut
américain' or maybe New American (although not so new anymore). The service is
distinctive: consummately professional yet also somewhat casual. Our waiter (in slacks,
apron, and a crisp man-tailored shirt with sleeves rolled up) inquired at length about food
allergies (which turned out to be necessary in my mother's case) yet also joked around
with us. I remember being struck by that style, which I don't think you'd encounter in a
French restaurant of the same caliber, the first time I tried GT. Following a glass of
Prosecco, we opted for the three-course "Greenmarket Lunch," featuring the outstanding
produce from the Union Square Greenmarket down the street. I had a delicious celeriac
(a new taste for me) soup; it tasted so rich I thought it had cream in it but it only
featured a bit of butter (there was an amuse-bouche too, but I forget what it was). For
our main dish we both had grilled skate, perfectly cooked (I usually give credit only to
French restaurants for cooking fish so beautifully) on top of a bed of mini greenmarket
veggies and surrounded by some sort of delicious coulis. For dessert, we split a
cheesecake (small, oval-shaped) w/a ball of clementine (?) sorbet, and some fresh pear
sorbet. Excellent coffee. And a small bowl of the most perfect, flavorful Concord grapes
to finish. The portions were rather small and I ate very slowly so fortunately the meal did
not bother my stomach. I'm glad that we sat in the (quiet!) main dining room rather than
the bustling tavern/bar area up front, where patrons were eating appetizing looking
hamburgers grilled on a wood fire, among other more casual dishes.
The year ended wonderfully, as I spent part of the day with two of my best friends from
grade school, Eva and Zia. I met Zia (a writer, who also teaches writing at the New
School) at a store we had wanted to visit since I had read a NYTimes article about it: the
New York branch of Sabayasachi (https://sabyasachi.com/password). The designer
Sabayasachi is credited with having 'reinvented the sari' largely (but not exclusively) for
a wealthy Indian-American (in the case of the NY boutique) clientele (if you're a sucker
for reality shows, as I am [!], check out "Indian Weddings"). All we could say on entering
the boutique (way west on Christopher St.) through massive teak (?) doors is that we felt
we were in another world, in a beyond opulent décor featuring Indian tapestries, objects,
calligraphy; lots of chinoiserie; vases, porcelain, furniture that would not be out of place
at Versailles; dozens of crystal chandeliers; elegantly-bound editions of literary classics
(Voltaire) plus colonial-era literature (Kipling). Within this fantasy environment, the
wedding clothing, pashminas, jewelry -- all highly ornate -- are displayed. There were a
few customers (mainly Indian and Indian-American) trying on wedding clothing; I frankly
thought the clothing looked a bit more 'glitzy' than it does on Sabayaschi's Instagram. I
thought I might buy myself a scarf but the prices were prohibitive. The staff, however,
was lovely (the manager seemed like he might be Indian but told us he was half-Middle
Eastern, half-Danish) and let us spend quite a while there, visitors at a museum. There is
                    1.530 / 1.901
likely a sociological angle to this place and the entire upscale Indian wedding industry,
I'm sure; perhaps Zia will be able to parse it, as she and her mom Madhur are definitely
better attuned to Indian culture than I am. We certainly had fun gawking!
We headed towards Zia's mother and stepfather's house on W. 12th street -- another jolt
from the past as this is the same apartment where I spent *hours* as a teenager and pre-
teen, sleeping over in the bedroom Zia shared with her two sisters; locking ourselves in
the bathroom when we wanted to have gossipy conversations; sometimes sleeping on
the floor in the living room, on a bed of comfy pillows and blankets. Zia's parents weren't
home, but let us use the apartment for the delightful lunch that Zia prepared. Eva (who
lives in Sag Harbor, LI, with her husband Drew, and currently works in insurance) arrived
and, over lunch and a glass of Pinot Grigio, we had a great conversation that seemed to
roam between past and present, milestones and challenges (marriages, relationships,
illness, aging parents), sprinkled with whatever wisdom we've picked up over the years.
Lots of laughs. I had brought the diary I kept the summer of 1974 (we were all 15), which
captured so many vignettes from that summer featuring the three of us, like a sweltering
summer evening when about a dozen of us classmates hung out at the San Gennaro
street fair in Little Italy, intoxicated by the smell of sizzling Italian sausage and onions
and zeppoli, the lights of the city, and the unsurpassed feeling of independence.
New Year's Eve I stayed in and made dinner (linguine with a lemon cream sauce) for my
mother and Arnold, to go with our Veuve Clicquot! I was so tired I didn't even make it to
midnight. 
Ben and I drove back to State College on 1/2. He teleworked here and helped me out for
the week. He was a darling in every way, and I really appreciated (and needed) his help.
He's headed to Boulder, CO, soon to visit his friend Nolan while he works from there. The
guys will do lots of skiing, I'm sure.
