January 16, 2023 - Ars moriendi
                    1.546 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, January 16, 2023  
I don't have much of a medical update to share. I am *still* awaiting results of the CT-
scan (pelvis/abdomen/lungs) I had last Wednesday, which I am supposed to discuss with
Dr. Patel tomorrow morning in order to assess my condition and develop a treatment
plan. I've left three messages with Dr. Patel's office today to see if they can
access/expedite the report and have also called Geisinger's Radiology department. Very
frustrating. I also need to write a letter to Aetna after receiving an astronomical bill for
my last two chemo treatments, from Nov. and Dec. 2022. I had apparently maxed out
my coverage for these treatments, but of course I was never alerted to this. I don't
believe this cap was even mentioned in the Explanation of Benefits I received. Grrrr! So
frustrating.
If only I had my usual energy to throw myself full throttle into combatting these two
problems, which must be resolved. The first one will likely resolve itself, but I may not
have the results of the CT-scan before I talk to Dr. Patel tomorrow, unfortunately. The
second problem - battling the insurance company, appealing the charge -- will require
stamina, focus and determination, all of which I have historically prided myself on. But
I've not been feeling well for a few weeks, and this makes routine (and less routine)
                    1.547 / 1.901
tasks arduous to perform. I find myself (still) very tired, winded, and lacking  appetite.
I'm consuming only liquids now, but trying to bulk up with milkshakes, Carnation instant
breakfast, soup etc. Have lost about 15 pounds, and should not lose much more. My PCP,
Paul Damaske, whom I saw on Friday (very compassionate guy, who's keeping close
track of me along with my other doctors here) attributed much of how I'm feeling to -
simply - cancer. After nearly four years of treatment, my body is tired. Some of my
'systems' (e.g. digestive) may be slowing down. Radiation also causes fatigue. He gave
me another med, Protonix, for my stomach/digestive issues, and I also started taking
something like Maalox that my palliative care doctor proposed. Hoping for another
"honeymoon period."
[Update on my update: Dr. Patel's office just wrote. They said they had called the
radiologist, who promised to write his report for Dr. Patel to read before I see him
tomorrow morning. Whew. Problem #1 solved].[Update #2: I see that the radiologist's
report has been uploaded to my portal. But now I'm too scared to read it. I may wait for
Dr. Patel to parse it for me tomorrow morning].
I feel the impulse to censor or 'curate' my medical update as I am conscious of not
wanting to concern, even alarm, those reading this entry.
Visits with friends have definitely provided cheer over the past few weeks. My friends
Jackie and Monique came for tea on consecutive days, Monique bearing a large container
of homemade chicken soup (she's been supplying me with this 'Jewish penicillin' at
critical junctures ever since I was in the hospital after Ben was born nearly twenty-eight
years ago!). The day after Jackie's visit, she insisted on hand delivering a mocha chip
milkshake from Meyer's Dairy (liquid goodness, I indulged in a chocolate root beer float
today) and Wegman's OMG Tomato Soup (I'm clueless about the name). Have also
zoomed with my grade school friend Jane, who recently sold her house on Cape Cod and
moved to Hawaii (her invitation to visit is tempting....); my former grad student turned
colleague and good friend, Denis; and, this evening, my cousin. In touch with other
friends via text, email etc. Ben is in Boulder, Colorado for a few weeks, teleworking and
skiing and hanging out with friends and otherwise 'livin' the life,' but we're in touch every
day. He loves it there!
Whitman in I Sing the Body Electric: "I have learned that to be with those I like is
enough."
__________________________________________________________________________________
Over the many years I taught French "civilization" (we now opt for the far less
'imperialistic' and historically more accurate moniker of "culture and society"), I always
looked forward to teaching the sessions on "Visions de la mort au Moyen Age" (Visions of
Death in the Middle Ages). Why? Objects such as memento mori or frescoes in
churchyards depicting the danse macabre, seemed so alien to me and my students in
                    1.548 / 1.901
their strangeness, underscoring the 'pastness of the past.' This topic would never fail,
also, to generate interesting discussions (in French!) on topics ranging over Goth culture,
the AIDS quilt, celebrations of life, depictions of death in popular culture (today, I'm
certain that COVID and its fallout would be in the mix as well, considered in parallel with
the Black Plague; I remember in the very early days of COVID, around March 2020, I had
a dream in which a black-robed, masked, plague-doctor appeared!).
I'm not sure where I want to go with this musing. I'm too lazy (and likely not well-
informed enough) to take on a full-fledged comparison of 'images of and attitudes
towards death in the Middle Ages and today.' That would truly be an undertaking
doomed to failure.  I think I simply want to say that those discussions, and those images,
have stayed with me, and have much greater resonance for me now. I wonder if any of
the students in my classes had experienced death closely enough (within their families
or among friends, for example) to be moved (or even traumatized) by these images?
When I taught them, it was always at an intellectual remove.
How does one 'die well,' as various illustrated tracts from the 15th century onwards
asked (or rather advised)? In the Middle Ages, the Ars Moriendi, likely written by
churchmen, were treatises prescribing behaviors constituting a 'good death.' In the
context of the times, this meant a death preceded by an upright Christian life and ending
with the passage of body and soul to heaven, after angels and devils warred over the
mortal flesh until the very end (this was graphically, and sometimes gruesomely,
depicted in woodcuts accompanying the text). One can surmise that the ultimate end of
such treatises was to reinforce the power of the Church and encourage obedience. They
ultimately functioned as technologies of control and discipline.
And what of today? I just ordered B.J. Miller's new book, The Beginner's Guide to the End,
whose approach, as I understand it, is eminently practical; one chapter is entitled "How
to write a eulogy and an obituary." A good death, in Miller's vision, might be one in which
all the practical matters of dying (paying for the funeral, writing the obituary, choosing
burial options etc.) are dispensed with expertly. But my attention and imagination shift,
for the moment, to Georges Montorgeuil's fanciful vision of revelers high above
Montmartre, tutelar spirits inhabiting this magical place. They float joyfully, perhaps
headed not so much 'up' but out, into a vaporous sky, free, holding hands and kicking up
their heels. I guess I'd like to think of a 'good death' not as the fearful vision of the Ars
moriendi but something akin to Montorgeuil 'vie à Montmartre,' devoid of acute bodily
suffering, joyful in having lived well, free-floating.
[I think my train of thought is not yet well-developed here, but these images have been
on my mind lately!]

January 18, 2023 - Update
  by Willa Silverman, January 18, 2023  
I was too tired and stressed to write anything on Monday or Tuesday as I awoke
extremely early both days for bloodwork, magnesium infusion, meeting with Dr. Patel,
vitamin B-12 injection etc. After having slept twelve hours last night (which seems to be
what I need these days), I'm able to provide an update.
                    1.553 / 1.901
I'm afraid the update may seem 'anticlimactic' as it certainly didn't convey any news I
didn't expect, except for that of a new spot on my liver (about 1 cm+ in size; will be
targeted by my next course of chemo). Progression of disease, totally expected. The
cancer progresses gradually, and is now present in my lymph nodes, on my liver, in my
brain and likely elsewhere (a few tumors at the base of my abdomen). The mass in the
lymph node *behind* my stomach (I actually thought it lay on top of my stomach) is
quite sizeable. I haven't actually read the report yet (but will); Dr. Patel interpreted it for
me, and I'll ask Dr. Beavis about it, too.
I asked if radiating the mass in my lymph node was possible; Dr. Patel said that, because
of the location of the lymph node, radiating it would entail piercing through other organs
and healthy tissue, a much too toxic option.
Dr. Patel, unfortunately, does not have a definitive explanation of my recent symptoms
(fatigue, lack of appetite and weight loss, stomach discomfort). He ruled out organ
function (my liver, kidney functioning normally) and low hemoglobin, platelet, or white
blood cell count (these are ok as well). The stomach discomfort might be due to a partial
blockage (which we'll only worry about if I'm vomiting chronically, which I'm not); the
fatigue can be partially attributed to the chemo drugs and radiation. Stress could
certainly cause or accentuate all these symptoms. Dr. Patel had another theory that had
to do with magnesium and metabolism but 'llI have to look at my notes for the details. I
now have a small cornucopia of meds targeting my digestion, nausea etc. I will take
them all, simultaneously, and see if that helps.
I might try a low dose of Ritalin for an energy boost.
I need to maintain my weight and not lose more; today it seems to be stable (lots of
milkshakes and Carnation instant breakfast!).
One piece of good news, per Dr. Patel: my symptoms do not signal the stage
immediately preceding death (LOL - three cheers for small victories!). Am I happy to be
here? Without a doubt.
Another piece of good news: for *now* (but this can change quickly) my head/brain are
'behaving.' I'm fearful of a 'double whammy' (brain stuff + all the rest), but so far I've
managed to stave this off. Brain MRI in about a month and a half.
Good news #3: both Dr. Patel and his nurse feel I look quite well, belying the seriousness
of my condition.
We are next (and perhaps finally?) going to try a chemo drug I've not been given before,
called Alimta (Pemetrexid), along with Avastin. I need to talk to Dr. Beavis and find out
                    1.554 / 1.901
why they wish to continue w/Avastin, if the previous treatments with it have not worked
or worked well. Avastin gives me nosebleeds, and I always worry about the risk of bowel
perforation. If I do decide to go ahead with this combo (of course, I could stop, or could
have stopped, treatment at any point, such as before my brain surgery, in which case I'd
be dead by now but would have avoided some of the real discomfort I'm experiencing
currently), I'll be infused every three weeks. It's all about balancing my quality of life
against the effects, and effectiveness, of the treatment. At the moment, my quality of
life seems to have taken a dip, but again: am I glad to be here, driving in my car
listening to NPR, picking up a milkshake at Meyer's Dairy, chatting with store clerks,
enjoying the mundanities of living? Absolutely!
May be making some progress on getting additional help around the house, which I
sorely need. Something like 1-2 hours a day, every day, and we'll see how it goes after
that. 
While I never like to plan too far in advance these days, I'm still hoping my beloved grad
school friends will arrive in late Jan. on what we're calling the "spoil her rotten express"
for a weekend of laughs and silliness and pampering. 
Also have tentatively planned five days of pool, a sparkling bay, spa, lounging and *sun*
with another dear friend in early Feb. - if things remain stable. I think it will do me good.
Can you guess where we're headed (no spoilers, for the two or three of you who know!)?

 January 27, 2023 - Themes/dreams/reads + a health report
  by Willa Silverman, January 27, 2023  
Health report: status quo, i.e. 'new normal,' i.e. fatigue, shortness of breath on even
relatively mild exertion, discomfort in my stomach/abdominal area, decreased appetite
and preference for liquids (maintaining weight loss of about 14 lbs.; plenty of milk
shakes, root beer floats [thank you, Lisa, for bringing me one today!], Carnation instant 
breakfast and some soft foods like bananas). I can't really say I'm in pain, although if I
eat the wrong thing, I experience cramping or other discomfort in my stomach. My
(in)digestion is wonky.
Very happy to be here, it goes without saying. In fact, I have taken offense, or been
taken aback, or taken...somewhere where alarm bells are ringing, when, for the first
time, two of my doctors recently addressed the issue of my stopping treatment. My
palliative care doc, Dr. Vithalani, asked me point blank if I wanted to pursue the next line
of treatment. I know, of course, that the choice is always mine, but somehow the
possibility never occurred to me as a real option, one that I would consider seriously. She
suggested that while stopping treatment might shorten my lifespan (further), it might
also improve the quality of the life I have left (off chemo for several weeks now while
awaiting insurance pre-certification for Alimta, I have indeed been feeling better,
although spending time with friends is really the elixir that energizes me and lifts my
spirits; I felt that today over lunch at a newish ramen place in town with my friend Helen,
who dazzled me with stories of her recent trip to Israel, a country that enthralled me
when I visited, and also on Monday, when Kathryn, Sandy, and Cheryl came over for
convo and...milkshakes! Am greatly looking forward to the arrival tomorrow of Vinni,
Shanny and Isa, my dear grad school friends, for two days of giggles and various
indulgences). Dr. Beavis also suggested yesterday that I might try the new chemo drug,
Alimta (Pemetrexid), see how I react to it, and discontinue it if it doesn't sit well with me.
Stopping treatment is of course a scary prospect. Feels like free fall. Even if I'm receiving
the chemo somewhat prophylactically, I still have some notion (illusion?) of control over
my disease as long as I'm in treatment. But we're not at the critical juncture yet. Dr.
Beavis has mentioned one final (?) line of (post-Alimta) treatment, for which I would have
to have my tumor tested and for which there also appears to be a national shortage of a
necessary reagent. I'm not feeling terribly optimistic about this possibility.
I am still haggling with Aetna over an astronomical bill for two chemo treatments. And
now I am also somewhat haggling with Dr. Patel's office over whether or not he will write
a letter in support of my appeal. Decidedly, this is not bringing me joy.
                    1.558 / 1.901
What is leaving me more time for whatever brings me joy is the additional home help
I've  been able to arrange through sheer force of will(apower) - and with a big thanks to
Maria. I now have one of three very nice women coming in *every day* for 1-2 hours to
do a mix of cleaning/straightening/groceries/errands (nothing medical); I'm also
engaging them in a big downsizing/organizing effort throughout my house, an
undertaking that, admittedly, may take a while but that is making me feel,
psychologically and emotionally, much happier -- which leads me to my recent dreams.
THEMES
'Living in the material world…'
'The things they carried.' What we take with us v. what we leave behind…
Unfinished business.
Going on a journey and nothing must be left behind, unaccounted for. On the other hand,
once it’s all packed, everything must be left behind.
"Don’t leave a mess" (Miller and Berger, _A Beginner’s Guide to the End_; guess I flunked
that chapter :{)
Feeling overwhelmed; events and phenomena over which I have little to no control, yet I
still try to control them (flailing all the while). Maybe the key is to relinquish control and
have faith that everything will be alright.
DREAMS
I've essentially had the same dream every night for the past several weeks: I have to
pack up, clean up etc. for a trip or move of some sort. It's a monumental job and
everything's a mess. Meanwhile, there's lots of other activity going on: sometimes it’s an
activity I’d much rather be pursuing (like swimming in an enticing ocean), other times it’s
another major responsibility I have to acquit, and I’m not really succeeding at anything!
Snapshots:
Packing, huge mess of clothes strewn everywhere. Do I have enough space in my
suitcases, do I even have enough suitcases? (In another dream: suitcases bulging, I'm
trying to push them up onto some kind of overhead rack as on a train, with difficulty).
In one bin of stuff to pack: some pretty, small framed prints and artifacts from late 19th
c? Old. But one was contained in a gaudy, bling-y frame with the name “Gucci"
prominently spelled out in rhinestones.
                    1.559 / 1.901
In the midst of all this frantic packing  – other people around – I decide to take a shower
and wash my hair (light switches to turn on overhead lights in shower don’t work). I’m
taking the shower but know that I have much else to take care of, including the packing.
I’m starting to get tired.
I have a class to teach (recurring theme in many of my dreams). I’m barely keeping it
(the class) together. This one concerns the Belle Epoque. The session I’m supposed to
cover that day centers on posters and graphic art in general, a subject I know well. I
realize that I can simplify things for myself by simply asking the class: Why is this era
called “L’âge du papier?” I’m glad to have hit on this idea because I realize that the
question will get us into the subject of technology and its importance. But I also realize
that I’m barely on top of this class. There appears to be an essay due soon or a big test
that I’m supposed to make everyone aware of, but I’m clueless. There’s an undercurrent
of (my) worry about this important fact.
Related: I'm showing up for the last class session of a course in which I had hardly made
an appearance all semester. Much to my surprise, a few of the students actually show
up; I think they want to get their homework assignments returned after waiting nearly all
semester. Did this take place in the old NBS (my grade/high school) building? And I think
students from this class were combined with those (in the same room) of another one I
was teaching.
Many tasks to take care of, confusion, fatigue, feeling overwhelmed. Have to send
something in the mail but it becomes very complicated because I don't have an
envelope, nor perhaps a stamp. Go out looking for these, need to walk very far; some of
the route completely unfamiliar (buildings in a city I do not recognize; I seem not to be
taking the most direct route). Then I somehow realize I am near NYU (my graduate
school alma mater) and find Bobst Library. Get to Bobst Library, speak with a janitor or
handyman who implies he can get me an envelope but this turns out to be complicated (I
need to wait for the envelope/stamp, or go somewhere else to get it).
I am staying “at my mother and father’s” for the summer. I am recounting this to
someone on the phone, sort of unhappily. Is it our old apartment in Gramercy Park
(where I lived most of my life, at least on and off, from age 6-mid 20s)? This apartment,
at least, is neat and very quiet, contrasting with the chaos of the rest of the dream.
I thought I had cleaned up a huge mess that we (+ other people, family members?) had
to take care of before leaving the premises of an apartment that belonged to someone
else (perhaps we had rented it). Then I realize there's *much more* to clean out/pack up
than I had first imagined -- entire shelves and closets bulging with stuff. One of these
spaces looks like my spice cabinet. I suggest putting each jar of spices/herbs in a plastic
bag and sealing it, but someone (my mother?) thinks it will attract bugs. There are also
half-used bottles of vinegar, oils etc. I don't know what to do with them. There's so much
                    1.560 / 1.901
stuff, everywhere! I feel totally overwhelmed. I think the part about being in my mother
and father’s calm apartment (above) was actually the last part of the dream.
Mom seems younger in the dream, as do mom and dad in Gramercy Park – an earlier era
of my life.
Allen E. (former therapist) in dream. He’s mad at me because I’ve somehow ‘messed up’
with therapy, perhaps neglected to attend group sessions, done something wrong. He
appears stern and chastising, and I feel sheepish and flustered. In another part of that
dream (which was part of larger dream), a young boy (either little Ben or Ethan or
amalgam) and I are in AE’s presence to do some therapy work. The boy has some
recrimination of me that he wishes to express (although not meanly or angrily, just
pretty matter-of-factly) but I preempt him by saying what *I* think is going wrong in our
dynamic, ie my and the boy's>grammar??). I start speaking rather loudly and
assertively, depriving the boy of the opportunity to speak.
Last night: Yes, as in all the dreams, mess is omnipresent. But somehow I'm able to fish
out an outfit that I put on: a turtleneck or cowl neck gray cashmere-like form-fitting
sweater and a black skirt. I look at my profile and think I look quite attractive; the weight
loss flatters me. I also put on some blingy sparkly earrings with matching necklace. Am a
bit disappointed as it's not the blingy necklace I had expected to wear but a nice yet
simple silver chain with small horseshoes dangling from it. My hair is about shoulder
length and looks good. Pretty sure action in this dream also takes place in our Gramercy
Park apartment!
Next, I am in bathroom of this apartment and see something pushing up from under the
floor. I expect it might be a groundhog but it is a cat! It is gray (mottled), has matted
hair, semi-closed eyes, and looks like it's 'been through the wringer." I pick up cat and
take it next door to bedroom (my old bedroom in the apartment!) to give to little Ben (or
Ethan?), who is in bed. The cat escapes from Ben's hands, however, and somehow finds
another hole in the floor of the room that s/he falls into or escapes through. The cat is
gone. [IRL: My neighbors Paul and Marcia have sent two emails to the other condo
owners in our complex to let us know their cat, Luther, is missing; I have been worried
about this].
Why all the concern w/'stuff' in the dreams while seemingly less concern about people
(taking or leaving them). Does the 'stuff' represent the people? Is my overconcern with
the 'stuff' obscuring my tending to my people? Paging Dr. Freud...
READS
Carl Hiassen, _Squeeze Me_ [thanks, Steve!] (a *welcome* change of pace from some of
the heavier stuff I've been reading/thinking/feeling/living these days, a satirical mystery
                    1.561 / 1.901
set in Trump-era south Florida; it made me laugh!);Ross Gay, _The Book of Delights_
[thanks, Paula!] - some of the author's 'delights' are a bit arcane (for me), others not (the
pleasure of saying 'whatevs' whenever possible!), but the style is original and
compelling. I enjoyed this book of 'essayettes;' Joan Didion, _The Year of Magical
Thinking_ (thanks, Maria!) Oh my. Please everyone read this book.  So perceptive about
how grief unfolds, about its many layers, its relationship to the past, present, and future,
its 'vortices.' Didion's spare style, her sense for the telling detail, the permission she
gives herself to be so intimate, so vulnerable in her writing. I love this book; BJ Miller and
S. Berger, _The Beginner's Guide to the End: Practical Advice for Living Life and Facing
Death_. I ordered this book because I'm a huge fan of B.J. Miller's and am open to
receiving 'practical advice' in the same way I was when I read _What to Expect when
you're Expecting._ So 21st century America, I know, a 'how-to' guide for dying (cf my
post on the _Ars moriendi,_ above)! I've just dipped into it but can tell that it's about
much more than practicalities: spirituality, relationships, ritual. Interesting and ultimately
helpful stuff.

February 1, 2023 - De l'amitié OR Here comes the 'spoil her rotten'
express!
  by Willa Silverman, February 2, 2023  
                    1.564 / 1.901
                    1.565 / 1.901
"Si on me presse de dire pourquoi je l'aimais, je sens que cela ne se peut exprimer qu'en
répondant: 'Parce que c'était lui [elle], parce que c'était moi.'" Michel de Montaigne, 
Essais
"If you press me to say why I loved him [her/them], I can say no more than because
s/he/they was/were s/he/they, and I was I." Michel de Montaigne, "De l'amitié" ("On
Friendship), Essais
*I've modified the pronouns, more completely in the English translation.
How do four close friends of forty years, living in four different states, last all together in
pre-Covid 2019 at Kripalu Yoga Center in the Berkshires, all in the midst of (or having
had) successful college/university careers in French Studies (research, teaching,
administration, program development etc.), one recently promoted to the rank of 
chevalier in the French Legion of Honor,  spend their 'sleepover' in Happy Valley?:
*cooking and eating delicious, healthy (yet indulgent) meals and snacks: homemade
soups made by Vinni (curried butternut squash), Isa (red lentil) and Shanny (tomato);
cheeses; French-style sausage; an excellent salad; baba ganoush; pastries and more
(these women are superb cooks);
*hanging out in my sunroom in our p.j.s, imbibing cup upon cup of bergamot tea,
morning coffee, and scrumptious smoothies.
*sipping Cosmos made by Shanny, mixologist extraordinaire, among all else;
*Indulging in a 'home spa' also set up by Shanny with much forethought (mud masques,
herbal steam facials); they think of everything,* these filles!
*Exchanging gifts, which always seem perfectly adapted to the receiver because we
know one another's tastes so well;
*Speaking a mix of English, French, franglais, peppered with ludicrous literal translations
of idioms (faire un point, frapper la route etc.) 
*Filling in the 'backstory' for all those photos of us between 1988, when we began our
graduate studies at NYU, through the Paris years and subsequent trips to France (many),
and on through weddings, divorces, kids, boyfriends, deaths and other milestones. The
time Shanny put salt instead of sugar in the apple pie we were serving our guests in
Paris, who hoped for a 'taste' of American Thanksgiving. The countless dinner parties
Vinni, Shanny and I organized in Paris for the interesting local pals we had met in
                    1.566 / 1.901
seminars at Sciences Po and through other friends. The adventuresome trips Vinni and I
took to London, Madrid (yes, we really did get lost one freezing New Year's Eve outside a
bullfighting ring!). Isa and Rob's beautiful wedding (we caravaned from NY); her mother,
Mathé, who became our Parisian 'mom' during our stays in the capital;
*Hugging;
*'Losing' our phones in my house;
*Giggling uncontrollably, shaking with huge bursts of laughter over and over...
*Non-stop talking, sharing, digging deep, being silly, getting real, shedding tears: our
kids (their triumphs and challenges) and aging parents; our clothes (where did you get
that cute sweater?); our health; our family histories; work, retirement, and beyond; a
recent French film, _De son vivant,_ about a terminally ill cancer patient and his
compassionate oncologist; my own cancer journey; other health challenges; beliefs
about what happens after death; endings/beginnings; friendship.
Afterwards I reflected that the two days were like _un condensé_ (a condensed version)
of our forty years of friendship.
My mood was euphoric.
They took care of me. I hope I have helped take care of them.
I wish days like these would never end. Nourishment for the soul, mind and body. Trust.
Laughter and fun.
Parce que c'étaient elles, parce que c'était moi.
******
Monday night I was equally nourished by a zoom call with two of my 'besties' from high
school, Zia and Eva, whom I recently saw in NY. My pals of a half-century. How we've
changed, how we've remained the same, what the journey's been like. I open a yearbook
or one of my diaries and see us there, in our blue pleated skirts, white blouses and knee
socks, our innocent images belying all the mischief we were up to, all the longings,
curiosity, and at times inner chaos of our teenage years in NY.
*****
And Monday, if all goes as planned (still a bit nervous about jinxing myself), I'll fly
towards warmer climes for five days of poolside relaxation, spa indulgences, and
                    1.567 / 1.901
whatever hijinks my dear friend Kay (whom I've know the longest of all, since we met
one summer when we were twelve in Amherst, MA, as castmates in a production of _The
Adventures of Tom Sawyer_ ) has dreamed up for us.
****
I remember that when I was little my cousins gave me a book entitled _A Friend is
Someone who Likes You,_ by Joan Walsh Anglund. It was really my first introduction to
the *notion* of friendship, which has meant so much to me over the years. Thank you,
dear friends, both those whose roots plunge back into the past along with mine and
those of more recent date.
Maybe B.J. Miller is calling it again: "I am asking we make space so that aging
and dying can become a process of crescendo through to the end."
P.S. I did a thing. I had my hair, skimpy as it is, cut and colored for the first time in
several years.  This is the second time my hair has grown back since I was diagnosed in
2019. I am pleased to witness my skin (i.e. hair) regenerating in this way and am told
that my ultra-short cut is 'cute.'

 February 12, 2023 - Welcome to Miami
  by Willa Silverman, February 12, 2023  
                    1.574 / 1.901
                    1.575 / 1.901
"No work, all play, ok?"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IwBS6QGsH_4
...and it did the trick. Now if they would just get rid of that scary governor...
At the Mandarin Oriental (henceforward MO), the staff smiles, pampers, coddles, flirts,
brings you cucumber and lemon water by the pool, fixes a tropical fruit salad of dragon
fruit and pineapple, squeezes fresh orange juice, concocts the most beautiful purple
cocktail: Prosecco, hibiscus, elderflower liqueur; calms you with meditation and
visualization in a room with floor to ceiling windows overlooking glistening Biscayne Bay;
softly plays Burt Bacharach tunes for you in the lounge.
Curling up in a soft towel for a rest by the infinity pool or feeling my body absorb the
sun's enlivening rays; jacuzzi. Restful sleeps.
Spa time: smells divine (vaguely woodsy and leathery); tea ritual on arrival (rejuvenating
cool hibiscus tea, on a tray with warm towels and vibrantly colored fresh blossoms);
fluffy robes, slippers; facial (masque, creams, peels, exfoliants, lip balm, heat, cool,
gentle massage); manicure (I brought one of my favorite OPI shades, "Princesses Rule!);
aromatherapy steam room (feel the pores open, the body exude moisture covering you
in rivulets); visualization (I am encased in an aqua blue, green and pink cocoon, floating
high above); deep breathing; shower (hot water pummeling you from all sides, rosemary-
scented bath gel); feeling so pleasantly in touch with my body, for the moment no longer
a source of pain.
Food: dinner two nights at La Mar, the hotel restaurant, Peruvian with some Asian fusion.
Sat outside overlooking the glittery (glitzy?) Miami skyline. Bustling place, bustling city.
Lots of ceviche: octopus, calamari, prawns, scallops, tuna marinated in lime, sometimes
tamarind, cilantro and other deliciousness. Empanadas. Mojitos! Pisco sours! Dulce de
leche, tres leches cake w/banana.
Other night ventured 'off campus' to Cafe La Trova in Little Havana. Food maybe a B+
(tried something with lime-marinated pork and pineapple rice; prawns w/white beans in a
brown sauce), drinks A+ (some sort of amazing frozen Campari concoction). Atmosphere
A+: packed place, 'old Havana' décor (including a vintage Cuban car in one corner), live
music (intoxicating blend of African, Caribbean, European and other rhythms that you
*can't not* move to; people dancing between tables, at the bar, bartenders also breaking
out their trumpets, maracas, bongos, cowbells). Chica, welcome to Miami!
Lovely lunch with my very dear aunt Marlene and cousin Julie, who were kind enough to
drive 1.5 hours from Boca, where they live, to have lunch with me and Kay. Yummy fresh
                    1.576 / 1.901
salmon burger, iced tea at River Oyster Bar. Delightful to see them and spend time
together.
Many in Miami speak only Spanish; this surprised me. You really don't need English at all
to get by. Although this proved a bit frustrating once or twice (e.g. arranging to have a
wheelchair pick me up in the Miami airport), I found it pleasantly dépaysant. Heavily
Latinx and generally international city: encountered folks from Puerto Rico, Haiti, France,
Cuba, Peru etc.
'Old money' (i.e. 40-something man in attire of a New England preppy>the Palm Beach
crowd?) v. 'new' (lots of bling, heavy gold watches, women in sparkly skin tight clothing,
thigh-high boots). Admittedly, my sample is small.
And then there was Kay. We met in about 1971 in Amherst, MA (she lived there, I was
summering there while my father taught at UMass), through a local production of "The
Adventures of Tom Sawyer" (Kay, a dancer, choreographed; I played Aunt Polly). We
became fast friends and visited one another in NY and Amherst throughout middle and
high school; my trips to Amherst would always involve a walk down to the back door of
the Grist Mill restaurant to buy the crispest French fries straight out of the fryer in the
kitchen. We wound up classmates - even dormmates - at Harvard, but with different
friend groups. We drifted a bit after that -- always keeping in touch through annual
birthday phone calls and occasional get-togethers, but our connection became slightly
perfunctory. My illness brought us back together, even back to the closeness of our
earliest friendship, with Kay visiting me in State College last year and now agreeing
enthusiastically, and kindly, to take this trip with me (and a bit for me too, I suspect).
Everyone should have a Kay in their life.
Who else would:
>Gift me, on arrival, with a pair of white sunglasses, the better to look glam (or some
version of it!) by the pool?
>Gift me, soon after, with a Mandarin Oriental cap and fan pin (the fan being the logo of
MO), so we'd be decked out in full regalia as "Friends of MO?" This was all documented in
photos, of course. The cap had a decal on it that said "50+," which we soon realized
would become the theme of our visit: the anniversary of our 50+ years of friendship. This
theme was in part inspired by the emails I received from MO addressed to "Mr. Young"
and those Kay received addressed to "Ms. Silverman," and wishing us a happy
anniversary!
>Purchase an enormous, oversized stuffed rabbit in the hotel gift shop just because "she
had to have it?" She dubbed the rabbit...MO (Moe?) and we quickly anthropomorphized
                    1.577 / 1.901
him (her? them?), envisioning him screaming for dear life when stuffed into Kay's
suitcase for her flight from Miami to San Antonio, to visit her soon to be married son?
>Be dramatic, witty, uproariously funny, real, considerate, supportive, trustworthy, and
easygoing? Now I understand why we look giddy and gleeful in the photo taken of us
perhaps fifty years ago! Now I understand why we always stayed up half the night during
our sleepovers, digging deep into the existential questions! Study the present to
understand the past.
>Carry a clutch covered in green grass and wear funky platform sandals topped by a
huge tuft of brown fluff -- and adopt MO the rabbit --  because she insists she loves
things that "she can pat?"
>Ensure I felt comfortable and enjoyed myself?
"Parce que c'était [elle], parce que c'était moi."
The trip felt the antithesis of death-centric; au contraire, it was rejuvenating and life-
affirming. I actually felt...healthy? Kay suggested that I might do more of this type of
travel as it felt so vivifying. The travel, the prospect of which I had been nervous about,
was not unmanageable. Sedona, anyone?The trick: a wheelchair in the airport.
Yes, totally and completely self-indulgent I know. Don't hate me.
**********************************************************************************
Back to Department of ssdd: Have put off my new line of chemo for a few more days
since, on my return home, I discovered that my copay would be $700 for each
treatment, once every three weeks. Lily Oncology Support Center denied my application
for their Savings Card Program. I will take a few days to see whether I am eligible for any
other type of support. Of course, if Alimta does indeed turn out to be the silver bullet it
will be worth it, but...yikes. Meanwhile, I go without treatment.  Also, I continue to haggle
with Aetna about the $25K they billed me for my last two chemo treatments of 2022,
bills that I am appealing. I think big pharma + the insurance companies are conspiring to
kill me.

February 12, 2023 - More Miami
  by Willa Silverman, February 12, 2023  
                    1.585 / 1.901
                    1.586 / 1.901
Photos
                    1.587 / 1.901

February 21, 2023 - Headspace(s)
  by Willa Silverman, February 21, 2023  
Health update: Since returning from my fab trip to Miami recently, I started a new, and
ostensibly final, course of chemo last Friday: Alimta (new drug for me) + Avastin. One
treatment every three weeks; a three-day course of steroids + folic acid to help
                    1.607 / 1.901
absorption. A three-hour magnesium infusion this past week as my level was quite low.
No notable side effects yet except fatigue. 
March 13th will bring another brain MRI, as it's been three months since my last one.
Thankfully, as if my brain 'knew' I would need my energy to contend with
abdominal/stomach discomfort and fatigue, it has been 'behaving' the past few months.
That is, no crippling headaches thank goodness, although I may feel a bit of swelling in
the area of my cerebellum when I'm lying on my right side or on my back at night.
What happens after this course of chemo? How will this all play out? I don't know.
Another treatment option? Free fall? A miraculous feat of further survival? I'd love to
make it to the five-year mark in April 2024.
I am hanging in. I am feeling so-so. Some things are becoming harder for me. Lifting
anything even remotely heavy causes a tugging or tearing sensation in my lower
abdomen, where tumors are situated (I remember how difficult it became for me to carry
my briefcase to my car right before I was first diagnosed). My digestion is still a bit
wonky and I have to be careful (but drinking healthy smoothies in the morning with all
sorts of fresh fruit, yogurt, açai juice, flax seed etc. helps). I feel tired a lot but still
haven't tested the Ritalin I was prescribed.
I find myself in a rather strange 'headspace' now. I sometimes feel alienated in normal
social situations. Or perhaps rather, I sometimes feel I'm living in a bubble, on another
plane. I inhabit a resolutely existential space, dealing often 24/7 (yes, in my dreams too!)
with the most profound existential questions about mortality, legacy, suffering, love and
transition -- whether I'm walking through the peaceful garden at the Centre County
Memorial Park, recognizing the markers of fellow congregants who will one day be my
neighbors or sitting in a room surrounded by urns and caskets, discussing Jewish burial
customs with the director at the Koch Funeral Home (needless to say, my cultural
historian's curiosity was piqued by this convo).
I'm downsizing, simplifying, streamlining. The two wonderful young women who help me
out for an hour or two each day are organizing all my closets, opening up space. My
house feels airy, light, stripped of things that (pace Marie Kondo) do not 'bring me joy.'
This helps me so much psychologically. I'm also paring down my circle of acquaintances.
I hesitate to mention this as I think it sounds 'mean' but I'm involved in a process of
clarifying. In the end, it's not hard.
I am so grateful to the friends who have truly made the effort to understand my reality,
to 'hold space' for me through this journey and be with me physically when they can. I
hope you know who you are. Thank you for not fearing being afraid, sad, repelled, upset,
confused, disoriented. You certainly make me feel less alone. Without seeming arrogant,
I hope you feel in some way that it's a privilege to be part of this journey, and that it
                    1.608 / 1.901
might make it easier when you need to confront something similar down the line. You'll
have wise(r) perspective. So I hope I've been able to provide some type of service (dare I
say gift?) for you in that way. We've been lucky that way, I guess. In the end, these
relationships distill into love, authenticity, gratitude. And that's a magical thing.
I appreciate a good number of other well-wishers. Some I know less well than others, or
for less time than my oldest friends, so I understand the challenges (for you) of
translating emotions into words and actions.
Despite what I've written above, I remain very much 'in the world,' or perhaps 'between
two kingdoms,' as Susan Sontag observes in "Illness as Metaphor." A few gratitude-
inducing items, currently:
>Ben is here! For almost two weeks. He's working remotely and has installed his gentle,
helpful, calm, kind, caring, droll self in our home, in his bedroom upstairs. His presence
makes me feel so much better. Although it's become more difficult, I just *had* to do
some cooking for his arrival: homemade stuffed shells w/homemade sauce etc. and
Indian rice pudding (both came out very well but it's a heavy combo, perhaps my
inadvertent nod to Mardi Gras). This week I'll also make an Ottolenghi salad with braised
fennel.
>The small army of helpers who now pop in every day, *eradicating* the series of
dreams I was having about gigantic messes that I need to clean up while feeling
powerless and overwhelmed.
>My oncology nurses -- Brianne, Tracey, Rachel, Beth, Jess -- who have become friends; 
>The days are getting longer! I def. want to make it to fresh asparagus season, so I can
drive out among the Amish farms and buy armfuls of them for tasty asparagus soup.
>We're in the Pisces zone! I'm picking up on the energy of my moon sign (4 March), and
Michael's (24 February), and my nephew Isaac's (26 February), all born within less than a
two-week span (in different years, naturally). Something about '4' also feels significant:
Michael's bday is the 24th of this month, I'm the 4th of March, and Ben is April 4th (my
good friend Monique's bday is February 4th). I remember packing my bag for the hospital
on my birthday in 1995, thinking Ben might arrive two weeks before his due date. Turns
out he was two weeks late, had to be induced, and didn't arrive for a full month, while
my hospital bag sat in the corner. On the night he was born, we were shocked to see out
the window, perhaps a quarter of a mile from the hospital, a large, fiery burning disk. A
burning bush? An omen surrounding Ben's birth? Come to find out (as they say in these
parts) that the conflagration likely resulted from an act of arson committed by one of the
sons of Jerry Sandusky, convicted child molester and former PSU football coach. Strange
convergences...
                    1.609 / 1.901
How two Pisceans (Michael and I) ever raised an Aries son like Ben (confident leader,
determined, sometimes stubborn) is a mystery to me. However, Michael is *not at all* a
typical Pisces, unlike me (dreamy, creative, artsy, intuitive, mystical, spiritual etc.) and
must have his sun in a sign like Aries or Capricorn. I recently found out myself that my
sun is in Capricorn too, tempering my penchant for 'flowery thoughts' (as a social
scientist colleague once joked about me) with a highly tenacious, ambitious core. More
astrological musings another time.... :)

 March 6, 2023 - Birth Day
  by Willa Silverman, March 6, 2023  
                    1.613 / 1.901
                    1.614 / 1.901
Health update: I haven't felt bad since my last chemo infusion on 17 February. That is,
nothing acute (e.g. intestinal blockage, severe headache, clot etc.) has made its
presence known (but could any time, of course). Reason enough to be thankful. Tumors
in my lower abdomen make standing (or sitting, for that matter) for more than an hour
or two difficult - and painful. Fatigue fluctuates: some days I have to lie right back down
on the couch after breakfast, others I can make it through the day without a rest, take
care of business/work at my desk, run errands, visit with friends. Tomorrow I will meet
with Dr. Patel; I want to know how he sees the next few months unfolding, when he
thinks I should next have a CT-scan to see how my cancer is faring on the new line of
chemo etc. This Friday I have chemo + a two-hour magnesium infusion. Next Monday I'll
see my palliative care doctor and then undergo a routine brain MRI, which I'll then
discuss with Dr. Patel 'jeune,' my radiation oncologist, next Thursday. I am most anxious
about the MRI. Are there new metastases in my brain? Is the slight discomfort I feel at
night when my head presses into the pillow at certain angles 'something' - or nothing?
And if it's 'something,' what's the plan? Of course lying completely immobile for 45
minutes in a tube, agitated by the sound of violent jackhammering, is disconcerting and
stressful (time to practice the meditation techniques I picked up at the spa in Miami!).
The current treatment goal, to reiterate, is to contain my cancer and its spread. In the
best case scenario, perhaps we'll see some shrinkage of tumors and cancerous areas.
Any thought of 'cure' is off the table. In fact, I haven't received any good news on that
front (remission etc.) in about three years! Still, I soldier on. Living one day at a time,
while quite difficult, has proven the most effective strategy for staying in the now.
I attribute my feeling no worse the past two weeks, and in fact mostly relatively ok, to
Ben's presence and to seeing and hearing from so many friends around my birthday.
Plus, the fabulous vibe of the Miami trip has lingered.
I was glad to lift a glass to my son at my birthday party and declare, "Ben makes
everything better." I loved stumbling out of my bedroom every morning for the two
weeks he was here and having him come downstairs from his bedroom/workspace to
exchange a quick hug and greeting. He helped me out around the house, cleaned up
after the party, cooked me dinner (shakshuka), ran errands for me, brought me tea,
pitched in to advance my downsizing efforts -- all quite willingly! What we especially
enjoy doing together: a) cooking; b) watching the Knicks; c)collaborating on the NYTimes
Spelling Bee; d) hanging out. Ben also treated me to a cocktail at Pine Grove Hall, a local
place that is ambitious about its food (sometimes more successfully than others) and
libations. The place has two fantastic bartenders who mix serious drinks: they scoff at
anything overly sweet but do wonders with hard liquor+++. Sc'Eric concocted a drink for
me (on the spot) that featured applejack, crème de cacao, a few other ingredients,
within a salted rim. Very yummy.
                    1.615 / 1.901
Ben's doing well, and will soon be off to Vienna to ski with Sammi somewhere in Austria.
In early April, the two of them will return to NY together, as Sammi's year working at the
IAEA (International Atomic Energy Agency) will have come to a close. I'll be relieved
when both of them are back in the States.
The best things about birthdays, in no particular order: BUTTERCREAM. All the Facebook
messages, texts, cards, phone calls, DMs, bouquets, and emails, and the happy
adrenaline 'ping' each one brings. Being remembered. Spending time with loved ones.
Getting dressed up. This year, four gorgeous floral arrangements from Daniel Vaughn
(wonderful local florist) sent by special people. Parties!
When I was little, my mother arranged lovely birthday parties for me (with my younger
brother Ethan in attendance). We played games (pin the tail on the donkey, musical
chairs). I always had a cake from the Gramercy Park Pastry Shop, adorned with figurines
(usually ballerinas, maybe circus figures; boys' cakes, in those gendered to the max and
generally unwoke days, featured a baseball team or cowboys and Indians....) and
covered in BUTTERCREAM. In the late 60s (?) I had a paper dress party; often on a 'flower
power' theme, those mini-dresses were all the rage. Another year, when I was perhaps
11 to 13, my friends Eva and Zia gave me makeup! I was enthralled. Mary Quant (her
vibe was London's Carnaby Street, flower power, Twiggy, swinging 60s, cosmetics in
bold, daring purple and red) and Yardley. I remember a sticky orangey lip gloss in a
white plastic container. I felt so grown up! I've spent many birthdays in France, at least
two with student groups I was leading. One year (sans students) brought brilliant
sunshine but also wind and a bit of a chill; I took the day off and spent it gallivanting all
over Paris by myself, treating myself to lunch, chocolates, tea and a lemon tart - and
other indulgences. 
My party guests this year were eager to gab, meet people they didn't know, dance (a
conga line!), and direct their healthy appetites to a 'well-curated' (thanks, Deb, for that
description) selection of charcuterie, olives, pâté/cornichons, gougères, fruit salad, Italian
cookies from Veneiro's bakery in New York, and a spectacular cake -- chocolate layers
with mocha BUTTERCREAM, covered with BUTTERCREAM flowers and, as a nod to one of
my signature emblems, gold foil gingko leaves. And a teal cancer ribbon in fondant.
Veuve Clicquot, wine, and Negronis (which I love) mixed by a friend who has a way with
cocktails.
I am one lucky girl.
Let me die in a vat of BUTTERCREAM.
Someone conjectured that this birthday might be 'poignant' for me. Of course, I had the
passing thought: "What if this is my last?" Well, then I will have gone out like the
Montmartre revelers I wrote about a while back, carpe diem-ing, kicking their heels up in
                    1.616 / 1.901
the clouds. Or I could be that proverbial "they gave her a year but she lived for five"
person that we've all met or heard about.  Who knows? Again, living in the now means
not dwelling on the future when it's unnecessary. On my birth day, I felt energized by the
presence of friends and had a great time; I hunger for more days like this. But for now,
eat, drink, and be merry..... And eat the BUTTERCREAM first!

 March 12, 2023 - Experiences
  by Willa Silverman, March 12, 2023  
                    1.625 / 1.901
                    1.626 / 1.901
Back to the mood swings after the uplift of Ben's visit and much birthday cheer. But
that's just how we roll these days.
Had my regular check-up/check-in with Dr. Patel this past Monday. For the first time
ever, he asked whether I 'had my affairs in order.' I understand that this is a reasonable,
pro forma question to ask someone whose cancer is both advanced and metastatic, but
still, for some reason, it threw me. While Dr. Beavis has been the self-described
'quarterback,' with a clear sense of the layout of the entire field, Dr. Patel has always
been my 'kick the can' guy. For Beavis, the best case scenario in terms of survival would
bring me to Baltimore, alive and kicking, for an annual checkup this December; for Patel,
it's always been: "Here's the problem, here's how we're going to treat it." I had never
before heard him mentioning anything pertaining to an 'end game,' projected lifespan
(he won't go there), etc. Before now. Of course, he was simply doing 'due diligence' as
an oncologist, and also acknowledging that some folks simply can't face this task of
'tying up,' but need to for all the reasons. Still, not easy to hear.
He also told me not to be disappointed by the results of the next CT scan, to occur in
roughly 3-6 weeks, I believe. I've had so many lines of chemo that the cancer cells have
become very adept at mutating in order to not be targeted by the successive lines of
treatment.
Finally, I *think* I understood him to say, in response to a question I had, that at this
point an acute incident might become more likely as my disease is now more advanced.
I need to verify this: occasionally I miss a word or two of his due to his heavy Indian
accent and rapid-fire talk, but it's really just as likely (if not more so) that I was filtering
the info I was receiving. So now of course I'm nervous about being struck unexpectedly
by an acute event: intestinal blockage; double vision; migraine headaches, stroke. My
thoughts careen and I need to reel them in, stay in the moment (a mantra: "This is the
day I've been given. How do I wish to best use it?").
The mystery: I look good, as I'm often told, and manage to accomplish a decent amount.
I'm worried that things may become significantly harder, though.
Had chemo on Friday - second infusion of Avastin + Alimta plus two-hour magnesium
infusion. Quite tolerable. However, I did not sleep *one wink* the preceding night; I'm not
sure why my sleeplessness was so very extreme. It wasn't all unpleasant: I revisited my
middle school/high school years, with a vivid, extended focus on some of my wonderful
teachers. Mainly women, they were totally invested in our education (I remembered this
as I was going through and finally discarding many of my old school notebooks). They
were smart, serious, and many of them happened to wear dark rectangular glasses that
made them look particularly intellectual. They also formed, I realized, a fascinating
                    1.627 / 1.901
émigré community within our school: our dance teacher, Anita Zahn, a former student of
Isadora Duncan's sister, hailed from Germany; she lived in an apartment she rented out
in the hotel my grandmother owned, the Wales, across Madison Avenue on 92nd street;
Madame Tatiana Bouteneff, a tall, slightly haughty yet jovial French teacher, was born in
France to an aristocratic White Russian family, the Troubetzkoys; our wonderful, free-
spirited art teacher, Miss Basilevsky ('Miss Basi') was also (White) Russian; our stern,
rigorous Latin teacher, Miss von Heereman, had been, I believe, a member of the Dutch
Resistance during WWII (perhaps one of my NBS classmates can flesh this out a bit); our
History teacher, Mrs. Gordon, was French, the daughter of Edouard Morot-Sir, French
cultural counselor in New York. And another beloved, fiercely smart French teacher,
Madame Schless, about whom I now read in a NYTimes obituary:  "Edmee de M. Schless
of New Canaan, CT, and Lectoure, France, died peacefully of natural causes. Born
December 28, 1921, in Paris, as the third of nine children of the Count and Countess
Boula de Mareuil, she led a privileged life until the onset of World War II. Her older
brother, Camille, was an organizer of the Normandy resistance who was captured early
in the War. His notoriety forced the rest of the family to disperse and added to the
struggle and hardship that Edmée experienced during the War as she raised her two
youngest siblings." Madame Schless' brother's story is fascinating and tragic (if you wish
to know more, and read French: https://www.wikimanche.fr/Camille_Boula_de_Mareuil). I
wish I had known more about these intrepid expat women at the time.  Someone must
really write about them. Anyway, it was a night of mental meanderings, which left me
pretty tired for chemo, but I'm back on track with sleep now.
I also met with my lawyer and talked through some modifications I am making to my will.
This too left me stressed as I thought about the many details I still need to attend to. I
was able to go through just a few of these with Michael as he was driving me to chemo
yesterday and need to catch with Ben too. Death and taxes: dealing with both of these at
once right now. Yes, both are inevitable!
Brain MRI scheduled for tomorrow. I'm nervous. Thankfully, the past three months I've
avoided the telltale headaches that have tipped me off to likely brain mets in the past.
But I intuit there may still be 'stuff' going on, and how (or whether) we decide to treat it
is unclear. I'll discuss the results Friday with Dr. Patel the younger. If the results look
good, I am hungering (literally) for a trip to Paris, which Dr. Patel the elder seems to
support, as soon as possible after I know the scan results (I know this wouldn't
necessarily please Dr. Beavis...). I badly want to see my friends there, sit in favorite
spots and *feel* why they make me happy, shop on the rue des Francs-Bourgeois and at
Anne Elisabeth and La Petite Tonkinoise, and taste test tartes au citron all around town. I
want to immerse myself in the smells, sounds, and tastes of the marché d'Aligre. If I
have the energy, I'd love to view the new Sarah Bernhardt exhibit at the Petit Palais.
Wanna join me? Of course, this trip is a huge IF at this point, but it's fun to think about,
and who knows?... And maybe a few days in the city soon too, but again it all hangs in
the balance until Friday at least.
                    1.628 / 1.901
I feel I must double down on asserting my dislike for martial metaphors  in discussion of
serious/terminal illness (I was likely thinking about this at about 4 a.m. during my
sleepless night). Americans love winners (a generalization, I know). Ergo, 'winning the
battle,' or even fighting it valiantly etc., is praiseworthy. By implication, is the person
who 'loses the battle' a loser? Further, how do I construe my decision to kill off many of
my healthy cells (which might be construed as 'losing') in order to destroy even more
cancer cells? A Pyrrhic victory at best. My mind, emotions, and spirit, of course, are
doing everything imaginable to will my survival, but my body may simply not be able to
follow suit.
Having cancer is an experience.
Being a mother is an experience.
Going to graduate school was an experience.
Being a teen in New York in the 1970s was an experience.
Being a married woman was an experience.
Attending high school, attending college were experiences.
Living abroad was an experience; my travels, collectively, constitute an experience.
Like all the experiences mentioned above, my cancer journey is a longer-term
experience (to be distinguished from the many other types of experiences we can have).
Like the aforementioned experiences, having cancer features its own cast of characters,
evokes widely ranging emotions, conjures memorable moments and bleak ones, teaches
me. While the winner/loser trope does not resonate with me in the slightest (I think I'm
simply doing what most of us would do if we want to live, to thrive), the 'experience' idea
meshes nicely with my current beliefs. So let's just skip the whole 'fighting the battle,'
'winning/losing the war' etc. thing, ok?
Memorable moments this week: catching up with my high school friend Jane on Zoom; I
have an open invitation to visit her in Hawaii and it is tempting! A wonderful dinner with
friends last night -- delicious food and drink, lively conversation, warmth and
camaraderie.  Tea and cake at my house today with my friend Jackie, a wise woman and
compassionate friend (the cake I made was Namoura, a Middle Eastern semolina cake
aerated with yogurt and baking soda, soaked in a sugar, lemon and rosewater syrup, and
sprinkled with almonds and crushed pistachios).The two young women who come over
every day for an hour or two to help keep things running smoothly for me are
*godsends.*
                    1.629 / 1.901
Recent reads/viewings: Toni Morrison's _Beloved_ (why on earth had I not read this
masterpiece sooner?). Then saw the movie version with Oprah and Danny Glover (not
bad but nearly impossible to capture the narrative inventiveness and language of the
novel).  Joan Didion's _Blue Nights,_ a sort of pendant to _The Year of Magical Thinking_
(both very moving). _The Banshees of Inisherin_ (good acting and evocative
cinematography; also, great sweaters. Oscar worthy, though?)

March 19, 2023 - "How far off, I sat and wondered?"
                    1.632 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, March 19, 2023  
                    1.633 / 1.901
                    1.634 / 1.901
"I woke last night to the sound of thunder/
How far off, I sat and wondered."
This lyric from my high school years pairs well with my dream or reverie of a few
days/nights ago: I could hear/feel thunder rumble, but didn't know how far it was from
me. It felt ominous.
Sooo.... it was a bit of a medical-centric week. Monday I met with my palliative care
doctor, Dr. Vithalani. We talked a bit about my getting a medical alert system for home.
There wasn't too much of substance to talk about at this point, although I like and
appreciate her (although, to be honest, I think she needs to become more
knowledgeable about the types of cancers her patients are contending with). From there
I drove to the hospital for my brain MRI (with a pit stop en route to enjoy an Otto's root
beer float with mocha chip!). The actual procedure, which I've now undergone many
times, went quite smoothly. I was tired, so I just relaxed to the point of dozing, zoning
out the clanging and loud humming assaulting my head.
Tuesday, my mother underwent what was supposed to be an outpatient procedure to
regularize her heartbeat. From my brother's texts throughout the day, it sounded like a
stressful experience: my mother had to wait several hours for the procedure and felt
quite shaky afterwards, which resulted in her spending the night in the hospital. Of
course, I was concerned about this, but now my mom is home and feeling a bit better
each day. Her doctor will tweak her heart medications to bring her blood pressure, heart
rate etc. under control. Ethan's well-earned reputation as a mensch extraordinaire (a
great example to his nephew Ben, I must say, and undoubtedly to Ethan's own kids too)
did not falter throughout my mother's several days of travails (which could have been
worse, of course): when I called my mother after she returned home, Ethan was in the
kitchen cooking his yummy chicken soup!
Thursday I was at the hair salon. My hair continues to grow back and looks fairly decent
(although it's so short that when I wake up it tends to stick straight up, making me look
like Bello the Clown). Pic attached.
As I hadn't received the radiologist's report on my MRI by Thursday, I called and
requested that it be posted to my Mount Nittany Medical Center Portal. I didn't read it
until Friday, though, before my appointment with the radiation oncologist. Not quite
knowing what to expect (I knew, for example, that I hadn't had any severe headaches,
double vision, or loss of sensation in extremities for at least three months), I was
heartened by the sentence "No new areas of enhancement identified to suggest
progressive metastatic disease" and by the radiologist's "impression: Overall, stable to
decrease in size." The less good news is that, in going over the images with a fine tooth
                    1.635 / 1.901
comb, Dr. Patel the younger identified four tiny (1-2 mm) spots that were there before
but that have increased very slightly in size. He said we could wait three months to treat
them (after another MRI) -- essentially kicking the can -- or we could radiate them. It all
depends on my goals: do I want to treat every bit of cancer we safely can if it might
prolong my life and ensure the quality of it or do I simply not want to be bothered with
committing to five more rounds of radiation, having that awful mask made again, etc.
And I do wonder about $ too with the changes to our PSU insurance policy. I will likely go
for more radiation, which he said there is no rush to perform (I could wait up to six
weeks, potentially). The two Drs. Patel spoke; the elder told the younger (as the younger
reported to me) that I "look good" and could definitely manage more radiation at this
point. In any event, Dr. Patel (who I've come to like; he's kind, but a straight shooter)
does not consider this a 'bad' report, rather one that shows "subtle progression," in his
words. There are no new spots. The spots we radiated last time are gone. It could be
worse.
From there, I went straight to the ER (merely to the front entrance of the hospital as the
cancer center is located at its rear), a visit that was somewhat more vexing. I was hoping
they would scan my side/abdomen/stomach etc. to see if they could assess what was
causing my discomfort in those areas, and that's exactly what they did. There were long
waits for everything, of course, but overall I found the care perfectly competent, which
has not always been my experience at Mt. Nittany (including when Ben was born there). I
was fairly certain that the nice young doctor, Dr. Burton, was the same one who had first
detected my cancer on a dreary Easter Sunday in 2019, when I had come to the ER
because of severe constipation (due to lesions on my colon, I found out). I remember Dr.
Burton seeming shaken when he had reviewed that first CT-scan in 2019, because so
much cancer was present (I had shut down from shock). In any event, this time Dr.
Burton went through his records and confirmed that he was indeed the very same
doctor! I told him that I had had a good four years since he had seen me, and he was
very warm. I also could have sworn that the technician guiding me through the CT-scan
on Friday was the same one as in 2019, the one who had asked me, somewhat
ominously, I felt, "how long have you had this problem?" and who had wished me "good
luck" - sinisterly, it seemed to me, as I was being wheeled out of the scan room. This
time, I simply asked him how long he had been at the hospital and he responded twelve
years. Definitely a PTSD moment. And as my friend Andrew noted wisely, commenting on
a previous post, my assumption that this technician had 'secret knowledge' that gave
him some sort of power over me felt very scary. So much for that trip down memory
lane, lol.
Enfin -- the CT scan did not reveal an infection, nor a kidney stone (due to some blood in
my urine and discomfort/pain on my flank), nor anything of that nature. However, it did
show progression of my cancer, revealing a new spot on my liver and a spot on my lung.
The doctor felt this could be causing my discomfort, given where it is localized (although
Dr. Vithalani or someone told me that I was unlikely to feel pain from cancer on my
                    1.636 / 1.901
liver). Obviously, this is not great news, although not unexpected. The metastases,
though, make me quite nervous.
I was so exhausted from my day at the hospital, and the stress induced, that I went to
bed at 10 p.m. Friday and slept until 4 p.m. the next day! I had been given morphine at
the hospital, which lifted my pain and relaxed me, but on coming off it I was really wiped.
At 4 p.m. I heard someone knock on my door and then enter my house. It was Michael;
Ben had been worried that he hadn't been able to get in touch with me and was worried
(Michael was pretty sure I was sleeping; his intuitions on these things are usually quite
sensible). Unfortunately, my iPhone settings had also changed during the night,
preventing my seeing notifications of phone messages in the usual manner. I texted and
called Ben immediately as well as others who had been nice enough to check in. 
Voilà.
Current mood: very pissed off thinking about all the things I wanted to do (a list maybe
for another time) and all my goals that I will likely not be able to accomplish.
To improve my mood, I think I'll go to NY this week, provided I feel up to it. I want to
check on my mother and help her if I can, see family and friends as my energy permits
(also frustrated that I definitely have the *will* but am somewhat limited in what I can
do; Uber is my friend). On the other hand, as in my experience get-togethers with friends
have tended to energize me (as does my city), it's possible that this will hold true next
week.
Random stuff:
Re my last post: for my NBS pals: Miss von Heereman had not been a member of the
Dutch Resistance. She was born in Silesia, a German-speaking part of Poland, to an
aristocratic family and educated by private tutors, one a priest who taught her Latin. She
left Silesia via Switzerland because of the political situation, seemingly an allusion to the
rise of Nazism (per an NBS publication). So yes, I regret I won't have time to write a
book, or at least an article, about these fascinating expat women who educated us!
Reading: _The Remains of the Day,_ Kazuo Ishiguro. Oh my, what a novel.
I know that out of caring some of you wanted to get news of my MRI results as soon as
they became available. I appreciate your concern but please understand that I have to
do this on my own time. It's not that I want to withhold information but sometimes I have
a lot to process. I need to ensure that I have time to do this before sharing news with
anyone outside my family.
Not a whole lot of 'fun' this weekend, but I'm going to visit my friend Maria in her new
house later.
                    1.637 / 1.901
Photos

March 29, 2023 - "'Till I Collapse"
  by Willa Silverman, March 29, 2023  
                    1.640 / 1.901
                    1.641 / 1.901
It's been a minute. Apologies.
A rough day Friday the 17th, as recounted in my last post -- identification of four tiny
cancerous spots in my brain, to be radiated soon, followed immediately by an ER visit
that revealed via CT-scan progression of my cancer, w/additional liver and lung mets --
sent me (after I *crashed* for eighteen hours of sleep) into a panicked, desperate mode;
I felt I needed to go into overdrive to get 'everything' done within an ever-shrinking time
frame. When I calmed down, I simply decided that I needed to get away ('flight'
response?), needed a change of scene, of ideas. And I wanted to see my mother, who
recently underwent a heart procedure. So last Tuesday I got on the train to New York.
Time with old friends + family + favorite taste treats + the city both energizes and
relaxes me. It's a non-chemical mood enhancer and remedy. I needed it, and frankly,
sometimes I need to be in denial, to not think about my health challenges. At the same
time, while I did push myself a bit, I also made necessary adjustments (Ubers and buses
instead of the subway; get-togethers mainly near my mother's apartment, where I was
staying). I arranged ahead of time to see four of my oldest and dearest friends, two from
grade school -- Jill, with whom I traveled to Paris last May, and Zia -- and two from grad
school -- Isabelle (we shared thin-crust pizza, giggles and bubbles at Posto on 18th st.)
and Shanny (tea near Rock Center). One thing I love about these get-togethers is that
*there is always so much to talk about* because these friendships have such strong
foundations and long histories. And it just feels so great to spend time together, enjoying
each other's company: "Parce que c'était [elle], parce que c'était moi" (pace Montaigne).
My brother Ethan and I caught up over an Indian thali platter in 'Curry Hill,' then shopped
at international foods mecca, Kalustyan (I bought their store-made hummus, labne with
fig jam, and a small piece of halvah); it felt warming and familiar to hang out with my
brother and indulge in foodie activities in a corner of the city we grew up in. I also caught
Ben for dinner on the eve of his departure to Vienna to meet up with Sammi. They're in
Lisbon right now and will come home together on April 8th, at the conclusion of Sammi's
year in Vienna (I will be *so* happy when these two are back on US soil). After dinner
(ramen/sushi, mediocre) we visited with my mother for a while. Mom, Arnold and I also
had dinner at my mother's one night; Arnold, at 97, is off on a trip to the World War II
museum in New Orleans. He's amazing! Also loved taking in the smells and sights of
early spring both at the large Greenmarket in Union Square and along E. 17th st. near
Rutherford Place, where blooming magnolia trees looked lovely against a row of 19th
century brownstones topped with miniature figures of jockeys! Did some minor shopping
-- Sephora for shimmery eye shadow, Breads Bakery for babka (which I gifted a friend)
and one of their superior egg salad sandwiches. 
My mother's recent, usually outpatient, heart procedure to correct a-fib did not go
entirely as smoothly as expected (she wound up in the hospital overnight). She's home
                    1.642 / 1.901
and stable (has been going out in the neighborhood etc.) but still lacks energy in the
morning. I tried to help out as much as  I could -- cooked asparagus soup, ran errands,
accompanied her to an urgent care clinic one morning (she feels better now) -- and was
glad for the time I was able to spend with her. She'll have a telehealth appointment with
her cardiologist on Friday.
Back in PA, more uncertainty and anxiety. I was at the radiation oncologist's yesterday
for the CT-scan that Dr. Patel the younger will use to pinpoint the cancerous spots he will
then zap. I also had made, for the third time, that hideous Darth Vader mask that will be
used to bolt me down to the table; nothing like having warm plastic molded around your
face while you clamp down on a bit pushed into your mouth. But really, the brain
radiation is the least of my worries right now!
Drs. Beavis and Patel want to stop my current course of chemo (Avastin/Alimta) because
it's not working (as the CT-scan from the ER clearly indicated). So, no chemo this week.
Dr. Beavis is willing to try - as a final option (?) - a new chemo drug just authorized by
the FDA last December, called Elahere. It's so new that Dr. Patel senior has never
administered it. It works a bit differently from my previous chemo drugs (I forget how;
will need to look at Dr. Beavis' email). Dr. Beavis tested it on my tumor (of which they've
kept a sample at Hopkins!) and was glad to see that I have the 'correct' tumor type to be
able to receive Elahere. Questions: can it be obtained and administered in State College?
Will insurance cover it? How will I tolerate it? Dr. Patel's nurse emailed me yesterday and
suggested that perhaps I would start treatment w/Elahere at Hopkins because it may
take a while for my Geisinger facility to obtain it. I'll see Dr. Patel on Friday and will have
many questions for him.
Then there is the question of side effects. From my (granted brief, initial) reading about
Elahere, I have learned that a potential side effect is severe ocular degeneration. Dr.
Patel's nurse therefore informed me that my ophthalmologist would need to be on board
and I'd have to visit him frequently to receive doses of steroid eye drops under his
supervision. Oh my. Between Scylla and Charybdis: do I stop all treatment now,
hastening my demise, or try Elahere and risk impairing my vision, which provides me
with most of the agency I enjoy now (driving, walking, reading, writing, cooking etc.
etc.)? Need to find out more on Friday.
A few nights ago, I found myself again spinning towards panic and desperation and said
out loud, to no one in particular: "I'm scared." The next day I got a grip.
Physically, I'm feeling so-so. I have discomfort on my side that may be attributable to the
cancer in my liver. A heating pad helps. Clearly, my cancer is becoming more perilous
these days.
                    1.643 / 1.901
In a suggestive article in the NYTimes today, written by a palliative doctor, I read this: 
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/29/opinion/how-to-accept-death.html
"Reconsidering what we think acceptance means — and whether it will come to pass — requires loosening our
expectations of those who are dying. To become better at talking to one another honestly about death and to
truly prepare for it, we must first understand why we expect the dying to demonstrate readiness in the first
place."
In regard to what I wrote in another post about historical conceptions of "a good death," this doctor posits that
there is really no 'right way' to die, and that notions of 'acceptance,' death bed confessions, last-minute patching-
up of conflicts, etc., are -- like the martial metaphors applied to death that I've been railing against - ways for
some people to keep death at a distance, to fit it into a neat box and to deny its right to 'messiness,' to defying of
categorization.
This article resonated with me and in some way relieved me of the 'pressure' to have a 'good death' or even to
accept death. I realize I've been mouthing a narrative of acceptance -- perhaps simply to keep myself from going
off the deep end -- but not entirely buying into it. At the current moment, I'm finding it obscene and entirely
unacceptable that a vibrant sixty-four-year old woman with so many goals for her future and who savors life so
much should have to die. But then again, my moods and thoughts can change like quicksilver.
I took a peaceful country drive the morning after I returned from the city, another non-chemical antidote, this
one to the densely-packed streets and quick pace of New York. The sight of clotheslines fluttering in the breeze
on Amish farms; cows, horses, and sheep peacefully grazing; a buggy or two rolling by; the earth readying to
yield its first crops (maybe asparagus, spring onions, and rhubarb?) was a natural calmant.
And was happy to join three friends for dinner last night at Allen Street Grill, and look forward to having
breakfast tomorrow with my friend (and college classmate, and former State College resident) Heather, after
several years. And Passover is next week! A celebration of renewal and freedom!
P.S. More NY pictures to follow
P.P.S. Please know that I would really have liked to have seen other friends in the city, too. I am sorry that I did
not have more time and physical wherewithal to do so. 
.

much connection, joy, and celebration—quintessential Willa qualities—that it feels wrong
to lead with the negative in my comments. I am so happy that you followed your
