  —Melissa Beattie Moss, March 29, 2023  
I love that notion about how, as a consummate and trained over-achiever, one can even
pressure oneself to do dying the best way possible. I believe there is an inherent
impossibility: on the one hand one doesn’t want to give up treatment options, no matter
if they have uncertain probability of helping, yet one is also tasked with living one’s life
so that one is ‘ready’ and prepared to die. That’s too hard and mutually exclusive. If one
needs to face death and deal with it, that’s a load that’s sufficiently ambitious and
difficult to send one’s way and author one’s road/journey (excuse the mixed metaphors).
But if one feels time ticking and some pressure to be fully prepared and also, at the
same time, must deal with the huge difficulties of managing doctors and treatments and
the gauges of ‘progress’, that is also no small task. So we take someone who by the
nature of dying is alone and frightened and physically di is he’d and charge them with
both navigating treatment and being fully prepared to die…and we provide little support
and compassion around either task, and we end up flogging the prone to worry and
                    1.650 / 1.901
excess effort achiever with too full and too contradictory a set of tasks. We don’t help
people realize when they are best served working towards a good enough death and
relieve them of a sense of what steps the must accomplish and transition to the notion of
letting go and finding some inner acceptance and peace and stopping the harried and
desperate attempts to ‘fight’ and save one’s own life….and, instead, ask how they might
bring themselves some quiet, peace, relaxation, and relief in this chapter. No tasks to
accomplish, no tough decisions, no work to do…just the embrace of finding one’s way
into one’s sanctuary and maybe one’s sense of G-d and the wider world of existence
through time. How can one give oneself over into G-d’s protective care? How can one
use their tradition and it’s resources to pray and meditate and look for peace? And isn’t
that task enough? And don’t you deserve that? If you don’t stop the harried to-ing and
fro-ing and treatment roller coaster and turn to face G-d now, then when? In your last
week(s)? Why does that get squeezed into only a few days? It’s big and important work
and offers peace and solace. Nobody tells you it’s time to turn. But it is. One man’s
humble thoughts, my friend. You can say no more to running and chasing improvement
and being repeatedly disappointed. You can decide to turn and face G-d, instead, and
ask for peace and affirmation and comfort and even salvation (tho that may be a fraught
concept in Judaism). It’s time to relax and turn things over to G-d. My love and total
consideration and compassion are with you, friend. Go peacefully in the direction of relief
and support and peace and resolution and free yourself of the ‘must do’ feelings. You
aren’t waging war. You have no battle to fight nor jobs to do. Your job is to turn yourself
to G-d. Again, one man’s view. ��
  —Andrew Compaine, March 29, 2023

April 9, 2023 - Updates
  by Willa Silverman, April 9, 2023  
                    1.652 / 1.901
                    1.653 / 1.901
Again, it's been a minute. Much going on. But that's how we roll.
On the 31st, I had an appointment with Dr. Patel. Dr. Beavis had sent him information
about Elahere and I could tell that his staff (Kayla, his lead nurse; the nurses in the
infusion room; Dr. Patel) were motivated to educate themselves about this new (for
them, as only recently FDA-approved) drug and to gear up for the first infusion. I had
already pretty much come around to moving ahead with Elahere (what's the
alternative??), but remain nervous due to potential side effects, notably the ocular
toxicity (visual impairment, corneal damage, pain behind the eyes) that occurs in 60% of
the cases, according to one study I read (this damage reverses itself in about half the
cases, but if it doesn't?...). I will use two types of eyedrops (one a steroid) regularly,
beginning right before the first infusion. There are other unsavory potential side effects
too: neuropathy, GI issues, bone pain, fatigue and nausea etc. But I will try to move
forward 'courageously,' as Dr. Patel encourages me to do. He seems ready for this new
challenge, and that heartened me, too. Elahere has about a 30% effectiveness rate,
again according to a study I read. As a a folate receptor alpha directed antibody and microtubule
inhibitor conjugate (can some scientist remind me what this means?), it acts differently than the previous
chemo drugs I've been treated with. From what I understand, it is much more 'targeted,' affixing itself directly
to cancer cells rather than being released diffusely into the blood stream.  In any event, I'm scheduled
to have my first infusion this coming Friday provided the medication arrives in time. If it
doesn't, the infusion will need to be rescheduled for the following week. I should be able
to have all the infusions here and not at Hopkins, because it turns out we are able to get
the medication here soon. And we received word from Highmark that the cost will be
covered (yay!), although I don't know what the copay will be. Hopefully reasonable.
I also joined an online discussion group exclusively for women on Elahere; it's proving
fairly helpful.
Dr. Patel and I also discussed the significant persistent discomfort I'm having on my right
side, the issue that sent me to the ER a few weeks ago. He believes it is due to cancer in
the pleura (lining/coating of the lung). A heat pad helps, but damn it's uncomfortable and
I pray that Elahere can target some of the cancer there. In the meantime, the usual:
Tylenol, Oxycodone.
Then it was off to the eye doctor this past Tuesday to have my eyes checked. I was
happy to learn that my optometrist, Dr. Nelson, has been getting herself up to speed
about Elahere too (for subsequent visits, every three weeks, we agreed that I would see
the ophthalmologist in the group, Dr. Marcovich). Dr. Nelson's eye exam revealed a fairly
significant worsening of the vision in my left eye, which I had also detected, likely due to
the cataracts we had discussed at my last visit in January. "The next step is cataract
surgery," she said. Oy gevalt! On top of everything! We agreed, though, that we'd wait
                    1.654 / 1.901
to see what kind of damage Elahere does (or doesn't) before further discussing cataract
surgery.
Five sessions of brain radiation are also coming up. I expect a call early this week to set
them up, hopefully for this week and next.
I do wonder how much further the cancer can progress before it really begins to
incapacitate me.
Well, let's get on with it.
Despite this (bleak? overwhelming? how does it seem to you?) account of the upcoming
treatment plan, all in all I've been in pretty good spirits recently and have enjoyed some
lovely moments with friends: a really good talk with a friend (two, actually) currently
confronting health challenges due to disease. I feel a deep kinship with these friends,
almost as if they're the only ones who can truly understand what I'm experiencing
(physically, emotionally, psychologically); lovely Sunday dinner at my friends' Maria and
Greg's new condo, complete with 'Mama Rose's' (Maria's mom's) lasagna and meatballs
and Italian sausage in red sauce. A lively pre-Easter dinner party at friends' last night, a
couple of curly-headed boy toddlers running about (adorable!); fabulous food, featuring
some of the Mexican dishes my (Mexican-born) friend/colleague excels at: ceviche,
guacamole, salsa macha (a discovery). Glazed pork roasts that John scouted out in
"Trump country" (i.e. from a butcher way out in the boonies, although not too far from
here, who had just slaughtered the pig!). And lots of texts, emails and zooms with dear
ones. And Ben (who turned twenty-eight on the 4th) and Sammi (whose birthday is
upcoming in early May) are home from Europe! They had a great time visiting Lisbon,
skiing in the Tyrol, and hanging out in Vienna as Sammi finished up her stay there. They
tentatively plan to visit for Mother's Day and stay for a while. Other visits on the horizon
as well.
I want to report on Passover in another blog post. And also - in yet another post? - to
remember the Easter Sunday four years ago when a young ER doc at our local Mount
Nittany Medical Center, visibly shaken, conveyed to me that CT-scan imaging had
revealed sizeable masses in my pelvic and abdominal areas. The promise of 'redemption'
that Easter holds out seemed like a bad joke to me that day, and I am grateful to have
spent this sunny Easter Sunday relaxing, although not discomfort-free.
Photos

April 13, 2023 - Update
  by Willa Silverman, April 13, 2023  
                    1.665 / 1.901
                    1.666 / 1.901
Tomorrow beginning at 9 a.m. I'm having my first infusion of Elahere. While normally
that drug is infused for only thirty minutes, Dr. Patel has booked six hours for this first
treatment, between premeds (Benadryl, Zofran, Tylenol etc.), a titrated infusion of
Elahere, postmeds, and then a two-hour infusion of magnesium as my level remains
chronically low. In preparation for tomorrow, I've begun taking the two prescribed eye
drops, one a steroid, the other artificial tears. As I was instructed to give myself the
steroid drops every four hours, I had to jolt myself out of a deep sleep at 2 and 6 a.m. I
have to rinse and repeat for about a week, while also lubricating with artificial tears at
least four times a day. Today I feel foggy... although sitting in the sun (an unseasonable
84 degrees!) at lunch with my friend Kathryn felt relaxing. A FB page I joined for women
on Elahere is pushing the consensus many of them came to individually: take the steroid
eye drops during waking hours so as not to compromise sleep. I'd *love* this, but need
to check w/Dr. Patel first. If I can handle having my lung drained at 4 a.m., giving myself
injections for many months, draining fluid from my stomach area into bags dangling from
my body (also for many months), being life flighted to Hopkins, surviving a thirteen-hour
debulking surgery, a nine-hour fistula repair, and removal of a brain tumor....well then, I
can probably handle feeling groggy for a week every three weeks.
I simply don't want to leave the party.
I'll stay on Elahere (once every three weeks) until a)it proves ineffective (tbd via CT-scan,
I'm not sure when) or b)I cannot tolerate the drug.
And my next round of brain radiation begins next Tuesday: five sessions spread over the
next two weeks. If these treatments proceed as they did the first two times the side
effects were minimal. I remember some fatigue but that's about it. We are treating four
(I believe) very small (1-2 mm) cancerous spots, not tumors, so the effects should
normally be proportionally less disruptive and fewer.
I'm *marginally* more hopeful about Elahere as it belongs to a new class of drugs, more
targeted than their predecessors. But I have a lot of cancer in me. But there may be
scary side effects. Heading into year five of treatment while my disease has continued to
progress, I will only say  for now: "we'll see." Damn that pernicious, aggressive
carcinoma sarcoma that started it all.
****
Mary Quant has died! As much of the late-1960s 'swinging sixties,' hippie and 'mod'
cultures trickled down to me and my friends when were in our early teens, I remember
our being enthralled by Mary Quant's vivid palette and 'flower power' iconography when
we were just beginning to express our individuality (or, conversely, faddishness) with
                    1.667 / 1.901
clothes and makeup. I could have sworn I boasted some Mary Quant of my own, but
looking back at the info sheet I put together after my thirteenth birthday party in 1972, I
see that, along with incense burners, scented candles, Snoopy stickers, a poster, and
stationery, my friends Eva & Zia gifted me not Mary Quant but the brand that remains
intertwined with Mary's in my mind: Biba! No doubt I loved the plum eyeshadow and
mulberry nail polish that I would attempt to transform into (especially as I headed
towards high school)  a kind of goth (goth before goth), vixen-like, vampy, Stevie Nicks
wannabe look. I also see that Zia and Eva gave me (along with Revlon mascara and
'lemon lotion'), a Yardley Pot o' Gloss, when Yardley also conjured London Mod and lip
gloss was becoming all the rage. As with the genie's bottle, memories of those bygone
late 1960s/early 1970s (a particular source of nostalgia for me, perhaps because
experienced as the gateway to my teens) tumble from my Yardley lip gloss pot and Biba
eye shadow compact.
Photos

April 14, 2023 - Elahere Day 1
  by Willa Silverman, April 14, 2023  
I was heartened to receive so many CB messages, texts, and emails expressing concern
and support. I would love to thank each person individually but need to prioritize rest
right now. Please know how much I appreciate every kind gesture and thought; I'm a
lucky girl!
All went fine today. The procedure did not differ from what I'm used to: 2-hour
magnesium drip, pre-meds and solution (saline, Benadryl, Tylenol, Decadron, Zofran),
titrated Elahere drip (2 hours?). I spent six hours in the chair (and up and down a bit), ate
some lunch, dozed, sent a few texts. Dr. Patel swung by to see how I was doing; he
indicated that I might shorten the time between each dose of steroid eye drops to enable
me to have a (less) interrupted sleep. having been jolted out of a deep sleep at 2 and 6
a.m. the past two nights has done a real number on my circadian rhythms. My excellent
nurse, Brianne (who feels like a friend by this point), had been prepped extensively on
my treatment and there were no glitches whatsoever. Many thanks to Helen for the ride
to chemo this morning (the opportunity for a quick catch-up!), to Jackie for picking me up
(and swinging by Meyer's Dairy for the ritual post-chemo root beer float), and to Michael,
for bringing me dinner tonight (luscious grilled lamb chops, mashed potatoes and
zucchini). And to my helper Kelsey, who ensured my return to an orderly, neat, and
                    1.672 / 1.901
peaceful home. My new gingko-themed quilt (bien sûr) invited me to take a nap when I
got home, and I just woke up.
I don't expect to encounter side effects today but am prepared to take on whatever
Elahere throws at me in the days ahead. Tonight I'll crash on the couch and relax w/a few
shows that are tempting me (Mrs. Maisel and another I won't mention as it's pure,
addictive junk). :)
Thank you once again. We are interconnected branches of a vine that produces the fruits
we've been sanctifying this time of year. Good shabbos. It's a 'day to walk lightly through
the world.'

April 18, 2023 - Midweek update
  by Willa Silverman, April 18, 2023  
                    1.676 / 1.901
                    1.677 / 1.901
Thank you to everyone who's been checking on me this week. I'm hanging in. While
Elahere has not been 'a walk in the park' so far, the side effects have been manageable.
I've only had one day I would qualify as 'bad,' two days after my first infusion: GI issues,
abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, dehydration and fatigue. I couldn't do much more than
rest that day. Abdominal discomfort has continued but is under control; staying hydrated
as best I can and now taking Immodium (and soon, Lomotil). I also started my third
course of brain radiation today (!). Like the first two, it makes for a most uncomfortable
20-30 minutes as I'm literally bolted to the table by a tight plastic head mask (with a
nose hole for breathing, of course, very _Silence of the Lambs;_ speaking of which, a
heavily-guarded prisoner in an orange jumpsuit sat manacled in the waiting room,
awaiting his radiation treatment after mine!). I didn't realize I was so tired from the
radiation-chemo double whammy until I slept away most of the afternoon after I came
home. As hard wired as I am to feel pissed off about being 'unproductive,' I know I need
my 'sleep cure.'
Taking my different medications at the right time(s) (not my forte) is somewhat
challenging, but I'm managing that too. The first five days of my chemo cycle, I was
giving myself steroid eye drops six times a day and artificial tears (at least) four times a
day (it turns out I've been using the wrong type of artificial tears and had to buy new
ones - preservative free - today). After five days, I've dropped to steroid eye drops four
times a day and artificial tears (at least) four times a day. Soon I'll use only artificial tears
until the next infusion. All this involves getting up at least once during the night for the
drops. And there must be at least ten minutes between the two types of drops! On top of
this, I have to take an oral steroid an hour before each radiation session. My head is
spinning. I joined a FB page for Elahere users and it's proved quite helpful. Another
woman and I are basically keeping pace with one another (we had our first infusion on
the same day), and have been updating one another on how we're doing.
The discomfort on my side (pleura/ribs/lung?) has not abated and seems to stretch
around to my back. A heat pad provides relief. What is the end game in terms of this
particular hurt? I'll talk to my oncologist about it this week.
Yes, I'll see Dr. Patel on Friday. His nurse, Kayla, called me today to check on me and
recommend medication for my abdominal discomfort. I was grateful for her call.
All pretty exciting, huh? It's the end of the school year - my favorite time of year when I
was teaching - and I wish I were on campus for the various student awards ceremonies,
dissertation defenses, commencement, and celebratory rituals that helped power us
through all the final grading, tired but happy. And a row of hyacinths (or maybe lilacs?)
along "Deans' Walk" on campus perfumes the air divinely in late April. I've nicely been
invited to attend a few defenses via Zoom, will take a favorite student to lunch next
                    1.678 / 1.901
week, and will be on hand to help celebrate an esteemed colleague's (and friend's!)
retirement. So at least I will have a taste of end of year if I can't be more squarely in the
mix.
Will need to try to do something fun this weekend. Get together with friends. Cook or
bake (I am awaiting the first stalks of rhubarb and asparagus with bated...taste buds).
Take a drive. Watch a movie. Look forward to late April/May visitors, including Ben and
Sammi for Mothers Day, and zoom visits with a few friends on the west coast.
Time to go watch the Knicks.

April 24, 2023 - Update
  by Willa Silverman, April 24, 2023  
                    1.680 / 1.901
                    1.681 / 1.901
Elahere came back to bite me this past weekend, after a week of relatively smooth
sailing. Felt like some devil had gotten into my intestines and was squeezing, twisting,
and pulling. My entire GI system was cramping, rolling waves of intense discomfort (as
opposed to sharp pain). And fatigue. And nausea. And diarrhea. I could barely drag
myself to the couch Saturday and Sunday, where a heating pad numbed some of the
cramping while I steadied myself for the next wave of pain. A cocktail of Trazadone,
Oxycodone and Tylenol PM (ok'd by my doctors) helped me sleep -- for fourteen hours
Friday night. No appetite, have hardly eaten anything in close to four days (and am
about four pounds lighter) but have been keeping hydrated. Tonight I'll have some
Chinese chicken noodle soup; the warm broth is appealing.
Initially, I couldn't figure out the source of my discomfort. Elahere? A stomach or
intestinal blockage? Consequently, I couldn't figure out how to treat it. Antacid?
Immodium? Nothing? Liquid diet? A trip to the ER (which I was seriously considering)? I
decided to query the online chat group for Elahere users that I recently joined. Several
women confirmed that they had experienced the exact same symptoms as I was having.
One said she simply relied on Tylenol to provide relief. Another reported powering
through on Oxycodone. So I experimented with taking some Oxycodone during the day
(and not just 5 mg at night, when I usually take it); that helped. Today I'm feeling
somewhat better but not completely. It's a reminder to me that these symptoms can hit
unexpectedly.
I was in so much physical distress that I questioned whether I was "fighting to live"
rather than "living to fight." My thought was that if this distress continued through the
three cycles of Elahere before CT-scan, I would call it quits at that point. But today I felt a
bit better and I put away that thought.
I was also at the hospital for two radiation treatments this past week (with three more
upcoming this T, Th and Fr). I only experience fatigue from radiation, although three
treatments in one week may be a rough go. Instead of asking to keep tuned to the overly
mellow playlist piped into the radiation room, with Peter, Paul and Mary crooning about
"leaving on a jet plane," I requested 70s' r&b and disco! As I was being bolted to the
table, KC and the Sunshine Band were teasing, "That's the way, uh huh uh huh, I like it,
uh huh uh huh." All I could think was "This is NOT the way, uh huh uh huh, I like it. I do
NOT like this at all, nuh huh nuh huh!!"
On Friday I met with Dr. Patel to assess how my treatment is going so far. At this point,
he's all about my living my best life: "Just go, go, go, just do, do, do!" Even Paris if I feel
up to it, which remains to be seen. The one matter I'm concerned about (he seemed less
so, although he's keeping an eye on it), are two elevated liver markers (ALT and AST),
indicating liver damage. They may be elevated as an effect of the Elahere, the cancer, or
                    1.682 / 1.901
some combination. It's imperative that I keep well hydrated. The thought of liver damage
makes me anxious.
Despite not feeling well, I managed to rally to keep all my weekend plans: a lovely
retirement reception and dinner for a spectacular colleague in English, my friend Cheryl;
a play, _Emilia,_ with my friend Maria, about a female poet of Shakespeare's day, largely
lost to history; and a catch-up visit from my friend Monique. I also made my first batch of
the season of strawberry-rhubarb sauce, and bought raw cream off a farm to serve with
it. My 'rhubarb reconnaissance mission' took place on a glorious April day - fields the
color of limes, early blooms in purple, yellow, and beige -- that had me headed to the
large Belleville Wednesday market (ignore all the awful Trump flags and firearms for
sale! head straight for the rhubarb!) and meandering along back roads. "Whan that April
with his showres soote...." I still remember those fifty first lines of the Prologue to _The
Canterbury Tales_ that my schoolmates and I had to memorize, and I'll bet they do too!
I'm very excited for the visit of my grade school friends, Zia and Eva, this weekend.
They'll take Amtrak from New York. We'll open the voluminous archives -- letters,
journals, photos, notes, stories, 'birthday books' and more we've kept and exchanged
over the years -- and revel in this precious circle of life moment.

April 28, 2023 - Quick update
  by Willa Silverman, April 28, 2023  
...before I head to Lewistown to pick up my girlhood friends, Eva & Zia, arriving on
Amtrak from New York. I am super excited about their visit, which will involve a good
amount of 'hanging' and reminiscing via our abundant personal 'archives' (especially as
rain is predicted all weekend).
                    1.688 / 1.901
I am done with my third course of radiation! Fifteen treatments in all, targeting spots in
my brain. Everything seems to have gone well and I'll have an MRI in three months, for
reimaging. I'm not sensing any cognitive deterioration at all (as mentioned, Dr. Patel the
Younger and the man known only as The Physicist target the spots ultra-precisely so as
not to damage any healthy tissue). As always, I simply feel tired (however, the steroid I
take before the treatment is guaranteed to mess with my sleep tonight, as it did last
night, as it will next Friday night post-chemo). Dr. Patel hopes he won't have to see me
again for more radiation (as do I), but we'll always be keeping an eye on it.
For my musical pleasure during radiation, yesterday I requested all Bob Marley and
today all Handel. I felt Handel would work well on this rainy day (>calming, melodious)
following a night of poor sleep (>rousing and uplifting>_Water Music!_).
I've been lubricating my eyes diligently and hope the next infusion (a week from today)
will not bring about any of the ocular toxicity I've been fearing.
Monday I'll have a long infusion -- two hours of fluids + two hours of magnesium. I'm
glad to be receiving hydration this way as, no matter how much I drink (and I likely could
drink more, although I try!) I still tend to feel dehydrated.
Fun stuff this week: attended via Zoom the (successful) dissertation defense of a student
I worked closely with until I retired; W lunch at India Pavilion with a favorite undergrad,
soon to be a graduate and off to work for a year as a public educator at Neuengamme
concentration camp; beer and quesadillas creekside at Voodoo Lounge with my friend
Ted (who eons ago was my student); cooking (more strawberry-rhubarb sauce; soon:
cream of asparagus soup!).
I seem to be encountering a striking number of folks (in my approximate age range)
dealing with different types of cancers right now. Did we work so hard to be successful in
our careers and parenting that our immune systems were compromised? What is going
on?? I wish every one of them a return to wholeness of body and spirit.
Lunch this coming Tuesday with my dear '3Cs;' very much looking foward.
Shabbat shalom everyone.

 May 3, 2023 - Mercury retrograde
  by Willa Silverman, May 4, 2023  
                    1.690 / 1.901
                    1.691 / 1.901
Health update: unfortunately, still hindered by debilitating GI discomfort, a side effect of
Elahere, but trying to stay glued together with Oxycodone and Tylenol. Rest, heat pad
help; had two-hour infusion of fluids on Monday for extra hydration. At the same time,
allowing myself to feel a *smidgen* of hopefulness on seeing a)my magnesium level
climb to almost normal (it's been as low as .9 and as high, this past Monday, as 1.4;
anything 1.5 or above is considered normal and I'd been hovering at 1.2 or 1.3 for
weeks); b)my liver enzyme markers (ALT and AST) plummet (a good thing) where the
previous week they'd been alarmingly high; c)something else that I deem 'tmi' in this
context but that is normally a sign of improved liver/pancreatic health. So tomorrow I'll
start prepping for infusion #2 of Elahere on Friday: lab work; steroid eye drops and
artificial tears 6x/day. Praying my eyes (specifically, my corneas) are not affected;
hoping for no worsening of neuropathy, GI woes etc. For now, I won't create worries.
Update (Thursday): good liver enzyme marker numbers maintained after labs this
morning.
*******
With Mercury appearing, as it does right now, to travel backward across the sky, we
should refrain from embarking on new endeavors, signing contracts, succumbing to
travel mishaps, and over-relying on technology. This much my girlhood friends, Eva and
Zia, and I agreed upon as we revisited our common belief in astrology en route to the
train station in Lewistown. Instead, this may well be a propitious time to look backwards,
take stock, review past errors -- which is exactly what we did during our magical
weekend together.
As became clear over the weekend, both my friends have 'reviewed past errors' over the
decades, whether in their personal, professional, or familial lives-- and conquered them
with accomplishments, mental, physical and emotional grit, courage, clear-sightedness,
and intelligence . It's not been easy. All three of us are confronting health challenges
right now. I think we're pretty badass.
I am so proud of these women.
We were eleven (in 1971) when we met (Eva and Zia had just enrolled in our private
girls' school in NYC and had even had acting roles in a movie, _Savages,_ before that; I
had attended Nightingale since second grade); we soon became the closest of friends. I
must have been drawn to these girls with such interesting heritages (Indian: Zia; German-
Iraqi: Eva). These girls with the larger than life mothers: Zia's is Madhur Jaffrey; my dog-
eared copy of _An Invitation to Indian Cooking_ introduced me (and likely millions of
other Americans) to a spectacular world of tastes, smells, colors, and spices; Eva's mom,
Angelika Saleh, lent her name to the legendary cutting-edge art movie house on Houston
St. 
                    1.692 / 1.901
The anticipated centerpiece of the weekend was a plunge into our pasts, via dozens and
dozens of letters exchanged among Zia, Eva and myself from ages eleven to eighteen
(1971-78), sent from Delhi, Germany, New York, Amherst, MA (where my father taught
summer school one year), Maine, the Hamptons (an au pair gig for Zia), Cambridge, MA.
Missives communicated on every variety of stationery: air letters, cute writing paper
decorated with lemons (and smelling of them too), birds, hearts, flowers (is stationery
even a 'thing,' anymore?); as a teen, I fill up every available cm of paper with my writing,
as I still do! Photos, diaries, and documents -- among them Zia's meticulously prepared
'data sheet' on the science teacher many of us were crushing  on, Mr. Mann, which
conveyed such observations as "Likes water," and detailed our forays to his apartment
building where we got on our bellies in front of his apartment door and tried to
detect...any signs of movement within from the slit on the bottom. The driving rain this
past weekend provided the perfect backdrop for this memory plunge (punctuated by two
delicious dinners featuring Indian shrimp and also cauliflower, thanks to Zia), and we
veered between convulsive laughter (the Mr. Mann document), tears, incredulousness,
and fascination. Was this really us?
Saturday night, I went to bed around 11, leaving Eva and Zia to begin scanning the
letters until 2 a.m.; I awoke the next morning to  find my friends in the exact same spot
in my sunroom, scanning away on just a few hours of sleep! Such an act of love and
remembrance. If I had more time (ie a longer life expectancy), I'd consider drawing on
our archive to craft a longer piece.  My historian's skill set would come in handy but how
to render the emotional charge of all this?
We are constantly self-berating and apologetic: for our 'sloppy' handwriting; for the pen
that is running out of ink, our 'boring' summer, our 'boring' news (Zia: "Well, don't fall
asleep...;" Eva from Munich: "I'm getting really bored here;" Eva from New York: "I'm
very bored here, but Zia will be here soon;." Eva finds her letter to me so boring that "I
should have told you in the beginning to rip it up."). Zia claims to be "getting uglier by
the minute." Was this a sort of 'trope' of our correspondence or were we really so lacking
in confidence? I worry.
We are touchingly, almost desperately loyal, constantly proclaiming our status as best
friends (Zia: "I'm so glad you write, for I have never had a more faithful friend;" "Always,
let's be friends, of the best kind."); fretting about what it might 'mean' when
experiencing radio (or rather, epistolary) silence from one of our classmates ("all my so-
called friends are not writing!"), as during the summers in which we were totally
dependent on the mail service for communication; always on guard for 'betrayals' should
one of our classmates turn on us (this did indeed happen, as revealed in a shunning
letter one of the popular girls in our class of twenty-five sent to me and Zia, and perhaps
Eva). In no uncertain terms and in the written equivalent of a scream, she advised us to
"FORGET IT" (ie having a friendship), since we apparently had placed certain conditions
                    1.693 / 1.901
on this relationship. Mean girls - wow. "ARE YOU STILL MY BEST FRIEND??"
We are semi-tuned in to current events, the Watergate trials and Nixon's resignation in
August 1974 topping the list --  scandals that Zia, last weekend, correctly deemed
'quaint' by today's standards.
We are precious, precocious, and pretentious (yet in retrospect, impressive!) young
teens. Zia, at fourteen, is reading Hemingway (as am I, apparently: "you too have been
reading Hemingway"), Hugo's _Les Misérables,_ Paton's _Cry, the Beloved Country,_
Truman Capote, and  _The Chosen,_ yet she finds the portable Faulkner "a bit much"
(LOL). I'm trying to convince her to appreciate Renoir, whom I've recently discovered: Zia
finally demurs after viewing his work at the National Gallery in London: "He certainly was
talented" (LOL). Both these fourteen-year-olds will become writers and teachers, though
of slightly different ilks. Eva is playing Mozart sonatas with her grandfather in Germany. 
Strong, smart, talented, and insightful, she'll remain engaged with film for many years
before becoming a successful insurance broker specializing in personal property in the
Hamptons.
We are children of the 1970s: "Bridge Over Troubled Water," the Carpenters, the Beatles'
_Revolver,_ incense burners, candles, Biba eye shadow, bell bottoms, catch phrases ("ya
dig?!").
We  constantly have sleep-overs at one another's houses. We have lots of crushes.
There is something about a "rhinoceros' toenail," alluded to several times in the letters,
that we all find side-splittingly funny.
We have nicknames for one another: I am "Susi" (why?), 'Willie,' and 'Willy,' Eva is 'Evy.'
I am so grateful for these girls.
I am so grateful for these friendships.
It occurs to me in writing that perhaps our childhoods -- or the fragments of them that
live on to spark further memory -- weren't all that unusual. Maybe they're not even all
that different, in some ways, from those of NYC girls today attending one of several girls'
private schools on the UES.
So what was so special about my childhood?
It was mine.
******
                    1.694 / 1.901
Coda: Zia, fifty-two years ago: "Are you saving all your letters from me? I'm keeping all
of yours."

May 8, 2023 - Quick update
  by Willa Silverman, May 8, 2023  
Thankfully, I seem to have averted, so far, the worst side effects of last Friday's infusion
(my second with Elahere): the horrendous stomach cramps that felt like a massage of
my intestines  -- and not in a good way. I do have some stomach discomfort and bad
diarrhea (hopefully not tmi? Cancer has made me lose any iota of  embarrassment  I
ever had about my body and its functions!). This last symptom also means dehydration
that I'm always trying to combat, and  may call for another infusion of fluids, like last
time. Otherwise, I'm fatigued, but that symptom's been worse before, too.
Next infusion: Friday, May 26. Then, presumably, a scan. I'll be curious/anxious for the
                    1.710 / 1.901
results. Some women in the Elahere FB group I joined are reporting improvements,
others not. As Elahere may be my 'chemo of last resort,' I'll be directing my fervent
wishes towards stabilization or reduction of my cancer load. Needless to say, a 'cure' is
off the table. My goal is to stay alive and enjoy a decent quality of life.
I really want to sneak off to Paris for a week or ten days after my third infusion. Maybe?
I felt well enough yesterday to briefly attend a brunch in honor of one of my former, and
favorite, students, Casey, whose career at Penn State has been nothing short of
phenomenal. I worked with her as a freshman in my course on France and the Holocaust
in Film and Literature (she also participated in the Holocaust-focused weeklong trip to
Paris I led over spring break 2019 - right before I was diagnosed). A student in the
Schreyer Honors College here (from which Ben also graduated), Casey has taken
advantage of every opportunity to learn, grow, and investigate future career
possibilities; this led her to study abroad experiences in Paris, Poland (a Holocaust-
focused trip), Israel (archaeological dig), and Curaçao (museum work). She won first
prize from the PSU libraries for her BA/MA thesis on Jewish communities in central
Pennsylvania. Next year she'll be a public educator at Neuengamme concentration
camp. In any event, It was delightful to be able to honor Casey and also to feel a bit back
'in the mix.' It made me realize how much I miss and feel energized by helping students
achieve their goals.
I've made a nice connection through the online Elahere group: a woman named Karen
whose treatment follows the exact same schedule as mine (she also had her second
infusion of Elahere last Friday and we are checking in with one another about side
effects). Karen is a poet living in the Boston area. I read several of her poems about
cancer online and find them quite affecting: https://donyorty.com/2023/04/30/karen-
friedland-reads-from-incurable-inoperable-poems-and-notes-from-a-deadly-diagnosis/. It
feels comforting to be in lockstep with another Elahere user/kindred spirit of sorts. We
seem to have a lot in common!
I greatly look forward to Ben and Sammi's visit this weekend. They usually prepare a nice
Mothers Day breakfast for us (I couldn't resist ordering some very pretty petits fours
from The Cakeshop by Tati), which we'll follow with a jaunt in the country (to discover
one of PA's charming covered bridges? a greenhouse? an antiques store?) and perhaps a
beer at one of several new breweries in the area. Ben has made time to help me tick off
one of my very few bucket list items - any guesses? And Sammi and I will enjoy a girls'
spa day at the lovely Omni Bedford Springs Resort, a haven for 'curists' in the late 19th
c..

May 15, 2023 - Mayday/May Day(s)
  by Willa Silverman, May 18, 2023  
It's strange how joy and suffering can coexist. "Mayday!" calls can pierce the stillness of
the most joyous, serene May days.
One morning last week, I awoke sensing that my eyesight had precipitously declined, as
all surrounding me was a blur. I was fairly certain that a frightening side effect of
Elahere, ocular toxicity, had gotten hold of me and hung over me like the sword of
Damocles. Strangely (or not), many of the women reporting this symptom pinpointed its
inception at about ten days past the second infusion (this was my case too). Fortunately,
I had an ophthalmologist appointment just a few days after this. Dr. Marcovitch
confirmed that both my corneas were damaged; the right one, he said, was damaged so
badly that it fell below the minimum strength legally required to drive. Fortunately in PA
you only need one 'good' eye to drive. I'm managing to drive when necessary, although
my eyesight's somewhat blurry; Ben and Sammi felt understandably nervous about my
driving back from the train station in Lewistown (about 25 miles away) after depositing
Sammi there, but I knew that if I couldn't get out and about on a beautiful May day, I'd
become depressed. No amount of attempting to see clearly with glasses, without
glasses, with or without sunglasses etc. really helps as my vision has changed so
radically, so suddenly. But I'm managing. Dr. Marcovich advised me to get back on the
steroid eye drops four times a day, every day (instead of for only ten days out of the
month); I'll go back to him on Monday and see if this has helped. I hope he will take
some time to get up to speed on my problem; he doesn't seem to know much about
Elahere and its effects (in fact, he had to Google information about it while I was there!).
This condition (keratitis is the generic name for corneal damage) is supposedly
reversible; at the same time blindness is another potential side effect of Elahere
infusions (!) but I've not heard of anyone going blind from this drug. Talk about being
between Scylla and Charybdis... Meanwhile, I'm forging ahead, like the Knight in _Monty
Python and the Holy Grail,_ who remarks, after having his arm severely wounded and
squirting abundant blood in a sword fight, 'Tis but a scratch.' LOL.
                    1.713 / 1.901
I'm supposed to have my third infusion next Friday but I suppose we'll have to see how
my eyes are faring. I'll see Dr. Marcovich again on Monday and he'll examine my
corneas. If there's still severe damage, I am not sure whether Dr. Patel will want to wait a
week or so until my eyes improve (presuming they improve), before proceeding to the
next infusion.
I am also continuing to experience on and off the terrible GI cramping brought about by
Elahere, sometimes accompanied by chills (but no fever). It's tiring and I feel better
when I'm experiencing this discomfort if I lie down. The cramping etc. has been so bad a
few times that I've thought of giving up, but then remind myself that the bad days are
(usually, up to this point) followed by better/good ones. And when the good ones arrive,
I'm angry at myself for even thinking of calling it quits.
I'm putting the brakes on certain plans until the above-mentioned issues are resolved.
While meeting with my palliative care doctor last week, she told me that a therapist
specializing in oncology patients has joined the oncology team at Geisinger. I have an
appointment with her on the 31st as I'd like to see what she could bring to the table that
might help me. Although I have a very good therapist with whom I've worked with for
over a decade and whom I see every other week, I am curious to explore this new
avenue too.
May days: Ben and Sammi temper the suffering with joy and bring much serenity,
energy, helpfulness, and happiness to our home. They helped make my Mother's Day
wonderful, as we've been celebrating the holiday together the past several years. For
brunch, they made me farm fresh eggs (so yummy!) and bacon (also from a local farm),
fruit salad, bagels, smoked salmon and cream cheese, and creamed herring and pickles
from Shelsky's in Brooklyn. I bought, from the marvelous Cake Shop by Tati, the most
delightful and delicious petits fours, coated in icing and piped spring flowers, with moist
cake layers separated by jam. We then sat by the creek in Spring Creek Park, enjoying
the sun and the pretty pastel colors of spring (green, pink, white). Following that, we
returned home where we caught the second half of the Celtics-76ers game (it's all about
the NBA playoffs in our house these days), then ventured out again to a new brewery in
town to enjoy a frosty beer in radiant sunshine. Despite all the satisfaction I garnered
from my career (and my career was going gangbusters when I was diagnosed, sigh...), I
still think motherhood is the best gig ever and am eternally grateful for my child.
Tuesday Sammi and I enjoyed a 'girls spa day' at the Omni Bedford Springs Resort, about
a 1 1/4 hour drive from State College. My grad school besties Vinni and Isabelle, and I,
had spent two wonderful days last year hiking the trails on the property leading to
various springs (which attracted all manner of 'curists and tourists' in the 19th century),
dining in a nice Italian restaurant in the cute town of Bedford, cooking s'mores over an
outdoor fire pit, drinking champagne, indulging in spa treatments and a wonderful
                    1.714 / 1.901
variety of baths and sauna, and purchasing a few of the spa's signature bath products,
all honeysuckle based. One day not long ago I had the thought that a spa day would be a
nice birthday treat for Sammi, a relaxing getaway for me, and an opportunity for me to
catch up in depth with Sammi about her recent year in Vienna. We both luxuriated in
'spa pedicures' featuring all kinds of scrubs, rubs, lotions, leg massages, then polish (a
Merlot color for me, pastel blue for Sammi). We ate lunch outside (pretty day but turned
a bit cloudy) and looked at some of the memorabilia in the historic hotel (the guest
register on display featured both Presidents James Buchanan and James Polk). Then we
headed back to the spa for a good hour of showering, soaking in both hot and cold tubs
featuring jets directed at different body parts - shoulders, neck, lower back etc.,
sweating in the sauna infused with eucalyptus oil, and finally relaxing in a tranquil room
with potted palms, comfy chaises, soft throw blankets, pitchers of cucumber water, fresh
strawberries... I think I snoozed a bit. Otherwise, we gabbed the whole time (Sammi
drove both ways due to my vision problems). It was delightful to spend the day with
Sammi.
On the way home, I stopped off to vote in our municipal elections. Every election is so
crucial. I'm pleased to see that a progressive slate of school board candidates won their
election.
On the way home from dropping Sammi off in Lewistown yesterday, I stopped at several
farms and the big farmers market in Belleville, found some good-looking asparagus from
someone's uncle's farm. I've made asparagus soup and tonight am making an Ottolenghi
asparagus salad with an interesting-sounding dressing/topping. Maybe an asparagus
galette soon?
Other May days stuff: a visit from a dear friend I hadn't seen in quite a while; lunch at a
Venezuelan place with my friend Kathryn followed by a walk in Thompson Woods
Preserve, which I did not know about.
Tomorrow is 'bucket list' day. I hope it's fun and that I have the stamina for it. No,
Melissa, it's not a ride in a hot-air balloon but that's a great guess! :)
[Having difficult uploading pics. They will follow.]

May 20, 2023 - A Creek Runs through it
  by Willa Silverman, May 20, 2023  
                    1.736 / 1.901
                    1.737 / 1.901
Over my many years of driving along backroads in central PA, I've delighted at the
figures, seen in miniature from afar, which render the surrounding landscapes
picturesque and serene: Amish women stooped over to  hoe their vegetable gardens or
collect eggs from their chickens; farmers rolling up bales of hay; Amish children playing
in the yard of a one-room schoolhouse or seated in a cart, led around the backyard by a
miniature horse. These charming figures, a bit idealized and precious, always called to
mind for me the residents of medieval fiefs illustrating the famous medieval book of
hours, The Very Rich Hours of Jean, duc de Berry (Les Très Riches Heures de Jean, duc de
Berry) or, in an Art nouveau vein, the women picking flowers or raking leaves throughout
the year in the calendar illustrated by Eugène Grasset, Les Mois.
In the spring and fall, sightings of anglers in the network of creeks running through
Penns Valley have also enchanted me. Casting, catching, or simply standing waist deep
in the chilly creek, these solitary figures dotting the water, dappled by sunlight or
shrouded in mist, seem enveloped in a blissful stillness, a state of Zen. Less ambitiously,
kids and adults dangle all manner of fishing rods into the creek from embankments lining
it.
And so we arrive at my one and only bucket list experience (sure, there are lots of
others, but they're currently beyond my reach). Accompanied by Tess, our most
excellent guide, Ben and I spent the day learning how to fly fish for trout in a creek
reputed internationally for this activity. At The Feathered Hook in Coburn, PA, ground
zero for all things fly fishing in these parts -- which also boasts a bed and breakfast and a
lodge for the many anglers both skilled and novice, corporate groups, and others -- we
were given waders, extremely heavy boots, and a wading stick. Tess took us to a spot
that she intuited would yield trout (catch and release). She explained why Penn's Creek,
which is something like twenty-seven miles long, is such an appealing body of water for
anglers: a microclimate filled with the types of insects trout like to feed on, for example,
and ultra-clean water boasting a specific Ph-level. Once we had entered the creek and
walked to about the middle of it (a folding chair was an enormous help for me), Tess
taught us the basics of casting relying on something called "European technique," which
seemed so complicated initially that I almost gave up before we started ("nevertheless,
she persisted"). The exact positioning of the rod and the fishing line, of the body in
relation to the water, the speed at which the line is dragged through the water, every
detail is calibrated. Getting the fish in the net once caught seemed to require even more
precision. Tess gave Ben a bit more instruction than me (as I had expected); advising
him to take three steps to the left, one step forward, etc. and to cast his rod towards a
rippling and roiling spot, which the fish apparently like because of the oxygen pockets it
creates. He looked very much the natural. I was perfectly content to sit in my folding
chair casting, although I did change position several times (my badly compromised
vision, about which more later, was a challenge). I took several breaks from fishing to
                    1.738 / 1.901
simply savor the environment: the clear, cold water; birds chirping; verdant trees lining
each bank; and blue sky (until it turned cloudy). We bantered with the anglers walking
by, asking how many fish we had caught.
We caught five! Ben 4, Willa 1. Ben caught one rainbow trout and three brown trout.
Gorgeous fish, with silky skin dappled with brown spots. I was *amazed* that I caught a
fish, a small, speckled brown trout. Tess skillfully taught us how to work our rods until
she could maneuver the fish into the net.
We sat on an embankment and ate lunch. As part of our 'package,' Tess brought subs,
drinks and all kinds of snacks. She lives half the year in Bozeman, MT, and fishes out
there too, leading workshops for women anglers (or wannabe anglers) -- a great idea as
the sport seems quite male-dominated. We found no lack of common interests
(progressive politics - yay! - cooking, Penn State, life in central PA etc.). She was so
friendly and such a good teacher.
We called it quits around 3:00 as we were tiring (once again, I seemed to 'rise to the
occasion' in terms of stamina; I actually could have kept going a bit longer). I found the
experience of fly fishing enticing. I'd love to get out there again and spend the day
sitting in the middle of that cool creek, casting my rod (might be a bit of a challenge on
my own, though....). The monotony didn't bother me; on the contrary, I found it calming. 
So maybe one day you'll find that I've hung a shingle on my front doo: Gone fishin'....
So that's my 'big fish' story!
******
Unfortunately, my vision has worsened even further since last week. Perhaps I need
another type of steroid drop. Everything's  blurry -- and I'm extremely worried. I can't
make out the score in the basketball game on my large t.v. screen. I must put my face
nearly up to my large computer screen to type. I will try not to drive for the near future
unless completely necessary. I will see Dr. Marcovich, the ophthalmologist, h on Monday
and impress upon him that I'm fighting for my life here and need him to be on board
100%; I'll also contact Dr. Patel and explain what's going on so we can determine
whether or not I'll receive my third infusion on Friday, and at what dosage. I'll ask Dr. P's
nurse to send Dr. Marcovich (again) the info sheet about Elahere so that he can make
*sure* to educate himself about this drug. I sorely wish I could go to the Wilmer Eye
Institute at Hopkins; perhaps I will if I do not get satisfaction here asap.  I don't mean to
be melodramatic, but will I need to choose between blindness and death? Obviously, it's
a depressing situation. I might need to have a 'guest blogger' (!) for one of my next
postings if I don't see improvement in my vision soon.
                    1.739 / 1.901
'Tis but a scratch' -ha.
Thankfully, I've had such a pleasant visit with Ben, as always (and with Sammi earlier
this week). He's been kind and attentive and helpful and loving in every way. Today we
enjoyed breakfast pastries and coffee at the Cake Shop by Tati, followed by a trip to
Sammi's Greenhouse to purchase some begonias and thyme to pot, and finished off with
a visit to my favorite antiques store, where I bought a few pretty Limoges pieces in
cobalt blue to adorn my table (when cooking becomes less challenging....). Tonight Ben's
dad Michael invited us over for grilled hot dogs (a favorite of mine) and hamburgers. I'll
be sad to see Ben return to NY tomorrow but hopefully I'll see him before long. His dad is
driving him to pick up his rental car as I don't want to risk driving when I don't absolutely
have to. :(

  —Janet Horne, May 20, 2023  
How "Willa" to begin with an enchanting bucket list narrative complete with painterly
reminiscences (all of which took most of the space on this journal entry)! A gift to her
caring readership.
Segueing, inevitably, however, into the very troubling medical update most of us must

June 5, 2023 - Innervisions II
  by Willa Silverman, June 5, 2023  
I'll try to blog instead of vlog here, as at the moment I'm able to see the  lettering on the
screen from about 1.5 ft. away. To update everyone and proceeding in reverse order:
Tomorrow I am going to Hopkins for an appointment with Dr. Oliver Schein, one of the
'big guns' (I guess) at the Wilmer Eye Institute. I'm very much hoping he will have a
concrete suggestion for my still extremely blurry vision and/or will help me understand
to what this problem is due. I am still seeing Dr. Marcovitch in State College but felt that
I definitely needed input from a (cornea) specialist who may have some experience
seeing Elahere patients. And I simply can't continue in such a radically compromised
state!
So back to Charm City tomorrow, hon. My appointment's at 1:30 to enable a roundtrip in
one day. I'm using a driver Michael and Sue suggested, who sounded quite nice on the
phone. She'll pick me up at 8:45 at my house and will drive us to Hopkins in my car. My
friend Sandy also very kindly offered to take me, and it's always a bit of a (fun)
adventure when we make the trip together, but I don't want to impose on my friends all
the time. I may need to rely on them again! I would love to see my Baltimore friends and
family tomorrow but will be short on time, unfortunately.
This past Friday I received my third dose of Elahere (reduced by 15% because of the
ocular toxicity I've experienced) + a two-hour magnesium infusion. Dr. Patel suggested
we "take the risk" when I met with him last Thursday. What annoyed me was that he had
not read any notes from Dr. Marcovitch, which I had taken pains to have sent to Dr.
Patel, so Dr. P. had to rely on *my summary* of my visit with Dr. Marcovitch to make this
important decision about my chemo! Seemed pretty lame to me to rely on this
                    1.753 / 1.901
'laywoman's' account (and convinced me further that Hopkins was the ticket...).
Subsequently, I found out that Drs. Patel and Marcovitch spoke about my case on the
phone, which put my mind at ease as at least one doctor previously seemed resistant to
making the necessary effort to work as a team. And I need a team!
Chemo was rough this week. I experienced no other side effects other than fatigue (and
the lingering vision issues) but the exhaustion was a doozy. I slept most of Saturday and
Sunday (of course while kicking myself that I 'should' be doing something 'productive').
Saturday morning I was able only to pick up some fresh strawberries (I can drive within a
mile's radius when needed) and Sunday evening I watched the basketball playoffs (with
my face practically smushed against the t.v.).
W I had had a third appointment with Dr. Marcovitch. He said my corneas actually looked
much better (which opened the door for me to receive chemo two days later). But then
why is my vision still so compromised? He couldn't really pronounce on that question: it
might be a rapid worsening of my cataracts (which need to be operated on); it might be
a rapid worsening of my vision due to factors other than corneal damage. How these
three factors may or may not be working together or separately is unclear to me (and, I
think, to him). He said he could probably give me a new prescription, but it's likely to
change again. At this point, I'm pretty desperate to have my vision improve even
somewhat. So perhaps it's merely a matter of needing a new prescription after a drastic
change in vision. Hopefully tomorrow's appointment will help clarify (no pun intended!)
the situation.
I felt much less alone having two lovely friends accompany me to my appointments last
week: my friend John O., who took me to Dr. Patel's (I treated him afterwards to
coffee/tea in the garden of Café Lemont), and my friend Lisa S., who came with me to Dr.
Marcovitch's (aka 'the prune') and then to lunch at a tasty local taco place. And my great
combo of Janis and Jackie provided chemo rides this past Friday. All this helped me feel
less isolated, as the dimming of my vision + the exhaustion from chemo were conspiring
to make me feel as if I were sequestered in a black hole.
I'll have a CT scan on June 20th. This will produce the most conclusive evidence about
whether Elahere is working (ie stabilizing or reducing my tumor size/cancer load) and
thus whether I will continue treatment with this drug. As far as I know there is no plan B
(more like plan 'P' at this point...) but I'm putting that out of my mind for now.
Today I met via vidchat with a psychosocial oncologist to see what she might bring to the
table. My palliative care doctor suggested I might meet with her, as she's now part of the
Geisinger oncology team. I might try another session or two with her; I'm not positive I'll
pursue further. It wasn't unhelpful but perhaps a bit 'formulaic.' There is some sort of
workbook I'd need to complete based on my reading of Viktor Frankl's _Man's  Search for
Meaning_ (a book on my 'to read' list in any case). I'm not unconvinced that my long-
                    1.754 / 1.901
time therapist, although not specialized in oncology patients, doesn't provide enough
insight into my situation to be helpful (and she's super-smart). I do have curiosity,
however, about some of the concepts mentioned by Dr. Perez, such as that of "radical
acceptance." At this point, though, I'm not sure I need more psychotherapy to muddle
through facing a terminal illness, as opposed to reading more philosophy, religion etc.
We'll see.
Was delighted that Ben and Sammi were invited to Shabbos dinner in Crown Heights
with his (second) cousins Zev and Yosef (two of the sons of my first cousin, David) and
his lively (second) cousin from New Zealand, Gresham (son of David's sister, Janie). A
good time was had by all, apparently. The next generation after mine and my cousins'
(and brother's) is coming together in a beautiful 'rainbow coalition" (of degrees of faith,
nationality, profession etc.) and I feel that (we're) all is in good hands. This makes me
happy!
  
Comments

June 8, 2023 - Back
                    1.756 / 1.901
  by Willa Silverman, June 8, 2023  
I meant to include two items in my last post: 1)I recently watched (sitting about 6 inches
from the t.v. screen) Michael J. Fox's new documentary about his life and career, "Still"
(on Apple TV+). Well-made, moving and 'relatable' (a word I dislike, but whatever)
regarding drastically reduced horizons, living long-term with incurable illness, "radical
acceptance," etc.; 2)At the nadir of my vision issues, about a week or so ago, I decided
to listen to audiobooks and podcasts to pass the time. Something of a failed experiment
on two counts as a)the soothing voice of the reader of Michael Chabon's _The Amazing
Adventures..._ put me to sleep (!) and b)I had a very marked PTSD-type reaction to the
intro to/techno-ish music accompanying the _NYTimes_ podcast, "The Daily," which I
used to listen to for hours on end about four years ago, immobilized on my chaise and in
pain after my big debulking surgery in 2019. I had no idea these few seconds would be
such a trigger...
*********
Back from Hopkins on Tuesday, back from an appointment yesterday with Dr.
Marcovitch. I was thanking some higher power this morning for the fact that two days
ago -- for the first time in about a month -- I could sense my sight improving. On the
drive down to Baltimore, the passing landscape appeared in much more vivid relief than
before; the past two days my vision has been less blurred although by no means perfect.
It's still hard to make out fine detail. But I no longer feel the need to feel the space in
front of me to assess the safety of walking. And yesterday Dr. Marcovitch cleared me for
driving during the day! I drove about two miles to my dermatologist's office this morning
and I felt confident doing so. However, I'm still accepting rides for longer drives and until
I've made a fuller return to clear-sightedness.
The reason I can see better (but this seems actually part of a more complicated
interaction among corneas, cataracts, and compromised vision) is that, per Dr.
Marcovitch, my left cornea is almost completely healed and my right one looks dry but is
coming along (>continue with artificial tears every few hours). Why my corneas have
improved while my vision appears radically worse is, again, complicated. It may be that
the irregularities on my corneas (assessed by a special machine at Hopkins that
produced a kind of topographical map of my corneas), while less notable than before,
are positioned right at the center of the surface (ie the epithelium) of the cornea, where
they impact vision most dramatically.
Indeed, my vision has become significantly worse as a result of this episode. *This* fact
is not likely to change much. Obviously, this is a disappointment. I have a prescription for
new lenses but may only wind up with a left lens, as the decline is most dramatic in my
left eye (my right eye, in fact, has not changed that much). Because my vision is sort of
in flux, it's possible I may need a new prescription before long.
As mentioned, what has improved are my corneas. The damage to this transparent layer,
                    1.757 / 1.901
again, is most apparent on their surface; the rest of the layer is intact. Both doctors
concur that my corneas should return to normal soon. 
Hope that I'm not 'speaking out of school' here. Am trying to provide as clear yet
accurate an explanation as I'm able of ocular issues whose vocabulary is foreign to me!
The trip to Hopkins and back, twelve hours in toto, was pretty exhausting for me, yet
quite useful. Michael and Sue had connected me with an excellent driver based nearby
who also drives a Fullington bus. We took my car and reached Baltimore in about three
hours, with about 45 mn to spare before my appointment. I found the Wilmer Eye
Institute, which I had passed many times during my previous trips to Hopkins. When I
checked in, the clerk assisting me stood up, walked over to a side desk and handed me a
large, rectangular, flat white box. "Oh great," I thought, "some big pharma company is
foisting samples and pamphlets onto the Hopkins people, which they in turn are dumping
on us!" Only on closer look, and to my absolute surprise, did I see a note in French
affixed to the box, addressed to "notre chère cousine," wishing me well with my
appointment and hinting at some delicious treats inside to enjoy on the ride home (I
hadn't eaten lunch and was famished). Indeed, nestled inside the box were an
assortment of yummies that looked like they came straight from a French pâtisserie:
lemon tart, macarons, croissant. My darling Baltimore cousins  -- "les Aigles" (the Eagle
family) had gotten wind of my appointment (likely from this blog?), know all about my
Francophilia of course, and had shopped for me at a kosher boulangerie. This remarkably
thoughtful gesture in the midst of a stressful day lifted me up and reminded me of the
miraculous moments of human connection that can make a twelve-hour schlep to
Baltimore and back worthwhile! Truly the highlight of my day. [In my previous post, I
wrote about how Ben and Sammi recently experienced more 'cousin love' in Brooklyn
with two of these Baltimore-born sons of my cousins David and Yehudis, Zev and Yosef].
I spent about 1.5 hours being examined by Dr. Oliver Schein, his fellow (Dr. Adam
something), and their assistant, who performed a battery of preliminary tests on me. The
team was very thorough, testing my eyes in various ways with seemingly more up to
date equipment than at Dr. Marcovitch's office and, as mentioned, photographing my
corneas.
Dr. Schein seemed personable and kind (his fellow actually spent longer with me than he
did). Based on his experience of observing how other chemo drugs (but not Elahere...)
can affect vision, he reiterated to me that the intense blurriness I was experiencing
would dissipate and my corneas would heal, but that this could take one-two months
total (I had been seduced into anticipating a much shorter timeline based on accounts by
a few women in my Elahere chat room -- a small sample, to be sure). He provided me
with a new prescription. He asked to see notes from my baseline eye exam on Jan. 4 with
Dr. Nelson in State College, from just before I was to start receiving treatment with
Elahere. And he asked his fellow to proceed with a basic measure that Dr. Marcovitch
                    1.758 / 1.901
had seemed resistant to using: inserting eye plugs. Small silicone plugs are placed in the
top and bottom tear ducts; consequently, one's tears do not drain but instead remain on
the surface of the eye, 'irrigating' it with natural tears and providing continuous
hydration that can benefit the eye. Dr. Adam X inserted these plugs for me (I hardly feel
them as they're tiny). I don't remember what else we discussed but Dr. Schein genuinely
seemed kind and strongly disposed to help me. We didn't discuss a return visit but I'd
like to think that I could avail myself once again of the excellent care at Hopkins if/when
needed.
The last month's been a misery. Try to imagine, in as much detail as possible, what it
would mean for you to have your sight radically compromised. I know that people adjust
('radical acceptance?'), yet I still feel much compassion for the legally blind living in a
'sighted' world (I myself had passed into this realm about a week ago).
As for the million dollar question - will this cycle repeat after subsequent Elahere
infusions? - I don't know but somehow I tend to think not. And for another million dollars:
will I even be having another infusion of Elahere? The results of my CT-scan on June 20th
will tell. So now 'all' I have to worry about is the possibility of progression of my disease
despite treatment or discovery of new mets in my brain and/or elsewhere. LOL. I'll stick
with considering the next eleven days a reprieve -- and will bend with the bamboo.
Things have skewed off kilter the past month in terms of any attempts I might make to
formulate summer plans, goals (such as they are), even day to day objectives. I am
toying with the idea of trying to honor the trying emotions of the past month (and four+
years) in a non-judgmental way, which does not mean that I find them 'acceptable' for
myself (or anyone else, for that matter).
So much is out of our control. 
****
On the drive home, I asked Millie to swing by Alvaro's Bakery in Harrisburg, my usual pit
stop between B'more or D.C. and State College, for a few more treats for both of us and
a dinner entrée for me as I was way too exhausted to cook (indeed, I *needed*
someone's Italian-American mama to cook up some lasagna and meatballs for me and
Alvaro's happily obliged).
Looking forward to a little country jaunt to buy flowers, herbs etc. tomorrow with my
friend John. Was at the farm market about a mile from my house this morning. The
strawberries this year are a wonder.

June 16, 2023 - Numbering the days
  by Willa Silverman, June 16, 2023  
                    1.761 / 1.901
                    1.762 / 1.901
Last weekend was fairly miserable. I don't think I realized how tired I was, mentally and
physically, from the quick round-trip to Hopkins. I still wasn't seeing well. I think I slept
most of the weekend, besides taking a drive on Saturday and attending an event Friday
night (about which more further on). My body was craving sleep (and actually still does,
often). My sides/pleura shading into my back, abdomen, and stomach all ached, as if I
had a band of pain girding the middle section of my body. The pain tired me further.
Oxycodone helped (my palliative care dr. said I could even increase my dose by 50%,
although I'm still trying to not take more than two pills a day). I had to cancel three
social engagements and missed the second annual Pride parade in town, a welcome
addition to State College's 'culture' and vibe, which of course made me sad. Dark
thoughts were getting the better of me. I was convinced the pain was a harbinger of
imminent death. Somehow I managed to not spiral down completely, reminding myself
of the simple fact that, at least for now, there are good and bad days.
This week has been better. I still need a good amount of sleep (but am sleeping
erratically), but my pain has decreased while my energy has increased. And my vision is
improving! This means I can drive, cook, write, watch t.v., read etc. - an enormous step
forward. I tried to get my new prescription for lenses filled today but I botched the
mission (for reasons too complicated and uninteresting to explain) so I will hopefully take
care of that on Monday, the day I also have an eye doctor appointment here. What else?
I had appointments with my therapist and my palliative care doc, both stalwart pillars of
my medical/care team.
Next Tuesday afternoon I'll have a CT-scan to determine whether Elahere is working,
whether my disease has progressed, remained stable, or even regressed. I am trying not
to think about the scan until Monday, not to generate anxiety that may or may not be
warranted. There's no Plan B that I know of; at this point, we're sort of winging it,
relieved that a new drug came along in time for my doctors to add it to the treatment
plan. The thought that I *might* need to stop treatment, if Elahere's not helping, while
still feeling relatively ok overall is certainly sobering.
This week was another one in which I felt rather 'unmoored,' as if the ground was shifting
under my feet. Plans get cancelled. A scan looms. My vision improves but remains iffy.
Fatigue weighs on me sometimes. Friends leave town on vacation, coming and going. I
*did* try to get a grip by arranging a July vacation for myself, Ben and Sammi, in a place
I love. Something to look forward to! I won't say more for now so as not to jinx these
plans. But I hope they'll help me plant my feet on terra firma after several weeks of
feeling adrift.
Last Friday night, despite not feeling 100%, I attended a Pride-themed service at our
synagogue, the first in my memory. My wonderful chemo nurse, Brianne, had expressed
                    1.763 / 1.901
an interest in going (her Lutheran pastor had apparently announced it to his
congregation), along with her wife, Natalie, and charming daughter, Kaylen. The service
featured specially selected, Pride-themed readings. I was gratified for the large turnout
(including many people I didn't know, who also wished to attend such a purposefully
inclusive service). Coincidentally, Brianne and Natalie (and Kaylen) knew a number of
people there from school, work, and other circles. It feels so important to show up for
one another (and not just at events 'designated' for this...). I may try to put this belief
into practice again tomorrow if/when I check out the town's Juneteenth goings-on.
Of course, I'm in farmers market heaven right now. I realize that I much prefer summer
to winter cooking because of the abundant 'farm to table' possibilities. Now that I can
see better, my cooking mojo has returned; this week I made a beet salad with goat
cheese and pecans; warm German potato salad (had a craving, but I think it's too heavy
a dish for me) and garlic scape pesto (packs a garlicy punch - oh my!). I'm also intensely
into iced teas right now and am experimenting with different varieties. Plan to start
cooking for others soon, too. 
A restful sabbath to all. 
Photos
                    1.764 / 1.901
                    1.765 / 1.901

June 24, 2023 - The 'poor player'
  by Willa Silverman, June 24, 2023  
The radiologists' report on my last scan, which I read Wednesday, reveals a significant
progression of my disease, so much so that Dr. Patel admitted to me when I saw him on
Thursday that he felt apprehensive about speaking with me that day. It turned out I
made his task much easier by being what he termed 'practical' - a word seldom if ever
applied to me! - but by which I think he meant some combination of realistic and
graceful (ie full of grace).
Always hard for me to parse the medical language but Dr. Patel helped: increase in the
size of several lymph nodes, at least one in the thoracic area; increase in size of spots on
liver; increase in size of at least one tumor at base of abdomen. These areas are not
necessary painful for me (although the abdominal tumor causes discomfort); instead, for
some reason, my back and 'flanks' ache *a lot* (a heating pad helps, as does
Oxycodone, which I'm relying on a bit more now). This might simply be from arthritis or
else from cancer in the pleura (membrane lining the thorax and coating the lungs);
                    1.772 / 1.901
cancer is there.
I asked Dr. P. if it is common for cancer to accelerate in this way, as this is certainly the
'worst' scan report I've seen throughout my illness. He (re) explained that after so many
lines of chemo being thrown at them, as had been my case, the cancer cells have
become expert at mutating and otherwise figuring out how to elude the drugs targeting
them. The cancer cells create their own environment within my body, complete with
blood supply and everything else they need to do their deadly deeds. Insidious, indeed.
Or maybe the worst 'tenants' ever, the ones who take over and trash your beautiful
home, causing permanent damage beyond repair.
I am certain that the doctors and other medical personnel reading this are not
necessarily surprised to learn of this progression, nor are a few friends who have lost
partners to cancer. I myself was not surprised, while still retaining a glimmer of hope due
to the promise of a newly-approved drug (I am detecting mixed results among women
currently on Elahere).
The 'good' news (!) in all this is the absence of fluid build-up, for example in my lungs.
Ironically, my magnesium level is back in normal range for the first time in a long while,
which mean no magnesium infusion yesterday. Obviously, we're discontinuing Elahere as
well. Both Dr. Patel and a fellow who was shadowing him on Thursday remarked on how
well I look; my by now legendary (lol) positive attitude tempered with realism impressed
her. It's got to have helped some but sadly is not sufficient to beat back those cancer
cells.
Back on the rollercoaster, part XXX?: Yesterday, Dr. Beavis emailed me to say she had
seen the scans (her own radiologists produced a report on them also), to express regret
at what they show, and to offer to talk about potential next steps (??) and/or possibility
of clinical trials at Hopkins. The challenge here will be logistical; she'll be on vacation July
2-11. We can meet virtually, but I'll need to drive to MD as she can't practice across
state lines. And I'm scheduled to be away July 7-12. I'll wait until Monday to see what she
can offer.
I of course want to hear what she has to say. And in the name of 'due diligence,' I'll likely
call/write MSK and see if they have anything to offer. I may look into alternative
treatments too. But quality of life is my overriding concern; given my relative dearth of
energy these days and the pain I'm currently dealing with, I'm adamant about using my
time/energy for activities and people that/who give me pleasure.
It's a strange time. Lots of emotions. I really don't know what I should be doing, thinking,
feeling. Still trying to throw out as much junk, old papers etc. as possible and get
organized. But it's really been the same old existential question all along, per the title of
the Gauguin painting: "Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?"
                    1.773 / 1.901
Ben will be coming from NY over July 4th weekend. Of course, I can't wait to see him.
Having him here makes me feel so much better. If my health holds (and Dr. Patel felt it
will, as the vacay is coming right up), Ben and I will take off from here by car on July 7th,
staying overnight at a midway point of Fishkill, NY. The next day we'll pick up Sammi at a
train station along our route and head to the magnificent Chatham Bars Hotel on the
Cape for a few days of sun, beach, oysters, lobster rolls (although I don't have much of
an appetite!) and relaxing. I am unsure whether I'll return via NY or if we'll devise
another plan.
Local friends (or even those w/in driving distance!): if you feel inclined to pay me a
shortish visit, I would love that! We can sit in the sun room or outdoors and have some
iced tea, maybe even trade a few memories. No need to feel obligated, though.
Unfortunately, I'm currently not really able to run around as is my preference, but I'm
still likely up for lunch or iced tea out (or a cocktail - why not!), a drive in the country etc.
Enjoyed dinner with my friends John and Kathryn at the Hublersburg Inn a few nights
ago. And having a summery dinner w/friends tonight - very much looking forward.
*I know that for the very great majority of those reading this, it's unnecessary for me to
write this, but please respect my privacy and do not share any of the above info via
other social media.
*Please feel free to DM or text me if the paratextual commentary seems too fraught in
this instance.
